name: — Introduction to Aerospace Science Engineering
description: Course Description: Description of the field of aerospace engineering with examples from industry, government, and research. Aerospace engineering principles, ethics, and responsibilities.

name: — From the Wright Brothers to Drones & Quadcopters
description: Course Description: History of aircraft and its influence on society. Topics covered will include Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, safety considerations, economics and privacy issues. Aerodynamics, stability and control will also be introduced.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Theoretical & Computational Aerodynamics
description: Course Description: Development of general equations of fluid motion. Study of flow field kinematics and dynamics. Flow about a body. Thin airfoil theory. Viscous effects. Applications of numerical methods to wing analysis and design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 103 C- or better; ENG 105 C- or better; (ENG 180 C- or better or EAD 115 C- or better or MAT 128C C- or better or EME 115 C- or better).

name: — Applied Aircraft Aerodynamics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Principles, governing equations, and predictive theories for aircraft aerodynamics. Lift and drag of 2D airfoils, 3D wings, and high-lift devices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EME 106 C- or better.

name: — Stability & Control of Aerospace Vehicles
description: Course Description: Aircraft and spacecraft stability and control. Derivation of fundamental equations of motion for aircraft/spacecraft. Fundamentals of feedback. Aircraft flight control systems. Spacecraft attitude control systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better.

name: — Aircraft Performance & Design
description: Course Description: Major aircraft design experience with multiple realistic constraints including aerodynamics, performance analysis, weight estimation, stability and control, and appropriate engineering standards.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EAE 126 or EAE 127 C- or better); EAE 129 C- or better (can be concurrent).

name: — Aircraft Performance & Design
description: Course Description: Major aircraft design experience including detailed design, cost analysis, analysis of aircraft structure, propulsion system, aerodynamics, aircraft handling qualities, manufacturing, or meeting relevant engineering standards.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EAE 130A C- or better.

name: — Finite Element Methods in Structures
description: Course Description: Introduction to the aerospace structural design process. History of aircraft and spacecraft materials. Effects of loading beyond elastic limit. Deflections and stresses due to combined loading. Virtual work principles, and finite element methods. Applications to aerospace structures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 104 C- or better.

name: — Aerospace Structures
description: Course Description: Analysis and design methods used in aerospace structures. Shear flow in open, closed and multicell beam cross-sections, buckling of flat and curved sheets, tension field beams, local buckling.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 104 C- or better; EAE 126 or EAE 127 recommended.

name: — Structural Composites
description: Course Description: Overview of materials and technology for creating structures from fiber reinforced resin matrix composite material systems. Elementary design analysis and case studies emphasizing aeronautical applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 104 C- or better.

name: — Aircraft Propulsion
description: Course Description: Analysis/design of modern aircraft gas turbine engines. Development/application of cycle performance prediction techniques. Introduction to design of inlets, compressors, burners, turbines, and nozzles. Cycle design for specific applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EME 106 C- or better.

name: — Rocket Propulsion
description: Course Description: Fluid and thermodynamics of rocket engines, liquid and solid rocket propulsion. Space propulsion concepts and space mission requirements.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EME 106 C- or better.

name: — Space Systems Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to space systems design including space project organization, requirements definition and specification, concepts formulation, system tradeoffs, subsystem design. Prototype space mission concepts are presented and a multidisciplinary mission design is developed that considers all relevant architecture elements.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better; EME 106 C- or better.

name: — Orbital Mechanics
description: Course Description: Satellite orbits, multistage rockets, current global boosters, and new technologies. Design application problems include satellites, trajectory optimizations, and interplanetary trajectories.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better.

name: — Space Vehicle Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Governing equations and operational practices of robotic and human space travel. Principles of Systems Engineering are introduced and are used as a basis for a team project in spacecraft reverse-engineering and design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better; ENG 103 C- or better; ENG 105 C- or better.

name: — Space Mission Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to space systems design including space project organization, requirements definition & specification, concepts formulation, system tradeoffs, and subsystem design. Prototype space mission concepts & multidisciplinary mission design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EAE 143A C- or better.

name: — Flight Simulation & Testing in Design of Aircraft & Spacecraft
description: Course Description: Teaches flight test techniques together with data analysis methods to prepare students for any type of flight testing including fixed wing, rotary wing and launch vehicles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102; consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — African-American Culture & Society
description: Course Description: Critical examination of the historical, political, social, and economic factors that have affected the development and status of African-American people in contemporary society.

name: — Introduction to African Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to African Studies which will focus on the various disciplinary perspectives through which African society and culture are generally studied. A survey of methods, resources and conceptual tools for the study of Africa.

name: — Introduction to African American Humanities
description: Course Description: Introduction to the humanist tradition developed by writers, philosophers, and artists of African descent in the West. Attention also given to African sources, as well as European, Caribbean, Latin-American, and North American variations on this tradition.

name: — Verbal & Performance Arts in Africa
description: Course Description: African verbal arts; oral texts from different African cultures. Types of critical response to oral texts, role of oral artists, context and esthetics of oral performance in Africa.

name: — Women in African Societies
description: Course Description: Gender relations in traditional and contemporary African society. Involvement of African women in politics, religion, the economy, the arts. African responses to feminist theory. Images of women in African literature.

name: — Introduction to Caribbean Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to the contemporary culture, peoples, politics, and societies of the Caribbean. Topics include movements of people, goods and ideas across the Atlantic world and creative productions within the Caribbean.

name: — Black Popular Culture
description: Course Description: Survey of the African American images in popular culture (film, television, comedy, sports and music).

name: — History of Afro American Dance
description: Course Description: Evolution of African-American dance, tracing its history and development from West and Central Africa to the United States. Investigates the social and cultural relevance of African American dance and its artistic merits through  contributions from its choreographers and performers.

name: — African Traditional Religion
description: Course Description: Introduction to traditional religions of the sub-Saharan African peoples: emphasis on myths, rituals and symbols in West, East, Central and South African indigenous religions. Examines themes: sacred kingship, divination system, women, prophecy, conversion and adaptation to Islam and Christianity.

name: — Black California
description: Course Description: Introduction to the experiences and contributions of people of African descent in California from the early 18th century to the present.

name: — Introduction to Black Politics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the analysis of Afro-American politics, using conceptual frameworks from political science and other social sciences.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Survey of Ethnicity in the US
description: Course Description: Sociological and historical analysis of the experience, culture, and relations of and between groups considered racial and/or ethnic minorities in the United States.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Research in the Afro-American Community
description: Course Description: Introductory survey of Afro-American Studies methods and techniques; problems and methodology in Afro-American Studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010; or consent of instructor.

name: — African Descent Communities & Culture in the Caribbean & Latin America
description: Course Description: Origin and development of African descent communities and cultures in the Caribbean, and Latin America. Similarities and differences among African descent communities and cultures in terms of religious practices, music, and national identity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — African Descent Communities & Culture in North America
description: Course Description: Study of the origin and development of African descent communities and cultures in the U.S.A., Canada, and Mexico.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — African Descent Communities & Culture in Asia
description: Course Description: Study of the origin and development of African Descent communities and cultures in Asia.

name: — African Descent Communities & Cultures in Europe
description: Course Description: Study of the origin and development of African Descent communities and cultures in Europe.

name: — West African Social Organization
description: Course Description: Ecology, population, social and political organization, and culture of West Africa in the precolonial, colonial, and post-colonial periods.

name: — Cultural Politics in Contemporary Africa
description: Course Description: Themes and style of new cultural forms in Africa as displayed in art, music, film and writing, especially in regard to blending of indigenous and foreign influences. Social and political forces shaping contemporary cultural expression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 012; or upper division standing.

name: — Kingdoms in Contemporary African Politics
description: Course Description: Kingdoms and monarchies in sub-Saharan Africa and their role in contemporary politics through the comparative political economy approach.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 012 recommended.

name: — Presidential Politics in Africa
description: Course Description: Political leadership in sub-Saharan Africa, focusing on historical, institutional, and biographical influences and outcomes through political economy approaches.

name: — Black Female Experience in Contemporary Society
description: Course Description: Black female social, intellectual, and psychological development. Black women's contributions in history, literature, and social science; life experiences of Black women and philosophical underpinnings of the feminist movement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Education in the African-American Community
description: Course Description: Examination of the history of the education of African Americans in the United States. Examination and critique of contemporary theories concerning the schooling of African Americans. (Former AAS 140.)

name: — The Black Family In America
description: Course Description: Analysis of social science research to examine relationship between black (African-descent) family structures, patterns of functioning, and political, economic, and social conditions in the U.S.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Psychology of the African American Experience
description: Course Description: Introduction to the psychological issues faced by African Americans. Description of any disparities in mental health care experienced by African American and Diaspora populations in the United States. Analysis of issues from European/Western and Afrocentric frame of reference. Emphasis on Optimal Theory, a psychological theory based on an Afrocentric world view.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010; or consent of instructor; upper division status.

name: — Black Social & Political Thought
description: Course Description: Exploration and analysis of Black social and political thought in the Americas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010 or AAS 080; or consent of instructor.

name: — Black Intellectuals
description: Course Description: Exposition and critical analysis of selected theoretical writings of Black intellectuals, and especially political and social thinkers, in the Americas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (AAS 010,  AAS 080,  AAS 145A); or consent of instructor.

name: — Afro-American Visual Arts Tradition: A Historical & Cultural Study
description: Course Description: Afro-American visual arts tradition, folk and formal, in historical and cultural context, from 1600 through Reconstruction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Afro-American Visual Arts Tradition: A Historical & Cultural Study
description: Course Description: Afro-American visual arts tradition, folk and formal, in historical and cultural context, from Reconstruction to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Afro-American Vernacular Music & Verbal Arts
description: Course Description: Socio-political dimensions of Afro-American musical forms like spiritual, work song, minstrelsy blues, rhythm and blues, jazz, gospel, soul and contemporary pop, and related verbal arts like preaching, toasting, rapping.

name: — Major Voices in Black World Literature
description: Course Description: Recurrence of cultural tropes in the works of major black world authors and formation of an African-oriented canon. Principal activities include critical reading and discovery of literature as a cultural resource.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010 or AAS 012 or AAS 018; upper division standing.

name: — African Literature
description: Course Description: Colonial and post-colonial sub-Saharan African literature and the African oral traditions from which it emerged. Genres and themes of African literature from the 19th century to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — African-American Dance & Culture in the United States, Brazil & the Caribbean
description: Course Description: Comparative study of the African American dance forms in the U.S.A., Brazil, Haiti, Cuba, Jamaica, Barbados, and Trinidad. Examination of ritual, folk, and popular dance forms and the socio/historical factors that have influenced these forms.

name: — Language & Identity in Africa & the African Diaspora
description: Course Description: Relationship between language and identity in literature from Africa and the African Diaspora. Use of pidgins, Creoles, translation from African languages and impact of language policies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 012; or upper division standing.

name: — Literature & Society in South Africa
description: Course Description: Political and social developments in 20th-century South Africa as illustrated by a range of South African writing. Response of different writers to race relations, impact of government policy on types and context of writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — African-American Folklore
description: Course Description: Theory and history of African American folklore and folklife, including music, material culture, oral narrative, proverbs, and humor. African and Caribbean cultural influences on New World folk genres will be probed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010.

name: — Islam in Africa & the Americas
description: Course Description: Comparative and historical survey of Islam in the regional and cultural settings of Sub-Saharan Africa and the Americas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 060 or AAS 012 or AAS 110.

name: — African Religions in the Americas
description: Course Description: Comparative study of African religious heritage in the Americas: Jamaica, Trinidad, Cuba, U.S.A., Haiti, and Brazil. Emphasis on the origins and development of Candomble, Santeria, Shango, Vodun, and Rastafarianism in the New World.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010; AAS 015; or consent of instructor.

name: — Afro-Christianity & the Black Church
description: Course Description: Examination of the historical role of Christian belief and practice as well as the institution of the Black Church in the experience of African Americans, from slavery to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 010; AAS 015; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Black Documentary: History & Practice
description: Course Description: Study of Black documentary history and understanding of the use of the documentary form for political purposes. Discussion of documentary theory. Each student, singly or in a team, will create and carefully edit a documentary project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; AAS 170; and consent of instructor; AAS 050 recommended.

name: — History of African American Television
description: Course Description: History of the representation of African Americans in television; how the representations reflect social and political forces in American society. Role of African Americans in actively shaping their representation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 050 recommended.

name: — African-American Film & Video
description: Course Description: Comparative approach in the study of fictional film and video dealing with the African American experience drawing on film and cultural studies to examine and discuss selected works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; AAS 050 recommended.

name: — Black African & Black European Film & Video
description: Course Description: Comparative approach in the study of dramatic films and videos that treat black life in Africa and Europe. Critical attention focused on the imaginative construction of ethnicity, race, nationality, gender, and sexuality in each particular work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 015 or AAS 050 or ENL 160 or ENL 162; or consent of instructor.

name: — Diaspora & New Black Identities
description: Course Description: Critical analysis about what it means to be Black/African American in the United States today. Topics include old and new diasporas, immigration, national origin, language, religion, class, education, politics, identity and cultural heritage.

name: — Black Documentary: History & Theory
description: Course Description: Black documentary history and documentary theory. Use of black documentary for political purposes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; AAS 170; AAS 050 recommended.

name: — Black Documentary Practicum
description: Course Description: Creation of documentary projects, with students working in production crews.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 175A; and consent of instructor.

name: — The Politics of Resources
description: Course Description: Examination of the ways in which the processes of the extraction, purification and use of natural resources and the complex regimes of valuation and commodification they (re)produce lead to cooperation and conflict in contemporary Africa and beyond.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 012 or AAS 110.

name: — Politics of Life in Africa
description: Course Description: Existing (in)capacities in the structures of state and society in Africa for people to live well. Topics include institutions and practices that define state and civil society encounters in Africa; democracy, ethnicity, economic crisis, religion, citizenship, etc.

name: — African Modernity & Globalization
description: Course Description: Exploration of modernity and globalization and their dimensions and impacts in/on Africa. Examination of modern necessities and constrains in Africa in relation to (neo)colonialism, transnational encounters, technology,  gender, risk, ritual, identity, culture, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 012; or consent of instructor.

name: — Race & Ethnicity in Latin America
description: Course Description: Social and political effects of racial and ethnic categorization in Latin America, including issues of economic production, citizenship, national belonging, and access to resources. Emphasis is on peoples of African, Indigenous, and Asian descent.

name: — Hip Hop in Urban America
description: Course Description: History, aesthetics, urban context, and economics of hip-hop in the US, and its globalization. Hip-hop's four artistic elements-rap, deejaying, breakdance, and aerosol art-allow the examination of issues of race, ethnicity, and gender in youth culture and American society.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Hip Hop Culture & Globalization
description: Course Description: Investigation of hip-hop youth cultures outside the United States using globalization and Cultural Studies theories. Analysis of international hip-hop sites in Africa, Asia, Europe, South America, and the Middle East through reading, discussion, and visiting virtual sites.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 181 preferable, not required.

name: — Policing, Prison, & Protest in Local Perspective
description: Course Description: Study of the history and current state of policing, prisons and protest movements in the U.S. through Black Studies framework and methods.

name: — Policing, Prison, & Protest in Global Perspective
description: Course Description: Study of the history and current workings of police, prisons, and protest movements globally through Black Studies frameworks and methods.

name: — Topics in African American Film
description: Course Description: Intensive study of special topics in African American film.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 170; AAS 050 recommended.

name: — Topics in African & African-Diaspora Studies
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a special topic or problem in African or African Diaspora Studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in African American  African Studies (AAS) courses or consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in African-American & African Studies
description: Course Description: Supervised internship in community, government, or private institutions, in all subject areas offered by the African American & African Studies Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 12 units of upper division study in African American  African Studies (AAS) courses; upper division standing.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in preparation of a senior honors thesis under the direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in preparation of a senior honors thesis under the direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AAS 194HA; consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Afro-American Studies
description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of major committee; upper division standing with major in African American  African Studies.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Critical Foundations in African American Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to history of African American Studies. Topics include: research agendas, policy implications, debates, crises, and institutional frameworks.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Critical Foundations in African Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history and current organization of African Studies as area of intellectual investigation. Offers an opportunity to review research agenda and policy implications, debates, crises, and institutional frameworks surrounding the production of knowledge about Africa.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Critical Foundations in African Diaspora Studies
description: Course Description: Integrative conceptual framework includes History, Geography, Political Economy, Culture, Aesthetics as tools to investigate the African Diaspora. Engage African Diaspora theories within student's research projects understanding issues developing from the movement of Africans to the rest of the world.

name: — Methodologies in African American & African Studies
description: Course Description: Relationship between theory and methodology, with emphasis on identifying relevant methodological approaches and constructing theoretically informed research projects for studying the experience of people of African descent whether on the African continent or in the rest of the world.

name: — Directed Group Study in African American & African Diaspora Studies
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Directed Group Study in African Studies
description: Course Description: Directed group study in African Studies.

name: — Directed Research
description: Course Description: Directed research.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Selected topics in agricultural and environmental chemistry, presented by students.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: The chemistry and biochemistry of foods, nutritional chemicals, pesticides, and other special topics as they apply to agricultural and environmental chemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Arrangements should be made well in advance with a faculty member of the Group in Agricultural & Environmental Chemistry.

name: — Introduction to Agricultural & Environmental Technologies
description: Course Description: Technologies of agriculture and the environmental sciences. History & revolution of industrial technology and its impacts on agriculture, environment, energy, and bioproducts; types of sensing technologies; communication and information transfer technologies; artificial intelligence, technologies for control of automatic processes; technologies for the production of food, bioproducts, clean energy and water purification; gene-editing technology; wearable technologies.

name: — Sustainable Energy Technologies
description: Course Description: Sustainable and efficient energy technologies and their application in agriculture and other sectors. Basic principles of energy efficiency, conservation, and conversion technologies using solar, wind, water, biomass, geothermal, and other renewable sources. Environmental impacts and energy policy. Experiential learning about solar drying, controlled environment agriculture, net-zero energy building, electricity generation, energy storage, biofuels, and integrated waste management; field visits.

name: — Mobile Communication & Computing Technologies for Agriculture & the Environment
description: Course Description: Modern computer technologies and the applications of sensing technologies and the Internet of Things (IoT) in agriculture and the environment. IoT and embedded devices; history and evolution of IoT, communication, and computing technologies; sensors and actuators; microcontrollers; data communication technology; introduction to data analysis and data visualization; designing web applications; and hands‐on IoT-based projects.

name: — Smart Control Systems for Agricultural & Environmental Technologies
description: Course Description: Smart devices that communicate, sense their environment, and control their environment. Application examples include smart plant & animal care, and irrigation & fertigation. Technologies include Supervisory Control & Data Acquisition (SCADA) and Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) for applications in agricultural, environmental, and food sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; TAE 030 recommended.

name: — Controlled Environments for Plants & Animals
description: Course Description: Principles of environmental control (temperature, humidity, lighting, CO2, air circulation, air quality) for plants and animals. Psychrometrics and applications. Energy-efficient building envelopes for greenhouses, vertical farmings, and animal barns. Heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems, lighting and CO2 enrichment systems, growing substrates, and irrigation systems. Control systems (sensors and sensing for automated control). Visiting controlled environment facilities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in Agricultural  Environmental Technology; or consent of instructor.

name: — Economic Basis of the Agricultural Industry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Agriculture and man; the agricultural industry in U.S. and world economies; production and supply, marketing and demand; agricultural land, capital and labor markets; economic and social problems of agriculture in an urban and industrialized economy emphasizing California.

name: — Economic Basis of the Agricultural Industry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Agriculture and man; the agricultural industry in Australia and world economies; production and supply, marketing and demand; agricultural land, capital and labor markets; economic and social problems of agriculture in an urban and industrialized economy emphasizing Australia. May be taught abroad in Australia under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty member.

name: — Population, Environment & World Agriculture
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Economic analysis of interactions among population, environment, natural resources and development of world agriculture. Introduces students to economic thinking about population growth, its causes and consequences for world food demand, and environmental and technological limits to increasing food supplies.

name: — Business Law
description: Course Description: General principles of business law in the areas of contracts, business organization, real property, uniform commercial code, sales, commercial paper, employment relations, and creditor-debtor against a background of the history and functioning of our present legal system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Sophomore standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Microeconomics: Theory of Production & Consumption
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Theory of individual consumer and market demand; theory of production and supply of agricultural products, with particular reference to the individual firm; price determination, and employment of resources under pure competition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better); ECN 001B C- or better); ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better,  MAT 016C C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better)).

name: — Intermediate Microeconomics: Imperfect Competition, Markets & Welfare Economics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Price determination, and employment of resources under conditions of monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ((ECN 001A C-  or better or ECN 001AY C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better); ECN 001B C- or better); ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better,  MAT 016C C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better)); ARE 018 C- or better.

name: — Econometric Theory & Applications
description: Course Description: Statistical methods for analyzing data to solve problems in managerial economics. Topics include the linear regression model, methods to resolve data problems, and the economic interpretation of results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better; (PLS 021 C- or better or PLS 021V C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better).

name: — Econometrics for Business Decisions
description: Course Description: Covers state-of-the art econometric and statistical methods for causal and predictive modeling with applications to finance and marketing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ARE 106 C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Fundamentals of Organization Management
description: Course Description: Role of organizational design and behavior in business and public agencies. Principles of planning, decision making, individual behavior, management, leadership, informal groups, conflict and change in the organization. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing recommended.

name: — Fundamentals of Marketing Management
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Nature of product marketing by the business firm. Customer-product relationships, pricing and demand; new product development and marketing strategy; promotion and advertising; product life cycles; the distribution system; manufacturing, wholesaling, retailing. Government regulation and restraints.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A or ECN 001AV; For non-majors only.

name: — Economic Development
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Major issues encountered in emerging from international poverty, problems of growth and structural change, human welfare, population growth and health, labor markets and internal migration. Important issues of policy concerning international trade and industrialization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

name: — Economic Development
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Issues include problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment. Important issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

name: — Economic Development
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment. Issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

name: — Tax Accounting
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development and application of a framework to understand the tax effects of typical management decisions on both entities and their owners. Impacts that different methods of taxation have on business entities with emphasis on tax planning, using income and deduction strategies, retirement plans, and choice of business entity for tax minimization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better; ARE 018 recommended.

name: — Intermediate Managerial Accounting
description: Course Description: Use of accounting information by mangers in decision making, planning, directing and controlling operations. Focuses on managerial/cost accounting theory and practice. Covers costing systems, budgeting, and financial statement analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better.

name: — Agricultural Policy
description: Course Description: Analytical treatment of historical and current economic problems and governmental policies influencing American agriculture. Uses of economic theory to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture; how public policy influences the nature and performance of American agriculture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better.

name: — Agricultural Policy
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analytical treatment of historical and current economic problems and governmental policies influencing agriculture. Uses of economic theory to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture; how public policy influences the nature and performance of agriculture. May be taught abroad in Australia under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Economics of Agricultural Sustainability
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Application of economic concepts to agro-environmental issues relevant to agricultural sustainability. Topics include market efficiency, production externalities, government policies, agricultural trade, product differentiation, all linked to sustainability issues. Case studies include biofuels, genetically modified foods and geographically differentiated products.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better.

name: — Agricultural Markets
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Nature, function, organizational structure, and operation of agricultural markets; prices, costs, and margins; market information, regulation, and controls; cooperative marketing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 106 C- or better; ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Cooperative Business Enterprises
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of cooperative business enterprise in the United States and elsewhere; economic theories of behavior, principles of operation, finance, decision-making, and taxation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better.

name: — Introduction to Behavioral Economics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Inclusion of non-economic factors such as psychological principles in economic decisions and model predictions. Emphasis on behavioral principles, resulting strategies and implications for diverse market settings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better); (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better).

name: — Agribusiness Marketing Plan Development
description: Course Description: Fundamental components required to develop a marketing plan. Appreciation of the concept of marketing plans, appropriate research required, including the use of library, Internet, survey and interview instruments, government documents, market analysis, business proposition, action planning, financial evaluation and monitoring.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Managerial Marketing
description: Course Description: Application of economic theory and econometrics to the study of marketing and consumer research. Emphasis on industry structure, history, regulatory aspects, integrated brand promotion, market segmentation, optimal product mix, message placement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100B C- or better; ARE 106 C- or better; ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — International Commodity & Resource Markets
description: Course Description: Basic nature and scope of international trade in agricultural commodities, agricultural inputs, and natural resources. Market dimensions and policy institutions. Case studies to illustrate import and export problems associated with different regions and commodities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ARE 100B C- or better.

name: — Futures & Options Markets
description: Course Description: History, mechanics, and economic functions of futures and options markets; hedging; theory of inter-temporal price formation and behavior of futures and options prices; price forecasting; futures and options as policy tools.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Farm Management
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Farm organization and resources; economic and technological principles in decision making; analytical techniques and management control; problems in organizing and managing the farm business.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better.

name: — Personal Finance
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Management of income and expenditures by the household. Use of consumer credit, savings, and insurance by households. Principles of tax, retirement, and estate planning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001B.

name: — Investments
description: Course Description: Survey of investment institutions, sources of investment information, and portfolio theory. Analysis of the stock, bond and real estate markets from the perspective of the investor.

name: — Real Estate Economics
description: Course Description: Economic theory, analysis, and institutions of real estate markets and related financial markets. Techniques for appraising property values. Cases drawn from the raw land, single family, multifamily, industrial and office real estate markets.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better.

name: — Farm & Rural Resources Appraisal
description: Course Description: Principles and procedures of the valuation process with emphasis placed on rural real estate. Includes identification of the major physical and economic determinants of value, the three primary appraisal approaches to valuation, discussion of appraisal activity and practice.

name: — Business, Government Regulation, & Society
description: Course Description: Variety, nature and impact of government regulation: anti-trust laws and economic and social regulation. Nature of the legislative process, promulgation of regulations, and their impact, especially as analyzed by economists.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ARE 100B C- or better.

name: — Resource & Environment Policy Analysis
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Natural resource use problems with emphasis on past and current policies and institutions affecting resource use; determinants, principles, and patterns of natural resource use; property rights; conservation; private and public resource use problems; and public issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A or ECN 001AV.

name: — Resource & Environmental Policy Analysis
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Natural resource use problems with emphasis on past and current policies and institutions affecting resource use; determinants, principles, and patterns of natural resource use; property rights; conservation; private and public resource use problems; and public issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A or ECN 001AV.

name: — Agricultural Labor
description: Course Description: Analysis of labor markets with focus on U.S. and world agriculture. Labor supply, demand, market equilibrium; why farm labor markets are different; global trends in farm labor; U.S. farm labor history; unions and collective bargaining; immigration policy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better.

name: — Operations Research & Management Science
description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative methods used to analyze business and economic processes: decision analysis for management, mathematical programming, competitive analysis, and other methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Introduction to Mathematical Economics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Linear algebra for economists; necessary and sufficient conditions in static optimization problems; implicit function theorem; economic methodology and mathematics; comparative statics; envelope theorem; Le Chatelier principle; applications to production and consumer models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100B; ARE 155; ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Analysis for Operations & Production Management
description: Course Description: Application of economic theory and quantitative methods to analyze operations and production management problems including process strategy, quality management, location and plant layout, and inventory management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 155 C- or better; ARE 100A C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better); STA 103 C- or better.

name: — Emerging Economies & Globalization
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Economic drivers and policy challenges in the major emerging markets, with an emphasis on the effects of rising incomes, population growth, urbanization, and relative wages on world markets and natural resources.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ARE 115A; ARE 115B; completion of ARE 106 ECN 162 strongly recommended.

name: — Economics of Global Poverty Reduction: What Works & Why
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Application of microeconomic theory and econometrics to understand causes of poverty and critically evaluate poverty alleviation policies in low income countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ARE 100B C- or better or ECN 100B C- or better); (ARE 106 C- or better or ECN 140 C- or better); (ARE 115A C- or better or ECN 115A C- or better).

name: — Principles of Finance
description: Course Description: Principles of corporate financial management. Time value of money, interest rates, principles of valuation, NPV, risk and return, and cost of capital.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better; ARE 106 C- or better; MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better.

name: — Financial Management of the Firm
description: Course Description: Financial analysis at the firm level: optimizing capital structure; minimizing the cost of capital; dividend policies; mergers and acquisitions; real options; and risk management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 171 C- or better; ARE 106 C- or better; ARE 100A C- or better; MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better.

name: — Capital Markets
description: Course Description: Introduction to asset pricing. Valuation and risk characteristics of financial assets, including stocks, bonds, futures, and options. Investors’ attitudes toward risk, capital allocation, portfolio selection, the capital asset pricing model, and the efficient market hypothesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 171 C- or better; ARE 106 C- or better; ARE 100A C- or better; MGT 011A C- or better; MGT 011B C- or better.

name: — Natural Resource Economics
description: Course Description: Economic concepts and policy issues associated with natural resources, renewable resources (ground water, forests, fisheries, and wildlife populations) and non-renewable resources (minerals and energy resources, soil).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better or ECN 100A C- or better or ECN 100 C- or better.

name: — Environmental Economics
description: Course Description: Role of the environment in economic activity and methods for protecting and enhancing environmental quality; implications of market failures for public policy; design of environmental policy; theory of welfare measurement; measuring the benefits of environmental improvement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better or ECN 100A C- or better or ECN 100 C- or better.

name: — Topics in Managerial Economics
description: Course Description: Selected topics in managerial economics, focusing on current research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A; STA 103; and consent of instructor.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Internship experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Agricultural & Resource Economics. Internships are supervised by a member of the staff.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100B; ARE 106; ARE 155 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; minimum GPA of 3.500; major in Agricultural  Managerial Economics or Managerial Economics; senior standing.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100B; ARE 106; ARE 155 (can be concurrent); minimum GPA of 3.500; major in Agricultural  Managerial Economics or Managerial Economics; senior standing.

name: — Tutoring in Managerial Economics
description: Course Description: Undergraduates assist the instructor by tutoring students in one of the department's regularly scheduled courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing in Managerial Economics and consent of Department Chairperson.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Microeconomic Theory
description: Course Description: Linear and non-linear optimization theory applied to develop the theory of the profit-maximizing firm and the utility-maximizing consumer.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Microeconomic Theory
description: Course Description: Characteristics of market equilibrium under perfect competition, simple monopoly and monopsony. Emphasis on general equilibrium and welfare economics; the sources of market success and market failure.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A.

name: — Microeconomic Theory
description: Course Description: Uncertainty and information economics. Individual decision making under uncertainty. Introduction to game theory, with emphasis on applications to markets with firms that are imperfect competitors or consumers that are imperfectly informed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200B.

name: — Introduction to Applied Research Methods
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of philosophy and methodology of applied research in agricultural economics. Methods of conceptualization of researchable topics. Method of communication and constructive criticism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204A; ARE 200A (can be concurrent); ARE 256A.

name: — Applied Microeconomics: Consumer & Producer Behavior
description: Course Description: Application of consumer and producer theory in models of individual behavior and market-level phenomena. Implications of consumer and producer theory for specification of empirical models of supply and demand for inputs and outputs and market equilibrium displacement models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A; ARE 200B (can be concurrent); ARE 202A.

name: — Research Design for Applied Microeconomics
description: Course Description: Third of three courses in the Ph.D. level applied microeconomics sequence. Examines the design of empirical research and the application of econometric theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 202B; ARE 240A.

name: — Microeconomic Analysis I
description: Course Description: Behavior of consumers and producers and their interactions; tools and methods needed to analyze economic behavior in the marketplace. Application of those methods to real-world problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100B or ECN 100; advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.

name: — Microeconomic Analysis II
description: Course Description: Behavior in imperfectly competitive markets–monopoly and price discrimination; oligopoly. Introduction to noncooperative game theory. Analysis of decisions made under risk and uncertainty and imperfect information. The economics of externalities and public goods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Development Economics
description: Course Description: Review of the principal theoretical and empirical issues whose analysis has formed development economics. Analysis of economic development theories and development strategies and their application to specific policy issues in developing country contexts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A; ARE 100B; ECN 101; ARE 204A and ECN 160A, ECN 160B recommended.

name: — Microdevelopment Theory & Methods I
description: Course Description: Agricultural development theory, with a focus on microeconomics. Agricultural household behavior with and without imperfections and uncertainty. Analysis of rural land, labor, credit and insurance markets, institutions, and contracts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A or ARE 204A; ARE 240A recommended.

name: — Open Macroeconomics of Development
description: Course Description: Models and policy approaches regarding trade, monetary and fiscal issues, capital flows and debt are discussed in the macroeconomic framework of an open developing country. Basic analytical focus is real exchange rate and its impact on sectoral allocation of resources.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ARE 200A or ARE 204A); (ARE 214 or ARE 215A); (ARE 200D or ARE 205).

name: — Microdevelopment Theory & Methods II
description: Course Description: Extension of development theory and microeconomic methods. Agricultural growth and technological change; poverty and income inequality; multisectoral, including village and regional models. Computable general equilibrium methods and applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 215A.

name: — Environmental & Economic Development
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary course drawing on theoretical and empirical research on interactions between environmental resource use and economic development processes. Analysis of issues emerging at the interface of environmental and development economics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A; (ARE 204A or ARE 275).

name: — International Agricultural Trade & Policy
description: Course Description: Analysis of country interdependence through world agricultural markets. Partial equilibrium analysis is used to study the impacts of national intervention on world markets, national policy choice in an open economy and multinational policy issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ARE 100B or ARE 204A); ECN 160A; or the equivalent of ECN 160A.

name: — Economics of Agriculture
description: Course Description: Analytic treatment of the historical development and contemporary role of agriculture in the global, U.S. and California economies. Uses economic reasoning and evidence to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture, agricultural issues, and related government policies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204A (can be concurrent); ARE 256A (can be concurrent); or equivalent course(s) completed or concurrent required.

name: — Supply & Demand for Agricultural Products
description: Course Description: Analysis of supply and demand for agricultural commodities emphasizing the effective use of microeconomic theory with econometric methods, and other empirical procedures, in conducting applied analysis of supply and demand at the firm and industry level.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A; ARE 202A; ARE 240A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Agricultural Commodity Markets
description: Course Description: Economic analysis of industries that produce, market, transport, store, and process basic commodities. Analysis of market equilibrium under perfect and imperfect competition, with and without government involvement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A; ARE 202A; ARE 240A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Agricultural Policy
description: Course Description: Nature, formation, evolution, and institutions of economic policy applied to food, agricultural, and rural issues. Examples for detailed consideration include food security, commodity issues, and trade policy. Analytical approaches include static and dynamic welfare analysis, policy design, and political-economic analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 200A; ARE 202A; ARE 240A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Econometric Foundations
description: Course Description: Prepares students for econometric theory and empirical work by examining the statistical foundation of econometrics. Special attention is paid to problems specific to non-experimental data common to social sciences. Topics from matrix algebra are also covered.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Econometric Methods
description: Course Description: Least squares, instrumental variables, and maximum likelihood estimation and inference for single equation linear regression model; linear restrictions; heteroskedasticity; autocorrelation; lagged dependent variables.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 239; or consent of instructor.

name: — Econometric Methods
description: Course Description: Topics include asymptotic theory and instrumental variables, pooled time-series cross-section estimation, seemingly unrelated regression, classical hypothesis tests, identification and estimation of simultaneous equation models, cointegration, errorcorrection models, and qualitative and limited dependent variable models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 240A.

name: — Time Series Econometrics
description: Course Description: Probability theory; estimation, inference and forecasting of time series models; trends and non-standard asymptotic theory; vector time series methods and cointegration; time series models for higher order moments and transition data; state-space modeling; the Kalman filter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 240B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Cross Section Econometrics
description: Course Description: Estimation and inference for nonlinear regression models for cross-section data; models for discrete data and for limited dependent variables; models for  panel data; additional topics such as bootstrap and semiparametric regression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 240B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Time Series Econometrics
description: Course Description: Modern econometric techniques for time series data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B and ECN 240C. Contents vary from year to year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 240C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Cross Section Econometrics
description: Course Description: Modern econometrics techniques for cross-section data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B and ECN 240D. Contents vary from year to year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 240D; or consent of instructor.

name: — Optimization with Economic Applications
description: Course Description: Microeconomic topics in the framework of mathematical programming.

name: — Dynamic Optimization Techniques with Economic Applications
description: Course Description: Necessary and sufficient conditions in the calculus of variations and optimal control, economic interpretations, the dynamic envelope theorem and transversality conditions, infinite horizon problems and phase diagrams, local stability and comparative statics of the steady state, comparative dynamics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Elementary knowledge of ordinary differential equations.

name: — Applied Dynamic Structural Econometric Modeling
description: Course Description: Covers structural econometric models of static games of incomplete information, single-agent dynamic optimization problems and multi-agent dynamic games, with a focus on applications to issues relevant to the environment, energy, natural resources, agriculture, and development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 254.

name: — Applied Econometrics I
description: Course Description: First of two courses in the Masters-level econometrics sequence. The linear regression model and generalizations are applied to topics in applied economics. Tools for empirical research for problems requiring more sophisticated tools than standard regression models are emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 106 or ECN 140; or consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Econometrics II
description: Course Description: Second of two courses in the Masters-level econometrics sequence. The linear regression model and generalizations are applied to a variety of topics in applied economics. Tools for empirical research for problems requiring more sophisticated tools than standard regression models are emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 256A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Demand & Market Analysis
description: Course Description: Application of theoretical material covered in ECN 204A and ECN 204B, with particular focus on production theory/factor demand and imperfect competition/market power. Use of theoretical models as a foundation for empirical economic analysis, and empirical exercises. Independent research on chosen topics, with empirical application.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204B; ARE 256B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Financial Economics
description: Course Description: Risk, aversion, choice under uncertainty. Arrow-Debreu securities. Valuation and risk characteristics of financial assets, capital allocation, portfolio selection, Capital Asset Pricing Model, efficient market hypothesis. Applications to topics in agricultural, resource and development economics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204A; ARE 256A.

name: — Economic Analysis of Resource & Environmental Policies
description: Course Description: Development of externality theory, market failure concepts, welfare economics, theory of renewable and non-renewable resource use, and political economic models. Applications to policy issues regarding the agricultural/environment interface and managing resources in the public domain.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204A.

name: — Environmental Economics: Externalities
description: Course Description: Introduces fundamental and recent research in environmental economics, focusing on the design, implementation and evaluation of environmental policy instruments to correct market failures. Exposure to economic theories and empirical techniques frequently used in this field.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students should have completed the first year graduate level sequence in microeconomics and econometrics.

name: — Environmental Economics: Non-Market Valuation
description: Course Description: Second Ph.D. field course in environmental economics, covering theory and econometrics of methods for valuing non-market goods and environmental quality changes. Topics include revealed preference (travel cost, hedonics, sorting equilibrium) and stated preference (contingent valuation, choice experiments, conjoint analysis) techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students should have completed the first year graduate level sequence in microeconomics and econometrics.

name: — Natural Resource Economics
description: Course Description: Application of capital theory and dynamic methods to issues of optimal use of renewable and nonrenewable resources. Examination of policy issues associated with forests, fisheries, groundwater, energy resources, watersheds, soil, global climate, and wildlife.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 254; or consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Agricultural & Resource Economics
description: Course Description: Selected topics in agricultural and resource economics, focusing on current research.

name: — Analysis of California Agriculture & Resources
description: Course Description: Review and analysis of production, marketing, and resource issues facing agricultural firms in California. Application of economic theory and measurement to individual firm and industry decisions in an applied setting. Fieldwork-45 hours total, including one five-day summer field trip.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Advanced study through special seminars, informal group studies, or group research on problems for analysis and experimentation. Sections:(1) Managerial Economics; (2) Agricultural Policy; (3) Community & Regional Development; (4) Natural Resources; (5) Human Resources; (6) Research Methods & Quantitative Analysis.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Sections: (1) Managerial Economics; (2) Agricultural Policy; (3) Community & Regional Development; (4) Natural Resources; (5) Human Resources; (6) Research Methods & Quantitative Analysis; and (7) Dissertation Research Prospectus.

name: — Special Study for Doctoral Dissertation
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Special study for doctoral dissertation.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship off and on campus in areas of agricultural education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: AED support moved to ANS, informed July 2018 by Lisa Holmes. Subject moved in ICMS, took some time.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Concepts in Agricultural & Environmental Education
description: Course Description: Philosophy and nature of formal and non-formal agricultural and environmental education programs. Emphasis on understanding the role of the teacher and observing a variety of programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Vocational Education
description: Course Description: Philosophy and organization of vocational education, with particular reference to educational principles for agriculture commerce, home economics, and industry.

name: — Audiovisual Communications
description: Course Description: Theory and principles of audiovisual communications. Comparison of audiovisual materials such as transparencies, slides, computer- generated graphics, and videos. Operation and use of audiovisual equipment is stressed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Multimedia Productions
description: Course Description: Design and production of educational, technical, and professional multimedia presentations. Instructional or professional presentations using a variety of media, including slides, video, transparencies, and computer-generated graphics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 171 recommended.

name: — Capstone for Agricultural & Environmental Education Majors
description: Course Description: Critical thinking in reference to undergraduate coursework. Assessment of Agricultural & Environmental Education Student Learning Outcomes. Preparation to utilize these concepts and skills professionally.

name: — Seminar in Agricultural Education
description: Course Description: Discussion of selected critical issues in agricultural education.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship off and on campus in areas of agricultural education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study.

name: — Directed Field Experience in Teaching
description: Course Description: Experience as teaching assistant in agriculture or home economics programs in public schools.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 100.

name: — Planning for Instructional Programs
description: Course Description: Major paradigms in program planning and development. Emphasis on key steps in curriculum development, including selection and organization of educational objectives, learning experiences and teaching materials and resources.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 100; AED 300 (can be concurrent).

name: — Teaching Methods in Agricultural Education
description: Course Description: Development of teaching strategies with special emphasis on the designing of learning experiences, instructional execution, and use of teaching aids in agricultural education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 100; AED 300 (can be concurrent).

name: — Field Experience with Future Farmers of America & Supervised Experience Programs
description: Course Description: Develop an understanding of the Future Farmers of America and supervised occupational experience programs through planning, conducting, and evaluating actual programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 306B (can be concurrent); acceptance into a teacher education program.

name: — Field Experience in Teaching Agriculture
description: Course Description: Directed teaching including supervision of occupational experience programs and youth activities in secondary schools or community colleges.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 306A (can be concurrent); AED 100; AED 300; AED 301; AED 302; and consent of instructor.; acceptance into a teacher education program.

name: — Resource Development: Agricultural Education
description: Course Description: Selection and implementation of community resources in teaching.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 306A; AED 306B.

name: — Seminar: Issues in Agricultural Education
description: Course Description: Discussion and evaluation of current issues, theories and research in agricultural education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AED 306A; AED 306B; acceptance into a teacher education program.

name: — American Lives Through Autobiography
description: Course Description: American culture as understood through the individual life stories told by Americans, with attention to the roles of gender, race, ethnicity, social class, and sexual orientation in the individual's life course.

name: — Nature & Culture in America
description: Course Description: Uses and abuses of nature in America; patterns of inhabitation, exploitation, appreciation, and neglect; attention to California; emphasis on metaphor as a key to understanding ourselves and the natural world; attention to models of healing: stewardship, ecology, the "rights" movement.

name: — Freshman Seminar
description: Course Description: Investigation of a special topic in American Studies through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site visits). Emphasis on student participation in learning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students who have completed fewer than 40 quarter units.

name: — Technology in American Lives
description: Course Description: Technology as both a material cultural force and a symbol in American culture; the lives of engineers at work and play; images of the engineer and technology in popular culture; social political and ethical issues raised by technology.

name: — Introduction to American Studies
description: Course Description: Ideals, conflicts, and realities defining American Cultures through study of popular music, advertising, and other media. Themes include Imagining America, Citizenship and Belonging, and Cultural/Spatial Practices.

name: — U.S. Disability Culture & Medicine
description: Course Description: Disability as a form of social exclusion; disability as social and cultural identity; intersections of disability with race, gender, class, and sexuality; popular culture, art, television, film, and literature by disabled people; critiques of medicine by people with disabilities; health disparities; ways to make medicine more inclusive.

name: — Objects & Everyday Life
description: Course Description: Material culture (objects and artifacts ranging from everyday objects like toys and furnishings to buildings and constructed landscapes) as evidence for understanding the everyday (vernacular) lives (gender, social class, ethnicity, region, age, and other factors; collecting and displaying material.

name: — United States as a Business Culture
description: Course Description: Business as a cultural system and its relation to religion, politics, arts, science, technology, and material culture; business themes of success, creativity, invention, and competition in American autobiographies, fiction, advice literature, film, and television; cultures of the workplace; multinational business.

name: — Images of America & Americans in Popular Culture
description: Course Description: Investigation of verbal and visual discourses about American identity in various popular culture products, including film, television, radio, music, fiction, art, advertising, and commercial experiences; discourses about the United States in the popular culture of other societies.

name: — Food in American Culture
description: Course Description: Relationship between food and culture; relationship between food and the social order; influences on eating habits and the tensions between them including identity, convenience, and responsibility; multiple disciplines and genres.

name: — Music & American Culture
description: Course Description: Examination of music and American culture. Studies will explore music in its cultural contexts, which may include examinations of recording and broadcasting, of race, class, and gender, the role of technolgy, and relationships between musical production, consumption and listening.

name: — Careers & Identity in American Culture
description: Course Description: Defining one's identity through the career. Life course, preparation, and choices. Personality and career. Ethics. Gender, ethnicity, sexuality, and social class in the workplace. Transnational workplace. Conflicts between the career and other social roles.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Individual study for undergraduates.

name: — Methods in American Studies
description: Course Description: Design and implementation of interdisciplinary research, analysis and writing for American Studies and other cultural studies fields. Library and Internet research skills, project/problem definition, methods for study of texts, individuals, communities. Hand-on, skill-building, focused reading, discussion.

name: — Special Topics: Popular Culture Studies
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

name: — Special Topics: Queer & Trans Studies
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects in queer and/or transgender studies. Specific topic depends on research interests of the instructor.

name: — Special Topics: Material Aspects of American Culture
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

name: — Special Topics: American Lives Through Autobiography
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

name: — Special Topics: Interrelationship Between Arts & Ideas
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

name: — Special Topics: New Directions in American Culture Studies
