description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of a broad problem or theoretical issue in art, architecture, or material culture. Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Art History major, minor, or other significant training in Art History recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Art History: Islamic
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of a broad problem or theoretical issue in art, architecture, or material culture. Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Art History major, minor, or other significant training in Art History recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Art History: 19th Century
description: Course Description: Study of a broad problem or theoretical issue in art, architecture, or material culture. Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Art History major, minor, or other significant training in Art History recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Art History: Architecture & Heritage
description: Course Description: Study of a broad problem or theoretical issue in art, architecture, or material culture. Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Art History major, minor, or other significant training in Art History recommended.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised program of internships at professional art institutions such as museums, galleries, and art archives including collections of slides and photographs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Honors Thesis Research
description: Course Description: Research and initial drafting of a senior thesis paper in a scholarly area of Art History, under supervision of Art History faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; a minimum GPA of 3.7 and completion of one undergraduate seminar in Art History (AHI 190A-L).

name: — Honors Thesis Writing
description: Course Description: Final writing of a senior thesis paper in a scholarly area of Art History, under supervision of Art History faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AHI 194HA A- or better; consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group Study. May be taught abroad.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Visual Theory & Interpretive Methods
description: Course Description: Close study of selected recent developments in interpretive methodology used by art historians and other analysts of visual culture and the place of those developments within art history's history and in the larger field of social, cultural and historical analysis.

name: — Research & Writing Methods in Art History
description: Course Description: Development of the research, writing, and editing skills necessary for producing publishable work. Focus on reference tools used by art historians and the mechanics of scholarship, from question framing and organization of ideas to writing clear, effective prose.

name: — Thesis Writing Colloquium
description: Course Description: Meeting concurrently with AHI 200B, the colloquium provides a structured, supportive environment for second-year Art History graduate students drafting masters' theses. Offers a forum for technical discussions, discussion of writing/editing procedures, and peer review of writing in progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AHI 200B; taken by all Art History M.A. students in their first year.

name: — Museums, Art Exhibitions & Culture
description: Course Description: Issues accompanying the evolution and function of museums from cabinets of curiosities in 16th-century Europe to modern art centers. Examination of divergent motives behind collecting, exhibiting, and interpretation of objects. Investigation of museums' historical legacies and continuing philosophical dilemmas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate status in art history or an allied field.

name: — Problems in Art Historical Research
description: Course Description: Major topics in art historical research, emphasizing special methods of investigation, and of historical and critical analysis.

name: — Seminar in Classical Art
description: Course Description: Selected areas of special study in classical art of the Greek and Roman tradition.

name: — Seminar in Chinese Art
description: Course Description: Selected areas of special study in Chinese Art.

name: — Seminar in Medieval Art
description: Course Description: Selected areas of special study in medieval art from Early Christian to late Gothic.

name: — Seminar in Italian Renaissance Art
description: Course Description: Selected areas of special study in Italian art from the 14th to the 16th century.

name: — Seminar in Visual Culture & Gender
description: Course Description: Selected areas of special study in the relationship between visual culture and gender in Europe and America from 1750 to present.

name: — Seminar in European & American Architecture
description: Course Description: Exploration of selected topics in European and American architectural history with concentration on the Modern Period.

name: — Special topics in Art History
description: Course Description: Special research seminar in the theory or methods of Art History, or in a period of Art History. Topic varies depending on the interests of the instructor or students.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship at professional art or cultural institution including museum, galleries, archives, government offices, visual resources libraries, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Individual study.

name: — Introduction to Teaching Art History for Teaching Assistants
description: Course Description: Designed for teaching assistants with emphasis on problems and procedures encountered by teachers of undergraduate art history.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Museum Training: Exhibition Methods
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. History of exhibition methods in private and public collections. Comparisons of different types of museums and their exhibition problems. Lighting and techniques of display with emphasis on actual design. Experimentation with unusual presentation forms.

name: — Introduction to Studio Art Practice
description: Course Description: Introduction to studio art practice. Overview and practice of artists’ creative process including hands-on visual exercises, reading, writing, presentation, and critique.

name: — Beginning Drawing
description: Course Description: Introduction to drawing using various black and white media to articulate forms and organize space, with reference to historical and contemporary works.

name: — Beginning Sculpture
description: Course Description: Basic sculpture techniques using a variety of media. Form in space using cardboard, plaster, and/or cement, wood and/or metal and other media.

name: — Beginning Painting
description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques and concepts in the practice of painting.

name: — Beginning Ceramic Sculpture
description: Course Description: Introduction to ceramic sculpture construction and processes. Large scale hand-building, glazing, kilns and kiln firing technology.

name: — Beginning Photography
description: Course Description: Introduction to visual language of photographic art and technique. Manual camera operation and printing techniques. Concept and practice of photography as an art form and creating photographic projects.

name: — Contemporary Art Appreciation
description: Course Description: Survey of contemporary art since 1960; includes discussion. Explores contemporary thought within the visual arts using forms and strategies of painting, sculpture, installation, performance, photo and video in collaborative, ephermeral and multimedia approaches. For Art and non-Art majors.

name: — Contemporary Art Appreciation
description: Course Description: Survey of contemporary art since 1960; includes fieldwork. Explores contemporary thought within the visual arts using forms and strategies of painting, sculpture, installation, performance, photo and video in collaborative, ephermeral and multimedia approaches. For Art and non-Art majors.

name: — Beginning Printmaking
description: Course Description: Introduction to printmaking such as monoprint, intaglio, lithography, relief and digital techniques. Practical methods taught within a workshop environment using art historical and contemporary examples.

name: — Beginning Video
description: Course Description: Production techniques of video shooting, editing, lighting, sound and effects. A conceptual framework for video-art techniques.

name: — Introduction to Experimental Video & Film
description: Course Description: Evolution of moving image technologies. Shifts within avant-garde artistic practices. Conceptual and historical differences between film and video. Relationship of film and video to fine arts.

name: — Introduction to Contemporary Visual Culture
description: Course Description: Establishing visual literacy across the media of fine art, photography, advertising, television and film; media culture; focus on critical decoding of contemporary visual culture.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Painting
description: Course Description: Individualized projects exploring color and space in a variety of subject matter and approaches. Builds on basic skills and concepts from beginning drawing and painting courses. Study of historical and contemporary art in relation to studio practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 007.

name: — Intermediate Painting: Figure
description: Course Description: Study of the human figure through the medium of painting with emphasis on development of skill and conceptual awareness.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 007.

name: — Intermediate Painting: Watercolor
description: Course Description: Watercolor as a means of visual expression. Techniques and medium used in water media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 007.

name: — Intermediate Painting: Installation
description: Course Description: Expanded fields of painting and installation art in the context of contemporary art practice. Painting's possibilities in relation to space and pushing the boundaries of two-dimensional art.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 007.

name: — Intermediate Painting: Reinterpreting Landscape
description: Course Description: Interpretation of landscape through painting, drawing, and related media. Integration of historical, cultural, natural, and artistic contexts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 007.

name: — Advanced Painting: Studio Projects
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Sustained development of painting for advanced students. Approaches will vary according to the instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 101A.

name: — Advanced Painting: Special Topics
description: Course Description: Special topics in painting for upper division students. Emphasis on development of a personal practice of painting informed by awareness of contemporary issues in painting and their historical background. Topics will vary with instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ART 002,  ART 007,  ART 101); (ART 102A or ART 102B).

name: — Intermediate Drawing
description: Course Description: Study of drawing composition using charcoal and ink.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 002.

name: — Intermediate Drawing: Figure
description: Course Description: Study of the human figure through the medium of drawing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 002.

name: — Intermediate Drawing: 3 Dimensions
description: Course Description: Study of drawing composition using three dimensional media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 002.

name: — Advanced Drawing: Studio Projects
description: Course Description: Exploration of composition and process in drawing. Emphasis on the role of drawing in contemporary art and on drawing as an interdisciplinary practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 002; (ART 103A or ART 103B or ART 103C).

name: — Intermediate Photography: Black & White Analog
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to 35mm and medium format camera. Development of personal aesthetic and portfolio of black and white prints.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009.

name: — Intermediate Photography: Digital Imaging
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Comprehensive introduction to all elements of digital photography, including scanning, imaging software and printing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009.

name: — Intermediate Photography: Photographic Lighting
description: Course Description: Effects of lighting on photographic image. Ability to read, utilize, modify natural lighting conditions. Studio lighting equipment, and use of photographic studio. Photographic production management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009; or consent of instructor.

name: — The Photobook
description: Course Description: History and practice of photographic book. Sequencing, use of text & image, page layout and bookbinding techniques. Development of major photographic project. Includes technical lessons on image correction, digital page layout, and bookbinding techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009; or consent of instructor.

name: — The Photobook
description: Course Description: Continuation of 110DA. Advanced practice of photographic book. Sequencing, use of text & image, page layout and bookbinding techniques. Development of major photographic project. Topics include cover design and use of non-photographic techniques such as screen printing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009; ART 110DA; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Photography: Special Topics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Special topics related to photography and contemporary art practice. Multiple projects in a variety of approaches.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009; (ART 110A or ART 110B).

name: — Advanced Photography: Digital Imaging
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: In-depth exploration of digital photography, including refined digital imaging techniques. Theoretical issues involved in digital media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009; ART 110B.

name: — Sound for Vision
description: Course Description: Sound composition and development of an audio databank. Study of repetition and phase shifts. Creation of descriptive acoustic space recordings in combination with other artistic media. Audio as stand alone or accompaniment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 012 or CDM 020 or CTS 020.

name: — Interdisciplinary Art
description: Course Description: Experimental interdisciplinary strategies. Use of various media in creation of collaborative or independent works. Production of participatory audio-visual works, installations, or two dimensional explorations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in Art Studio, Theater and Dance, Design, Technocultural Studies, or Music.

name: — Intermediate Video: Animation
description: Course Description: Exploration of animation as an artistic approach and conceptual platform. Relationship between drawing, digital stills, and moving images through use of drawing techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 012 or CTS 020 or CDM 020.

name: — Intermediate Video: Experimental Documentary
description: Course Description: Experimental documentary practice. Use of interviews, voice-overs, and still and moving images. Production of alternative conceptual and visual projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 012 or CTS 020 or CDM 020.

name: — Intermediate Video: Performance Strategies
description: Course Description: Use of video to expand performance art production. Exploration of improvisation, direction, projection, and image processing in real time.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 012 or CTS 020 or CDM 020.

name: — Advanced Video & Electronic Arts
description: Course Description: Independently driven video, digital, and/or performance projects. Further development in the electronic arts ranging from video installation to performance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 012 or CDM 020; (ART 112 or ART 114A or ART 114B or ART 114C or CDM 100 or CDM 104 or CDM 105 or TCS 100 or CDM 101 or TCS 104); upper division standing Art Studio majors.

name: — Intermediate Printmaking: Relief
description: Course Description: Relief printmaking, experimental printing of found surfaces, single-color block printing and reduction woodcut techniques. Development of conceptual and technical progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011.

name: — Intermediate Printmaking: Intaglio
description: Course Description: Intaglio printmaking techniques including copper-plate drypoint, engraving, etching, aquatint. Development of on soft-ground, spit bite and chine-collé. Development of conceptual and technical progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011.

name: — Intermediate Printmaking: Lithography
description: Course Description: Polyester-plate printing. Drawing materials and chemistry for stone or ball-grained plates. Digital processes in photo-platemaking. Development of conceptual and technical progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011.

name: — Intermediate Printmaking: Screenprinting
description: Course Description: Screen printing including the introduction of photo-emulsion, hand stencil making and digital stencil making techniques for screen printing on paper or alternative surfaces. Development of conceptual and technical progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011.

name: — Intermediate Printmaking: Post-Digital Print Media
description: Course Description: Post-digital print media integrating digital forms of image making and print-on-demand technology with established printing processes; screen printing, lithography or intaglio. Development of conceptual and technical progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011 D or better.

name: — Advanced Printmaking
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of intermedia printmaking. Advanced modes in print technologies: relief, serigraphy, intaglio, surface, as well as addition of digitized imagery. Production of prints using multi-plate prints and other methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 011; ART 125A or ART 125B or ART 125C or ART 125D.

name: — The Artist's Book
description: Course Description: Creation of an artist's book in an edition of three. Use of a variety of media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of three upper division Art Studio (ART) courses.

name: — Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture: Industrial Production Methods
description: Course Description: Ceramic sculpture creation using two forms of industrial processes: plaster mold design, fabrication and casting; and extrusion with dies, including die fabrication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 008.

name: — Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture: Material Study
description: Course Description: Study of ceramic materials and processes. Areas studied include clay and clay bodies; glaze materials through temperature, color and texture; history and technology of kilns and kiln firing. Examination of material properties and characteristics through experimentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 008.

name: — Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture: Ceramics & the Painted Surface
description: Course Description: Exploration of the ceramic surface for creative expression. Use of glazing techniques including china paint, decals, luster, and silkscreen with underglaze and overglaze as well as the use of common materials such as epoxy, paint, oil and wax.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 008.

name: — Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture: Special Topics
description: Course Description: Studio work and professional practice practicum. Visit artist's studios, museums and galleries, and attend artist lectures. Both drawings and written journals are kept throughout the term.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 008.

name: — Advanced Ceramic Sculpture: Studio Projects
description: Course Description: Experimentation with all techniques learned in prerequisite ceramics classes. Includes class projects in consultation with faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 008; (ART 142A or ART 142B or ART 142C).

name: — Theory & Criticism of Photography
description: Course Description: Development of camera vision, ideas, and aesthetics and their relationship to the fine arts from 1839 to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 009.

name: — Theory & Criticism: Painting & Sculpture
description: Course Description: Study of forms and symbols in historic and contemporary masterpieces.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005 or ART 007 recommended.

name: — Introduction to Critical Theory
description: Course Description: Overview of 20th-century critical theories of culture and their relation to visual art and mass media culture.

name: — Theory & Criticism of Electronic Media
description: Course Description: Study of electronic media, focusing on critique, application, and relationship to art practice. Analysis of the conceptual basis of electronic media as an artistic mode of expression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 024 recommended.

name: — Intermediate Sculpture
description: Course Description: Individualized explorations through multiple projects in a variety of sculpture media and techniques. Builds upon technical skills and concepts covered in ART 005.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Studio Projects
description: Course Description: Sculpture for advanced students. Emphasis on concept, idea development and honing technical skills. Approaches and projects will vary according to the instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Material Explorations
description: Course Description: Primary application and exploration of a single sculpture material chosen by the student. Examination of its properties, qualities, and characteristics for three-dimensional expression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Concepts
description: Course Description: Investigation of a specific idea chosen by the class. Relationship of idea to form and content. Individual development of conceptual awareness.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Metals
description: Course Description: Technical aspects of the use of metals in contemporary art practice. Projects assigned to demonstrate the evolution of concepts and processes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Site Specific Public Sculpture
description: Course Description: Place and site specificity in contemporary sculpture. Individual and group work to conceive and fabricate sculpture in a public space.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: Figure
description: Course Description: Exploration of historical and contemporary approaches to the body in three-dimensions. Projects based on observational and conceptual strategies. Variety of media and techniques, including clay, wax, plaster, plastics, found objects, and others.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Advanced Sculpture: The Miniature & Gigantic
description: Course Description: Exploration of scale, from the very small to the very large in a series of projects in a variety of media. Tools and techniques of enlargement and miniaturization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ART 005; ART 151.

name: — Mexican & Chicano Mural Workshop
description: Course Description: The Mural: a collective art process that empowers students and people through design and execution of mural paintings in the tradition of the Mexican Mural Movement; introduces materials and techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 070; and consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Art Practice
description: Course Description: Introduction to professional practices. Development of an artist's packet including a resume, cover letter, artist statement, and statement of purpose. Ongoing independent studio work with group critiques. Research on galleries and museums, and readings in contemporary theory and criticism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing Art Studio major and completion of two upper division ART classes.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised program of internships in artists' studios and at professional art institutions such as museums, galleries, and art archives including collections of slides and photographs.

name: — Expanded Field: Artist Lecture Series
description: Course Description: Exploration of the expanded field of practice, theory and criticism in the visual arts. Presentations and discussions with professional practitioners in the field.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Methods for Artists
description: Course Description: Research methods for artists through critical reading and writing, studio practice, presentations, site-visits, and professional engagement related to the field of visual art.

name: — Critical Exploration & Collaboration
description: Course Description: During the first year of study, MFA graduate students take the Critical Exploration & Collaboration seminar. Explore and analyze a range of subjects in contemporary art and begin to define their relationship to these ideas through speaking, writing, research and presentation in ways that are relevant to their own art practice.

name: — Advanced Critical Exploration & Collaboration
description: Course Description: Advanced course for second-year graduate students. Explore and analyze a range of subjects in contemporary art and begin to define their relationship to these ideas through speaking, writing, research and presentation in ways that are relevant to their own art practice.

name: — Concepts & Critique
description: Course Description: Focuses on research methods for artists through critical reading and writing, studio practice, presentations, site-visits, and professional engagement related to the field of visual art. Faculty-moderated group critique course to develop a sense of the theoretical foundations and implications of the work of each of the participants through class analysis and extended discussion.

name: — Theory & Concepts on Critical Issues in Contemporary Art
description: Course Description: Critical and conceptual foundations for graduate students. Political, social and cultural questions as they relate to the production and reception of art. Contemporary theories to develop verbal and analytical skills.

name: — Professional Practice in Contemporary Art
description: Course Description: Fluctuating critical and cultural environment of the professional art world. New strategies to support the social and philosophical networks and frameworks that inform contemporary cultural production. Emphasis on new esthetics concepts, practices and technologies.

name: — Exhibition Strategy & Thesis Seminar
description: Course Description: Completion of a body of work and development of a thesis show. Curation, design, installation, documentation, contributing to catalog content and design, and promoting work in a public forum.

name: — Collaboration & Interdisciplinarity
description: Course Description: Explores methodologies in practice with emphasis on collaboration and interdisciplinarity. Artistic production and directed research supporting the development of site. Work across artistic mediums, academic disciplines, and social concerns.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Original works produced for group discussion and criticism; associated topics of a contemporary and historical nature.

name: — Critical Discourse in Contemporary Art
description: Course Description: Critical discourse in contemporary art and application to practice. Exploration of concerns in broader artistic and contemporary context. How artists look to shift prevalent expectations through critical analysis.

name: — Critical Discourse in Studio Practice
description: Course Description: Advanced course for second-year graduate students. Critical discussion and contemporary readings pertinent to studio practice and artwork, including video, installation, photography, interactive arts, performance, sculpture, painting, printmaking, ceramics, sound, and all other mediums.

name: — Critical Discourse in Materiality
description: Course Description: Mid-year study focusing on individual work in the studio. Explores mediums, techniques, skill building, resourcing and problem solving. Defining the artists relationship to topics in contemporary art through speaking, writing, research and presentation.

name: — Critical Discourse in Context
description: Course Description: Advanced course for second-year Graduate students. Discussion of social, political, cultural, and economic issues in a constantly changing world. How contemporary art practice are affected by global issues.

name: — Critical Discourse on Media
description: Course Description: Critical discussion and contemporary readings pertinent to artwork that uses digital media including video, installation, photography, interactive arts, performance, sculpture, painting, printmaking, ceramics, sound, and all other mediums.

name: — Critical Discourse in Presentation
description: Course Description: For second-year graduate students. Study focuses on individual performance work. Exploration extends into other mediums, techniques for props or sites, tapping the resources of peers, problem solving with the intention to deepen understanding and engagement with an audience. Exploration and analysis of subjects in cont. art and begin to define their relationship to these ideas through speaking, writing, research and presentation in ways that are relevant to their performance art practice.

name: — Seminar: Critical Evaluation
description: Course Description: Seminar in critical evaluation.

name: — Seminar: Comprehensive Qualifying
description: Course Description: Further critical evaluation of the student's work to determine his eligibility to begin the Comprehensive Project.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Individual study.

name: — Comprehensive Project
description: Course Description: An original body of work accompanied by a catalog summarizing the student's aesthetic position.

name: — Museum Training: Curatorial Principles
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Study of private and public collections. Museum personalities. Appraisal of works of art; ethics of appraisal. Auction and sales: methods and catalogues. Registration. Technical problems of the museum. Connoisseurship. Collateral reading. Visits to museums.

name: — Museum Training: Exhibition Methods
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. History of exhibition methods in private and public collections. Comparisons of different types of museums and their exhibition problems. Lighting and techniques of display with emphasis on actual design. Experimentation with unusual presentation forms.

name: — Historical Experience of Asian Americans
description: Course Description: Introduction to Asian American Studies through an overview of the history of Asians in America from the 1840s to the present within the context of the development of the United States.

name: — Contemporary Issues of  Asian Americans
description: Course Description: Introduction to Asian American Studies through the critical analysis of the impact of race, racism, ethnicity, imperialism, militarism, and immigration since post-World War II on Asian Americans. Topics may include sexuality, criminality, class, hate crimes, and inter-ethnic relations.

name: — Social & Psychological Perspectives of Asian Americans
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Major psychosocial issues of Asian Americans. Theories and empirical research that address cultural values, behavioral norms, ethnic stereotypes, racism, acculturation, ethnic identity development, family communication, stressors and social support systems, academic achievement, interpersonal effectiveness, and psychopathology.

name: — Asian American Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary course examines the multiple ways in which race, class, sexuality and gender, as well as the recent turn to transnationalism and postcolonial theory, have changed the ways we read Asian American literature and see art, theater and film.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship in community and institutional settings related to Asian American concerns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily intended for lower division students.

name: — Student Facilitated Course
description: Course Description: Student-facilitated (taught) course intended for lower division students.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Asian American Communities
description: Course Description: Survey and analysis of Asian American communities within both historical and contemporary contexts. Presentation of the analytical skills, theories, and concepts needed to describe, explain, and understand the diversity of Asian American communities within the larger, dominant society.

name: — Theoretical Perspective in Asian American Studies
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Explores major theories of race and its intersections with class, gender, and sexuality from interdisciplinary perspective. Introduces key theoretical developments, issues, debates. Through case studies, analyzes ways various theoretical frameworks and perspectives have been incorporated into range of scholarship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ASA 001 or ASA 002 or ASA 003 or ASA 004; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Asian American Women
description: Course Description: Experiences of Asian American women from major ethnic subgroups comparatively examined in their social, economic and historical contexts using theoretical perspectives from social sciences, humanities/arts: identity, racialization, immigration, gender, sexuality, labor, socialization, cultural expression, social movements and feminist theorizing.

name: — Asian American Sexuality
description: Course Description: Restrictive U.S. immigration laws, labor exploitation, race-based exclusionary laws, removal and internment, anti-miscegenation laws, and other examples of social control are surveyed to assess their role in shaping the sexuality of the different Asian American groups.

name: — Asian Diasporas
description: Course Description: Asian diasporic communities and the experiences of its members in the United States and internationally. Community building, cyberspace, gender issues, labor, transnational practices, effects of globalization, political organizing, homeland politics, humanitarian projects, citizenship and nationalism.

name: — Multiracial Asian Pacific American Issues
description: Course Description: Introduction to the experiences of biracial and multiracial Asian Pacific people in the U.S., concentrating on theories of race, racial identity formation, culture, media, and anti-racist struggles. Critical approaches to the analysis of popular media and academic representations.

name: — Asian American Youth
description: Course Description: Social experiences of diverse groups of Asian American youth. Ways in which youth themselves actively create cultural expressions and political interventions.

name: — Asian American Performance
description: Course Description: Performance work by, for, and/or about Asian Pacific Americans including dramatic literature, performance art, dance, and film. Ethnicity, gender and sexuality, class and age as they intersect with Asian Pacific American identities in and through dramatic performance.

name: — Asian American Literature
description: Course Description: Works of Asian American literature by writers from the major ethnic subgroups, examined in their social, economic and historical contexts. Intertextual analysis of their thematic and formal elements to form an understanding of Asian American literary traditions.

name: — Ethnicity, Culture, & the Self
description: Course Description: Cultural and social psychological influences on Asian Americans focusing on the individual.

name: — Health Issues Confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders
description: Course Description: Health issues confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders.

name: — Asian Americans & the Political Culture of Fashion in the U.S. & Asia
description: Course Description: Historical, cultural and sociopolitical development of fashion in Asia and the U.S. as it relates to the Asian Diasporas. Specific aspects of material culture: textiles, clothing and fashion.

name: — Filipino American Experience
description: Course Description: Examination of the relationship between the Filipino-American community, the Philippine home community and the larger American society through a critical evaluation of the historical and contemporary conditions, problems and prospects of Filipinos in the U.S.

name: — Japanese American Experience
description: Course Description: Different analytical approaches to understand Japanese American history, culture and society.

name: — Chinese American Experience
description: Course Description: Survey of the historical and contemporary experiences of Chinese in the United States, starting with the gold rush era and concluding with the present-day phenomenon of Chinese transnational movement to the United States and its diasporic significance.

name: — Korean American Experience
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary survey of the historical and contemporary experiences of Koreans in the United States from the late-19th century to the present.

name: — Southeast Asian American Experience
description: Course Description: Historical survey of Southeast Asian experiences with special focus on United States involvement and post 1975 migrations. Defines international and transnational conditions that led up to the large exodus and resettlement of Southeast Asians.

name: — South Asian American History, Culture, & Politics
description: Course Description: South Asian American experiences, focusing on the histories, cultures, and politics of Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, and Sri Lankan communities in the U.S. Interdisciplinary approaches to migration, labor, gender, racialization, ethnicity, youth, community mobilization.

name: — Asian American Legal History
description: Course Description: Legal history of Asian Americans, from the mid-19th century to present. Laws and administrative policies affecting Asian American communities, including those governing immigration, social and economic participation, WWII internment, and affirmative action.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: History
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; history.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Culture
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; culture.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Physical & Mental Health
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; physical and mental health.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Policy & Community
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: policy and community.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Comparative Racial Studies
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: comparative racial studies.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Asian Studies & Asian American Studies
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: asian studies and asian american studies.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Race, Class, Gender, & Sexuality
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: race, class, gender, and sexuality.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Society & Institutions
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: society and institutions.

name: — Topics in Asian American Studies: Politics & Social Movements
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: politics and social movements.

name: — Internships
description: Course Description: Supervised internship in community and institutional settings related to Asian American concerns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern position with priority to Asian American Studies minors; consent of instructor.

name: — Asian American Studies Capstone Course
description: Course Description: Synthesis of the approaches and methods learned by students in Asian American Studies and development of specialization in their areas of interest. Development of a research proposal for thesis project.

name: — Asian American Studies Senior Thesis Seminar
description: Course Description: Synthesis of the approaches and methods learned in Asian American Studies. Production of an original research paper on a topic of student's interest, building on the research proposal submitted in the capstone seminar.

name: — Tutoring in Asian American Studies
description: Course Description: Tutoring in lower division Asian American Studies courses in small group discussion. Weekly meetings with instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily intended for upper division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Student Facilitated Course
description: Course Description: Student-facilitated (taught) course intended for upper division students.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will offer under 098F/198F.

name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
description: Course Description: Student facilitated. Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ASA 199FA.

name: — Introduction to Cosmology
description: Course Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of modern cosmology, humanity’s changing view of the Universe, and our current understanding of its origin and evolution.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

name: — Introduction to Stars, Galaxies, & the Universe
description: Course Description: Non-mathematical introduction to astrophysics of the Universe beyond our solar system using concepts of modern physics.

name: — Observational Astronomy Lab
description: Course Description: Introduction to observations of the night sky using small telescopes in nighttime laboratory.

name: — Astronomy of the Solar System
description: Course Description: Introduction to naked eye and telescopic observations of events in the night sky: positions of sun, moon, planets throughout the year. Historical perspective on how our understanding of the solar system evolved to current non-mathematical astrophysical interpretation of planetary systems.

name: — Introduction to Modern Astronomy & Astrophysics
description: Course Description: Description and interpretation of astronomical phenomena using the laws of modern physics and observations by modern astronomical instruments. Gravity, relativity, electromagnetic radiation, atomic and nuclear processes in relation to the structure and evolution of stars, galaxies and the universe.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Good facility in high school physics and mathematics (algebra and trigonometry).

name: — Global Climate Change
description: Course Description: Scientific concepts needed to understand climate and climate change. Principles of regional variations in climate. Understanding observed seasonal, decadal and millennial changes. Analysis of the Antarctic ozone hole, El Nino and human-induced global warming.

name: — Fundamentals of Atmospheric Pollution
description: Course Description: Effects of human emissions on the atmosphere: smog, ozone pollution, and ozone depletion; indoor air pollution; global warming; acid rain. Impacts of these problems on the earth, ecosystems, and humans. Strategies to reduce atmospheric pollution.

name: — Severe & Unusual Weather
description: Course Description: Introduction to physical principles of severe and unusual weather: flood, blizzards, thunderstorms, lightning, tornadoes, and hurricanes. Emphasis on scientific perspective and human context. Not open to students who have received credit for ATM 100. (Former ATM 100.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school physics.

name: — Introduction to Atmospheric Science
description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of the physics, chemistry, and fluid dynamics underlying weather and climate. Solar radiation, the greenhouse effect, and the thermal budget of the Earth. Clouds and their formation, convection, precipitation, mid-latitude storm systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A or MAT 021A); (PHY 007A or PHY 009A).

name: — Atmospheric Science Internship
description: Course Description: Internship off and on campus in atmospheric science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Weather Observation & Analysis
description: Course Description: Acquisition, distribution and analysis of meteorological data. Vertical sounding analysis, stability indices, probability of local severe weather, weather map analysis. Use of National Weather Service analyses and forecast products. Laboratory makes use of computer-generated analyses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 060.

name: — Weather Analysis & Prediction
description: Course Description: Tools for analyzing observed properties of mid-latitude weather systems. The analysis-forecast system, including various weather forecast models. General structure and properties of mid-latitude weather systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 110; ATM 121B; (ATM 111L (can be concurrent) or ATM 111LY (can be concurrent)); knowledge of a programming language.

name: — Weather Analysis & Prediction Laboratory
description: Course Description: Subjective and objective analysis of weather data. Web-based learning of the analysis-forecast system and various weather forecasting situations. Weather map interpretation and forecast discussions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 111 (can be concurrent).

name: — Weather Forecasting Practice
description: Course Description: Formal practice in preparing local weather forecasts. Analysis of current weather conditions and recent model performance. Verification and discussion of prior forecast. Interpretation of current forecast model guidance. Posting of forecast.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 110.

name: — Hydroclimatology
description: Course Description: Examination of climate as the forcing function for the hydrologic system. Emphasis on seasonal variations in the relationship between precipitation and evapotranspiration for meso-scale areas. Watershed modeling of floods and drought for evaluating the effects of climatic fluctuations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 060.

name: — Modern Climate Change
description: Course Description: Factors that determine the Earth’s climate, including natural and human-caused changes. Impacts of climate change. Possible future climates and policies to reduce human emissions of greenhouse gases.

name: — Atmospheric Thermodynamics & Cloud Physics
description: Course Description: Atmospheric composition and structure, thermodynamics of atmospheric gases, thermal properties of dry and moist air, atmospheric stability; cloud nucleation, cloud growth by condensation and collision, cloud models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C; PHY 009B; ATM 060 (can be concurrent).

name: — Atmospheric Dynamics
description: Course Description: Fundamental forces of atmospheric flow; noninertial reference frames; development of the equations of motion for rotating stratified atmospheres; isobaric and natural coordinate systems; geostrophic flow; thermal wind; circulation and vorticity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 120; MAT 021D; PHY 009B.

name: — Atmospheric Dynamics
description: Course Description: Dynamics of fluid motion in geophysical systems; quasi-geostrophic theory; fundamentals of wave propagation in fluids; Rossby waves; gravity waves; fundamentals of hydrodynamic instability; two-level model; baroclinic instability and cyclogenesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121A.

name: — Meteorological Instruments & Observations
description: Course Description: Modern meteorological instruments and their use in meteorological observations and measurements. Both standard and micrometeorological instruments are included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 060.

name: — Radiation & Satellite Meteorology
description: Course Description: Concepts of atmospheric radiation and the use of satellites in remote sensing. Emphasis on the modification of solar and infrared radiation by the atmosphere. Estimation from satellite data of atmospheric variables such as temperatures and cloudiness.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 060; PHY 009B; MAT 022B; MAT 021D.

name: — Biometeorology
description: Course Description: Atmospheric and biological interactions. Physical and biological basis for water vapor, carbon dioxide and energy exchanges with the atmosphere associated with plants and animals, including humans. Microclimate of plant canopies and microclimatic modification such as frost protection and windbreaks.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B; one course in a biological discipline or consent of instructor.

name: — Air Pollution
description: Course Description: Physical and technical aspects of air pollution. Factors that determine local, regional, and global air quality; climate change; and physical and chemical properties of pollutants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021D; (MAT 022B or MAT 027B); CHE 002B C- or better; (ATM 121A or ENG 103 C- or better or ECI 100 C- or better).

name: — Introduction to Computer Methods in Physical Sciences
description: Course Description: Computational techniques used in physical sciences. Integral and differential equation numerical solution: mainly finite differencing and spectral (Fourier transform) methods. Time series applications (time-permitting). Specific applications drawn from meteorology. Accelerated introduction to FORTRAN including programming assignments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022B; PHY 009B; computer programming course such as ECS 030; additional courses in fluid dynamics (ATM 121A or ENG 103) and in Fourier transforms (MAT 118C or PHY 104A) helpful but not required.

name: — Boundary-Layer Meteorology
description: Course Description: Dynamics of the atmosphere nearest the Earth's surface. Friction and heat transfer. Properties of turbulent flows; statistical and spectral techniques; use and interpretation of differential equations. Emphasis on the importance to weather, air pollution, and the world's oceans.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121A.

name: — Introduction to Atmospheric Chemistry
description: Course Description: Quantitative examination of current local, regional and global problems in atmospheric chemistry (including photochemical smog, acid deposition, climate change, and stratospheric ozone depletion) using fundamental concepts from chemistry. Basic chemical modeling of atmospheric reaction systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002B.

name: — Atmospheric Science Internship
description: Course Description: Internship off and on campus in atmospheric science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Completion of 84 units.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; three upper division units in Atmospheric Science.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; three upper division units in Atmospheric Science and at least an overall B average.

name: — Advanced Hydroclimatology
description: Course Description: Theoretical and applied aspects of energy and mass fluxes linking the earth's surface, atmosphere, and hydrologic system. Emphasis on regional scale analysis and modeling, spatial data representation, and climate change influences on precipitation and its hydroclimatic expression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 115.

name: — Advanced Atmospheric Dynamics
description: Course Description: Conditions for instability in stratified atmospheres; baroclinic instability; forced topographic Rossby Waves; wave-mean flow interaction theory; tropical dynamics; stratospheric dynamics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121B.

name: — Advanced Boundary-Layer Meteorology
description: Course Description: Characteristics of the atmospheric boundary layer under convective and nocturnal conditions. Heat budget at the surface and boundary layer forcing. Similarity theory and scaling of the boundary layer. Measurement and simulation techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 230.

name: — Atmospheric Turbulence
description: Course Description: Dynamics and energetics of turbulence in the atmosphere including vorticity dynamics. Statistical description of turbulence; Eulerian and Lagrangian scales, spectral analysis, conditional sampling techniques. Turbulent diffusion; the closure problem, gradient-diffusion and second-order methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121B or ATM 158.

name: — Advanced Air Pollution Meteorology
description: Course Description: Processes determining transport and diffusion of primary and secondary pollutants. Models of chemical transformation, of the atmospheric boundary layer and of mesoscale wind fields, as applicable to pollutant dispersion problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 160; ATM 149A; course in fluid dynamics.

name: — Advanced Biometeorology
description: Course Description: Current topics in biometeorology. Physical and biological basis for water vapor, other gases, and energy exchange with the atmosphere. Topics include modeling and measuring turbulent transport from plant canopies, surface temperatures and energy budgets, bio-aerosol physics and aerobiology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 133; or consent of instructor.

name: — General Circulation of the Atmosphere
description: Course Description: Large-scale, observed atmospheric properties. Radiation, momentum, and energy balances derived and compared with observations. Lectures and homework synthesize observations and theories, then apply them to understand the large-scale circulations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121B.

name: — Climate Dynamics
description: Course Description: Dynamics of large-scale climatic variations over time periods from weeks to centuries. Description of the appropriate methods of analysis of atmospheric and oceanic observations. Conservation of mass, energy and momentum. Introduction to the range of climate simulations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121B.

name: — Cloud & Precipitation Physics
description: Course Description: Observations and modeling of clouds and precipitation. Physics and parameterization of cloud microphysical processes including nucleation, condensation/evaporation, deposition/sublimation, collision-coalescence and sedimentation.

name: — Climate Change, Water & Society
description: Course Description: Integration of climate science and hydrology with policy to understand hydroclimatology and its impact upon natural and human systems. Assignments: readings, take-home examination on climate and hydrologic science, paper that integrates course concepts into a research prospectus or review article.

name: — Meso-Scale Meteorology
description: Course Description: The study of weather phenomena with horizontal spatial dimensions between 2.5 and 2500 kilometers. Methods of observational study and numerical modeling of the structure and temporal behavior of these weather systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 150; graduate standing; course in partial differential equations or consent of instructor.

name: — Numerical Modeling of the Atmosphere
description: Course Description: Principles of numerical modeling of the dynamic, thermodynamic and physical processes of the atmosphere. Hands-on experiments on model development using the shallow water equations and the primitive equations. Operational forecast models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121B; ENG 005; ATM 150 recommended.

name: — Atmospheric Chemistry
description: Course Description: Chemistry and photochemistry in tropospheric condensed phases (fog, cloud, and rain drops and aerosol particles). Gas-drop and gas-particle partitioning of compounds and effects of reactions in condensed phases on the fates and transformations of tropospheric chemical species.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 160.

name: — The Art of Climate Modeling
description: Course Description: Over the past fifty years, global models have given us incredible insight into the Earth system. Provides an introduction to these models, with a focus on their design and the science questions they have been built to address.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 121A.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Meteorological Statistics
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in meteorological statistics.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Computer Modeling of the Atmosphere
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in computer modeling of the atmosphere.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Design of Experiments & Field Studies in Meteorology
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in design of experiments and field studies in meteorology.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Solar & Infrared Radiation in the Atmosphere
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in solar and infrared radiation in the atmosphere.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Aerosol & Cloud Physics
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in aerosol and cloud physics.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: Atmospheric Chemistry
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in atmospheric chemistry.

name: — Topics in Atmospheric Science: General Meteorology
description: Course Description: Applications and concepts in general meteorology.

name: — Air Quality Policy in the Real World
description: Course Description: In-depth investigation of an air quality problem with a team and mentor from government or industry. Science, engineering and policy will be involved. Findings will be presented orally and in writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ATM 149 or ECI 149); ECI 242; consent of instructor, or equivalent of ECI 242.

name: — Air Quality Policy in the Real World
description: Course Description: In-depth investigation of an air quality problem with a team and mentor from government or industry. Science, engineering and policy will be involved. Findings will be presented orally and in writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ATM 280A; and consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Current developments in selected areas of atmospheric research. Topics will vary according to student and faculty interests.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Atmospheric Science or related field.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: Air Quality Meteorology
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in Air Quality Meteorology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: Biometeorology
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in Biometeorology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: Boundary Layer Meteorology
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in Boundary Layer Meteorology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: Climate Change
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in Climate Change.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: General Meteorology
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in General Meteorology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Atmospheric Science: Atmospheric Chemistry
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current literature and research in Atmospheric Chemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Introduction to Poultry Science
description: Course Description: The mosaic of events that have tied poultry science to other scientific disciplines and poultry to humans. Poultry science techniques and production methods from the time of domestication to the present. One field trip required.

name: — Birds, Humans & the Environment
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Interrelationships of the worlds of birds and humans. Lectures, discussions, field trips and projects focus on ecology, avian evolution, physiology, reproduction, flight, behavior, folklore, identification, ecotoxicology and conservation. Current environmental issues are emphasized. Half-day field trip.

name: — Management of Captive Birds
description: Course Description: One weekly discussion and field trip to study practical captive management (housing, feeding, equipment, marketing, diseases). Visit facilities rearing birds such as commercial parrots, hobbyist exotics, ostrich, raptors, waterfowl, game birds, poultry and pigeons.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Captive Raptor Management
description: Course Description: Hands-on experience handling birds of prey. Students are taught all of the skills required to handle and care for raptors, including husbandry, biology, habitat requirements, cage design, veterinary care, rehabilitation methods, research potential and long-term care requirements. One Saturday fieldtrip.

name: — Raptor Migration & Population Fluctuations
description: Course Description: Identify raptors: study of effects of weather, crops, agricultural practices on fluctuations in raptor species and numbers. Familiarize with literature; design a project; survey study sites; collect, computerize, analyze data, compare with previous years. Species, observations, emphasis different each quarter. One Saturday field trip.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Raptor Migration & Population Fluctuations
description: Course Description: Identify raptors: study of effects of weather, crops, agricultural practices on fluctuations in raptor species and numbers. Familiarize with literature; design a project; survey study sites; collect, computerize, analyze data, compare with previous years. Species, observations, emphasis different each quarter. One Saturday field trip.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Raptor Migration & Population Fluctuations
description: Course Description: Identify raptors: study of effects of weather, crops, agricultural practices on fluctuations in raptor species and numbers. Familiarize with literature; design a project; survey study sites; collect, computerize, analyze data, compare with previous years. Species, observations, emphasis different each quarter. One Saturday field trip.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in the Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Internship on and off campus in poultry, game birds or exotic bird production, management and research; or in a business, industry, or agency concerned with these entities. Compliance with Internship Approval form essential.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Sophomore standing preferred.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Avian Biology
description: Course Description: Biology of domesticated poultry, specifically chickens and turkeys. Avian genetics, immunology, reproduction, growth and development, broiler and layer management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; ANS 002 preferred.

name: — Avian Development & Genomics
description: Course Description: Unique features of avian development and genomics: Incubation; Staging; Egg Structure/Function; Fertilization; Pre-oviposital; Oviposition, Cold Torpor; Post-oviposital Development; Organogenesis, Growth; Sexual Differentiation; Extraembryonic Membranes; Mortality/Hatching; Genome Organization; Comparative Avian Genomics; Telomere Biology; Sex Chromosomes/Sex Determination; Advanced Technologies; Genome Manipulation; Mutations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B.

name: — Raptor Biology
description: Course Description: Study of birds of prey: classification, distribution, habits, migration, unique anatomical and physiological adaptations, natural and captive breeding, health and diseases, environmental concerns, conservation, legal considerations, rehabilitation, and falconry. Includes two Saturday field trips.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; or equivalent.

name: — Avian Reproduction
description: Course Description: Breeding cycles and reproductive strategies, egg and sperm formation, incubation, sexual development, imprinting, hormonal control of reproductive behavior and song. Species coverage includes wild and companion birds. Course has a physiological orientation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B.

name: — Management of Birds
description: Course Description: Captive propagation of birds, including reproduction, genetic management, health, feeding, artificial incubation, artificial insemination, and related legal aspects, including trade and smuggling. Emphasis on exotic species and the role of captive propagation in conservation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B.

name: — Egg Production Management
description: Course Description: Management of commercial table egg flocks as related to environment, nutrition, disease control, economics, housing, equipment, egg processing and raising replacement pullets. Offered in alternate years. One Saturday field trip required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AVS 011; or consent of instructor.

name: — Nutrition of Birds
description: Course Description: Principles of nutrition specific to avian species, including feedstuffs, feed additives, nutrient metabolism, energy systems, and nutritional support of egg production and growth. Use of computers for feed formulation to support production.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 (can be concurrent) or BIS 103 (can be concurrent).

name: — Designing & Performing Experiments in Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Experiments in current problems in avian biology. Introduction to experimental design. Students choose a project, design a protocol, perform an experiment and report their findings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AVS 100 or WFC 111; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Avian Biology
description: Course Description: Ecology, behavior, functional morphology and lifehistory evolution of birds. Emphasis on the importance of body size as a principle determinant of most aspects of avian performance from lifespan to reproduction and species abundance. Analytical synthesis and critical thought emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AVS 100 or WFC 111.

name: — Seminar in Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Seminar in Avian Sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Internship on and off campus in poultry, game birds or exotic bird production, management and research; or in a business, industry, or agency concerned with these entities. Compliance with Internship Approval form essential.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Current Research
description: Course Description: Discussion of topics of current interest in avian sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in lower division avian sciences courses; weekly conference with instructors in charge of courses; written critiques of teaching procedures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Advanced Avian Development & Genomics
description: Course Description: In consultation with the instructor, students develop a lecture and associated instructional materials, i.e., lesson plan, including justification, reading and presentation and evaluation aids. Topic must complement a topic covered in AVS 103.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): AVS 103 (can be concurrent); graduate standing.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Reports and discussions of recent advances and selected topics of current interest in avian genetics, physiology, nutrition, and poultry technology.

name: — Research Conference
description: Course Description: Major professors lead research discussions with their graduate students. Research papers are reviewed and project proposals presented and evaluated. Format will combine seminar and discussion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Supervised Teaching in Avian Sciences
description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in lower, upper division, and graduate courses in Avian Sciences; weekly conference with instructor in charge of course; written critiques of teaching methods in lectures and laboratories.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular Genetics & Genomics
description: Course Description: Emphasizes molecular genetic and genomic approaches to address fundamental biological questions. Introduces and emphasizes the strengths of prokaryotic and eukaryotic model systems and serves as building block for the BMCDB core courses, which use model systems to develop their themes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; MCB 121; or equivalent courses.

name: — Macromolecular Structure & Interactions
description: Course Description: Conceptual and quantitative basis for macromolecular structure-function relationships. Investigation of the paradigm form follows function. Review of key elements of protein, nucleic acid, and membrane structure. Exploration of specific macromolecular associations by analyzing chemical structure and physical-chemical behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; or the equivalent, or consent of instructor.

name: — Cell Biology
description: Course Description: Analysis of basic processes governing cell organization, division, and transport. Study of the integration and regulation of cell behavior in response to changes in cellular environment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 104; or the equivalent, or consent of instructor.

name: — Developmental Biology
description: Course Description: Fundamental principles in embryonic development that guide application of modern cellular and genetic approaches to understand developmental mechanisms. Emphasis on experimental approaches used to critically address scientific questions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate biology course or consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular Biology
description: Course Description: Investigation of the basic cellular processes in prokaryotes and eukaryotes that govern the central dogma of molecular biology (DNA-RNA-protein).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BCB 211; or the equivalent, or consent of instructor.

name: — Graduate Reading Course
description: Course Description: Development of critical reading skills through study of major paradigm advances in specialized fields of biochemistry, molecular, cell, and developmental biology. Emphasis on active learning and student participation. Guided analysis of literature and major advances in field of study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory Rotations
description: Course Description: Two five-week assignments in BMCDB research laboratories. Individual research problems with emphasis on methodological/procedural experience, experimental design, proposal writing and oral communication of results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BCB 210; BCB 211 (can be concurrent); BCB 120L or the equivalent.

name: — Molecular Mechanisms in Early Development
description: Course Description: Analysis of the early events of development including: germ cells and other stem cells, gametogenesis, meiosis, imprinting, fertilization, genetically-engineered organisms, egg activation and establishment of embryonic polarity with focus on cellular events including gene regulation and cell signaling.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor; introductory background in developmental biology and/or cell biology recommended.

name: — Molecular Mechanisms in Pattern Formation & Development
description: Course Description: Genetic and molecular analysis of mechanisms that control animal development after fertilization. Establishment of embryonic axes, cell fate and embryonic pattern; induction, apoptosis, tissue patterning. Critical reading of current literature in C.elegans, Drosophila, and mouse genetic model systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor; introductory background in developmental biology and/or genetics recommended.

name: — Cell & Molecular Biology of Cancer
description: Course Description: Analysis of the pathologic alterations of cancer cells and therapeutic opportunities; with emphasis on animal models, tumor immunotherapy, stress response, metabolism, epigenetics, microRNAs and non-coding RNAs, and microbiota and inflammation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BCB 210; BCB 212; BCB 213; BCB 214.

name: — Cell Proliferation & Cancer Genes
description: Course Description: Genetic and molecular alterations underlying the conversion of normal cells to cancers, emphasizing regulatory mechanisms and pathways. Critical reading of the current literature and development of experimental approaches.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BCB 221C  BCB 221D or equivalent courses.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate-student research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and/or graduate standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Methods of Teaching
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Internship in Biological Chemistry
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in biological chemistry and related fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Biological Chemistry
