prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 129A; CHE 128B (can be concurrent).

name: — Organic Chemistry Laboratory
description: Course Description: continuation of PHE 129B.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C (can be concurrent); CHE 129B.

name: — Pharmaceutical Chemistry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of the design principles and experimental methods used in pharmaceutical and medicinal chemistry. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118C or CHE 128C.

name: — Pharmaceutical Chemistry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of CHE 130A with emphasis on case studies of various drugs and the use of computational methods in drug design. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130A (can be concurrent).

name: — Case Studies in Pharmaceutical Chemistry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Seminar. Exploration of medicinal and pharmaceutical chemistry topics through seminars presented by professional chemists (and allied professionals). Designed to highlight career opportunities for students with a degree in pharmaceutical chemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130A (can be concurrent); CHE 130B (can be concurrent).

name: — Modern Methods of Organic Synthesis
description: Course Description: Introduction to modern synthetic methodology in organic chemistry with emphasis on retrosynthetic analysis, reaction mechanisms, and application to multistep syntheses of pharmaceuticals and natural products.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C or CHE 118C.

name: — Advanced Bio-organic Chemistry Laboratory
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Separation, purification, identification and biological evaluation of organic compounds using modern methods of synthesis, computational chemistry and instrumentation. Emphasis on pharmaceutical and medicinal substances.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130B (can be concurrent).

name: — Good Quality Practices
description: Course Description: Preparation for work in GQP laboratories in both research and industry. Context within GQP-Good Quality Practices (GMP Good Manufacturing Practice, GCP Good Clinical Practices). Lab practice in GQP skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118B or CHE 129B.

name: — Chemistry of Natural Products
description: Course Description: Chemistry of terpenes, steroids, acetogenins, and alkaloids: isolation, structure determination, biosynthesis, chemical transformations, and total synthesis. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118C or CHE 128C.

name: — Scientific Programming for Chemistry
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Chemical applications of computer programming with Python. Numpy, Scipy, Matplotlib libraries. Multidimensional arrays, data visualization, linear algebra routines. Force fields and molecular dynamics simulations. Numerical integration of differential equations with applications to chemical kinetics. Least squares fitting of experimental data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 010 or ECS 032A; or equivalent; or consent of instructor.

name: — Chemical & Engineering Principles in Whisky & Fuel Alcohol Production
description: Course Description: Chemical & engineering principles underlying the manufacture of whisky & fuel alcohol. Biochemistry of malting. Assessment of grain modification & diastatic power, and of the phenol content of peated malt. Lautering as a problem of fluidized bed compaction. Fermentation and its assessment. Fractional distillation and the Rayleigh equation. The fate of congeners in pot and column distillation. Chemical reactions affecting flavor from kilning to maturation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; CHE 128B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Chemistry
description: Course Description: Supervised internship in chemistry; requires a final written report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; project approval by faculty sponsor prior to enrollment.

name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

name: — Careers in Chemistry
description: Course Description: Designed to give Chemistry undergraduate students an in-depth appreciation of career opportunities with a bachelors degree in chemistry. Professional chemists (and allied professionals) describe research and provide career insights.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Junior or senior standing in Chemistry.

name: — Projects in Chemical Education
description: Course Description: Participation may include development of laboratory experiments, lecture demonstrations, autotutorial modules or assistance with laboratory sessions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation in chemistry, mathematics and physics.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation in chemistry, mathematics, and physics.

name: — Chemical Uses of Symmetry & Group Theory
description: Course Description: Symmetry elements and operations, point groups, representations of groups. Applications to molecular orbital theory, ligand field theory, molecular vibrations, and angular momentum. Crystallographic symmetry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A; CHE 110B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Mathematical Methods in Chemistry
description: Course Description: Introduction to mathematical and numerical methods in chemistry. Real and complex functions. Methods of integration. Differential equations. Linear algebra and matrices. Special functions. Integral transforms. Statistics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C.

name: — Symmetry, Spectroscopy, & Structure
description: Course Description: Vibrational and rotational spectra; electronic spectra and photoelectron spectroscopy; magnetism; electron spin and nuclear quadrapole resonance spectroscopy; nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; other spectroscopic methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 201; or equivalent.

name: — Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in physical chemistry, biophysical chemistry or chemical physics chosen from areas of current research interest.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 210A; CHE 211A.

name: — Quantum Chemistry: Introduction & Stationary-State Properties
description: Course Description: Stationary-state quantum chemistry: postulates of quantum mechanics, simple solutions, central field problems and angular momenta, hydrogen atom, perturbation theory, variational theory, atoms and molecules.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Quantum Chemistry: Time-Dependent Systems
description: Course Description: Matrix mechanics and time-dependent quantum chemistry: matrix formulation of quantum mechanics, Heisenberg representation, time-dependent perturbation theory, selection rules, density matrices, and miscellaneous molecular properties.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 210A.

name: — Quantum Chemistry: Molecular Spectroscopy
description: Course Description: Molecular spectroscopy: Born-Oppenheimer approximation, rotational, vibrational and electronic spectroscopy, spin systems, and molecular photophysics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 210B.

name: — Advanced Physical Chemistry: Statistical Thermodynamics
description: Course Description: Principles and applications of statistical mechanics; ensemble theory; statistical thermodynamics of gases, solids, liquids, electrolyte solutions and polymers; chemical equilibrium.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Statistical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Statistical mechanics of nonequilibrium systems, including the rigorous kinetic theory of gases, continuum mechanics transport in dense fluids, stochastic processes, brownian motion and linear response theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 211A.

name: — Chemical Dynamics
description: Course Description: Introduction to modern concepts in chemical reaction dynamics for graduate students in chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on experimental techniques as well as emerging physical models for characterizing chemical reactivity at a microscopic level.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Theoretical & Computational Chemistry
description: Course Description: Mathematics of wide utility in chemistry, computational methods for guidance or alternative to experiment, and modern formulations of chemical theory. Emphasis will vary in successive years.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 211A; CHE 210B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
description: Course Description: Quantum mechanics of spin and orbital angular momentum, nuclear magnetic resonance, theory of chemical shift and multiplet structures, electron spin resonance, theory of gtensor in organic and transition ions, spin Hamiltonians, nuclear quadrupolar resonance, spin relaxation processes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 210A; CHE 210B (can be concurrent).

name: — X-Ray Structure Determination
description: Course Description: Introduction to x-ray structure determination; crystals, symmetry, diffraction geometry, sample preparation and handling, diffraction apparatus and data collection, methods of structure solution and refinement, presentation of results, text, tables and graphics, crystallographic literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Macromolecules: Physical Principles
description: Course Description: Relationship of higher order macromolecular structure to subunit composition; equilibrium properties and macromolecular dynamics; physical chemical determination of macromolecular structure.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A; CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or equivalent.

name: — Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds
description: Course Description: Identification of organic compounds and investigation of stereochemical and reaction mechanism phenomena using spectroscopic methods–principally NMR, IR and MS.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C; or equivalent.

name: — Laboratory in Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds
description: Course Description: Practical application of NMR, IR and MS techniques for organic molecules.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 219 (can be concurrent).

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

name: — Chemistry of Nanoparticles
description: Course Description: Chemical and physical aspects of inorganic nanoparticles, including synthesis, purification, reactivity, characterization, and applications for technology. Emphasis is on problems from the current literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C; or equivalent.

name: — Principles of Transition Metal Chemistry
description: Course Description: Electronic structures, bonding, and reactivity of transition metal compounds.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A; or equivalent.

name: — Bio-inorganic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Defines role of inorganic chemistry in the functioning of biological systems by identifying the functions of metal ions and main group compounds in biological systems and discussing the chemistry of model and isolated biological compounds. Offered every third year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 226; or consent of instructor.

name: — Main Group Chemistry
description: Course Description: Synthesis, physical properties, reactions and bonding of main group compounds. Discussions of concepts of electron deficiency, hypervalency, and non-classical bonding. Chemistry of the main group elements will be treated systematically. Offered every third year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 226; or consent of instructor.

name: — Solid-State Chemistry
description: Course Description: Design and synthesis, structure and bonding of solid-state compounds; physical properties and characterization of solids; topics of current interest such as low-dimensional materials, inorganic polymers, materials for catalysis. Offered every third year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A; CHE 110B; CHE 226; or equivalent.

name: — Homogeneous Catalysis
description: Course Description: Overview of homogeneous catalysis and related methods, with emphasis on kinetics, mechanisms, and applications for organic synthesis. The related methods may include cluster, colloid, phase transfer, enzymatic, heterogeneous and polymer-supported catalysis. Offered every third year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 226.

name: — Magnetochemistry
description: Course Description: Covers the basic principles and concepts of magnetism, methods used for characterization of magnetic properties, as well as specific state-of-the-art magnetic materials and topics from the recent chemistry literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A or CHE 201; or an equivalent class from either Physics or Chemical Engineering and Materials Science.

name: — Organic Synthesis: Methods & Strategies
description: Course Description: Current strategies and methods in synthetic organic chemistry. Focus on construction of carbon frameworks, control of relative and absolute stereochemistry and retrosynthetic strategies. Use of databases and molecular modeling software in multistep strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C; or equivalent.

name: — Advanced Organic Synthesis
description: Course Description: Current strategies and methods in synthetic organic chemistry. Continuation of CHE 231A. Organic synthesis of complex target molecules. Stereochemical considerations and asymmetric synthesis. Organometallics for selective transformations. Carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring formation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 231A.

name: — Physical-Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Introduction to elementary concepts in physicalorganic chemistry including the application of simple numerical techniques in characterizing and modeling organic reactions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; CHE 128B; CHE 128C; CHE 110A; CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or equivalent.

name: — Chemical & Molecular Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Basic principles in chemistry and molecular biology applied to questions in neuroscience. Chemical and molecular tools driving innovative work in chemical and molecular biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C; BIS 102; or equivalent courses.

name: — Organometallic Chemistry in Organic Synthesis
description: Course Description: Current trends in use of organometallics for organic synthesis; preparations, properties, applications, and limitations of organometallic reagents derived from transition and/or main group metals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C.

name: — Chemistry of Natural Products
description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of chemistry of naturally occurring compounds isolated from a variety of sources. Topics will include isolation, structure determination, chemical transformations, total synthesis, biological activity, and biosynthesis. Biosynthetic origin will be used as a unifying theme.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C; or equivalent.

name: — Bio-Organic Chemistry
description: Course Description: Structure and function of biomolecules; molecular recognition; enzyme reaction mechanisms; design of suicide substrates for enzymes; enzyme engineering; design of artificial enzymes and application of enzymes in organic synthesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Chemical Biology
description: Course Description: Synthesis of complex molecules in nature. Use of biosynthetic pathways in synthesis of new chemical entities. Applications of small molecules in chemical genetics and structural biology. Solving biological problems using synthetic biomolecules.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118C or CHE 128C; or equivalent; CHE 130A, CHE 130B and BIS 102, BIS 103, and BIS 104, or the equivalents recommended.

name: — Advanced Analytical Chemistry
description: Course Description: Numerical treatment of experimental data; thermodynamics of electrolyte and non-electrolyte solutions; complex equilibria in aqueous and non-aqueous solutions; potentiometry and specific ion electrodes; mass transfer in liquid solutions; fundamentals of separation science, including column, gas and liquid chromatography.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A; CHE 115; or equivalent.

name: — Surface Analytical Chemistry
description: Course Description: Concepts of surfaces and interfaces: physical properties, unique chemistry and electronic effects. Focus on gas-solid interfaces, with some discussion of liquid-solid interfaces.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C; or equivalent.

name: — Laser & X-ray Spectroscopy
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Concepts and mechanisms of light-matter interactions. Chemical applications of modern spectroscopic methods, including multiphoton spectroscopy, time-resolved laser and x-ray photolysis, and phase-contrast x-ray imaging.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110B; or equivalent.

name: — Mass Spectrometry
description: Course Description: Mass spectrometry and related methods with emphasis on ionization methods, mass analyzers, and detectors. Related methods may include ion-molecule reactions, unimolecular dissociation of organic and bio-organic compounds, and applications in biological and environmental analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C; CHE 115; or equivalent.

name: — Electroanalytical Chemistry
description: Course Description: Electroanalytical chemistry with consideration of mass transfer and electrode kinetics for polarizable electrodes. Current-potential curves for a variety of conditions, including both potentiostatic and galvanostatic control, and their application in chemical analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C; CHE 115; or equivalent.

name: —  Microscopy & Imaging Techniques
description: Course Description: Introduction to modern microscopy and imaging techniques: scanning tunneling, atomic force, far-field optical, fluorescence, scanning near-field optical, and scanning electron microscopy. Application to nanoscience and analytical and bioanalytical chemistry. Some laboratory demonstrations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C; CHE 115; or equivalent.

name: — Mechanistic Enzymology
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in chemical kinetics relevant to enzymes, enzyme kinetics, theory of enzyme catalysis, and the analysis of a selection of organic enzyme reaction mechanisms by the tools introduced in the first part of the course.

name: — Current Topics in Chemical Research
description: Course Description: Designed to help chemistry graduate students develop and maintain familiarity with the current and past literature in their immediate field of research and related areas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Chemistry Research
description: Course Description: Group and individual discussion of research activities in the Department and research topic selection. Designed for incoming graduate students preparing for higher degrees in chemistry.

name: — Introduction to Chemical Research Methodology
description: Course Description: Introduction to identification, formulation, and solution of meaningful scientific problems including experimental design and/or theoretical analyses of new and prevailing techniques, theories and hypotheses. May be repeated for credit when topic differs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 293; and consent of instructor; graduate student standing in Chemistry.

name: — Advanced Chemical Research Methodology
description: Course Description: Applications of the methodology developed in CHE 263 to experimental and theoretical studies. Advanced methods of interpretation of results are developed. Includes the preparation of manuscripts for publication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 263; or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminar.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Presentation of Chemistry Research
description: Course Description: Introduces first- and second-year Chemistry graduate students to the process of giving an effective research presentation. Advanced Ph.D. students give formal seminars describing the design and execution of their research projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Careers in Chemistry
description: Course Description: Designed to give Chemistry graduate students an in-depth appreciation of career opportunities with a M.S. or Ph.D. degree in chemistry. Professional chemists (and allied professionals) give seminars describing both research and career insights.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry.

name: — Research in Pharmaceutical Chemistry
description: Course Description: Laboratory provides qualified graduate students with the opportunity to pursue original investigation in Pharmaceutical Chemistry and allied fields in order to fulfill the letter-graded research requirement of the Integrated B.S./M.S. Program in Chemistry (Pharmaceutical Chemistry Emphasis).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130A; CHE 130B; CHE 135; CHE 233 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: The laboratory is open to qualified graduate students who wish to pursue original investigation. Students wishing to enroll should communicate with the department well in advance of the quarter in which the work is to be undertaken.

name: — Methods of Teaching Chemistry
description: Course Description: Practical experience in methods and problems of teaching chemistry. Includes analyses of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting of discussion sessions and student laboratories. Participation in the teaching program required for Ph.D. in chemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student standing in Chemistry.

name: — Advanced Methods of Teaching Chemistry
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in teaching chemistry. Analysis and discussion of curricular design, curricula materials, teaching methods and evaluation. For students who are planning a career in teaching chemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 390.

name: — Introduction to Chicana/o Studies
description: Course Description: Analysis of the situation of the Chicana/o (Mexican-American) people, emphasizing their history, literature, political movements, education and related areas.

name: — Chicana/o & Latina/o Health Care Issues
description: Course Description: Overview of health issues of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os in the State of California; role of poverty/lack of education in limited access to health care.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010.

name: — Chicana/o & Latina/o Health Care Issues
description: Course Description: Overview of health issues of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os in the State of California; role of poverty/lack of education and limited access to health care. All course instruction in Spanish. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y; or equivalent.

name: — Qualitative Research Methods
description: Course Description: Dominant models of qualitative inquiry in educational and social science research as well as mestizo approaches to research with latinos. Emphasis given to choosing and designing culturally appropriate strategies to investigate latino health, education, social context, and policy issues.

name: — United States Political Institutions & Chicanas/os
description: Course Description: Overview of the major political institutions and ideologies of the United States and the Chicana/o people's historical and contemporary role in, effects from, and responses to them. Theory, method and critical analysis.

name: — Comparative Health: Top Leading Causes of Death
description: Course Description: Introduction to the epidemiology of the leading causes of death for ethnic/racial minorities. Assessment of disproportionate rates at which ethnic/racial minorities suffer and die from chronic and infectious diseases and injuries and statistical methods used to calculate these rates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; or consent of instructor.

name: — Comparative Health: Leading Causes of Death
description: Course Description: Introduction to epidemiology of leading causes of death for ethnic/racial minorities. Assessment of disproportionate rates at which ethnic/racial minorities suffer & die from chronic and infectious diseases & injuries & statistical methods used to calculate these rates. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; or consent of instructor.

name: — Food Justice: Chicana/o & Indigenous Communities
description: Course Description: Issues surrounding food justice in Chicana/o and Indigenous Communities. Emphasis on discourses and practices of growing a food justice movement centered on the ecological care of the earth and decolonized environmental methodologies.

name: — Chicana & Chicano Culture
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary survey of Chicana/o cultural representation in the 20th century. Examines Chicana/o culture within a national and transnational context. Explores how Chicano cultural forms and practices intersect with social/material forces, intellectual formations and cultural discourses. (Former CHI 020.)

name: — Chicana & Chicano Representation in Cinema
description: Course Description: Introductory-level study of Chicana and Chicano representation in cinema. Depiction of Chicana and Chicano experience by Chicana/o filmmakers, as well as by non-Chicanos, including independent filmmakers and the commercial industry.

name: — New  Latin American Cinema
description: Course Description: Historical, critical, and theoretical survey of the cinemas of Latin America and their relationship to the emergence of U.S. Latino cinema. Emphasis on representation and social identity including gender, sexuality, class, race and ethnicity.

name: — Survey of Chicana/o Art
description: Course Description: Survey of contemporary Chicana/o art in context of the social turmoil from which it springs. Includes political use of the poster and the mural, the influence of the Mexican mural and graphic movement, and social responsibility of the artist.

name: — Chicana/o Art Expression Through Silk Screen
description: Course Description: Introductory level studio course using silk screen and basic printing techniques to explore and develop images of Chicana/o cultural themes and expressions. Students experiment with images and symbols from their immediate environment/culture. Integrated approach to Chicana/o philosophy of art.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Academic guidance combined with internship in community agencies serving Mexican/Latina/Latino/Chicana/Chicano clients. Students will use their bilingual skills and knowledge of history, culture, economics, politics and social issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Chicana/o Theoretical Perspective
description: Course Description: Critical examination of emerging Chicana/o Studies theoretical perspectives in light of contemporary intellectual frameworks in the social sciences, arts, and humanities. Includes analysis of practices of self-representation, and socio-cultural developments in the Chicana/o community.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; CHI 050.

name: — Chicana/o Feminist Theoretical Understandings of K-20 Educational Disparities
description: Course Description: Examination of educational disparities of the K-20 educational system. Chicana/o education theory and analysis with a specific emphasis on feminist frameworks and analytical tools used to guide and inform educational policy-making.

name: — Grassroots Community Activism & Mobilization Efforts Challenging Educational Inequity
description: Course Description: Exploration and research on effective grassroots community activism and mobilization efforts by Chicana/o students, along with their teachers, families, and other allies to protest structured inequality of the U.S. educational system. Mentoring and tutoring in a school under the supervision of a faculty member is required.

name: — Policy & Law Challenging Segregation & Educational Inequity
description: Course Description: Focus on successful lawsuits against school segregation of Mexican-origin children in the United States. Mentoring and tutoring in a school under the supervision of a faculty member is required.

name: — Sociology of the Chicana/o Experience
description: Course Description: The Chicana/o experience in the American society and economy viewed from theoretical perspectives. Immigration, history of integration of Chicana/o labor into American class structure, education inequality, ethnicity, the family and Chicana/o politics. (Former course SOC 110.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or SOC 001.

name: — Chicanas/Mexicanas in Contemporary Society
description: Course Description: Analysis of the role and status of Chicanas/Mexicanas in contemporary society. Special emphasis on their historical role, the political, economic and social institutions that have affected their status, and their contributions to society and their community. (Former CHI 102.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 050; (WMS 050 or HIS 169B).

name: — Globalization, Transnational Migration, & Chicana/o & Latina/o Communities
description: Course Description: Chicana/o and Latina/o migration experiences within a global context. Topics include national and/or transnational migration in Mexico, Central America, and the United States.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010.

name: — Latin American Women’s Engagement in Social Movements
description: Course Description: Examination of how women of different racial/ethnic and class backgrounds in Latin America challenge their marginalization. Exploration of US foreign policy, its effects on Latin American’s institutions and on Latin American citizens. Using Chicana feminist perspective.

name: — Women of Color Reproductive Health & Reproductive Politics in a Global Perspective
description: Course Description: Study contemporary issues in reproductive health and reproductive politics, both globally and in the U.S., for women of color.

name: — Women of Color Reproductive Health & Gender Politics in Cuba & the U.S.
description: Course Description: Study of contemporary issues in reproductive health, reproductive politics, and gender politics both in Cuba and in the U.S., for women of color.

name: — Chicana/o Psychology
description: Course Description: Introduction to the field of Chicana/o psychology. Analysis of socio-cultural context of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os. Special attention to issues of ethnic identity development, bilingualism, and development of self esteem. Impact of minority experience, migration, acculturation are examined.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 021; Introductory psychology course recommended.

name: — Chicana/o Community Mental Health
description: Course Description: Mental health needs, problems, and service utilization patterns of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os will be analyzed. Analysis of social service policy, and the economic context of mental health programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or CHI 020.

name: — Psychology Perspectives Chicana/o & Latina/o Family
description: Course Description: Role of migration and acculturation on family structure and functioning. From a psychological and Chicana/o Studies perspective, contemporary gender roles and variations in family structures are examined. Special topics include family violence, addiction, family resilience and coping strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; and consent of instructor; introductory psychology course highly recommended.

name: — Psychology Perspectives Chicana/o & Latina/o Family
description: Course Description: Role of migration and acculturation on family structure and functioning. From a psychological and Chicana/o Studies perspective, contemporary gender roles and variations in family structures are examined. Special topics include family violence, addiction, family resilience and coping strategies. May be taught abroad.

name: — Psychological perspectives on Chicana/o & Latina/o Children & Adolescents
description: Course Description: Psychological and educational development of Chicano/Latino children and adolescents, with particular attention to the formation of ethnic, gender, class, race, and sexual identities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 021.

name: — Latino Families in the Age of Globalization: Migration & Transculturation
description: Course Description: Impact of globalization on Latino families in the American continent. Relationships of political structure, economics and family. Intimate partner violence, child maltreatment and alcohol/drug abuse in contemporary Latino families. Offered in a Spanish speaking country; may be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or the equivalent highly recommended.

name: — United States-Mexican Border Relations
description: Course Description: Theories of U.S.-Mexican border relations, with an overview of the political, economic, and social relationships and an in-depth analysis of immigration issues, border industrialization, women's organizations, economic crises, and legal issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Chicanas in Politics & Public Policy
description: Course Description: Historical and political analysis of Chicana/Latina political involvement and activities in the general political system, women's movement, Chicano movement, and Chicana movement. Examines the public policy process and the relationship of Chicanas/Latinas to public policy formation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 030 or POL 001.

name: — Chicanas in Politics & Public Policy
description: Course Description: Historical and political analysis of Chicana/Latina political involvement and activities in the general political system, women's movement, Chicano/a movement. Examines the public policy process and the relationship of Chicanas/Latinas to public policy formation. May be taught abroad.

name: — Political Economy of Chicana/o Communities
description: Course Description: Historical and contemporary study of political and economic forces which define and influence the development of Chicana/o communities. Includes critiques of traditional and Marxian theories and concepts applicable to Chicana/o communities, case studies of Chicana/o communities,especially in California and Texas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; lower division Chicana/o Studies (CHI) course recommended.

name: — Transnational Latina/o Political Economy
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion and research on selected topics from Latin America and the U.S. with regard to immigrant and native communities. Topics include comparative immigration and macroeconomic policies in the U.S. and Latin America. Offered in a Spanish speaking country; may be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y; or consent of instructor, or equivalent; ECN 001A and ECN 001B recommended.

name: — Critical & Abolitionist Pedagogies
description: Course Description: How marginalized groups conceptualize learning and teaching as a practice of freedom. Foundational text and concepts in critical pedagogy. Diverse and intersecting intellectual traditions that inform how oppressed peoples use education as a tool of liberation.

name: — Quantitative Methods: Chicano/Latino Health Research
description: Course Description: Focuses on measuring Latino/Chicano health outcomes using a quantitative approach. Assesses main types of study designs and addresses measurement of disease frequency and health effects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra or the equivalent in college.

name: — Community-Based Participatory Research & Chicana/o & Latina/o Health
description: Course Description: Overview of CBPR, as well as methodological CBPR considerations in building community partnerships, community assessment, issue analysis, research planning, data gathering, and data sharing with Chicana/o and Latina/o communities in particular.

name: — Bi-National Health
description: Course Description: Examination of  health status and intervention strategies presented in public health care settings, private clinics and by indigenous healers in Mexico. Analysis of impact of high risk diseases. Offered in a Spanish speaking country under supervision of UC Davis faculty/lecturer; may be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001A; BIS 001B; BIS 001C; (SPA 021 or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y or SPA 031); or consent of instructor. Upper division standing only.

name: — Public Health in Latin America
description: Course Description: Critical examination of emerging Public Health issues in Latin America in light of economic, political and social conditions. Contemporary behavioral frameworks used in public health. Includes analysis of clinical medicine and health care systems.

name: — Indigenous Healing & Biodiversity in Latin America
description: Course Description: Contrast between western and traditional healing practices in Latin America and the role of the natural environment in creating sustainable health delivery systems. Questions of health status attributable to public health and environmental risk factors. May be taught abroad.

name: — Decolonizing Spirit
description: Course Description: Legacies of colonization and decolonization; indigenous forms of spirituality and sacredness. Emphasis on remembering traditions, practices, relations, and forms of indigenous knowledge.

name: — The Chicana & Chicano Movement
description: Course Description: Development of the Chicano Movement within the context of the socio-political movements of the 1960’s in a national and global perspective. Ideological/political perspectives and the implications for political strategies.

name: — The Chicana/o Novel
description: Course Description: Introduction to the forms and themes of the Chicana/o novel with special attention to the construction of gender, nationality, sexuality, social class, and the family by contemporary Chicana/o novelists. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126A.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

name: — Chicana/o Theater
description: Course Description: Examination of the formal and thematic dimensions of Chicana/o theater in the contemporary period with special emphasis on El Teatro Campesino and Chicana Feminist Theater. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126B.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

name: — Chicana/o Poetry
description: Course Description: Survey of Chicana/o poetry with special emphasis on its thematic and formal dimensions. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126C.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

name: — Chicana & Chicano Narrative
description: Course Description: Exploration of contemporary forms of the Chicana and Chicano narrative, encompassing visual art, fiction, poetry, film, theater, and creative nonfiction. Exposure to a variety of artists and scholars whose work shapes our evolving understanding of the Chicana/o experience.

name: — Contemporary Issues in Latinx Literature
description: Course Description: Contemporary Chicanx Literature within the broader umbrella of Latinx Literature. Genres, including fiction, nonfiction, and poetry, but also hybrid and mixed genre texts. New trends and topics relating to 21st Century Latinx authors, including intersectionality and multiple identities, AfroLatinx and Indigenous identity, Queer representation, Young Adult literature, and undocumented writers.

name: — Mexican Film & Greater Mexican Identity
description: Course Description: Survey of the role Mexican cinema plays in consolidation and contestation of post-revoluationary Mexican state and in the formation of a Greater Mexican cultural identity including Chicana/o identity. Showcases genres, perios, auteurs, movements and emphasis on gendered and sexualized narratives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish.

name: — Queer Latinidad
description: Course Description: Introduction to queer Latina and Latino studies with a focus on Chicana and Chicano theory and cultural production.

name: — Chicanas, Latinas & Mexicanas in Commercial Media
description: Course Description: The portrayal of Chicanas, Latinas and Mexicanas in commercial media. The relation between the representation of Chicana, Latina, and Mexicana women in commercial television and cinema and the role of women in Mexican and U.S. societies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 060; or other film or feminist theory course; conversational fluency in Spanish.

name: — Contemporary Issues in Chicano Art
description: Course Description: Issues and conflicts in the dismantling of the Contemporary Chicano Art Movement. Response and challenge to the dominant culture.

name: — Mexican & Chicano Mural Workshop
description: Course Description: The Mural: a collective art process that empowers students and people through design and execution of mural paintings in the tradition of the Mexican Mural Movement; introduces materials and techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 070; and consent of instructor.

name: — Chicana/o Voice/Poster Silk Screen Workshop
description: Course Description: The poster as a voice art form used by Chicanas/os and other people of color to point to the defects of social and political existence and the possibility for change, from the Chicana/o artists' perspective.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 070 or CHI 073; and consent of instructor.

name: — Grant Writing in the Chicana/o/Latina/o Community
description: Course Description: Overview of key elements for grant writing. Topics include community needs assessments, development of human subjects protocols, data collection, methods, evaluation designs and community based methodologies for grant development applications in the Latino community.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 023; or consent of instructor.

name: — Chicanas & Latinas in the U.S.: Historical Perspectives
description: Course Description: Historical issues in the lives of Chicanas and Latinas in the U.S. and their diverse countries of origin.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or WMS 050.

name: — Race & Juvenile Justice
description: Course Description: Individual and institutinal respnses to "troublesome" youth of color through history and in contemporary siciety. Emphasis on how race, as well as ethnicity, class, and gender have informed the treatment of "delinquent" youth.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or equivalent.

name: — Latino Youth Gangs in Global Perspective
description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of Latino youth gangs in Europe, Latin America, and the United States. Social, economic, political, and cultural factors leading to youth gangs as well as the responses are considered within a global perspective.

name: — Latino Youth Gangs in Global Perspective
description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of Latino youth gangs in Europe, Latin America, and the United States. Social, economic, political, and cultural factors leading to youth gangs as well as the responses to the youths are considered within a global perspective. May be taught abroad.

name: — Internship in the Chicana/Chicano/Latina/Latino Community
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Academic guidance combined with internship in community agencies serving Mexican/Latina/Latino/Chicana/Chicano clients. Use of bilingual skills and knowledge of history, culture, economics, politics and social issues. Internship project required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHI 010 or CHI 021 or CHI 050); (SPA 003 or SPA 003V); or equivalent of SPA 003.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Internship. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHI 010 or CHI 021 or CHI 050); (SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y); and consent of instructor, or equivalent of SPA 003, SPA 003V, SPA 003Y.

name: — Senior Honors Research Project
description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

name: — Senior Honors Research Project
description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

name: — Senior Honors Research Project
description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of Program Chairperson.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of Program Chairperson.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Chicano/Latino Hispanic Politics
description: Course Description: Examination of Chicano/Latino political experiences. Evaluate theories, ideology, and practice of Chicano politics. Brief history of Chicano/Latino/Hispanic political activity, comparisons among political modes, gendered politics, and understanding relationships among Chicano, Mexican, American and world politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two undergraduate courses in Chicana/o Studies (CHI) or consent of instructor.

name: — Community Based Participatory Research
description: Course Description: Provides knowledge & skills to plan and implement participatory & community based projects that highlight community empowerment framework.

name: — Group Study for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Group study for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Special Study for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Elementary Chinese
description: Course Description: Developing elementary level skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Introduction of fundamentals of pronunciation, grammar, and Chinese characters will be introduced.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No background in Chinese or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Chinese
description: Course Description: Introduction and practice in contexts of pronunciation, writing system, basic grammar and vocabulary as basis of communicative competency in Mandarin Chinese within a special nine-week intensive course which combines CHN 001, CHN 002 and CHN 003.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No background in Chinese or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Accelerated Written Chinese I
description: Course Description: Trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students who already have elementary level ability to understand or speak Mandarin Chinese. Emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers I
description: Course Description: Training in spoken Mandarin, particularly in the phonetic transcription system known as pinyin, for students who already read and write Chinese.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Chinese
description: Course Description: Continuation of elementary level skill development in listening, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Continued introduction of basic vocabulary and characters as well as core grammar, and further train pronunciation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Accelerated Written Chinese II
description: Course Description: Further trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students that already have elementary level ability to understand or speak Mandarin Chinese. Emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001BL; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers II
description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 001CN. Training in spoken Mandarin for students who can already read and write Chinese.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001CN; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Chinese
description: Course Description: Continuation of elementary level skill development in listening, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Continued introduction of basic vocabulary and characters as well as core grammar, and further train pronunciation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Accelerated Written Chinese III
description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 002BL with further trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing with emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations in more communication settings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002BL; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers III
description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 002CN. Prepares students for entering upper division courses in Chinese.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002CN; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Chinese
description: Course Description: Continuation of intermediate-level communication skills in spoken and written Mandarin, based on language skills developed in CHN 003.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 003 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Accelerated Intensive Intermediate Chinese
description: Course Description: Special nine-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of CHN 004, CHN 005, and CHN 006. Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural and communicative contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 003 or CHN 001A.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 003 or CHN 001A or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Chinese
description: Course Description: Training continues at intermediate-level in spoken and written Chinese in cultural contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 004.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 004 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Chinese
description: Course Description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 005.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 005; CHN 005 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Chinese Business Culture
description: Course Description: Introduction to business culture of China. Basic conversation and Romanization of Chinese words.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Chinese Language & Culture
description: Course Description: Chinese culture through the lens of Chinese language. Relationship of language to religion, food, arts, ethnic groups, dialects, writing systems, etc. All readings are in English; no previous background is necessary.

name: — Modern Chinese Literature (In English)
description: Course Description: Introductory course requiring no knowledge of Chinese language or history. Reading and discussion of short stories and novels and viewing of two films. Designed to convey a feeling for what China has experienced in the 20th century.

name: — Great Books of China (in English)
description: Course Description: Readings in English translation of classical and medieval Chinese poetry, Chinese historiography, tales of the supernatural, Tang romances, opera, and late imperial era vernacular literature, with key works by Sima Qian, Gan Bao, Tao Qian, Han Yu, and Feng Menglong. Background information on periods, authors and the interrelationships of culture, literature and social change.

name: — Introduction to the Literature of China & Japan
description: Course Description: Methods of literary analysis and their application to major works from the various genres of Chinese and Japanese literature (in translation), including film. East Asian cultural traditions will also be introduced.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Daoist Traditions
description: Course Description: English-language survey of key Daoist texts and scholarship. Topics include Daoist concepts of the cosmos, the natural world, scripture, the body, and immortality; Daoist divinities; Daoism and the state.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in Chinese history recommended.

name: — Confucian Traditions
description: Course Description: Key aspects of the Confucian tradition in dynastic China. Major themes addressed include ritual, classical studies, and Confucian influences on the Chinese family and state.

name: — Chinese Film
description: Course Description: English language survey of Chinese film, from its inception to the end of the 20th century. Chinese films as important texts for understanding national, transnational, racial, gender, and class politics of modern China.

name: — Modern Chinese Drama
description: Course Description: English language survey of modern Chinese spoken drama in the 20th century and its major playwrights, in the context of Chinese history and the interaction of Chinese culture with other cultures.

name: — Modern Chinese Fiction (in English)
description: Course Description: English language survey of Chinese fiction as it evolved amidst the great historical, social and cultural changes of the 20th century. Thorough study of the most influential writers and genres.

name: — Western Influences on 20th-Century Chinese Literature (in English)
description: Course Description: Introduction of Western literary thought into modern China, the experimentation with Western literary forms and techniques, and the development of Marxism in contemporary literary writing.

name: — Chinese Poetry (in English)
description: Course Description: Organized topically and chronologically, the lyric tradition is explored from the dawn of folk songs down to modern expressions of social protest. Topics include friendship, love, oppression, war, parting, death, ecstasy and beauty. All readings are in English.

name: — Traditional Chinese Fiction (in English)
description: Course Description: Dawn of Chinese fiction and its development down to modern times. Survey of literary history with close reading of representative works. Readings, lectures, and discussions in English.

name: — Poetry of China & Japan (in English)
description: Course Description: A comparative approach to Chinese and Japanese poetry, examining poetic practice in the two cultures; includes a general outline of the two traditions, plus study of poetic forms, techniques, and distinct treatments of universal themes: love, nature, war, etc.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Crime & Punishment
description: Course Description: Examines how crime and punishment have been represented in traditional Chinese short stories, novels, operas, and histories.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Women Writers (in English)
description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; women writers.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The Knight-Errant (in English)
description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the knight-errant.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The City in Fiction (in English)
description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the city in fiction.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The Literature of 20th-Century Taiwan (in English)
description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the literature of 20th-century Taiwan.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Popular Literature (in English)
description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; popular literature.

name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Scholar & The Courtesan (in English)
description: Course Description: Chinese romance stories, focusing on depictions of scholars and courtesans in Tang fables, late imperial operas, Ming short-stories, and 19th-century novels.

name: — Great Writers of China: Texts & Context (in English)
description: Course Description: Examination of major theoretical concepts and interpretive methods in the study of literature by using examples from the Chinese tradition; discussions of classical and modern works with an emphasis on the relations between literature, author, society, and culture.

name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Building on Chinese 006/003BL, further development of communication skills in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Reading of dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 C- or better or CHN 003BL C- or better or CHN 004A C- or better; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Intensive Third-Year Chinese
description: Course Description: Nine-week intensive summer course combines CHN 111, CHN 112, and CHN 113. Training at intermediate-high and advanced-low level in spoken and written Chinese in cultural and communicative contexts based on language skills developed in CHN 006.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 or CHN 003BL or CHN 004A; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Further development of communication skills from CHN 111 in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Reading dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China issues and discussing ethical, moral, aesthetic, social, and cultural concerns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of CHN 112, further developing communication skills in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Read dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China issues and discuss ethical, moral, aesthetic, social, and cultural concerns. Study strategies for moving between simplified and traditional Chinese characters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 112; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese
description: Course Description: Introduction to the language in which, until the 20th century, most official, documentary, scholarly, and belle-lettristic Chinese literature was written.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 112; or equivalent language proficiency. consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese II
description: Course Description: Continuation of enhancing classical Chinese reading skills with literature ranging from the prose found in Han dynasty historical works, Six Dynasties anecdotal literature, and Tang occasional texts, as well as the poetic shi and fu genres.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 114; or Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese III
description: Course Description: Translations of extended readings in the original sources and brief analyses of syntax. These sources will include texts written by well-known figures from the 8th through 15th centuries, composing in a wide variety of genres.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 115; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Chinese for Non-Native Speakers
description: Course Description: Analysis of material from various genres (literature, newspapers, blogs, TV, film, etc) with focus on Chinese society and culture. Advanced reading, writing, aural comprehension, and formal speech in Mandarin Chinese. For students who have completed the third-year Chinese series (CHN 111-113), but do not have substantial background as heritage or native speakers of Chinese.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113; or equivalent language proficiency; consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Chinese
description: Course Description: Evaluation of readings from various genres (literature, newspapers, TV and movies, etc.) develop advanced reading, writing, aural comprehension, and formal/professional speech skills in Mandarin Chinese. Chinese society/cultural studies, especially those sociocultural issues reflected in the language used in learning materials.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — Business Chinese
description: Course Description: Mandarin Chinese language for business and professional purposes. Appropriate usages and protocols within the context of Chinese business culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113 or consent of instructor.

name: — Readings in Traditional Chinese Fiction
description: Course Description: Examination of representative works of traditional Chinese fiction popular from the 12th Century until the 17th and 18th centuries. Translations in English of the Chinese texts will be available to students as reference.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency.

name: — Readings in Traditional Chinese Poetry
description: Course Description: Traditional Chinese poetry from its beginnings to the golden ages of Tang and Song, surveying forms and poets that best reveal the Chinese poetic sensibility and the genius of the language of Chinese poetry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

name: — Readings in Modern Chinese Poetry
description: Course Description: Chinese poetry from the Literary Revolution of 1917 to the present, surveying works that embody exciting innovations and reflect the modernity of 20th-century Chinese society and culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

name: — Readings in Modern Chinese Prose & Drama
description: Course Description: Literary works and scholarly essays on selected topics of Chinese prose and drama, development of a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through sophisticated reading materials of these two important genres of the modern period.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

name: — Chinese Film in Chinese Language
description: Course Description: Chinese film and scholarly essays on Chinese cinema and film history. Develop a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through viewing and studying Chinese films in the Chinese language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency.

name: — Readings in Classical Chinese
description: Course Description: Study and philological analysis of selected texts from the first millennium of Imperial China.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Fifth-Year Chinese: Selected Topics in Chinese Language, Literature, & Culture
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of literary works and scholarly essays on selected topics of Chinese culture and society. Development of a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through sophisticated Chinese speaking and writing exercises.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 120; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

name: — The Chinese Language
description: Course Description: Introduction to structural features of Chinese (Mandarin) sounds, lexicon, grammar, and writing (characters), as well as relevant dialectal and sociolinguistic issues of the language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 (can be concurrent) or CHN 003BL (can be concurrent) or CHN 003CN (can be concurrent) or CHN 004A (can be concurrent); or placement exam or consent of instructor; LIN 001 recommended.

name: — Chinese Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience in the Chinese language, with analytical term paper on a topic approved by instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of instructor.

name: — Senior Thesis Honors Project
description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in Chinese literature, civilization, or language studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing and qualification for the Chinese honors program.

name: — Tutoring in Chinese
description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the Department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Independent Study
description: Course Description: Directed independent study on a topic culminating in a term paper. Independent studies may only be arranged with consent of the instructor and when graduate seminars are unavailable.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Any course taught by a graduate student under the direction of the Director.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Introduction to Film Studies
description: Course Description: Analysis of film form and narrative, including cinematography, editing, and sound. Issues in film studies including authorship, stardom, race, gender, class, and cultural identity. Introduction to selected cinematic movements and national film traditions.

name: — Introduction to Technocultural Studies
description: Course Description: Contemporary developments in the fine and performing arts, media arts, digital arts, and literature as they relate to technological and scientific practices.

name: — Media Archaeology
description: Course Description: Evolution of media technologies and practices beginning in the 19th century as they relate to contemporary digital arts practices. Special focus on the reconstruction of the social and artistic possibilities of lost and obsolete media technologies.

name: — Introduction to Media Computation
description: Course Description: Introduction to key computational ideas necessary to understand and produce digital media. Fundamentals of programming and analysis of how media are represented and transmitted in digital form. Aimed primarily at non-computer science students.

name: — Filmmaking Foundations
description: Course Description: Introduction to filmmaking concepts, principles, and methods. Emphasis on form, content and historical dialectic between classical narrative filmmaking conventions and artists' challenges to these conventions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 and/or CDM 003 recommended.

name: — Filmmaking Foundations
description: Course Description: Introduction to filmmaking concepts, principles, and methods. Emphasis on form, content and historical dialectic between classical narrative filmmaking conventions and artists' challenges to these conventions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 and/or CDM 003 recommended.

name: — History of Cinema from 1895-1945
description: Course Description: Examination of the cultural context of the emergence of cinema. Discussion of cinema as a product of the age of industrialization and conquest, as well as an element of urban culture, and mass transportation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

name: — History of Cinema from 1945-Present
description: Course Description: Examines cinema from 1945 through the present, with focus on neo-realist, new wave and third-world movements. Examines social critique in cinema from studio system to New Wave, Cine Novo, postcolonial cinema and contemporary independent cinema.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

name: — History of Cinema from 1945-Present
description: Course Description: Examines cinema from 1945 through the present, with focus on neo-realist, new wave and third-world movements.  Examines social critique in cinema from studio system to New Wave, Cine Novo, postcolonial cinema and contemporary independent cinema.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

name: — Introduction to Games
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play. Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship, on or off campus, in the area of cinema and digital media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study in cinema and digital media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates in cinema and digital media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Experimental Digital Cinema I
description: Course Description: Experimental approaches to the making of film and video in the age of digital technologies. Builds upon the foundation provided by CDM 020. Instruction in technical, conceptual, creative, and critical skills for taking a project from idea to fruition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020 or ART 012; or consent of instructor.

name: — Experimental Digital Cinema II
description: Course Description: Continuation of CDM 100 with further exploration of digital cinema creation. Additional topics include new modes of distribution, streaming, installation and exhibition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 100; consent of instructor.

name: — Interactivity & Animation
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of creating interactive screen-based work. Theories of interactivity, linear versus non-linear structures & audience involvement and participation. Use of digital production tools to produce class projects.

name: — Documentary Production
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Traditional and new forms of documentary, with focus on technocultural issues. Skills and strategies for producing work in various media. Progression through all stages of production, from conception through post-production to critique.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020; CDM 155; or consent of instructor.

name: — Feminist Media Production
description: Course Description: Media production as a mode of cultural criticism, furthering feminist and social justice goals. Fundamentals of camera, editing and distribution via a social engagement model. Study and hands-on response to key historic and contemporary feminist and social justice media discourses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CTS 020 or CDM 020); or two WMS courses.

name: — Acting for Camera
description: Course Description: Analysis and practice of acting skills required for camera work and digital media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Community Media Production
description: Course Description: Use of video and new media tools to address social issues among neighborhood and community groups. Use basic video, sound, and lighting techniques while working with local groups in a group video project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020 recommended.

name: — Community Networks & Social Media
description: Course Description: Impact and implications of computer-based networks in community, civic, and social life. Subjects may include community-access computer sites, neighborhood wireless networks, the digital divide, open-source software, and citizen action.

name: — Introduction to Sonic Arts
description: Course Description: Introduction to the use of sound within the arts. Techniques and aesthetics of experimental contemporary practices. Creation of original sound works.

name: — Introduction to Sonic Arts
description: Course Description: Introduction to use of sound within the arts. Techniques and aesthetics of experimental contemporary practices. Creation of original sound works.

name: — Intermediate Sonic Arts
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Techniques of recording, editing, mixing, and synthesis to combine voice, field recordings, and electronic signals. Incorporating live, recorded, found sounds to create multidimensional stories. Presentation of live performances, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 121; or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Sonic Arts
description: Course Description: Techniques of recording, editing, mixing, and synthesis to combine voice, field recordings, and electronic signals. Incorporating live, recorded, found sounds to create multidimensional stories. Presentation of live performances, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 121 or CDM 121V; or consent of instructor.

name: — Sight & Soundtrack
