prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 261.

name: — Distributed Database Systems
description: Course Description: Concepts of distributed database systems and architectures, distributed database design, distributed query processing and optimization, transaction management and concurrency control, heterogeneous and multidatabase systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 165A.

name: — Spatial Databases
description: Course Description: Concepts, models, and architectures for spatial databases, spatial access methods, query processing, spatio-temporal data management, moving objects, spatial data mining.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 165A.

name: — Wide-Area Distributed Information Systems
description: Course Description: Wide-area distributed information systems, data broadcast, multicast, publish/subscribe, service differentiation, information retrieval, Web caching.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 152B or ECS 165A.

name: — Scientific Data & Workflow Management
description: Course Description: Scientific data integration, metadata, knowledge representation, ontologies, scientific workflow design and management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 165A.

name: — Visual Recognition
description: Course Description: Graduate seminar course on computer vision with an emphasis on object recognition, activity recognition, and scene understanding.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 171 or ECS 174; or equivalent.

name: — Artificial Intelligence
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Concepts and techniques underlying the design and implementation of models of human performance on intelligent tasks. Representation of high-level knowledge structures. Models of memory and inference. Natural language and story understanding. Common sense planning and problem solving.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 140A; ECS 172 recommended.

name: — Machine Learning & Discovery
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Artificial intelligence techniques for knowledge acquisition by computers. Fundamental problems in machine learning and discovery. Systems that learn from examples, analogies, and solved problems. Systems that discover numerical laws and qualitative relationships. Projects centering on implementation and evaluation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 170.

name: — Information Visualization
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in information visualization: perceptually effective display methods, color design and selection, interaction models and techniques, focus-context techniques, distortion methods, large graph visualization techniques, visual data mining methods, and evaluation methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 163 or ECS 175 recommended.

name: — Applied Visual Computing
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Visual computing paradigms, current visualization technologies, principles of 3-d graphics, user interface designs, and exploratory visualization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Automated Deduction
description: Course Description: Techniques of mechanical theorem proving. Methods based on resolution and termrewriting. Decision procedures. Induction. Applications to program verification, question/answering and plan generation. Study existing mechanical theorem provers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112; or MAT 125 or familiarity with first order logic.

name: — Advanced Computer Graphics
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in computer graphics. Hidden surface models, rendering of various surface types, subdivision methods, shading techniques, anti-aliasing, modeling techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 175 or ECS 177 or ECS 178.

name: — Advanced Computer Graphics
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in computer graphics and geometric modeling. Topics taken from advanced research papers in computer graphics, image synthesis, visualization and geometric modeling. Discussion of current research in the field.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 175 or ECS 177 or ECS 178.

name: — Advanced Volume Visualization
description: Course Description: Applications, available tools and techniques, the challenges confronting the field of volume visualization, and some of the advanced topics in the field. Primary emphasis on advanced software and hardware techniques to achieve interactive visualization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 177.

name: — Advanced Visualization
description: Course Description: Visualization of 3D data, including scalar fields, vector fields, and medical data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 177.

name: — Computer-Aided Geometric Design
description: Course Description: Mathematical techniques for the definition and manipulation of curves and surfaces. Bezier curves and surfaces, B-spline curves and surfaces, subdivision surfaces, wavelets. Integration into various computer graphics rendering models, visualization systems and computer-aided design systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 175.

name: — Computer Animation
description: Course Description: Surveys current research and fundamental techniques that lie behind character animation tools. Emphasis on improving expressive aspects of movement and how physics, motion capture data, the arts and psychology literature, and interactive techniques can be used towards this goal.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 175; or ECS 275.

name: — Virtual Reality Technology
description: Course Description: Fundamentals and principles of Virtual Reality (VR) technology. Potential and limits for its useful application. Developing a complete virtual reality application.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 175.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Computer Science Theory
description: Course Description: Special topic in Computer Science Theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Architecture
description: Course Description: Special topic in Architecture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Programming Languages & Compilers
description: Course Description: Special topic in Programming Languages & Compilers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Operating Systems
description: Course Description: Special topic in Operating Systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Software Engineering
description: Course Description: Special topic in Software Engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Databases
description: Course Description: Special topic in Databases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Artificial Intelligence
description: Course Description: Special topic in Artificial Intelligence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Computer Graphics
description: Course Description: Special topic in Computer Graphics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Networks
description: Course Description: Special topic in Networks.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Computer-Aided Design
description: Course Description: Special topic in Computer-Aided Design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Scientific Computing
description: Course Description: Special topic in Scientific Computing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Computer Science
description: Course Description: Special topic in Computer Science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Computer Science: Security
description: Course Description: Special topic in Security.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Bioinformatics & Computational Biology
description: Course Description: Special topic in Bioinformatics & Computational Biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Computer Science
description: Course Description: Participating seminar; discussion and presentation of current research and development in computer science.

name: — Graduate Research Group Conference
description: Course Description: Research problems, progress and techniques in computer science.

name: — Research in Computer Science
description: Course Description: Study of research topics in computer science, Ph.D. level research methodologies (experimental, applied and theoretical). Study skills necessary to successfully find/solve significant research problems. Finding and successful interacting with a research advisor. Ethical issues in research/collaborative work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in computer science.

name: — Research in Computer Science
description: Course Description: Study of Ph.D. level research methodologies (experimental, applied and theoretical), presenting research results for the computer science community. Study skills necessary to successfully find/solve significant research problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in computer science; ECS 293A recommended.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Research.

name: — The Teaching of Computer Science
description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant or associate-in in a designated engineering course. Methods of leading discussion groups or laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, use of laboratory equipment, and grading laboratory reports.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Meet qualifications for teaching assistant and/or associate-in in Computer Science.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Internship in Consumer Science
description: Course Description: Internship on and off campus in a consumer science related area.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Consumer Behavior
description: Course Description: Provides a set of behavioral concepts and theories useful in understanding consumer behavior on the part of the individual, business, and social organizations. Conceptual models to help guide and understand consumer research will be presented.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Preparation in areas of psychology or sociology and economics recommended.

name: — Internship in Consumer Science
description: Course Description: Internship on and off campus in a consumer science related areA.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Completion of a minimum of 84 units.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

name: — Introduction to Critical Theoretical Approaches to Literature & Culture
description: Course Description: Introduction to critical theory and its use for interpreting literary texts, film, and media forms in our present global culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Approaches to Critical Theory
description: Course Description: Critical overview of modern theoretical texts (e.g., semiotics, hermeneutics, deconstruction, social and cultural critique, feminist theory, psychoanalysis).

name: — Problems in Critical Theory
description: Course Description: Focused study of a particular critical theoretical approach, school or perspective. Topics may include but are not limited to: critical approaches to the study of literature, culture, film, historiography, visual culture, the body, and aesthetics.

name: — History of Critical Theory
description: Course Description: Critical analysis and discussion of pre-20th century theories of literary and cultural criticism. Topics may include but are not limited to: ancient and early modern philosophy; nature and culture in the Renaissance; theories of Mimesis from antiquity to the Renaissance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing.

name: — Critical Theory Special Topics
description: Course Description: Application of theoretical principles to one specific research topic. May be repeated for credit with consent of instructor when topic differs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing.

name: — Visual Culture
description: Course Description: Analysis of image production in the contemporary world (photography, film, television, advertising, etc.) and their effects on individual subjectivities and collective social identities.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Individual study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate student standing.

name: — Histories of Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Histories and traditions of cultural studies internationally; multiple legacies of cultural studies as a field of inquiry in various geographical contexts; foregrounds important critical perspectives resulting from social and intellectual movements world-wide.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor required. Undergraduate coursework in the humanities or social sciences recommended.

name: — Theories of Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Definitions of "critical" scholarship and examination of various contexts in which cultural studies theory has emerged worldwide. Both mainstream and alternative theoretical traditions, such as those developed by people of color and by other minoritized groups.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Practices of Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Methodological and practical applications of cultural studies research. Critical analyses of ethnography, textual analysis, social change, community development, and identity formation. Emphasis given to students' unique versions of cultural studies practices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A; CST 200B; or consent of instructor.

name: — History & Theory of Sexualities
description: Course Description: Studies of sexuality in feminist, literary, historical, and cultural studies research, specifically examining the emergence of "sexuality" as a field of research and the relationship of sexuality studies to cultural forms, subjectivity, and social relations generally.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Studies in Race Theory
description: Course Description: Theoretical framework for the critical study of race, drawing on contemporary cultural studies and postcolonial scholarship in order to understand the social production of "race" as a category for organizing social groups and determining group processes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Studies in Nationalism, Transnationalism, & Late Capitalism
description: Course Description: Contemporary theories of nation, nationalism, postcolonialism, and transnationalism. Specific attention to the relationship between cultural production and the formation of ideas about nation and nationalism, including examination of both "legitimizing" and resistant discourses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Memory, Culture, & Human Rights
description: Course Description: Explores the multiple convergences among memory, culture, and human rights. Discusses diverse approaches to how societal actors in different historical, cultural, and national settings, construct meanings of past political violence, inter-group conflicts, and human rights struggles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Studies in the Rhetorics of Culture
description: Course Description: Survey of critical and analytical approaches to the study of texts. Examination of multi-mediated objects to understand their cultural import by focusing on discursive production, dispersal, and reception processes, and related shifts in power relations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Studies in Political & Cultural Representations
description: Course Description: Framework for the analysis of political and popular cultural representations. Emphasis on concepts, theories, and methodologies illuminating dominant and vernacular cultural representation, appropriation, and innovation in transnational contexts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A (can be concurrent); consent of graduate advisor required.

name: — Research Seminar
description: Course Description: Designed to facilitate student interaction and promote student research by guiding students through the production of a publishable essay. Essays submitted, distributed, and discussed by seminar participants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200A; CST 200B; CST 200C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Cultural Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200C; CST 250; and consent of instructor.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Cultural Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200C; CST 250; and consent of instructor.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Cultural Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Cultural Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CST 200C; CST 250; and consent of instructor.

name: — Colloquium
description: Course Description: Designed to provide cohort identity and faculty student exchange. Opportunity to present papers, hear guest lecturers, and see faculty presentations, gather for organizational and administrative news, exchange information, and make announcements.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics
description: Course Description: Special topics courses offered according to faculty and student interests and demands.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Research
description: Course Description: Group research.

name: — Directed Research
description: Course Description: Directed research.

name: — Dissertation Research
description: Course Description: Dissertation research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to doctoral candidacy.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Internship in Cutaneous Biology
description: Course Description: Approval of project prior to internship by preceptor. Supervised work experience involving research on the skin. Final report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study in Cutaneous Biology
description: Course Description: Special study by individual arrangement of specialized topics in biology of skin. Work may be assigned readings, laboratory research or a combination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate standing and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Cutaneous Biology
description: Course Description: Independent research in cellular and biochemical mechanisms of cutaneous biology and pathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Integumentary System
description: Course Description: Cell biology, pathology, and physical diagnosis of the skin. Recognition of normal variations, and common or important dermatoses. Patient demonstrations of select conditions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.

name: — Dermatology Clinical Clerkship
description: Course Description: Observation and participation in dermatology clinics/practice and participation in Ward Rounds and Dermatology Clinics at UC Davis Medical Center, Kaiser, and private practitioner offices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of three years of medical school; or consent of instructor.

name: — Specialty Externship in Dermatology
description: Course Description: Externship provides in-depth exposure to one of a variety of sub-specialties in Dermatology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Away Acting Internship in Dermatology
description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Expectation is to provide direct patient management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Dermatopathology
description: Course Description: Integrated, multi-specialty approach to the microscopic diagnosis of inflammatory and neoplastic skin disorders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; previous rotation in a Dermatology Clerkship.

name: — Telehealth in Dermatology
description: Course Description: Introduction to the application of telehealth in dermatology to provide diagnoses, consultation, treatment, and education. Participate in teledermatology clinics with remote sites throughout California, conduct telehealth project(s), and review the latest literature in telehealth application in improving healthcare access.

name: — Insights in Dermatology
description: Course Description: Clinical experience limited to observation of delivery of dermatologic care and attendance at some conferences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second- year medical students in good academic standing.

name: — Wound Healing: From Bench to Bedside
description: Course Description: An integrated, multi-specialty approach to clinical soft tissue wound healing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Clinical Dermatology
description: Course Description: Individually arranged study of special topics in clinical dermatology determined by student and instructor. Assigned readings and/or clinical examination of selected patients.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Cutaneous Biology
description: Course Description: Research, either laboratory or clinical, on ongoing projects within the department under supervision of faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to design discipline through readings, writing, visual problem solving, and critical analysis. Topics: design principles and elements, vocabulary, color theory, Gestalt principles, conceptualization strategies. Role of designer and products in contemporary culture including social responsibility and sustainability.

name: — Design Drawing
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Drawing as a tool for design. Basic skills in objective observation and representation, including line, shape, tone, and space. Drawing as a tool for formulating and working through design problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); students with a background in drawing or Advanced Placement Art Studio units are encouraged to submit a portfolio for review to waive this course.

name: — Form & Color
description: Course Description: Understanding color, form and composition as ways of communicating design concepts and content. Color theory, color mixing, interaction of color. Design principles and elements. Gestalt theory. Explores a variety of materials, media and presentation techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Graphic Design & Computer Technology
description: Course Description: Introduction to digital tools with emphasis on graphic design including theory, practice and technology. Includes principles of color, resolution, pixels, vectors, image enhancement, layout, visual organization, visual hierarchy, typography.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Drafting & Perspective
description: Course Description: Introduction to mechanical drafting, including scaled drawing, orthogonal projection, isometric, axonometric and perspective. Includes basic rendering techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Energy, Materials, & Design Over Time
description: Course Description: Global history of design across time, viewed through the lens of the effects of the creation and discovery of new energy sources, processes, and materials on design.

name: — Ideologies of Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history and theory of design in particular relation to political, philosophical, cultural, economic, and environmental debates and objectives.

name: — Design for Aesthetics & Experience
description: Course Description: Global historical survey of design's engagement with changing notions of aesthetics and experience. Relates transformations in the theory, production, and reception of all aspects of design (objects, landscapes, architectures, etc.) to larger cultural, social, and political contexts.

name: — Designed Geographies: Environment, Containment, Sanctuary
description: Course Description: Historical survey of the role of design in the production of geographic location. Role of design in the choreography or enforcement of bodies in geographic space. Global exploration of the design imagination in the creation of alternatives to built space in the present.

name: — Introduction to Three-Dimensional Design
description: Course Description: Design concept development and detailing as it relates to the making of objects, structures and models using form, scale and materials. Product design and rapid prototyping methods using a range of techniques for advancing the design process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Computer-Assisted Drawing for Designers
description: Course Description: Computer-assisted drawing (CAD) and modeling using a mid-level, multi-use CAD program. Basic architectural drawing and modeling technique in both two-dimensional and three-dimensional CAD environments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Textile Design Structures
description: Course Description: Introduction to diverse methods for creating textile structures. Exploration of the creative potential of hand-constructed textiles, manipulation of fabric to create dimensional surfaces, and the basics of building and joining fabric structures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Structural Design for Fashion
description: Course Description: Study and practice of designing clothing for the human body. Emphasis on flat pattern development, structural joining sequences and the development of three-dimensional garments from two-dimensional drawings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Structural Design for Fashion
description: Course Description: Advanced study and practice of designing clothing for the human body through pattern development and structural joining. Emphasis on draping techniques and advanced conceptualization for fashion design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 077; or consent of instructor.

name: — Coding for Designers
description: Course Description: Programming concepts/skills for design. Algorithm-based design and development flowcharts. Pseudo-code entry level programming. Principles of coding logic syntax structure. Analysis of history. Development iteration presentation of design projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — UI/UX Design: Principles & Practices
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Conceptual approaches, technical practice for interactive media using the front-end stack (html, css, js). Conceptual framework, user experience, visual interface and interaction design. Research and written pre-production materials required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016.

name: — Photography & Digital Imaging
description: Course Description: Digital imaging techniques using black/white and color. Critical analysis of photographs and the role of photography in society. Explore use and meaning of single, sequence and single composite images.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; DES 015; DES 016.

name: — Letterforms & Typography
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of letterforms and typography. Characteristics of typefaces; formatting and composition of type. Principles of legibility, visual hierarchy, grid systems, and the integration of type and image.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Visual Communication: Graphic Design Studio
description: Course Description: Multiple, conceptually-linked assignments focusing on the fundamental choices designers make in translating concepts into effective graphic form. Problem finding and analysis of audience needs. Design process from research and initial concepts to project prototypes. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 115; or consent of instructor.

name: — Interactive Media I
description: Course Description: Practice of creating interactive visual media for network-based applications and principles of human computer interaction. Responsive design. User-centered research, information architecture, interface and interaction. Analysis of usability. Development and presentation of design production materials and completed interactive projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Design Ethnography
description: Course Description: Practical introduction to design ethnography through project-based work. Tools and methods, observation, interviews, fieldnotes, and synthesis of qualitative data. Exploration of participatory design. Examination of the ethical questions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; or consent of instructor.

name: — Sustainable Design
description: Course Description: Principles, practice and materials of contemporary sustainable design in the context of environmental crisis. History of sustainable design in relation to the fields of product design, material science, energy, architecture, and transportation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001.

name: — Studio Practice in Sustainable Design
description: Course Description: Analysis and practice of sustainable design within studio context. Design project that incorporate the reuse of post consumer waste; standard materials vs. sustainable materials; Cradle to Cradle philosophy and practice. Field trips required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 127A; DES 001; or consent of instructor.

name: — Biodesign Theory & Practice: Biodesign Challenge Part I
description: Course Description: Foundational principles of biodesign, with examples in textiles, fashion, graphics, lighting, products, and architecture. Team-based experience in biodesign intervention; first steps in a mini-entrepreneurial start-up experience.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Biodesign Experimentation & Prototyping: Biodesign Challenge Part II
description: Course Description: Team-based, experimentally grounded prototype design in a mini-entrepreneurial start-up context.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 128A C or better; consent of instructor.

name: — Global Fashion & Product Design
description: Course Description: Exploration of materials, embellishments, and structural techniques derived from historic and contemporary world cultures. Emphasis on unique qualities of individual expression applied to hand made textiles, fashion and textile products. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Textile Design: Woven Structures
description: Course Description: Foundation in handwoven textile structure and design, emphasizing yarn identification, basic drafting, basic weaves and their derivatives explored in context of original color effects and yarn combinations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Loom-Constructed Textile Design
description: Course Description: Intermediate level study of complex fabric structure with emphasis on pattern in relation to surface, dimension, and material.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 132A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Interior Design–Residential
description: Course Description: Introduction to the theory and practice of interior design with focus on residential spaces. Basic methods of design conceptualization, development, and presentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 021 or DES 051 or DES 150A); or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Interior Design–Commercial & Technical Spaces
description: Course Description: Introduction to the theory and practice of interior design with focus on small commercial and technical spaces. Archetypal spaces, non-residential building systems, ADA accessibility, design programming and research methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 021 or DES 051 or DES 150A); or consent of instructor.

name: — Furniture Design & Detailing
description: Course Description: Development of designs for contemporary furniture. Consideration of behavioral and physical requirements, cultural and historic expression, and structural and aesthetic qualities. Process includes research, drawings, and construction of scale models. Required field trip.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Furniture Design & Prototyping
description: Course Description: Design and construction of full size prototype furniture based on preliminary work completed in DES 135A. Material technology, construction methods, and finishes discussed. Development of shop drawings and furniture construction. Required field trip.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Lighting Technology & Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to lighting design and technology. Understanding the role of lighting and vision in the development of functional and aesthetically pleasing environments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Designing with Light–Industrial Design
description: Course Description: Design and manipulation of light sources, luminaires, and lighting controls to enhance the functional and aesthetic impact of interior and exterior spaces. Industrial design projects explore lighting effects, light distribution characteristics, and luminaire design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 136A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Daylighting & Interior Design
description: Course Description: Emphasis on understanding the effect of daylight on the perception of interior designs as well as on vision, luminous and thermal comfort, health and energy efficiency.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Daylighting Design Studio
description: Course Description: Introduction to daylighting through observation of its effects on interior designs using scale models of interior designs of choice and photographing them outdoors and in CLTC’s Heliodon to understand year-round performance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Materials & Methods in Interior Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to the finish materials used for interior design with special emphasis on sustainable and recycled products. Performance factors, relative costs and energy impacts, installation conditions and construction details, and design potential for a full range of interior materials.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; or consent of instructor.

name: — Cultural Studies of Fashion
description: Course Description: Cultural studies theories and methods used to explore an inclusive approach to design studies. Fashion in dress and other areas of design in society. Race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, class, national identity, dis/ability, age/generation, and religion, and the intersectionalities among these subject positions in the transnational design, production, circulation, and consumption of fashion.

name: — World Textiles: Eastern Hemisphere
description: Course Description: Social contexts, meanings, aesthetics, stylistic developments, and methods significant in eastern hemisphere textiles. Emphasis on Japan, China, Indonesia, Oceania, Southern and Central Asia, Africa.

name: — World Textiles: Western Hemisphere
description: Course Description: Social context, aesthetics, stylistic developments and methods significant in western hemisphere textiles. Emphasis on the Middle East, Europe, and the Americas up to contemporary times. Two required field trips.

name: — History of Fashion
description: Course Description: History of fashion design from the earliest times to the present focusing on the ancient Middle East and Common Era North America and Europe. Emphasis on aesthetic, functional, social, economic, political and cultural aspects of clothing and personal adornment.

name: — History of Interior Architecture
description: Course Description: Thematic survey of interior architecture. Emphasis on dwellings in their cultural settings and development of modern interior design theories. Interiors considered in relation to buildings' exteriors, sites, and uses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — History of Visual Communication
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Historical developments of visual communication, concentrating on the technological and aesthetic development of graphic design; origins and manifestations of current issues in visual communication; provide framework for analysis of current and future trends in visual communication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; or consent of instructor.

name: — Mobilities
description: Course Description: Mobilization of social space through ships, trains, bicycles, cars, planes, and skate parks. Exploration of the impact of driverless vehicles and civilian space travel on the safety, enjoyability, sustainability, and accessibility of social space. Critical, historical, aesthetic and political understanding of how humans move.

name: — Trend Research & Forecasting in Design
description: Course Description: Short term and long term trends, micro and macro trends. Theories of adoption and diffusion of trends. Economic, political, technological and psychological indicators in trend forecasting. Future trends in design using cultural brailing, cross-cultural analysis methods and ethnographic research.

name: — Information Design: Principles & Practice
description: Course Description: Design principles and visual strategies for effective information display; analysis of contemporary and historical examples of visual representations and visual narratives in science, humanities, and the arts; emergence of digital methods for interactive data presentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Computer-Assisted Presentations for Interior Architecture
description: Course Description: Computer-assisted architectural presentation including the development of complex 3D models, techniques of photo-realistic rendering and computer simulation of movement through architectural and interior space.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 051 or DES 150A.

name: — Type in Motion
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of creating motion-based, screen-based typography. Consideration of narrative structures, movement assemblage, and other visual languages, synthesized within a nuanced understanding of typography within digital space. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor. DES 115 recommended.

name: — Visual Communication: Message Campaign Design
description: Course Description: Principles and application of visual design strategies for projects that address a broad public audience. Emphasis on design for social awareness/interaction/benefit. Creation of public visual-media campaign.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 115; DES 116; DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Pattern, Form & Surface
description: Course Description: Experimental approaches to form-making through an examination of pattern, form, and surface in historical and contemporary contexts. Explorations of alternative design processes, methods, and materials that open up new possibilities for content creation and invention in design practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; DES 115; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; (DES 031 or DES 113); or consent of instructor.

name: — Graphitecture: Architecture in the Age of New Media
description: Course Description: New media and its impact on environmental design; analysis of contemporary projects at the intersection of architecture and new media; time-based strategies of representation; digital narrative.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016.

name: — Interactive Media II
description: Course Description: Technical practice for interactive media using the front-end stack (html, css, js). Conceptual framework, user experience, visual interface and interaction design. Research and written pre-production materials required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 111; DES 117; or consent of instructor.

name: — Interactive Media III
description: Course Description: Capstone interactive media course that furthers understanding of and experimentation with the front-end stack with libraries, databases, sensors and microcomputers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 021; DES 111; DES 112; DES 117; (DES 157 or DES 157A); or consent of instructor.

name: — Data & Large-Scale Installation
description: Course Description: Design of large-scale installations using data for engagement with sites, systems, phenomena, or situations that promote interaction between information, narrative, media, and space. Data literacy tools and methods in data acquisition, visualization, and analytics for designers. Data discoveries, formulating narratives, and building large-scale installations as critical design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; (DES 111 or DES 135A or ART 005); or consent of instructor.

name: — Design for Understanding
description: Course Description: Principles of effective information display including aspects of language, structure, legibility, sequencing, and context. Analysis of historical examples of typographic, diagrammatic, and cartographic excellence. User-centered research. Development and presentation of iterative design prototypes. Design that informs, connects, and inspires.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; DES 115; DES 116; or consent of instructor. DES 117 recommended.

name: — Textile Surface Design: Patterns & Resists
description: Course Description: Use of traditional and contemporary processes to create images and patterns on fabric using a variety of dyes, including direct applications, bound and mechanical resists, and surface additives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; or consent of instructor.

name: — Textile Surface Design: Screen & Digital Printing
description: Course Description: Design of textiles and screen printing on fabrics; soft-product development; integration of hand-produced and digitally generated imagery on cloth.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016.

name: — Studio Practices in Industrial Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: 3D studio methods for design, including: historic and contemporary developments in industrial design; innovation in material and fabrication technology; design based projects for everyday objects including soft goods, electronics, transportation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; or consent of instructor.

name: — Human Centered Design
description: Course Description: Human-centered approach to problem solving, ethnography, ideation, project framing, rapid prototypes, visual communication, and experiential learning. Creative approaches to graphic design, industrial design, fashion, business, and entrepreneurship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015.

name: — Prototyping: From Objects to Systems
description: Course Description: Exploration of rapid prototyping techniques for objects, interactive experiences, services and organizations. Understanding of additive manufacturing, foam models, digital interfaces and business models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; or consent of instructor.

name: — Interactive Objects
description: Course Description: Introduction to Physical Computing through a hands-on experience. Concepts, techniques and technologies required to conceptualize, design and prototype interactive devices by the merge of digital fabrication, computer programming, and electronics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Explorations in Textile Design
description: Course Description: Advanced exploration of textile design aimed at developing unique textiles for a specific end product such as a fashion collection, functional interior design, art textile or surface design competition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; DES 014 or DES 021; DES 015; DES 016; DES 160 or DES 161; or consent of instructor. DES 070 recommended.

name: — Experimental Fashion & Textile Design
description: Course Description: Experimental approaches to fashion and textile design. Emphasis on developing conceptual ideas and translating them into one-of-a-kind garments and soft products. Exploration of a variety of current topics including sustainability, pattern design, new technologies, and social activism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Fashion Drawing: Technical & Illustration
description: Course Description: Exploration of fashion design processes for industry within the social and physical context. Emphasis on two-dimensional conceptualization of ideas, garment construction, and ideation processes utilizing commercial textiles. Field trip required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor; DES 014 recommended.

name: — Functional Apparel Design
description: Course Description: Application of hands-on & theoretical human-centered design processes and methods to functional apparel. Materials and methods for designing functional apparel for extreme environments and activities, performance and bodily function enhancement, health and wellbeing of users. Dynamics of the human body that interact with clothing during environmental and activity-based challenges.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; DES 014; DES 015; and consent of instructor.

name: — Computer-Assisted Fashion Design
description: Course Description: Advanced exploration of apparel design processes for industry and personal expression with emphasis on computer-assisted design applications. Field trip required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 077; DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Design & Wearable Technology
description: Course Description: Introduction to wearable technology and related technologies. Emphasis on designing, and fabricating prototypes of wearable technology for value-added designs and to improve quality of life.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; (DES 037 or DES 111); or consent of instructor.

name: — Fashion Design: Signature Collection
description: Course Description: Advanced exploration of fashion design with an emphasis on professional portfolio development and presentation. Emphasis on conceptualizing, designing, and fabricating a cohesive line of wearable garments suitable for presenting in a public fashion show.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 077; (DES 107 or DES 177); DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Interior Design: Institutional Spaces
description: Course Description: Advanced interior design problems focused on complex institutional spaces. Introduction to building codes related to interior design. Integration of building systems with interior design solutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 021 or DES 051 or DES 150A); or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Interior Architecture
description: Course Description: Advanced problems in interior architectural design emphasizing space planning for corporate and institutional environments. Field trips required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (DES 180A or DES 134B); DES 134A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Exhibition Design
description: Course Description: Design of cultural and commercial exhibition environments, including exhibition development and object selection, spatial planning and architectural finishes, object placement and staging, interpretive strategies, exhibition and promotional graphics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor; DES 051 or DES 150A recommended.

name: — Environmental Graphic Design
description: Course Description: Design of informational and directional graphics for the built environment. Application and integration of typography, imagery and symbols into the architectural landscape. Development of universal wayfinding and graphic navigational systems to help people find their way.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 001; (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor; DES 115 recommended.

name: — Narrative Environments
description: Course Description: Design of storytelling environments and multi-sensory experiences for cultural, commercial, entertainment and public spaces. Interpretive planning and design for specific exhibit audiences. Manipulation of objects and the communication of complex ideas in the exhibition environment. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (DES 185 or DES 186); (DES 014 or DES 021); DES 001; DES 015; DES 016; or consent of instructor.

name: — Proseminar
description: Course Description: Philosophies of design explored through discussion and presentation of research results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Design major or consent of instructor.

name: — Workshops in Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Faculty initiated workshops featuring advanced studies and applications of original work in Design: Costume. Letter grading by contract. Field trips included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 014; DES 015; and consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Workshops in Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Faculty initiated workshops featuring advanced studies and applications of original work in Design: Environment. Letter grading by contract. Field trips included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 014; DES 015; and consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Workshops in Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Faculty initiated workshops featuring advanced studies and applications of original work in Design: Graphics. Letter grading by contract. Field trips included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 014; DES 015; and consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Workshops in Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Faculty initiated workshops featuring advanced studies and applications of original work in Design: Textiles. Letter grading by contract. Field trips included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 014; DES 015; and consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship, off and on campus, in areas of design including graphics, fashion, information, museum, interaction, interiors, lighting, product and textiles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Preparation and presentation of a culminating project. Supervision of an instructor in one of the creative or scholarly areas of Design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; qualification for Letters and Science Honors Program; senior standing; approval of Design Honors Program proposal by the Curriculum Committee and major advisor.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Preparation and presentation of a culminating project. Supervision of an instructor in one of the creative or scholarly areas of Design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 194HA; and consent of instructor; qualification for Letters and Science Honors Program; senior standing.

name: — Tutoring in Design
description: Course Description: Leading of small discussion groups or studio meetings affiliated with one of the department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

name: — Student-Taught Course
description: Course Description: Student-facilitated (taught) course intended for upper division students.

name: — Special Study of Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study of advanced undergraduates.

name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
description: Course Description: Planning and development for student led DES 198F under the supervision of a faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
description: Course Description: Student-facilitated course under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaching a course under 098F/198F.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 199FA; and consent of instructor.

name: — Theory & Issues in Design
description: Course Description: Perspectives on theoretical and aesthetic issues related to the design professions such as methodology in historical and contemporary contexts, implications of technology on design theory and practice, and design relationships to environmental sustainability, recycling, and other social issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Research Methods & Critical Writing for Design
description: Course Description: Focused on research methods and critical writing related to design topics including case studies, original and secondary sources, critical reviews. Expectation of a paper meeting professional standards suitable for publication from each student at end of course.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 221; graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Professional Practice & Ethics in Design
description: Course Description: Introduce students to issues of professional design practice: business ethics, contracts and business practices, social responsibility through case studies, guest lectures and field trips, and readings. Short written assignments and presentations will be required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 221; DES 222; graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Design Research & Teaching
description: Course Description: Work closely with instructor on a research and writing project related to subject matter of undergraduate history courses noted above with the goal of introducing student to advanced historical research processes and development of writing skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 221; DES 222; DES 223; and consent of instructor; concurrent academic appointment (TA) in DES 142A, DES 142B, DES 143, DES 144, DES 145; graduate standing in Design.

name: — Studio Practice in Design
description: Course Description: Students work together on a collective project to experience the multiple phases of design through an iterative process. Design projects will be geared towards relevance in contemporary social, cultural and political contexts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DES 221.

name: — Studio Practice & Critique
description: Course Description: Development of design mastery through individual design process and projects. Risk taking and development of the ability to add form to ideas both speculative and practical. Various design methodologies and creative making. Presentation of works in progress. Communication of effective feedback.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate status in the Department of Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Thesis Exhibition Studio & Critique
description: Course Description: Development of final thesis exhibition. Focus on audience engagement and accessibility. Ideation, content selection, formal development, spatial planning sketches, scaled models, mockups, material testing, sequencing, staging, technical riders, maintenance requirement write-ups. Individual statement writing, collective catalog writing, exhibition promotion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Design
description: Course Description: Selected topics in design methodology, research, communication, and education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Practicum in Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Interaction with a working professional in the student's field of interest to apply theories and concepts to working practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Directed group study for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Focused Study
description: Course Description: Advanced study in studio practice on independent projects with faculty consultation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor.

name: — Project Concentration
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Student creates a body of original work at a professional level, with written and visual documentation of process and concepts underlying the project, culminating in public presentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Design or consent of instructor; minimum of 22 units must be taken in Project Concentration and Individual Focused Study.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Biotechnology Fundamentals & Application
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of molecular biology and chemical engineering involved in recombinant DNA technology. Topics: principles of rate processes of biological systems, optimization of bioreactors, and issues related to overexpression and production of recombinant molecules. Participation in student-directed team projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; MIC 102; or consent of instructor; must be a graduate student in good standing.

name: — Biotechnology Internship
description: Course Description: Research at a biotechnology company or interdisciplinary cross-college lab for a minimum of three months as part of the Designated Emphasis in Biotechnology Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

name: — Current Progress in Biotechnology
description: Course Description: Seminars presented by guest lecturers on subjects of their own research activities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Theatre, Performance & Culture
description: Course Description: Introductory investigation of the nature of performance, moving from performance theory to consideration of various manifestations of performance including theatre, film and media, performance art, dance, sports, rituals, political and religious events, and other "occasions."

name: — Theatre, Performance & Culture
description: Course Description: Introductory investigation of the nature of performance, moving from performance theory to consideration of various manifestations of performance including theatre, film and media, performance art, dance, sports, rituals, political and religious events, and other "occasions."  For Short Term Programs Abroad; may be taught abroad.

name: — Acting: The Basics: History & Practice
description: Course Description: Introduction to the historical evolution of the actor–from ancient Greece & Asia to the Hollywood icon & postdramatic performer–and the practical foundations of acting for stage and screen. Onstage opportunities within lecture course structure.

name: — Understanding Performance: Appreciation of Modern Theatre, Dance, Film & Performance Art
description: Course Description: Relevance of theatre and performance to modern culture, science and society. Approaches to theatre/dance/media/performance art, integrated into Mondavi Center for the Arts and Theatre & Dance Department programs.

name: — Introduction to Acting
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of movement, speech, theatre games, and improvisation. Selected reading and viewing of theatre productions. Intended for students not specializing in Dramatic Art.

name: — Introduction to Contemporary Dance
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic issues and methods in contemporary dance. Focus on preparing the student for dancing and dance-making through basic techniques of improvisation and composition. Consideration of dance as a cultural practice.

name: — Introduction to Dramatic Art
description: Course Description: Understanding and appreciation of both the distinctive and collaborative contributions of playwright, actor, director, and designer to the total work of dramatic art. Study of plays from the major periods of dramatic art in their cultural contexts.

name: — Fundamentals of Acting
description: Course Description: Physical and psychological resources of the actor. Experience in individual and group contact and communication, theatre games, advanced improvisation, sound and movement dynamics. Viewing of theatre productions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Visual Aspects of Dramatic Art
description: Course Description: Understanding and appreciation of the visual aspects of dramatic art: theatre architecture, scenery, lighting, costume, and makeup.

name: — Entertainment Engineering & Management: Stagecraft to Stage Management
description: Course Description: Introduction to  technical production and management in theatre and dance. Topics include stage management, theatrical mechanics, backstage protocols, scenic construction, properties, lighting, basic shop tools, costume shop use and construction, basic make-up, sound equipment, graphics and robotics for theatre.

name: — Theatre Laboratory
description: Course Description: Projects in acting, production, scene design, costuming, lighting, directing, and playwriting. Participation in departmental productions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Beginning Modern Dance
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of modern dance focusing primarily on the development of techniques and creative problem solving. Basic anatomy, dance terminology, and a general overview of modern dance history.

name: — Intermediate Modern Dance
description: Course Description: Modern dance techniques. Basic anatomy, dance terminology and a general overview of modern dance history.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 040A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Beginning Jazz Dance
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of jazz dance; includes warm-ups, dance techniques and combinations. Basic anatomy, dance terminology and general overview of jazz dance history.

name: — Intermediate Jazz Dance
description: Course Description: Warm-ups, dance techniques and combinations at the intermediate level. Basic anatomy, dance terminology and a general overview of jazz styles of historically significant jazz choreographers and leading contemporary jazz choreographers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 041A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Beginning Ballet
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of ballet, focusing on the development of technique through proper alignment, quality, and rhythm. Basic anatomy, ballet terminology, and dance history.

name: — Intermediate Ballet
description: Course Description: Barre and center work at the intermediate level. Development and refinement of technique through proper alignment, rhythmic, and qualitative understanding. Anatomy, ballet terminology, and dance history.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 042A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Contact Improvisation Dance
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of contact improvisation and its applications to all forms of dance, performance, sports, physical safety and health. Solo improvisation, safety, communication, alignment, basic lifting and weight-sharing, intuition, developing relaxed readiness and personal expression.

name: — Intermediate Contact Improvisation
description: Course Description: Building on the fundamentals. Reviewing basics, extended improvising, skillfully working with partners of different sizes and abilities, advanced lifting, advanced safety practices, embracing risk and disorientation, subtle nuances of communication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 043A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Beginning Hip Hop Dance
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of Hip Hop dance focusing on developing a fluid movement vocabulary, facility in body isolations, intricate rhythmic patterning, quick shifts of weight and mastering dance combinations. Discussions on Hip Hop dance history, styles and terminology.

name: — Intermediate Hip Hop Dance
description: Course Description: Expansion of Hip Hop dance vocabulary by focusing on mastering body isolations and intricate rhythmic techniques, complex dance combinations, advanced across the floor sequences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 044A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Contemporary Local, National & Global Theatre, Dance & Performance
description: Course Description: Introduction a range of contemporary theatre, dance and performance in local, national and international settings. Training in critical  approaches to and aesthetic appreciation of these forms. Emphasis varies based on instructor.

name: — History of Theatre & Dance I: Myth, Magic & Madness
description: Course Description: Exploration of aesthetic movements in various disciplines of theatre and dance from the origins to 1550. Examination of Greek, Roman, Sanskrit, Kathakali, Chinese, Japanese, Mesoamerican, Medieval European, and Indigenous theatre and dance including oral, ritual and shamanic performance. Offered once a year.

name: — History of Theatre & Dance II: Romance, Revenge & Rebellion
description: Course Description: Exploration of aesthetic movements in various disciplines of theatre and dance from 1550-1850. Examination of genres related to romance, revenge and rebellion using European, North and South American, and Asian examples. Offered once a year.

name: — History of Theatre & Dance III: Sex, Society & the State
description: Course Description: Exploration of aesthetic movements in various disciplines of theatre and dance from 1850-1968. Examination of melodrama, popular theatre, naturalism, psychological realism, and the avant-garde using European, North and South American, Asian, and African examples. Offered once a year.

name: — Internship in Dramatic Art
description: Course Description: Internship outside the Department of Theatre & Dance enabling students to practice their skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Presentation, Communication & Collaboration
description: Course Description: Use of theater techniques for development of clear oral and physical communication skills that build confidence, presentational style and clarity for students whose command of English is at a competent to fluent level.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Representation & Identity in Culture & Cinema
description: Course Description: Issues of personal and collective identity via study of film narratives from different cultures. Reflection of dominant cultural identities in film. May be taught abroad in Australia.

name: — Theatre on Film
description: Course Description: Study of six/eight plays on film, using mixed casts and raising issues of diversity. Focus: sociohistorical context for production and reception, interpretation and analysis of topics (gender, ethnicity, age, politics, philosophy), and filming, screenwriting, design, and acting/directing for film.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Study of Major Film Makers
description: Course Description: Analysis of the contribution of some outstanding film creators. Study of diverse aesthetic theories of the cinema and their application to selected films.

name: — Design on Screen
description: Course Description: Analysis of the contribution of outstanding designers for cinema, television and filmed entertainment. Study of diverse aesthetic theories of production design and art direction, costume design, or cinematography. Introductory principles and practice, history.

name: — Intermediate Acting/Gateway: The Actor's Toolkit
description: Course Description: Implementation of acting tools drawn predominantly from Stanislavsky’s ‘system’. Gateway into the Advanced Acting courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 021A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Scene Study & Script Analysis
description: Course Description: In-depth study, analysis and performance of texts from different eras, genres and styles. Implementation of tools to undertake independent preparation of character creation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Rehearsal Processes & Practices
description: Course Description: Development of rehearsal practice and etiquette, using a variety of scenes from different eras and genres. Established to enable visiting artists in residence to undertake the instruction, as well as faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Character & Style
description: Course Description: Study of psycho-physical techniques to create characters with an emphasis on non-realistic styles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Devising & Collaboration
description: Course Description: Study and practice of various devising techniques, to collaborate on and produce a series of short etudes and dramatic scenes/short plays.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Shakespeare & His Contemporaries
description: Course Description: Study and performance of classical texts (monologues and dialogues), with a focus on Shakespeare and the Elizabethan world view.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Acting: Special Topics in Acting
description: Course Description: Intensive study and practical exploration of a specialized area; for example, World Theatre, Social Theatre, Physical Theatre, Musical Theatre, the Ancient Greeks, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Theatrical Design: Scenery
description: Course Description: Scene design processes, working drawings, sketching techniques, scale models, methods and materials of scenery construction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Theatrical Design: Scenery
description: Course Description: Analysis of plays in terms of scene design, elements of design, execution of designs for modern and period plays.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Theatrical Design: Lighting
description: Course Description: Theories of lighting the stage, equipment and control systems, execution of lighting plots.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Theatrical Design: Costume
description: Course Description: Source materials for theatrical costuming, selecting fabrics, elements of design, analysis of plays in terms of costume design, execution of designs for modern and period plays.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Costume Design for Film
description: Course Description: Theory and practice of the art and business of film costume design. Script analysis, costume research, developing design concepts, budgeting, and current production practices and methods. Execution of designs for period and contemporary films. Viewing of current films.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Scenic Painting: Studio
description: Course Description: Scene painting techniques, practices and materials including color mixing and matching, wood graining, faux painting techniques, glazing, creating foliage, stone and brick.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 024 or DRA 028; or consent of instructor. Upper division standing in Theatre  Dance, Art Studio, or Design.

name: — Principles of Performing Arts Stage Management
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Stage management principles for theatre, dance, musical theatre, music, and concerts. The dynamical role of the stage manager in the performing arts, upper-management team.

name: — Topics in Entertainment Engineering
description: Course Description: Engineering topics faced by technical designers in live entertainment. Project-based exploration of: theatrical rigging, scenic automation, the role of the technical director, and structural design for the stage.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 028 C- or better; consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Directing
description: Course Description: Director's creative approach to the play and to its staging.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Directing
description: Course Description: Director's creative approach to the actor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 127A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Theatre Sound
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of sound, sound equipment, and sound design as used in modern theatre and other performance venues. Assembly, set-up, and operation of basic theatre sound reinforcement system, recording system, and theatrical playback system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Approaches to Theatrical Design: Practice & Theory
description: Course Description: Advanced design study in specific areas including but not limited to: research, design styles and concepts, new materials and techniques, scenery, lighting, costume, makeup, photography, projections, computer technology, spectacle and special effects, and alternative theatre forms and genres.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 124A or DRA 124B or DRA 124C or DRA 124D or DRA 124E; upper division standing in Theatre  Dance, Art Studio or Design; or consent of instructor.

name: — Voice in Performance
description: Course Description: Progression of exercises to free, develop and strengthen the voice, as a human and then as an actor's instrument with emphasis on how the voice works, to freeing the channel for sound, to interpersonal communication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 021B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Dance Composition
description: Course Description: Introduction to the craft of choreography. Compose phrases and present movement studies based on the elements of choreography: motivation, space, time, force/energy.
