name: — Research Group Conferences in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Course Description: Research group conferences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

name: — Internship in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in electrical and computer engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Completion of a minimum of 84 units; project approval before period of internship.

name: — Senior Design Project
description: Course Description: Team design project for seniors in Electrical or Computer Engineering. Project involves analysis, design, implementation and evaluation of an Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering system. Project is supervised by a faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 196 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

name: — Senior Design Project
description: Course Description: Team design project for seniors in Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering. Project involves analysis, design, implementation and evaluation of an Electrical Engineering or Computer Engineering system. Project supervised by a faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 193A.

name: — Autonomous Vehicle Design Project
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Design and construct an autonomous race car. Work in groups to design, build and test speed control circuits, track sensing circuits, and a steering control loop.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECS 036A or EEC 007); EEC 018; (EEC 110B or EEC 157A (can be concurrent) or ECS 036B).

name: — Autonomous Vehicle Design Project
description: Course Description: Design and construct an autonomous race car. Students work in groups to design, build and test speed control circuits, track sensing circuits, and a steering control loop.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 195A.

name: — Issues in Engineering Design
description: Course Description: Covers various electrical and computer engineering standards and realistic design constraints including economic, manufacturability, sustainability, ethical, health & safety, environmental, social, and political.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing in Electrical or Computer Engineering.

name: — Tutoring in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Course Description: Tutoring in Electrical & Computer Engineering courses, especially introductory circuits. For upper division undergraduate students who will provide tutorial assistance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Navigating Graduate School
description: Course Description: Practical and non-technical skills necessary for first-year students in the Electrical & Computer Engineering Graduate Group. Mentorship, time management, research ethics, science communication, intellectual property.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year Electrical  Computer Engineering graduate student, Electrical  Computer Engineering transfer student, or instructor approval.

name: — Digital Signal Processing
description: Course Description: Theory and design of digital filters. Classification of digital filters, linear phase systems, all-pass functions, FIR and IIR filter design methods and optimality measures, numerically robust structures for digital filters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150B; STA 120 or MAT 131 or MAT 167 recommended.

name: — Computational Methods in Biomedical Imaging
description: Course Description: Analytic tomographic reconstruction from projections in 2D and 3D; model-based image reconstruction methods; maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods; applications to CT, PET, and SPECT.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIM 105 or STA 120); (BIM 108 or EEC 150A).

name: — Digital Image Processing
description: Course Description: Two-dimensional systems theory, image perception, sampling and quantization, transform theory and applications, enhancement, filtering and restoration, image analysis, and image processing systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150B.

name: — MOS Analog Circuit Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analysis and design of MOS amplifiers, bias circuits, voltage references and other analog circuits. Stability and compensation of feedback amplifiers. Introduction to noise analysis in MOS circuits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 110B; EEC 140A.

name: — Advanced Analog Circuit Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Noise and distortion in electronic circuits and systems. Application to communication circuits. Specific applications include mixers, low-noise amplifiers, power amplifiers, phase-locked loops, oscillators and receiver architectures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 210; STA 131A and EEC 112 recommended.

name: — Analog MOS IC Design for Signal Processing
description: Course Description: Analysis and design of analog MOS integrated circuits. Passive components, Single-ended and fully differential op amps, Sampled-data and continuous-time filters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 210.

name: — Data-Conversion Techniques & Circuits
description: Course Description: Digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion; component characteristics and matching; sample-and-hold, comparator, amplifier, and reference circuits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 210.

name: — Integrated Circuit Design for Power Electronics
description: Course Description: IC design for power electronics. Linear and switching regulation. Integrated power management. DC/DC and AC/DC conversion. Applications in portable electronics and wireless sensors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 210.

name: — Circuits for Digital Communications
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analog, digital, and mixed-signal CMOS implementations of communication-circuit blocks: gain control, adaptive equalizers, sampling detectors, clock recovery.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150B; EEC 210 (can be concurrent); EEC 165, EEC 166, or EEC 265 recommended.

name: — Low Power Digital Integrated Circuit Design
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Integrated circuit design for low power and energy consumption. Low power architectures, logic styles and circuit design. Variable supply and threshold voltages. Leakage management. Power estimation. Energy sources, power electronics, and energy recovery. Applications in portable electronics and sensors. Thermodynamic limits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 118.

name: — Radio Frequency & Microwave Filter Design
description: Course Description: Design of radio frequency and microwave filters including filter specification and approximation theory. Passive LC filter design covers doubly-terminated reactance two-port synthesis and coupling matrix based synthesis. Active filter design includes sensitivity, op-amp building blocks, and cascade filter design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132A; or consent of instructor.

name: — RF IC Design
description: Course Description: Radio frequency (RF) solid-state devices, RF device modeling and design rules; non-linear RF circuit design techniques; use of non-linear computer-aided (CAD) tools; RF power amplifier design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 210.

name: — RF Integrated Circuits for Wireless Communications
description: Course Description: Integrated RF front end circuit design of receivers and synthesizers for wireless communications, such as LNA, mixers, PLL; noise and linearity analysis and specifications; theory and working mechanism of synthesizers and phase noise analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132A; EEC 112.

name: — Terahertz & mm-Wave Integrated Circuit Design
description: Course Description: Fundamental theory of RF transmitter and receiver, including noise analysis, transceiver architectures, and antenna arrays. Fundamental limitations, theory and design of amplifiers, oscillators and signal sources at THz and mm-wave frequencies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132A; EEC 112; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Microwave Circuit & Device Design Techniques
description: Course Description: Theory, design, fabrication, analysis of advanced microwave circuits and devices. Wideband transformers, stripline/microstripline broadband couplers. Lumped and distributed filter synthesis. Broadband matching theory applied to microwave devices. Wideband and low noise FET/HEMT amplifiers. Advanced microwave oscillator theory. Phase noise analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132B.

name: — RF-MEMS & Adaptive Wireless Frontends
description: Course Description: Focuses on the modeling, design, fabrication, and characterization of RF-MEMS while providing a thorough introduction to the technology with an emphasis on how it will benefit the design of adaptive RF/microwave wireless systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130A.

name: — Electromagnetics
description: Course Description: Maxwell's equations, plane waves, reflection and refraction, complex waves, waveguides, resonant cavities, and basic antennas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130B.

name: — Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion I
description: Course Description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

name: — Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion II
description: Course Description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 231A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion III
description: Course Description: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 231B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Applied Electromagnetics I
description: Course Description: The exact formulation of applied electromagnetic problems using Green's functions. Applications of these techniques to transmission circuits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132B or EEC 230.

name: — Advanced Applied Electromagnetics II
description: Course Description: An advanced treatment of electromagnetics with applications to passive microwave devices and antennas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 132B.

name: — High Speed Signal Integrity
description: Course Description: Design and analysis of interconnects in high-speed circuits and sub-systems; understanding of high-speed signal propagation and signal integrity concepts; electromagnetic modeling tools and experimental techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130B.

name: — Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices I
description: Course Description: Physics & technology of electron beam emission, flow and transport, electron gun design, space charge waves & klystrons with applications to accelerator systems, RF power sources for radar & communication systems, thermionic energy conversion, and electric space propulsion. Recent advances in materials & manufacturing technologies are also reviewed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): B.S. degree in physics or engineering or the equivalent background or consent of instructor.

name: — Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices II
description: Course Description: Theory, modeling, & experimental design of traveling wave tubes, backward wave oscillators, and extended interaction oscillators employed in satellite commutations, plasma imaging, and underground imaging systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 234A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices III
description: Course Description: Physics & technology of gyrotrons, gyro-amplifiers, free electron lasers, magnetrons, cross-field amplifiers, and relativistic devices employed in plasma fusion reactors, microwave heating, and high power microwave applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 234B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Photonics
description: Course Description: Optical propagation of electromagnetic waves and beams in photonic components and the design of such devices using numerical techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130B; EEC 230 recommended.

name: — Nonlinear Optical Applications
description: Course Description: Nonlinear optical interactions in optical communication, optical information processing and integrated optics. Basic concepts underlying optical nonlinear interactions in materials and guided media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130B; EEC 230 (can be concurrent).

name: — Lasers
description: Course Description: Theoretical and practical description of lasers. Theory of population inversion, amplification and oscillation using semiclassical oscillator model and rate equations. Description and design of real laser system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 235; EEC 130B; or the equivalent of EEC 130B.

name: — Laser Physics II
description: Course Description: Oscillation threshold. Coupled cavity/atomic rate equations, Linear pulse propagation; dispersion, broadening, compression. Nonlinear pulse propagation. Energy extraction. Optical beams, resonators, eigenmodes, axial/transverse modes. Paraxial ray optics, resonator stability, ABCD matrices. Laser dynamics; transients, spiking, Q-switching, active and passive modelocking.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 237A or EAD 265A.

name: — Semiconductor Lasers & Photonic Integration
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Understanding of fundamental optical transitions in semiconductors and quantum-confined systems are applied to diode & unipolar lasers and selected photonic devices. The importance of radiative and non-radiative recombination, simulated emission, excitons in quantum wells, and strained quantum layers are considered. Photonic integrated circuits based on active (with optical gain) and passive (without optical gain).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 140A.

name: — Optical Communication Technologies  for High-Speed Data Networking
description: Course Description: Enabling technologies for optical fiber communication and data center networks. Physical layer issues for component and system technologies in high-speed data optical communications. High-capacity data multiplexing technologies including wavelength-division-multiplexing, time-division-multiplexing, and advanced coherent modulation. Optical signal transmission, optical amplification, and optical switching for telecom and data center networks.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130B.

name: — High-Capacity Optical Data Systems & Networks
description: Course Description: High-capacity optical data systems and networks, built-on modern optical communication technologies. Technologies behind data center networking, software defined networking, and RF-optical networking. Physical layer issues in light of networking architectures and protocols. Optical communications systems design and integration. Systems technologies and higher-level network architecture, case studies. WDM, TDM, and EON networking, optical and wireless access technologies based on PON and ROF.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 239A.

name: — Semiconductor Device Physics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Physical principles, characteristics and models of fundamental semiconductor device types, including P-N and Schottky diodes, MOSFETs and MESFETs Bipolar Junction Transistors, and light emitters/detectors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 140B.

name: — Introduction to Molecular Electronics
description: Course Description: Examines molecules for electronic devices and sensors. Covers: electronic states of molecules, charge transport in nanoscale systems, and fabrication and measurement of molecular-scale devices. Specific Topics: Hartree-Fock & Density Functional Theory, Landauer formalism, coulomb blockade, tunneling and hopping transport.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Nanostructured Devices
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Physics of nano-structured materials and device operation. Overview of new devices enabled by nanotechnology; fabrication and characterization methods; applications of nano-structures and devices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 130A; EEC 140A.

name: — Optical Imaging & Microscopy
description: Course Description: Theory and techniques of optical imaging & microscopy. Fourier optics; light propagation & light detection; imaging contrast mechanisms; optical & microscopy techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B; EEC130AB recommended.

name: — Introduction to Neuroengineering
description: Course Description: Survey of neuroengineering field from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication technology; optical and electrical techniques to monitor and modulate neural activity; computational tools and control systems; prosthetics and human machine interfaces; human performance and rehabilitation; cognitive neuroengineering; neuroethics; extensive proposal development to merge aforementioned themes into a multidisciplinary project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; or consent of instructor.

name: — Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
description: Course Description: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Projects in IC Fabrication
description: Course Description: Individualized projects in the fabrication of analog or digital integrated electronic or optoelectronic circuits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 146B.

name: — Advanced Semiconductor Devices
description: Course Description: Semiconductor devices, including MOSFETs, heterojunction transistors, light-emitting diodes, lasers, sensors, detectors, power and high-voltage transistors, MEMS resonators, organic semiconductors and photovoltaics. All material is from recent literature, encouraging students to utilize search methods and critically assess the latest research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Engineering.

name: — Photovoltaics & Solar Cells
description: Course Description: Physics and application of photovoltaics and solar cells, including design, fabrication technology, and grid incorporation. Mono and microcrystalline silicon devices; thin-film technologies, heterojunction and organic-semiconductor technologies. Collectors, electrical inverters and infrastructure issues. Challenges and concerns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 140B; or consent of instructor, or equivalent.

name: — Nanofabrication
description: Course Description: Theory and practice of nanofabrication (top-down and bottom-up approaches), used for producing integrated circuits, electronic devices, sensors, and microstructures. Process development and characterization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Engineering.

name: — Linear Systems & Signals
description: Course Description: Mathematical description of systems. Selected topics in linear algebra. Solution of the state equations and an analysis of stability, controllability, observability, realizations, state feedback and state estimation. Discrete-time signals and systems, and the Z-transform.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150A.

name: — Nonlinear Systems
description: Course Description: Nonlinear differential equations, second-order systems, approximation methods, bifurcations, Lyapunov stability, absolute stability, Popov criterion, circle criterion, sliding-mode control, feedback linearization techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 250.

name: — Multivariable Control System Design
description: Course Description: Review of single-loop feedback design. Stability, performance and robustness of multi-input multi-output control systems. H-infinity design. Frequency response methods. Optimization-based design. Algebraic design methods for uncertain systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 250.

name: — Optimization
description: Course Description: Modeling optimization problems in engineering design and other applications; optimality conditions; unconstrained optimization (gradient, Newton, conjugate gradient and quasi-Newton methods); duality and Lagrangian relaxation constrained optimization. (Primal method and an introduction to penalty and augmented Lagrangian methods.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022A; Knowledge of FORTRAN or C.

name: — Robotic Systems
description: Course Description: Introduction to robotic systems. Mechanical manipulators, kinematics, manipulator positioning and path planning. Dynamics of manipulators. Robot motion programming and control algorithm design.

name: — Reinforcement Learning
description: Course Description: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is the subset of machine learning, the core of artificial intelligence. Topics include fundamentals of RL, bandit problems, Markov decision processes, and dynamic programming.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 260; or the equivalent.

name: — Random Signals & Noise
description: Course Description: Random processes as probabilistic models for signals and noise. Probability and random variables, Convergence and limit theorems, Specification of random processes, Markov Chains, Wiener process and white Gaussian noise, Poisson process and shot noise, Processing and frequency analysis of random signals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150A; EEC 161.

name: — Signal Processing for Communications
description: Course Description: Signal processing in wireless and wireline communication systems. Characterization and distortion of wireless and wireline channels. Channel equalization and maximum likelihood sequence estimation. Channel precoding and pre-equalization. OFDM and transmit diversity. Array processing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 165; EEC 260; or consent of instructor.

name: — Multi-access Communications Theory
description: Course Description: Maximum stable throughput of Poisson collision channels. Classic collision resolution algorithms. Carrier sensing multiple access and its performance analysis. System stability analysis. Joint design of the physical/medium access control layers. Capacity region of multi-access channels. Multi-access with correlated sources.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EEC 173A or ECS 152A); STA 120; or equivalent of STA 120.

name: — Optimal & Adaptive Filtering
description: Course Description: Geometric formulation of least-squares estimation problems. Theory and applications of optimum Wiener and Kalman filtering. MAP and maximum likelihood estimation of hidden Markov models, Viterbi algorithm. Adaptive filtering algorithms, properties and applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 260.

name: — Estimation & Detection of Signals in Noise
description: Course Description: Introduction to parameter estimation and detections of signals in noise. Bayes and Neyman-Pearson likelihood-ratio tests for signal detection. Maximum-likelihood parameter estimation. Detection of known and Gaussian signals in white or colored noise. Applications to communications, radar, signal processing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 260.

name: — Principles of Digital Communications
description: Course Description: Introduction to digital communications. Coding for analog sources. Characterization of signals and systems. Modulation and demodulation for the additive Gaussian channel. Digital signaling over bandwidth-constrained linear filter channels and over fading multipath channels. Spread spectrum signals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 165; EEC 260; or consent of instructor.

name: — Information Theory & Coding
description: Course Description: Topics include Entropy, Relatively Entropy, Mutual Information; Asymptotic Equipartition Property; Entropy Rates of Stochastic Process; Data Compression; Channel Capacity; Differential Entropy; Gaussian Channel; Rate Distortion Theory; Network Information Theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 161.

name: — Mobile Communications
description: Course Description: Time-varying multi-path fading channel models and receiver performance in fading channels; multiple access techniques and multiple access receivers design and performance; optimum design and the capacity of wireless channels.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 260; EEC 265 (can be concurrent).

name: — Error Correcting Codes I
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the theory and practice of block codes,  linear block codes, cyclic codes, decoding algorithms, coding techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022A; EEC 160.

name: — Error Correcting Codes II
description: Course Description: Introduction to convolutional codes, turbo codes, trellis and block coded modulation codes,soft-decision decoding algorithms, the Viterbi algorithm,reliability-based decoding, trellis-based decoding, multistage decoding.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 165; EEC 269A.

name: — Computer Architecture
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to modern techniques for high-performance single and multiple processor systems. Topics include advanced pipeline design, advanced memory hierarchy design, optimizing pipeline and memory use, and memory sharing among multiprocessors. Case studies of recent single and multiple processor systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 170 or ECS 154B.

name: — High-Performance Computer Architecture
description: Course Description: Designing and analysis of high performance computer architecture with emphasis on vector processing, on-chip interconnect networks, chip-level multiprocessors, memory and storage subsystem design and impact of technological advances on computer architecture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 270 or ECS 201A.

name: — Networking Architecture & Resource Management
description: Course Description: Design & implementation principles of networking architecture and protocols. Internet, data center, and telephony case studies. Topics: Internet data & control planes; application & services; resource management; Quality of Service (QoS) provisioning; traffic engineering; performance evaluation, software-defined networks, & future research issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 152A or EEC 173A.

name: — Modern Parallel Computing
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Exploration of the architecture of modern parallel computers, their programming models, and their programming systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 036B or ECS 034; EEC 170 or ECS 154A recommended.

name: — VLSI Digital Signal Processing
description: Course Description: Digital signal processors, building blocks, and algorithms. Design and implementation of processor algorithms, architectures, control, functional units, and circuit topologies for increased performance and reduced circuit size and power dissipation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150B; EEC 170; (EEC 180 or EEC 180B); or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Design Verification of Digital Systems
description: Course Description: Design verification techniques for digital systems; simulation-based design verification techniques; formal verification techniques, including equivalence checking, model checking, and theorem proving; timing analysis and verification; application of design cerification techniques to microprocessors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 170; (EEC 018 or EEC 180A).

name: — Design & Optimization of Embedded Computing Systems
description: Course Description: Introduction to design and optimization of digital computing systems for embedded applications. Topics include combinatorial optimization techniques, performance and energy optimization in embedded systems, compilation and architecture-specific mapping, programmable and reconfigurable platforms; design automation and algorithmic improvements to design process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 170; (EEC 180 or EEC 180B); or consent of instructor. ECS 122A recommended.

name: — Introduction to Digital System Testing
description: Course Description: Review of several current techniques used to detect physical faults in both combinational and sequential circuits. Topics include fault modeling, fault simulation, test generation, compression techniques, and testing architectures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 018.

description: Course Description: Special topics in Computer Science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Course Description: Discussion and presentation of current research and development in Electrical & Computer Engineering.

name: — Graduate Research Group Conference in Electrical & Computer Engineering
description: Course Description: Research problems, progress, and techniques in electrical and computer engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Capstone Project For MS Plan II
description: Course Description: Conducting research projects in electrical and computer engineering. Communicating research results in written reports and oral presentations. Systemic project implementation to answer a comprehensive scientific or technical question in the area of electrical and computer engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Solid-State Circuit Research Laboratory Seminar
description: Course Description: Lectures on solid-state circuit and system design by various visiting experts in the field.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Seminar in Solid-State Technology
description: Course Description: Lectures on solid-state technology by various visiting experts in the field.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Computer Engineering Research Seminar
description: Course Description: Lectures, tutorials and seminars on topics in computer engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Communications, Signal & Image Processing Seminar
description: Course Description: Communications, signal and image processing, video engineering and computer vision.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Systems, Control & Robotics Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminars on current research in systems and control by faculty and visiting experts. Technical presentations and lectures on current topics in robotics research and robotics technology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Photonics Research Seminar
description: Course Description: Lectures on photonics and related areas by faculty and visiting experts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — The Teaching of Electrical Engineering
description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant or associate-in in a designated engineering course. Methods of leading discussion groups or laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, use of laboratory equipment, and grading laboratory reports.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Meet qualifications for teaching assistant and/or associate-in in Electrical Engineering.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching Assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
description: Course Description: Intended to give the undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students will learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies, using examples from ongoing studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate student in good academic standing at UC Davis.

name: — Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic Preceptorship
description: Course Description: Directed towards the undergraduate students at UC Davis that volunteer at the Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic (JVMC).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
description: Course Description: Intended to give the upper division undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate student in good academic standing at UC Davis.

name: — Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic (JVMC) Student Volunteer
description: Course Description: Field experience in health care delivery, patient histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up. Students must apply and interview.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: For students interested in working on specific EM projects in a more extensive way. Must commit at least four hours per week for two quarters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; experienced RA's who have successfully performed in the EMRAP program for a minimum of three quarters; must have database skills.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Directed research in the Department of Emergency Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Preceptorship in Emergency Medicine
description: Course Description: Exposure to the specialty of Emergency Medicine and observation of a wide array of patients in the Emergency Department.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
description: Course Description: First in a longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

name: — Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
description: Course Description: Second longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

name: — Introduction to Medical Toxicology
description: Course Description: In-depth review of clinical and medical toxicologic emergencies. Rotation includes contact with toxicology trained emergency faculty, didactic lectures, journal club, simulation training and exposure to a very busy poison control center.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good standing.

name: — Diagnostic Medicine for the Undifferentiated Patient
description: Course Description: Distance Learning Didactic Elective. Develop skills for clinical assessment and diagnostic planning for common acute complaints. Develop a process for further expansion of clinical assessment skills that can be utilized for any chief complaint. Develop a broad differential diagnosis based solely on the chief complaint; “scripts” are created. Problem-based learning, self-study, and a diagnostic modality project is utilized.

name: — Wilderness Medicine
description: Course Description: Introductory elective course for students to explore how physicians can interact with the environment in austere conditions through lectures, hands-on/field experience, and case-based learning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Emergency Medicine Clerkship
description: Course Description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery, and Pediatric Clerkship.

name: — Emergency Medicine Ultrasound for Fourth-Year Medical Student
description: Course Description: Intended for students interested in learning both the technical and cognitive skills of bedside ultrasound. Emphasis will be on the use of ultrasound in emergency medicine as a diagnostic tool and in procedural guidance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year Medical Student in good standing; interest in Emergency Medicine or Critical Care is recommended; EMR 440 or equivalent is recommended prior to the rotation.

name: — Ambulatory Elective in Emergency Medicine
description: Course Description: Credit will be given for approved non-AI Emergency Medicine courses at other institutions to which there is not an equal learning experience at UC Davis.

name: — Focus on POCUS A
description: Course Description: Directed towards gaining a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for those pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Focus on POCUS B
description: Course Description: Directed towards gaining a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for those pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Externship in Emergency Medicine
description: Course Description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery and Pediatrics.

name: — Pediatric Emergency Medicine Clerkship
description: Course Description: See patients in the Pediatric area of the Emergency Department under the supervision of an Emergency Medicine Attending. Emphasis on recognition and management of the acutely ill pediatric patient and treatment of common pediatric complaints.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery, and Pediatrics.

name: — Addiction Medicine; Advanced Clinical Clerkship
description: Course Description: Consists primarily of clinical experiences, with complementary didactics. Clinical experiences will be multidisciplinary, working with drug and alcohol counselors, harm reduction workers, and physicians in family medicine, emergency medicine, internal medicine, and psychiatry. Clinical skills focus on risk factors, diagnosis, comorbidities, and treatment of substance use disorders.

name: — Understanding Health Policy: A Focus on Analysis & Translation
description: Course Description: Paradigm of healthcare delivery in the U.S. is changing rapidly. To prepare the next generation of physician leaders, provide the skills, tools, and knowledge needed to impact decisions made at the policy level.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Emergency Procedures Elective
description: Course Description: Simulator-based skills training for emergency procedures. Topics include airway management, central venous access, chest tube placement, and general critical care resuscitation skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current basic life support (BLS) certification.

name: — Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Elective where topics may be selected in either basic or clinical research areas of Emergency and/or Critical Care Medicine. The goals will be tailored to each individual student. Enrollment requires prior discussion and consent of instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Endocrinology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in endocrinology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Endocrinology research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Endocrinology Clinical Clerkship
description: Course Description: Participation with members of subspecialty service in the initial evaluation, work-up, management and follow-up of patients with endocrinologic disorders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Clinical Nutrition Clerkship
description: Course Description: In-depth experience in assessment and monitoring of nutritional support of patients whose illnesses are complicated by malnutrition and of patients with problems in under-nutrition due to various illnesses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; consent of instructor of record.

name: — Insights in Endocrinology
description: Course Description: First- or second-year students observe in morning Endocrine and Diabetes clinics; attend bi-weekly noon and afternoon endocrine conferences. Present brief endocrine physiology oral presentation to the endocrine group.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in good academic standing.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Energy Systems
description: Course Description: Technical, societal and environmental components of energy systems at global, national and regional scales from an interdisciplinary perspective. Energy resources; end-uses and demand; electricity systems; energy efficiency; energy justice; energy emissions; energy policy.

name: — Life Cycle Assessment for Sustainable Engineering
description: Course Description: Life cycle assessment methodology. Emphasis on applications to infrastructure and energy systems. Life cycle design, life cycle cost methods, other tools from industrial ecology, and links to policy.

name: — Energy & Climate Policy
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of energy technology, economics, and policy. Survey and analysis of current and prospective climate policies at the local and global level, including but not limited to cap-and-trade, emissions offsets, intensity standards, technology standards, mandates and subsidies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100A or ARE 100A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Energy Seminar
description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in energy. Topics vary and will be announced at the beginning of each quarter. Seminar speakers include invited speakers from outside the university as well as faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Engineering
description: Course Description: Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

name: — Introduction to Engineering Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Introduction to Engineering Design
description: Course Description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills  integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Engineering Graphics in Design
description: Course Description: Engineering design, descriptive geometry, pictorial sketching, computer-aided graphics, and their application in the solution of engineering problems.

name: — Engineering Problem Solving
description: Course Description: Methodology for solving engineering problems. Engineering computing and visualization based on MATLAB. Engineering examples and applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better); (MAT 016B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 017B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 021B C- or better (can be concurrent)).

name: — Introduction to Entrepreneurship
description: Course Description: Students from all majors will learn the processes involved in modern entrepreneurship and identify an opportunity for innovation. The 3 C's of the entrepreneurial mindset (developed by KEEN) will be covered: Curiosity, Connections, and Creating Values.

name: — The Science Behind the Technology in Our Lives
description: Course Description: Understanding of how the technology in our lives works using only basic concepts and rudimentry mathematics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

name: — Issues in Engineering
description: Course Description: Engineering profession and its role in society; engineering design and development process; introduction to the engineering grand challenges; and professional resources for students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Issues in Engineering
description: Course Description: Engineering disciplines; the engineering profession’s methods, principles, and career opportunities; professional resources for students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Circuits I
description: Course Description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C; C- or better recommended.

name: — Circuits I
description: Course Description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C.

name: — Introduction to Space Exploration: Understanding the Technological & Environmental Challenges
description: Course Description: Introductory overview of the space environment. Discussion of space exploration technology including propulsion, orbital mechanics, and spacecraft engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school level Algebra, Geometry, General Science (Physics and Chemistry).

name: — Statics
description: Course Description: Force systems and equilibrium conditions with emphasis on engineering problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A C- or better or PHY 009HA C- or better); MAT 021D C- or better (can be concurrent).

name: — Properties of Materials
description: Course Description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); CHE 002A C- or better; PHY 009A C- or better.

name: — Honors Properties of Materials
description: Course Description: Examination of special materials science and engineering topics through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045 (can be concurrent) or ENG 045Y (can be concurrent); enrollment in the Materials Science and Engineering Honors Program; ENG 045 or ENG 045Y required concurrently.

name: — Properties of Materials
description: Course Description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); CHE 002A C- or better; PHY 009A C- or better.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Electronic Circuits & Systems
description: Course Description: Introduction to analog and digital circuit and system design through hands on laboratory design projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 017; C- or better recommended.

name: — Dynamics
description: Course Description: Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

name: — Fluid Mechanics
description: Course Description: Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis and boundary-layer flows.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; PHY 009B C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

name: — Mechanics of Materials
description: Course Description: Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams. Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

name: — Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
description: Course Description: Experiments which illustrate the basic principles and verify the analysis procedures used in the mechanics of materials are performed using the basic tools and techniques of experimental stress analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 104.

name: — Thermodynamics
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics: heat energy and work, properties of pure substances, First and Second Law for closed and open systems, reversibility, entropy, thermodynamic temperature scales. Applications of thermodynamics to engineering systems. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

name: — Engineering Economics
description: Course Description: Analysis of problems in engineering economy; the selection of alternatives; replacement decisions. Compounding, tax, origins and cost of capital, economic life, and risk and uncertainty are applied to methods of selecting most economic alternatives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in Engineering.

name: — Launching a Company
description: Course Description: Technological innovation and product development. Working as a team to turn ideas into companies through customer development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 008 or consent of instructor.

name: — Electric Machinery Fundamentals
description: Course Description: Principles of AC and DC electric motors and generators, their control systems and power sources. Selection of electric power equipment components based on their construction features and performance characteristics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 017 C- or better.

name: — Fluid Power Actuators & Systems
description: Course Description: Hydraulic and pneumatic systems with emphasis on analysis and control of actuators. Design of hydraulic and pneumatic systems, specification and sizing of components, and selection of electro-hydraulics/electro-pneumatics, servo valves, and closed loop systems to solve basic control problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 100 C- or better; ENG 102 C- or better.

name: — Introduction to Mechanical Vibrations
description: Course Description: Free and forced vibrations in lumped-parameter systems with and without damping; vibrations in coupled systems; electromechanical analogs; use of energy conservation principles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better; (ENG 006 C- or better or ENG 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better); ability to program in MATLAB.

name: — Environmental Physics & Society
description: Course Description: Impact of humankind on the environment are discussed from the point of view of the physical sciences. Calculations based on physical principles will be made, and the resulting policy implications are considered.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009D or PHY 010 or PHY 001B); MAT 016B; or the equivalent of MAT 016B.

name: — Engineering Analysis
description: Course Description: Solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations; approximation methods; solutions of ordinary differential equations; initial and boundary value problems; solutions of partial differential equations of Elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic types; Eigen value problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better or ECS 036A C- or better); ((MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)).

name: — Science & Technology of Sustainable Power Generation
description: Course Description: Focus on scientific understanding and development of power generation that is the basis of modern society. Concentration on power generation methods that are sustainable, in particular, discussion of the most recent innovations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007C or PHY 009C; upper division standing.

name: — Professional Responsibilities of Engineers
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Organization of the engineering profession; introduction to contracts, specifications, business law, patents, and liability; discussion of professional, ethical, societal, and political issues related to engineering.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: — Technology Management
description: Course Description: Management of the engineering and technology activity. Functions of design, planning, production, marketing, sales, and maintenance. Technological product life cycle. Research and development activity. Project planning and organization. Manufacturing issues. Case studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Literature
description: Course Description: Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Writers' Workshop
description: Course Description: Focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content for a writing task; to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Fiction
description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing fiction. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing creative non-fiction. Work in prescribed literary forms (such as essay, meditation, biography, memoir, book review, documentary, or experimental non-fiction forms) and forms of students' choosing. No final examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Poetry
description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: — Literatures in English I: To 1700
description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and consumption.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Literatures in English II: 1700-1900
description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1700-1900. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, colonization, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. America, Britain, Ireland, Scotland, and India as important sites of English literary production and consumption.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Literatures in English III: 1900 to Present
description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1900-present. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. Formal experimentation. Modernism as transnational phenomenon.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Introductory Topics in Literature
description: Course Description: Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Introductory Topics in Literature & Media
description: Course Description: Study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and moving-image media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

name: — Approaches to Reading
description: Course Description: Close reading and interpretation of literature from a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches. Topics include traditional textual and historical approaches; new criticism; formalism; psychological criticism; feminism and gender; reader-response; materialist approaches. Frequent written assignments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

name: — Introductory Topics in Drama
description: Course Description: Close reading of, and topics relating to selected works of British and American drama from a range of historical periods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Introductory Topics in Fiction
description: Course Description: Close reading of, and topics relating to, British and American Fiction: short stories, novellas, novels.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

name: — Introductory Topics in Poetry
description: Course Description: Topical study and close reading of selections from English and American poetry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

name: — Hot Bars, Supreme Lyrics, & Rhymes for Days: Hip Hop as Poetry
description: Course Description: Literary approaches to hip hop as poetry. Formal examination of rap lyrics in relation to technology, visual expression, dance, and knowledge production. Historical and cultural consideration of race, ethnicity, gender, urban culture, and politics.

name: — Pop Culture Shakespeare
description: Course Description: Critical approaches to the study of Shakespeare’s afterlife in contemporary American media. Focus on visual, audio, and kinesthetic modes of analysis and presentation. Relation of Shakespeare to contemporary society, politics, media, and economics.

name: — Youth in Revolt
description: Course Description: American literary and cultural representations of adolescence as a time of rebellious refusals and wild behaviors in relation to questions of gender and sexuality, psychological states, economic pressures, racial inequality, and methods of discipline and punishment.

name: — Literature, Health, &  Medicine
description: Course Description: Literary and cultural representations of health and medicine in relation to issues of race, gender, sexuality, and disability. Narratives and reading practices that provide complex accounts of the social determinants of health, contested understandings of illness, and critical perspectives on biomedicine.

name: — Literary Animals
description: Course Description: Literary exploration of animals as spectacles, symbols, scientific objects, human companions, and speaking subjects through animal fables and allegories, tales for children, poems, realist narratives, essays, and experimental fictions.

name: — Speculative Fictions
description: Course Description: Historical or thematic exploration of speculative genres such as science fiction, fantasy, utopia/dystopia, and/or horror. May include worldbuilding, intersections with scientific and other disciplinary knowledges, relation to social and political conditions.

name: — Racial Imaginaries
description: Course Description: Critical vocabularies and frameworks for studying the cultural construction of race as a signifier of human difference. Theories of racial formation in poetry, fiction, and other imaginative genres. Rhetorical and media strategies that present and/or obscure the material sources and institutional histories of race and racism.

name: — Introduction to Games
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play. Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

name: — Internship in English
description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; and consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; and consent of instructor.

name: — Student Facilitated Course
description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Creative Writing: Fiction
description: Course Description: Writing of fiction. No final examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P; ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

name: — Creative Writing Advanced Fiction
description: Course Description: Development and evaluation of students' work in prose, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published novels and short stories. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 100F.

name: — Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
description: Course Description: Writing of non-fiction. No final examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P or ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

name: — Creative Writing: Poetry
description: Course Description: Writing of poetry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P or ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

name: — Creative Writing Advanced Poetry
description: Course Description: Development and evaluation of students' work in poetry, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published works of poetry. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 100P.

name: — History of the English Language
description: Course Description: History of the English language. Examination of the language as recorded from Old English to present-day English. Relationship of English to other languages; development of vocabulary, phonology, and grammatical patterns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or the equivalent.

name: — English Grammar
description: Course Description: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or LIN 001 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or consent of instructor.

name: — English Grammar Practicum
description: Course Description: Practice in teaching the principles of grammar to the kinds of audiences teachers encounter in California. Discussions with teachers who teach in these areas. Examination of pedagogical research on teaching grammar.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 106; LIN 106 (can be concurrent).

name: — Freedom of Expression
description: Course Description: Historical development of fundamental issues and contemporary controversies about freedom of expression, with emphasis on literary and artistic censorship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or the equivalent.

name: — Introduction to Literary Theory
description: Course Description: Key theoretical terms, concepts, and thinkers from the Greeks to the modern era.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Introduction to Modern Literary & Critical Theory
description: Course Description: History of literary criticism in the modern era, with emphasis on the ties with the past and the special problems presented by modern literary theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Topics in Medieval Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused intensive examination of selected topics in Medieval British literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Chaucer: Troilus & the "Minor" Poems
description: Course Description: Development of the poet's artistry and ideas from his first work to his masterpiece, "Troilus and Criseyde"
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales
description: Course Description: Literary analysis of the complete "Canterbury Tales."  Courtly love, literary forms, medieval science and astrology, theology and dogma as they inform the reading of Chaucer's work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Topics in 16th- & 17th-Century Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of the Renaissance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Shakespeare
description: Course Description: Historically, generically, or thematically focused study of Shakespeare's works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Law & Literature
description: Course Description: Historically, thematically, or generically focused study of the relationship between law and literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Milton
description: Course Description: Selected major works, including Paradise Lost.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — 18th-Century British Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of 18th-century English literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Topics in Irish Literature
description: Course Description: Intensive study or treatment of special topics relating to the emergence, invention, and re-invention of Irish literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — British Romantic Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of Romantic English literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — 19th-Century British Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century English literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — British Literature, 1900-1945
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — British Literature, 1945 to Present
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Topics in Global Literatures & Cultures
description: Course Description: Historically or regionally focused study of world literatures in English (other than the national literatures of British Isles and the United States), particularly from post-colonial regions in Africa, the Caribbean, and Asia, and immigrant cultures in the English-speaking world.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Topics in Postcolonial Literatures & Cultures
description: Course Description: Study of postcolonial literature of Anglophone colonies. Specific emphases may include literature from and about Anglophone India, the Caribbean, the Middle East, South Asia, Africa, and/or South America.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Topics in Diasporic Literatures & Migration
description: Course Description: Study of literatures, histories, and cultures of one or more diasporic groups.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Early American Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature of the 17th and 18th centuries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — 19th-Century American Literature to the Civil War
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century American literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Post-Civil War American Literature
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of post-Civil War American literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Reading Race, Class, & Gender
description: Course Description: Readings in literature and culture that present race, class, gender, sexuality, ability, and citizenship as inter-articulated signifiers of difference. Literature is contextualized alongside works of sociology, history, philosophy, and law. Inter-discursive nature of racial thought and policy, and on historical and rhetorical practices through which race acquires meaning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — American Literature 1900-1945
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — American Literature, 1945 to the Present
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

name: — Topics in Literature
description: Course Description: Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not necessarily historically. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — British Drama to 1800
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of English drama prior to 1800.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Drama from 1800 to the Present
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British drama from 1800 to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Topics in Drama
description: Course Description: Historical or thematic study of drama.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — The Graphic Novel
description: Course Description: Thematically, historically, and formally focused study of the graphic novel genre. Contents may include any regional, national, or transnational group of graphic novels.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent courses.

name: — 18th-Century British Novel
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 18th-century British novel, with particular emphasis on its evolution, including the epistolary novel, the picaresque novel, and the Gothic novel: Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Austen.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — 19th-Century British Novel
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of 19th-century British novelists, with emphasis on the historical novel, the social novel, and novels by women: Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, Eliot, Hardy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — 20th-Century British Novel
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 20th-century British novel, with emphasis on impressionism; the revolt against naturalism; the experimental novel; the anti-modernist reaction: Conrad, Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence, Drabble, Rhys.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — The Short Story
description: Course Description: The short story as a genre; its historical development, techniques, and formal character as a literary form. European as well as American writers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — Detective Fiction
description: Course Description: Historically, formally, and thematically focused study of novels and short stories in the detective fiction genre.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

name: — The American Novel to 1900
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the rise and development of the American novel from its beginnings; Hawthorne, Melville, Twain, James, and others.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — The American Novel from 1900 to the Present
description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of important American novelists from 1900 to the present: authors may include Willa Cather, Nathanael West, William Faulkner, Ralph Ellison, Zora Neale Hurston, Thomas Pynchon, Ishmael Reed, Maria Helena Viramontes, Rachel Kushner, and others.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

name: — Topics in the Novel
