prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Renaissance & Reformation in German Literature
description: Course Description: Parabolic and didactic style in Germany's literature during the 16th century.

name: — German Literature of the Baroque
description: Course Description: The "Elegantiaideal" and the varying methods used to portray it in 17th-century German literature.

name: — The Enlightenment in German Literature
description: Course Description: Revolt against the concept of the Elegantiaideal, and evolution of a new literature based on reason and wit.

name: — Foreign Language Learning in the Classroom
description: Course Description: Overview of approaches to university-level foreign language instruction and the theoretical notions underlying current trends in classroom practices across commonly taught foreign languages.

name: — Sentimentality & Sturm und Drang in German Literature
description: Course Description: Reaction to overemphasis on Reason: theories of Hamann and Herder and works of poets such as Lenz, Leisewitz, the early Goethe and Schiller.

name: — The Classical Age of German Literature
description: Course Description: Inquiry into the aesthetic and humanistic qualities of Germany's greatest literary epoch.

name: — The Romantic Period in German Literature
description: Course Description: Survey of the works of early 19th-century authors in reaction against the age of classicism.

name: — Poetic Realism in German Literature
description: Course Description: Outstanding figures in German literature between 1840 and 1890. Important phases in their developments will be treated.

name: — 20th-Century German Literature
description: Course Description: Considers the revolt of the Hauptmann generation, Symbolism, Expressionism, and the chief currents of the contemporary scene.

name: — Special Topics in German Literature
description: Course Description: Various special topics in German literature, which may cut across the more usual period and genre rubrics.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Individual study.

name: — Special Study for the Doctoral Dissertation
description: Course Description: Special study for doctoral dissertation.

name: — The Teaching of German
description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — The Teaching of German
description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — The Teaching of German
description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Tutorial & Instructional Internship
description: Course Description: Apprentice training in ongoing undergraduate literature courses taught by regular staff, with supplementary weekly critique sessions; intern leadership of discussion sections under staff supervision.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Introduction to Global Disease Biology
description: Course Description: Introduction to the Global Disease Biology major, research and internship opportunities, and potential career paths in human, animal, and plant health. Communication, ethics and the nature of science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to GDB majors only, or consent of instructor.

name: — Epidemiology
description: Course Description: Principles and practice of epidemiology as applied to human, animal, and plant populations and the environment in which these populations co-exist. Quantitative analysis of both infectious and non-infectious disease. Inter-dependence between epidemiological analysis, decision-making and policy formulation will be highlighted.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SAS 013; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; ((STA 013 or STA 013Y) or (STA 100 or PLS 120)).

name: — Disease Intervention & Policy
description: Course Description: Examination of the prevention and treatment of diseases affecting humans, animals, and plants. Case studies illustrate the merits of a unified approach to promoting health at local, regional, and global scales.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 101; SAS 013; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; PMI 129Y; VME 158.

name: — Microbiome of People, Animals, & Plants
description: Course Description: Examination of the structure and function of microbial communities that live inside and on host organisms. Introduction to general concepts of the microbiome and microbiota, and their relationship to host health and disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

name: — Geographies of Health
description: Course Description: Multiple geographies of health, including how both physical environmental systems and human social, economic & political systems impact health and disease. Global, comparative geographical approach emphasizes the benefits of integrated multidisciplinary analyses for planetary health success.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Global Disease Biology Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminar leading to development of the research proposal and academic plan for the Global Disease Biology major.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 090; SAS 013.

name: — Global Disease Biology Senior Research
description: Course Description: Capstone research experience for the Global Disease Biology major. Project may be experimental, library research, or some other creative activity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 090; GDB 189D (can be concurrent); SAS 013; GBD 189D required concurrently the first time GBD 189 is taken.

name: — Global Disease Biology Research Discussion
description: Course Description: Prevent or solve problems during the students’ research activity. Independent advising and assistance on research proposal.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 090; GDB 187; SAS 013; GDB 189; or consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special Study for Undergraduates.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special Study for Undergraduates.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Preparation of undergraduate students in identified graduate school pipeline programs (e.g. McNair scholars) for graduate education. Emphasis on educating and training undergraduates on key skills and competencies needed for the development of a successful graduate school applicant and future graduate scholar. Topics will vary.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Training and preparation of graduate students for successful scholarship and future careers. Emphasis on development of written and verbal communication, professional development, leadership, and mentoring. Topics will vary.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Special study or research for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching in Higher Education
description: Course Description: Selected topics related to preparation for teaching in higher education, leadership in academic institutions, job opportunities and career pathways for graduate students pursuing careers in teaching and education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Preparation of graduate students for careers as teachers and educators in higher education. Emphasis on the development of clear written and verbal communication skills as well as leadership practices applicable to teaching in academic institutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Greek
description: Course Description: Introduction to the basic grammar and vocabulary of Classical and New Testament Greek. Development of translation skills with emphasis on Greek-English.

name: — Elementary Greek
description: Course Description: Continuation of GRK 001.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 001; or the equivalent.

name: — Elementary New Testament Greek
description: Course Description: Supplementary study of New Testament Greek.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 002 (can be concurrent); concurrent attendance required.

name: — Intermediate Greek
description: Course Description: Continuation of GRK 002. Selected readings from Greek authors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 002; or the equivalent.

name: — Elementary New Testament Greek
description: Course Description: Supplementary study of New Testament Greek.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; concurrent attendance required.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Readings in Greek Prose
description: Course Description: Review of Greek morphology, syntax, and vocabulary. Readings in Greek prose authors, including Xenophon.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003; or equivalent.

name: — Plato
description: Course Description: Study of Plato and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Euripides
description: Course Description: Study of Euripides and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Homer: Iliad
description: Course Description: Selected readings from Homer's Iliad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003.

name: — Homer: Odyssey
description: Course Description: Selected readings from Homer's Odyssey.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Menander
description: Course Description: Study of Menander and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Attic Orators
description: Course Description: Selected readings from the orators of 4th- and 5th- century Athens.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Greek Hexameter Poetry
description: Course Description: Selected readings from ancient Greek hexameter poetry. Wisdom poetry, hymns, epyllia, idylls, epic, natural history and other texts from the hexameter tradition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Readings in the Greek Novel
description: Course Description: Selected readings from Greek prose fiction of the late classical, Hellenistic and imperial periods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Sophocles
description: Course Description: Study of Sophocles and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Aristophanes
description: Course Description: Study of Aristophanes and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Thucydides
description: Course Description: Study of Thucydides and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Lyric Poetry
description: Course Description: Study of lyric poetry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Aeschylus
description: Course Description: Study of Aeschylus and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Herodotus
description: Course Description: Study of Herodotus and his works.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Greek Prose Composition
description: Course Description: Intensive grammar and vocabulary review through exercises in Greek prose composition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Readings in Later Greek
description: Course Description: Translation and discussion of selected readings from Hellenistic to Byzantine Greek literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Readings in Ancient Greek Philosophy & Science
description: Course Description: Selected readings from ancient Greek philosophical and scientific writers. Texts on logical truth and empirical sense data, material and social contexts of ancient Greek philosophy and science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Computer-Based Patient Records
description: Course Description: Introduction and overview of computer-based clinical record systems. Topics include data modeling, health system standards and terminologies; security, privacy and confidentiality; workflow modeling; data visualization; legal; decision support; public health; and evidence-based practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current enrollment within the Health Informatics Graduate Program or consent of instructor.

name: — Decision Support Systems
description: Course Description: Explores decision support systems for medical application. Topics include medical decision making, uncertainty, review of existing decision support systems, knowledge engineering, data mining, and knowledge based systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Medical Informatics in Web-Based Enterprise Computing
description: Course Description: Introduction to the decision making processes and technologies that are involved in developing web-based distributed enterprise applications in medicine. Focus on the Informatician's role as a team member.

name: — Data Acquisition & Analysis
description: Course Description: Examines the nature, acquisition, and analysis of medical data. Data ranges from signals of electrical potentials, sounds, text, images (still and motion), and data from nucleic acid and protein expression and sequencing instruments.

name: — Consumer Digital Health
description: Course Description: Landscape, technologies, and policies involved in data acquisition, storage and analysis in digital and connected health and consumer health informatics. Models of digital health data monitoring, including clinical, mobile health and telehealth, and theories relevant to health and information behavior by consumers and patients. Design, acquisition and analysis of data in the personal and consumer health ecosystem.

name: — Introduction to Health Informatics
description: Course Description: Overview provides broad exposure to the field of Health Informatics. Topics covered include, but are not limited to, networking, information systems, coding, HL7, Security, and HIPPA.

name: — Computer Security in Health Informatics
description: Course Description: Critical thinking about basic concepts in computer security and privacy. How the computer security and privacy impact health informatics, ranging from electronic health records to telemedicine to remote, virtual surgery.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MHI 210; MHI 202; MHI 209.

name: — Special Topics in Medical Informatics: Data Acquisition
description: Course Description: Special topics in Data Acquisition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Health Informatics: Seminars in Clinical Translational Informatics
description: Course Description: Seminars in current clinical translational informatics research topics. Guest presenters and faculty led discussions.

name: — Clinical Knowledge for the Health Informaticist
description: Course Description: Basic clinical knowledge for health informatics students. Human systems, disease states and conditions, treatments and prognosis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Database & Knowledge Management
description: Course Description: Objectives include understanding the informatics techniques for data capture, information management, and knowledge generation that a student will use throughout their career.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Health Informatics: Biostatistics
description: Course Description: Special topics in Biostatistics. Evaluation Methods and Statistics in Biomedical Informatics. Research design and analysis with special emphasis on Biomedical Informatics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Modeling Biological Systems
description: Course Description: Create awareness of how modern computer graphics have led to VR-Sim-Rob applications, and how they are modifying the teaching of medicine and in some cases the diagnosis and treatment of patients.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Programming in Health Informatics
description: Course Description: Basics of computer programming essential to the study of informatics. Impacts on systems within healthcare, public health, nursing, research, and others.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Medical Informatics
description: Course Description: Discussion of current graduate research and topics in Medical Informatics. Oral presentations of individual study.

name: — Group Study in Health Informatics
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student in good academic standing.

name: — Research in Health Informatics
description: Course Description: Independent research in Health Informatics.

name: — Elementary Hebrew
description: Course Description: Speaking, listening, comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals of modern Hebrew.

name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Hebrew
description: Course Description: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of HEB 001, HEB 002, and HEB 003. Introduction to Hebrew grammar and development of language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication.

name: — Elementary Hebrew
description: Course Description: Speaking, listening, comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals of modern Hebrew.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 001; or the equivalent.

name: — Elementary Hebrew
description: Course Description: Speaking, listening comprehension, reading and writing fundamentals of modern Hebrew.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 002; or the equivalent.

name: — Introduction to Biblical Hebrew
description: Course Description: Introduction to the Hebrew Alphabet and basic grammar rules of the biblical language. Students will learn to read most any biblical text and learn how to find the meaning of words by their roots and morphological structure.

name: — Introduction to Biblical Hebrew
description: Course Description: Continuation of HEB 010. Biblical text reading, simple/literal translation, verb and noun patterns, compounding of prepositions and nouns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 010.

name: — Introduction to Biblical Hebrew
description: Course Description: Continuation of HEB 011. Biblical text reading, simple/literal translation, verb and noun patterns, compounding of prepositions and nouns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 011.

name: — Intermediate Modern Hebrew I
description: Course Description: Development and refinement of grammar, composition, and language skills required for reading literary texts and conversing about contemporary topics at an advanced level. History of the Hebrew language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 003; consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Modern Hebrew II
description: Course Description: Continued development and refinement of grammar, composition, and language skills required for reading literary texts and conversing about contemporary topics at an advanced level. History of the Hebrew language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 021; consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Modern Hebrew III
description: Course Description: Continued development of grammar, composition, language skills required for reading literary texts and conversing about contemporary topics at an advanced level. History of the Hebrew language. Further development of writing and translating skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 022; consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Modern Hebrew I
description: Course Description: Third year Hebrew. Advanced grammar and composition. Focus on reading of literary texts, oral skills and accuracy in writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 023; or consent of instructor; students who took HEB 100A as second-year Hebrew may take HEB 100AN.

name: — Advanced Modern Hebrew II
description: Course Description: Third year Hebrew. Advanced grammar and composition. Focus on reading of literary texts, oral skills and accuracy in writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 100AN; or consent of instructor; students who took HEB 100B as second-year Hebrew may take HEB 100BN.

name: — Advanced Modern Hebrew III
description: Course Description: Third-year Hebrew. Advanced grammar and composition. Focus on reading of literary texts, oral skills and accuracy in writing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HEB 100BN; students who have taken HEB 100C as second-year Hebrew may take HEB 100CN.

name: — Research in Hematology-Oncology
description: Course Description: Experience in laboratory research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Topics in Hematology
description: Course Description: Basic concepts of the physiology of the hematopoietic organ, the pathophysiology of hematopoietic disease, and concepts of therapeutics will be offered for study. The specific topics to be dictated by the interest and background of the students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One year of graduate work and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Laboratory investigation contributing to the dissertation for a graduate degree.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Oncology
description: Course Description: Covers the principles of oncology and the pathophysiology of specific, common cancers correlated with organ systems pathophysiology and systemic pathology courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the SOM Committee on Student Promotions.

name: — Hematology-Oncology Consult Clerkship
description: Course Description: Acting intern on inpatient hematology/oncology ward service.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Hematology-Oncology Consult Clerkship
description: Course Description: Student is an integral member of the inpatient hematology and oncology consult service, the bone marrow service, and will attend all conferences sponsored by the Division.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Hematology-Oncology Ambulatory Clerkship
description: Course Description: Outpatient rotations in related clinics. Participation with members of the subspecialty service in the initial clinical evaluation, work-up, management and follow-up of the patient with hematologic or oncologic disorders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Cancer as a Process
description: Course Description: Covers cancer as a process, beginning with risks and prevention, preneoplasia, microinvasion, treatment options, metastases and systemic therapy, pain medicine and palliative care, and cancer communication. Format includes traditional lectures, student-led case discussions, and problem-based learning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Hindi/Urdu I
description: Course Description: Introduction to Devanagari Script through development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Hindi
description: Course Description: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of HIN 001, HIN 002, and HIN 003. Introduction to Devnagari Script through development of all language skills in cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

name: — Elementary Hindi/Urdu II
description: Course Description: Continuation of HIN 001. Devanagari Script through development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIN 001.

name: — Elementary Hindi/Urdu III
description: Course Description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi using the Devanagari script and brief introduction to basic literacy in Urdu using the Nasataliq script.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIN 002.

name: — Intermediate Hindi/Urdu I
description: Course Description: Intermediate level course for students who have completed Elementary Hindi/Urdu or the equivalent. Students will continue to practice their skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing in Hindi and Urdu.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIN 003.

name: — Intermediate Hindi/Urdu II
description: Course Description: Intermediate level course where students will continue to practice their skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing in Hindi and Urdu.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIN 021.

name: — Intermediate Hindi/Urdu III
description: Course Description: Intermediate level course where students will continue to practice their skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing in Hindi and Urdu.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIN 022.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to History
description: Course Description: Introduction to history, its key methodologies, writing tasks, and research practices. Examination of the development of history as an academic discipline; ethics in historical research. Topical focus changes regularly.

name: — Introduction to the History of Science & Technology
description: Course Description: Introduction to topics and methods of the history of science and technology. Emphasis on understanding the role of science and technology in the modern world through a long-term historical perspective.

name: — Introduction to the History of Science & Technology
description: Course Description: Introduction to topics and methods of the history of science and technology. Emphasis on understanding the role of science and technology in the modern world through a long-term historical perspective.

name: — Cities: A Survey of World Cultures
description: Course Description: Survey of urban world cultures, focusing on up to ten cities selected by the instructor.

name: — History of Western Civilization
description: Course Description: Growth of western civilization from late antiquity to the Renaissance.

name: — History of Western Civilization
description: Course Description: History of western civilization from the Renaissance to the 18th century.

name: — History of Western Civilization
description: Course Description: Development of Western Civilization from the 18th century to the present.

name: — Modernist Culture
description: Course Description: Modernist culture in global perspective. Introduction to early 20th-century innovations in visual arts, music, literature, film, and architecture in Europe, the Americas, Asia, and Africa.

name: — Introduction to the Middle East
description: Course Description: Survey of the major social, economic, political and cultural transformations in the Middle East from the rise of Islam (c.600A.D.) to the present, emphasizing themes in religion and culture, politics and society.

name: — History of Latin America to 1700
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history of Spanish and Portuguese America from the late pre-Columbian period through the initial phase and consolidation of a colonial regime (circa 1700). Topics include conquest, colonialism, racial mixture, gender, and labor systems.

name: — History of Latin America, 1700-1900
description: Course Description: Latin America from colony to republic. The nature of Iberian colonialism, the causes for independence, the creation of nation states, the difficulties in consolidating these nations, and the rise of Liberalism and export economies in the 19th century.

name: — History of Latin America 1900-present
description: Course Description: Latin America since the beginning of the 20th century. Themes include export economies, oligarchic rule, crises of depression and war, corporatism, populism, revolution and reform movements, cultural and ethnic issues, U.S.-Latin American relations, neo-liberal restructuring.

name: — History of Indian Civilization
description: Course Description: Survey of Indian civilization from the rise of cities (ca. 2000 B.C.) to the present, emphasizing themes in religion, social and political organization, and art and literature that reflect cultural interaction and change.

name: — History of East Asian Civilization
description: Course Description: Surveys traditional Chinese civilization and its modern transformation. Emphasis is on thought and religion, political and social life, art and literature. Perspectives on contemporary China are provided.

name: — History of East Asian Civilization
description: Course Description: Surveys traditional Japanese civilization and its modern transformation. Emphasis is on thought and religion, political and social life, art and literature. Perspectives on contemporary Japan are provided.

name: — Korean Culture & Society: From Ancient Three Kingdoms to the Global K-Pop
description: Course Description: Evolution of Korean society from Three Kingdoms period (B.C.E 57 to C.E. 676) to the contemporary era emphasizing the perseverance and transformations of traditional social and cultural patterns.

name: — World History to 1350
description: Course Description: Historical examination of the changing relationship of human societies to one another and to their natural settings through the year 1350, with particular attention to long-term trends and to periodic crises that reshaped the links of culture and nature on a global scale.

name: — World History, c. 1350-1850
description: Course Description: Major topics in world history from the 14th century to the beginning of the 19th century. Topics will vary but may include: oceans as systems of human communication and conflict; the global consequences of "industrious revolutions" in Europe and Asia, etc.

name: — World History III
description: Course Description: Major topics from world history of the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing the rise and fall of Western colonial empires; Cold War and the superpowers; the spread of the nation-states; and process of globalization.

name: — History of the Jewish People in the Modern World
description: Course Description: Histories and cultures of the Jews since 1492. Topics include: the making of Jewish diasporas, roots of antisemitism, the Holocaust in images and texts, changing ideas of the self, Jews in America,  contemporary visions of the Jewish past.

name: — Food & History
description: Course Description: Survey of the ways humans have fed themselves from the dawn of humanity to the present. Transformation of plants and animals into food, cooking into cuisine, and ceremony into etiquette.

name: — Global Sexualities
description: Course Description: Global history of sexualities, including comparative study of gender, marriage, and fertility before 1800, followed by the modern history of sexualities worldwide as it intersects with imperialism, race, population control, law, and globalization.

name: — History of Global Capitalism
description: Course Description: History of institutions, workers, commodity chains, and the social and cultural context of capitalism around the world from 1500-present. Emphasis on transnational and comparative histories of political economies and individual human lives.

name: — Africa to 1900
description: Course Description: Introduction to African history to 1900. Origins and impact of early human history, precolonial states and societies, slavery and the slave trade, religious and cultural movements, and the foundations of European colonialism.

name: — Africa Today
description: Course Description: Survey of major themes in colonial and postcolonial sub-Saharan African history, including colonialism, decolonization, nationalism and politics, economic history and labor, urbanization, popular culture, gender, marriage, and family life.

name: — Sex, Science, & Society
description: Course Description: Survey of the relationship between sex, science, and society in the history of the modern world. Emphasis on the development of scientific ideas about the human body against broader social, cultural, and political trends and from a global viewpoint.

name: — History of the United States
description: Course Description: The experience of the American people from the Colonial Era to the Civil War.

name: — History of the United States
description: Course Description: The experience of the American people from the Civil War to the end of the Cold War.

name: — Race in America to 1865
description: Course Description: Introduction to history of race and racial formation in the United States to the Civil War through a comparative approach. Examines the experiences of African Americans, Asian Americans, Native American, Mexican Americans and other Latino/a groups.

name: — Race in the United States Since 1865
description: Course Description: Introduction to the history of race and racial formation in America since 1865 though a comparative approach that examines the experiences of African Americans, Asian Americans, Native American and Mexican Americans and other Latino/a groups.

name: — Migration & Borders in Global History
description: Course Description: Introduction to global migration history from 1800 to the present; labor migration systems; border governance; undocumented migrants; partition, displacement, and refugee regimes; race, class, and gender in migration law.

name: — The Vietnam War
description: Course Description: A history of the Vietnam War, including its origins, fighting, and repercussions.

name: — Women & Gender in America, to 1865
description: Course Description: History of women and gender in America through 1865, emphasizing intersections of gender, race, class, and sexuality. Topics include interracial marriage, slavery, witchcraft, meanings of motherhood, war, domestic labor, moral reform, women’s rights, migrations, the effects of commercialization and industrialization.

name: — Women & Gender in America, 1865-Present
description: Course Description: History of women and gender in America since 1865, emphasizing intersections of gender, race, class, and sexuality. Covers emancipation, migration, immigration, war, media, same-sex and opposite-sex relationships, and the birth control, suffrage, labor, civil rights, feminist, and anti-feminist movements.

name: — The History of the United States in the Middle East
description: Course Description: History of the United States in the Middle East from 1900 to the present. Examination of U.S. foreign relations toward the Middle East, their regional ramifications and domestic repercussions.

name: — The History of the United States in the Middle East
description: Course Description: History of the United States in the Middle East from 1900 to the present. Examination of U.S. foreign relations toward the Middle East, their regional ramifications and domestic repercussions with extensive writing.

name: — Nature, Man, & the Machine in America
description: Course Description: History of the attitudes and behavior of Americans toward their natural environment and their technology, from colonial times to the present. No final examination.

name: — Research in History
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Emphasis on primary sources and archival research.

name: — Internship in History
description: Course Description: Supervised internship and study as a historian, archivist, curator, or an in another history-related capacity, in an approved organization or institution.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Selected Topics in History
description: Course Description: Selected Topics in History may be organized around a particular geography (e.g., the Balkans), a chronological framework (e.g., the 1960s around the world) or a thematic approach (e.g., the rise of ethnic or racial identities in a particular region).

name: — Introduction to Historical Thought & Writing
description: Course Description: Study of the history of historical thought and writing, analysis of critical and speculative philosophies of history and evaluation of modes of organization, interpretation, and style in historical writing.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Ancient
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Ancient.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Medieval
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Medieval.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Modern Europe to 1815
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Modern Europe to 1815.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Europe Since 1815
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Europe since 1815.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Russia
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Russia.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: China to 1800
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. China to 1800.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: China Since 1800
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. China since 1800.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Britain
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Britain.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Latin America Since 1810
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Latin America since 1810.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: American History to 1787
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. American History to 1787.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: United States, 1787-1896
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. United States, 1787-1896.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: United States Since 1896
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. United States since 1896.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Japan
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Japan.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Africa
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Africa.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Christianity & Culture in Europe, 50-1850
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Christianity and Culture in Europe, 50-1850.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: India
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. India.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Muslim Societies
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Muslim Societies.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Education Abroad Program
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Education Abroad Program; may be taught abroad.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in History: Comparative History
description: Course Description: Designed primarily for history majors. Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in the various fields of history. Comparative History, selected topics in cultural, political, economic, and social history that deal comparatively with more than one geographic field.

name: — Topics in Historical Research
description: Course Description: Individual research resulting in a research paper on a specific topic in one of various fields of history. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Historical Research & Interpretation
description: Course Description: Directed reading and research aimed at preparing students to select appropriate topics and methodologies for a senior honors essay and to situate their topics within a meaningful, broad context of historical interpretations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance into History Department Honors Program.

name: — Honors Thesis
description: Course Description: Research in preparation of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 104A.

name: — Honors Thesis
description: Course Description: Completion of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 104A; HIS 104B.

name: — Teaching History
description: Course Description: Teaching of American and world history at the K-12 level. Emphasis on introducing college students to the multiple ways in which history is taught, and on understanding how history education is determined.

name: — Medicine's Histories: Human & Veterinary Medicine from the Ancient World to One Health
description: Course Description: Global, comparative study of the related histories of human and veterinary medicine from the ancient world to today's interdisciplinary One Health. Emphasis on reintegration of human and veterinary medicine to meet the biggest health challenges today.

name: — Global Environmental History
description: Course Description: Global, comparative  study of how environmental change, human perceptions of nature, and manipulations of nature have changed over time. Primary focus post-1500, emphasis on critically analyzing many common ideas of environmental change.

name: — Environmental Change, Disease & Public Health
description: Course Description: Analysis of environmental changes from pre-history to the present and their influence on disease distribution, virulence and public health. Focus on critical study of many human-driven environmental changes and the accelerated transformation/spread of pathogens under globalization.

name: — Themes in World History
description: Course Description: Topics will emphasize the interaction of diverse regions of the world as well as common patterns of historical change.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing recommended.

name: — Colonialism & the Making of the Modern World
description: Course Description: History of the modern world, focusing on struggles between Europeans and colonized peoples; the global formation of capitalism; the creation of nation-states; and the constitution of bourgeois bodies and racial selves in modern societies.

name: — Ancient History
description: Course Description: History of ancient empires of the Near East and of their historical legacy to the Western world.

name: — Ancient History
description: Course Description: Political, cultural and intellectual study of the Greek world from Minoan-Mycenaean period to end of Hellenistic Age.

name: — Ancient History
description: Course Description: Development of Rome from earliest times. Rise and fall of the Roman Republic; the Empire to 476 A.D.

name: — Topics in Pre-Modern Jewish History
description: Course Description: Topics in the history of Jews from the Biblical era to the eras of Jewish emancipation. Topics can be framed chronologically (eg., medieval Jewry) or thematically (eg., trade and Jewish communities). May be repeated once for credit.

name: — Topics in Modern Jewish History
description: Course Description: Topics in the history of Jews from the era of Jewish emancipation to the present. Topics can be framed chronologically or thematically (eg. Zionism, assimilation, the post Holocaust Diaspora). May be repeated once for credit.

name: — History of Jews in the Muslim World
description: Course Description: History of Jewish communities in the lands of Islam from the time of the Prophet Muhammad to the present day.

name: — History of Modern Israel
description: Course Description: Topics include the rise and fall of utopian Zionism, the century-long struggle between Jews and Arabs, the development of modern Hebrew culture, the conflict between religious and secular Jews, and the nature of Israel's multicultural society.

name: — Histories of 20th Century Partition
description: Course Description: Politics of territorial separation in Ireland; Greece/Turkey; India/Pakistan; Palestine/Israel; the U.S./Mexico border, etc. Partition as a focus area in international governance; on refugee migration; race; problems of national citizenship; and the politics of hard borders.

name: — History of West Africa
description: Course Description: West and Central Africa from 1500 to the present. Origins and impact of precolonial states and societies, the trans-Atlantic slave trade, colonialism, decolonization, nationalism, and changes in religions, politics, economics, gender, and culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 015 recommended.

name: — History of East Africa & the Indian Ocean
description: Course Description: Eastern Africa and the Indian Ocean world from 1500 to the present. Origins and impact of precolonial states and societies, slavery, trade, colonialism, decolonization, nationalism, and changes in religions, politics, economics, gender, and culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 015 recommended.

name: — History of Southern Africa from Exploration to the Rainbow Nation
description: Course Description: Southern Africa from 1500 to the present. Origins and impact of precolonial states and societies, European colonization, industrialization, urbanization, nationalism, apartheid, and changes in religions, politics, economics, gender, and culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 015 recommended.

name: — Postcolonial Africa
description: Course Description: Survey of social, political, cultural and economic change in African societies since the ending of European colonial rule in the 20th century. Themes include development, health and medicine, war and conflict, urbanization, global and inter-continental migration, and family and gender.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 015 recommended.

name: — Slavery, Africa, & the Atlantic World
description: Course Description: History of the African Slave trades, from the early Egyptian and Saharan trades in the pre-modern period to the trans-Atlantic trade (15th-19th century) and the contemporary trafficking of humans.

name: — History of Modern North Africa, 1800 to the Present
description: Course Description: History of Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Libya (the Maghrib), 1800 to the present. Topics include conquest and pacification, reform movements, the rise of nationalism, decolonization, state capitalism, economic liberalization, Islamism, democratization and human rights, the interplay of history and memory.

name: — African History: Special Themes
description: Course Description: Themes of African history, such as African states and empires, slave trade, relationship of Egypt to rest of Africa, Bantu origins and migrations, and French policy of Assimilation and Association.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 015 recommended.

name: — World War I
description: Course Description: The First World War and the settlement that followed from 1914-1919. Causes, conduct, and consequences of the war including military, political, economic, social, and cultural factors, with special emphasis on connections between the home front and the battlefield.

name: — World War II
description: Course Description: The Second World War from 1931 to 1945 in all of its theaters. Causes, conduct, and consequences of the war including military, political, economic, social, and cultural factors, with special emphasis on battlefield strategy and mobilization of the home front.

name: — Medieval History
description: Course Description: European history from "the fall of the Roman Empire" to the 8th century.

name: — Medieval History
description: Course Description: European history from Charlemagne to the 12th century.

name: — Medieval History
description: Course Description: European history from the Crusades to the Renaissance.

name: — Selected Themes in Medieval History
description: Course Description: Each offering will focus on single major theme, such as medieval agrarian history, feudalism, the family, medieval Italy, or the Crusades. Readings include original sources in English translation and modern works. May be repeated for credit.

name: — Topics in Early Modern European History
description: Course Description: Social and cultural history, 1300-1800. Topics such as medieval and Renaissance Italy, early modern Italy, Ancient Regime France, family and sexuality, and material culture and daily life. May be repeated for credit.

name: — The History of Human Rights in Europe
description: Course Description: History of the origins, development, and state of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) in Europe. Emphasis on Enlightenment-era and modern theories of the source, utility, and limits of human rights.

name: — Popular Culture in Early Modern Europe
description: Course Description: Popular culture in 15th-18th century Europe. Topics may include food and festivals, literacy and religious beliefs, jokes and stereotypes, death and magic, as means of examining social status, gender, race, state power, local and national communities, religious change and conflict.

name: — Christianity & Culture in Europe: 50-1450
description: Course Description: History of the ideas and institutions of Christianity and their impact on the late Roman Empire and medieval Europe in terms of outlook on life, art, politics and economics.

name: — Christianity & Culture in Europe: 1450-1600
description: Course Description: History of the Lutheran, Zwinglian-Calvinist, Radical, Anglican, and Catholic Reformations as foundation stones of a new culture in Europe, with special attention to the interconnections between the revival of antiquity and the different reform movements.

name: — Christianity & Culture in Europe: 1600-1850
description: Course Description: Survey of the intellectual, cultural and political reorientation of European society in the aftermath of the Wars of Religion. "Secularization" will be discussed in the context of the Enlightenment and Romanticism.

name: — Early Modern European History
description: Course Description: Western European history from about 1350 to about 1500.

name: — European History During the Renaissance & Reformation
description: Course Description: Survey of European society, politics, and culture from the late 15th through the early 17th centuries, with particular focus on the Italian and Northern Renaissance, on the Protestant Reformation, and the Catholic Counter Reformation.

name: — The Old Regime: Absolution, Enlightenment & Revolution in Europe
description: Course Description: Survey of European society, politics, and culture in the 17th and 18th centuries, focusing on religious warfare, absolutism, Scientific Revolution, Enlightenment and the growth of religious tolerance, the French Revolution and the collapse of the old regime.

name: — Crime & Punishment in Early Modern Europe
description: Course Description: Deviance and crime in early modern Europe, contrasting imaginary crimes, e.g. witchcraft, with "real" crimes such as highway robbery and infanticide. Examines impact of gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity, and class in processes of criminalization.

name: — European Thought & Culture from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment
description: Course Description: History of European thought on politics, society, science, and religion from 1400 to 1800. Cultural impact of printing press, Protestant Reformation, wars, exploration, and empire.

name: — The Age of Revolution
description: Course Description: Ideas and institutions during the French Revolution and the Napoleonic era.

name: — History of Science to the 18th Century
description: Course Description: Survey of the historical development of science, technology, and medicine from the ancient world to the 18th century, with special emphasis on Isaac Newton as the culmination of the 17th-century scientific revolution.

name: — History of Science, 18th to 20th Centuries
description: Course Description: Survey of the historical development of scientific thought in geology, biology, chemistry, physics, and cosmology from the 18th to the 20th century, with special emphasis on emergence of broad explanatory principles that serve more than one science.

name: — Scientific Revolution
description: Course Description: Rise of modern science in Europe, 1500–1750. Transformation of ideas about nature, knowledge, medicine, and technology in the age of Copernicus, Vesalius, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton.

name: — The Rise of the Russian Empire, 1304-1825
description: Course Description: Expansion of the Russian state in Muscovite and imperial era. Emphasis on autocratic rule, the incorporation of non-Russian peoples, and emergence of Russia as a Great Power.

name: — Reform & Revolution in Tsarist Russia, 1825-1917
description: Course Description: Processes of state reform and social change in the 19th century; failure of reform and collapse of the Russian Empire; the revolutions of 1917.

name: — Russian History: The Rise & Fall of the Soviet Union, 1917 to Present
description: Course Description: Emergence of the Soviet Union as a socialist system and a Great Power; the decline and collapse of the Soviet Union and the formation of independent nation states in its place.

name: — Medieval & Renaissance Medicine
description: Course Description: History of medicine, circa 1000-1700. Revival of ancient medicine; role of the universities; development of anatomy, chemistry and natural history; ideas about the body; cultural understanding of disease; hospital and the public health system.

name: — Medicine, Society, & Culture in Modern Europe
description: Course Description: History of European medicine, 18th to 20th centuries, by examining the development of medical knowledge in epidemiology and anatomy; function of this knowledge, how it changed with technological breakthroughs and professionalization;and role of medicine in attitudes toward poverty, women, race, disease.

name: — The Rise of Capitalism in Europe
description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of major interpretations of the rise of merchant capitalism during the Middle Ages and Renaissance; European expansion overseas, 1450-1815; the transition to modern capitalism via industrial revolution. Interplay of social, political, cultural, and economic history.

name: — France Since 1815
description: Course Description: France since 1815.

name: — History of the Holocaust
description: Course Description: Topics include comparative genocide, medieval and modern antisemitism, modern German history, the rise of Nazism, Jewish life in Europe before the Nazi period, and the fate of the Jewish communities and other persecuted groups in Europe from 1933-1945.

name: — The Memory of the Holocaust
description: Course Description: Examination of the literary, philosophical, theological and artistic responses to the Holocaust of the European Jews. Exploration of how memory is constructed, by whom and for what purposes.

name: — History of Eastern Europe & the Balkans
description: Course Description: History of the Baltic, Danubian, and Balkan lands since the Middle Ages. National cultures and conflicts in the Polish Commonwealth and the Habsburg and Ottoman Empires; nationalist movements, 1789-1914; the 20th century, including an analysis of the contemporary scene.

name: — History of Germany, 1450 to 1789
description: Course Description: Survey of early modern Germany, 1450 to 1789, covering the theology and social history of the Reformation, the Peasants War of 1525, religious warfare, state building and absolutism, the rise of Prussia, Austro-Prussian dualism, and the German Enlightenment.

name: — History of Germany since 1789
description: Course Description: History of the German lands in the age of the French Revolution; 19th-century liberalism, nationalism, and industrialization; the World Wars, National Socialism, and the Holocaust; east and west Germany in the Cold War; the post-reunification scene.

name: — War & Revolution in Europe: 1789-1918
description: Course Description: Survey of revolutionary movements, international crises, and wars in Europe from the French Revolution to World War I.

name: — Europe in the 20th Century
description: Course Description: Survey of the history of Europe from 1919 to 1939.

name: — Europe in the 20th Century
description: Course Description: Survey of the history of Europe since 1939.

name: — European Intellectual History: 1800-1870
description: Course Description: European thought in the early industrial era. Shifting cultural frameworks, from romanticism to scientism; liberal and socialist reactions to social change. Focus on the work of Goethe, Hegel, J.S. Mill, Marx, Darwin and Flaubert.

name: — European Intellectual History: 1870-1920
description: Course Description: Cultural and intellectual watershed of the late-19th and early-20th centuries. Emergence of modern art and literature; psychoanalysis and the new social sciences. Focus on the work of Baudelaire, Wagner, Nietzsche, Freud, Weber and Kafka.

name: — European Intellectual History: 1920-1970
description: Course Description: European thought and culture since World War I. Coverage includes: literature and politics; Communism and Western Marxism; Fascism; Existentialism; Structuralism; Feminism. Particular attention to Lenin, Brecht, Hitler, Sartre, Camus, Beckett, Marcuse, Foucault, Woolf and de Beauvoir.

name: — Women & Society in Europe: 1500-1789
description: Course Description: Roles and perceptions of women from the Renaissance to the French Revolution. Emphasis on social and economic factors as well as on discussions of women in the writings of political theorists and social commentators.

name: — Women & Society in Europe: 1789-1920
description: Course Description: Roles and perceptions of women from the French Revolution to World War I, primarily in France and England. Emphasis on social and economic developments within a loosely chronological and comparative framework.

name: — Women in Society in Europe: 1914-Present
description: Course Description: History of 20th-century Europe from the perspective of women and the family, and of sexual and gender relations. Emphasis on the impact on women of major events and movements, such as World War I, fascism, Soviet communism, World War II, the welfare state, feminism, and mass culture.

name: — Comparative Cultural History of Modern Britain & France, 1880-1914
description: Course Description: Cultural comparison of the histories of Britain and France during the fin de siecle. Addresses cultural debates of the period (including gender, race, class) and the practices of cultural history.

name: — England: The Middle Ages
description: Course Description: Origins of England to the accession of the Lancastrians. Survey includes: impact of Norman Conquest on Anglo-Saxon institutions; rise of the Church, common law, parliament, and the economy; thought, arts, and literature to the age of Chaucer and Wyclif.

name: — England: The Early Modern Centuries
description: Course Description: From Lancaster and York to the Glorious Revolution. Includes growth of the Church of England; beginnings of modern worldwide economy; rise of the gentry and parliament; thought, arts, and literature in the times of More, Shakespeare, Hobbes, Wren, and Newton.

name: — 18th-Century England
description: Course Description: English history from the Glorious Revolution to the French Revolution. Examination of the transformation of one of Europe's most politically unstable kingdoms into the firmly established constitutional monarchy which provided an environment fit to engender the industrial revolution.

name: — Industrial England
description: Course Description: English history from Waterloo to the Battle of Britain; the rise and continuance of the first industrial nation, examining the transformation of landed to class society, oligarchy to democracy and bureaucracy, Bentham to Bloomsbury, empire to commonwealth.

name: — Latin American Migration History
description: Course Description: Migrations to, from, and within Latin America, with a focus on the period from independence to the present day. The historical development of settler colonialism, inter-regional migrations, rural-to-urban migration, migration promotion, restriction laws, naturalization, and sanctuary across Latin American scenarios. Research paper required.

name: — Business, Biomes & Knowledge: Latin American Environmental History
description: Course Description: Introduction to the geography, political ecology, environmental movements of Latin America and the Caribbean, regional biomes, commodity markets, and the relationships between non-human ecosystems and Latin American societies. Development of extractive processes, land law, agricultural practices, scientific knowledge, and environmental conservation in neotropical forests, Sonoran Desert, the Amazon, Andes and Pampas, among other ecologies.

name: — Special Topics in Latin American History
description: Course Description: Topics in the history of Latin America. Topics may be framed geographically (e.g., Central America), chronologically (e.g., The Cold War) or thematically (e.g., environmental history).

name: — Women & Gender in Latin American History
description: Course Description: Roles of women and men in the history of Latin America, with an emphasis on the intersection of gender with racial and class categories. Introduction to the theoretical premises of women’s and gender history.

name: — Spain & America in the 16th Century
description: Course Description: Atlantic world in the 16th century, particularly the transcultural and reciprocal social and economic relations between Spain and America in the course of colonization.

name: — Human Rights in Latin America
description: Course Description: History of the origins, denial and protection of Human Rights in Latin America. Emphasis on dictatorships, political violence, social resistance, democracy, justice, accountability, truth commissions, memory.

name: — History of the Andean Region
description: Course Description: History of the Andean region, the area that now comprises modern Peru, Bolivia, and Chile, from the beginning of human settlement to the present. May be taught abroad.

name: — History of Brazil
description: Course Description: The history of colonial and imperial Brazil from 1500 to 1889. Written reports.

name: — History of Brazil
description: Course Description: The history of the Brazilian republic from 1889 to the present.

name: — History of Chile
description: Course Description: Emphasis on the history of Chilean political economy from 1930 to the present. Various strategies of development (modernization, Marxism, Neo-Liberalism); the rise of mass politics; the course of foreign relations; and the richness of Chilean literature.

name: — Latin American Social Revolutions
description: Course Description: Major social upheavals since 1900 in selected Latin American nations; similarities and differences in cause, course, and consequence. May be taught abroad.

name: — History of Mexico to 1848
description: Course Description: Political, economic, and social development of pre-Columbian, colonial and national Mexico to 1848.

name: — History of Mexico since 1848
description: Course Description: History of Mexico from 1848 to the present.

name: — Modern Latin American Cultural & Intellectual History
description: Course Description: Introduce to the cultural and intellectual history of modern Latin America including architecture, cinema, painting, music and literature.

name: — History of Inter-American Relations
description: Course Description: Diplomatic history of Latin America since independence, intra-Latin American relations, relations with the United States, participation in international organizations, and communism in Latin America.

name: — Mexican-American History
description: Course Description: Economic, social, religious, cultural and political development of the Spanish-speaking population of the Southwestern United States from about 1800 to 1910.

name: — Mexican-American History
description: Course Description: Role of the Mexican and Mexican-American or Chicano in the economy, politics, religion, culture and society of the Southwestern United States since 1910.

name: — Colonial America
description: Course Description: Colonial society from 1607 to the American Revolution, with emphasis on European expansion, political, social and economic foundations, colonial thought and culture, and imperial rivalry.

name: — The American Revolution
description: Course Description: Analysis of the Revolutionary epoch with emphasis on the structure of British colonial policy, the rise of revolutionary movements, the War for Independence and its consequences, and the Confederation period.

name: — The Early National Period, 1789-1815
description: Course Description: Political and social history of the American republic from the adoption of the Constitution through the War of 1812 and its consequences.

name: — Slavery, Society & Expansion in the Early U.S.
description: Course Description: Political, social, economic history of early-19th century U.S. emphasizing slavery and expansion. The internal slave trade, the settlement of the Mississippi Valley and Far West, transformed economic and social relations, new reform movements.

name: — Civil War Era
description: Course Description: Examination of the political and social history of the United States from the Compromise of 1850 to the end of the Civil War in 1865. Causes of the war the war itself and the problems of reconstruction after the war.

name: — The Civil War in American Film
description: Course Description: Viewing and discussion of films with short writing assignments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 171B required concurrently.

name: — Reconstruction, America’s Second Founding
description: Course Description: After the U.S. Civil War, from 1865 to 1876. Emphasis on end of slavery; expansion of civil rights, voting rights, and birthright citizenship; overthrow of biracial Southern governments; segregation and disfranchisement; culture of reconciliation.

name: — Selected Themes in 19th-Century American History
description: Course Description: Interpretative overview of a single topic in the history of the United States in the 19th century. Sample topics include social history, the 1850s, and southern history.

name: — American Environmental History
description: Course Description: American history through connections between people and nature, pre-Columbus to climate change. Native America; conquest; epidemics; extinctions; industrialization; pollution; environmentalism; climate change and global warming; ideas of nature.

name: — Becoming an American: Immigration & American Culture
description: Course Description: Introduction to the wide range of immigrant experiences and cycles of nativism that have shaped American culture in the 20th century. From novels, memoirs and films, students will explore how external and internal immigration has created a multicultural society.

name: — The Gilded Age & Progressive Era: United States, 1876-1917
description: Course Description: US history and the construction of modern America from the end of Reconstruction to US entry into World War I. Includes Southern redemption, Western incorporation, electoral corruption, labor movements, Populism, Progressivism, women's suffrage, US imperial expansion, and immigration restriction.

name: — Emergence of Modern America: Discussion
description: Course Description: Intensive discussion of topics and readings for HIS 174A.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 174A required concurrently.

name: — War, Prosperity, & Depression: United States, 1917-1945
description: Course Description: America's emergence as a world power, the business culture of the 1920s, the New Deal and World War II. Emphasis on such issues as government regulation of the economy, welfare capitalism, and class, racial, ethnic, and gender conflicts.

name: — America in War, Prosperity & Depression: Discussion
description: Course Description: Intensive discussion of topics and readings for HIS 174B.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 174B required concurrently.

name: — The United States Since World War II, 1945 to the Present
description: Course Description: America's struggle to respond to new complexities in foreign relations, social tensions, family changes and media. Emphasis on such topics as: Cold War; anticommunist crusade; civil rights, feminist and environmentalist movement; New Left; counterculture; Vietnam; Watergate; and the moral majority.

name: — The United States Since World War II: Discussion
description: Course Description: Intensive discussion of topics and readings for HIS 174C.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 174C required concurrently.

name: — Selected Themes in 20th-Century American History
description: Course Description: Interpretive overview of a single topic in the history of the United States in the 20th century with attention to the phases and processes of historical change.

name: — Selected Themes in 20th-Century American History: Discussion
description: Course Description: Intensive discussion of topics and readings for HIS 174D.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 174D required concurrently.

name: — American Intellectual History
description: Course Description: Exploration of the ideas that have shaped politics and society in the United States from colonial times to the present. Topics include American liberalism, republicanism, democracy, constitutionalism, communitarianism, utopianism, pragmatism, feminism, Darwinism, nationalism, conservatism, and economics.

name: — Cultural & Social History of United States
description: Course Description: Study of social and cultural forces in American society in the 19th century with emphasis on social structure, work and leisure, socialization and the family, social reform movements and changes in cultural values.

name: — Cultural & Social History of United States
description: Course Description: Study of social and cultural forces in American society in the 20th century with emphasis on social structure, work and leisure, socialization and the family, social reform movements and changes in cultural values.

name: — History of Black People & American Race Relations: 1450-1860
description: Course Description: History of black people in the United States from the African background to Reconstruction.

name: — History of Black People & American Race Relations: 1860-Present
description: Course Description: History of black people and race relations from 1860-present. Emphasis on Civil War, Reconstruction, Segregation, Age of Accommodation, black nationalism, urbanization, civil rights, and changing ideology of race relations.

name: — Water in the West: Environment & Politics in America's Arid Lands
description: Course Description: Politics and environmental consequences of water development in the arid western United States since 1848, with emphasis on California and western rivers, including the Colorado, Columbia, Missouri, and Mississippi. Irrigated settlement, the making of state and federal water law and bureaucracy, urban vs. rural competition, Native water rights, growth of irrigation technologies, groundwater overdraft, wildlife impacts. One half-day field trip required.

name: — Asian American History, 1850-Present
description: Course Description: Historical experience of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the mid-19th century to the present. Migration, labor, community formation, race relations, women and gender, popular culture.

name: — American Political History, 1789-1896
description: Course Description: Growth of American politics from the birth of the republic to the end of the 19th century. Development of political parties, the expanding electorate, and how social issues such as slavery shaped the political process.

name: — American Political History, 1896-present
description: Course Description: Politics in the United States from 1896 to the present. Topics include race and partisan politics; communism and anti-communism; the New Deal and the centralization of government; and the rise of the imperial presidency.

name: — The Fight for the Right to Vote
description: Course Description: History of the struggle for voting rights from the colonial period to the present. Emphasis on the struggle for inclusion by African Americans, women, Latinos, and other groups.

name: — Religion in American History to 1890
description: Course Description: American religious history from colonization through the Gilded Age. Topics include religious diversity in America; native American religion; Protestant evangelism; gender and religion; religion and bigotry; African American religion; religion in the Civil War; and religion’s response to modernization.

name: — Gender & Justice in American History
description: Course Description: Intersection of gender and law in North America from the colonial period through the 20th century. Topics include witchcraft, suffrage, child custody, protective labor laws, regulation of sexuality. Analysis of legal change, trials, and cultural influences.

name: — The Frontier Experience: Trans-Mississippi West
description: Course Description: The fur trade, western exploration and transportation, the Oregon Country, the Greater Southwest and the Mexican War, the Mormons, mining discovery, and the West during the Civil War.

name: — The Frontier Experience: Trans-Mississippi West
description: Course Description: Spread of the mining kingdom, the range cattle industry, Indian-military affairs, settlement of the Great Plains and Rocky Mountain Regions and political organization of the West.

name: — History of Sexuality in America
description: Course Description: History of sexuality in America from pre-European through the late-20th century. Topics include birth control, marriage, sexual violence, prostitution, inter-racial relationships, heterosexuality and homosexuality, the feminist, gay, and lesbian liberation movements, AIDS, commercialization of sexuality.

name: — History of Science in America
description: Course Description: Survey of the European background. Study of American scientific institutions, ideas, personalities, creative processes in science, and of relationships between society and science from colonial times to present.

name: — History of Technology in America
description: Course Description: Study of American technology, emphasizing biographical approach to historical understanding of technological change, creative processes, institutions, ideas, and relationships between technology and society from colonial times to present.

name: — History of US Foreign Relations in the 20th Century
