name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Fluid Mechanics
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Fluid Mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Manufacturing Engineering
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Manufacturing Engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Mechanical Engineering & Product Design
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Mechanical Engineering & Product Design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Mechatronics Systems
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Mechatronics Systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: MEMS/Nanotechnology
description: Course Description: Directed group study in MEMS/Nanotechnology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Solid & Structural Mechanics
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Solid & Structural Mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Thermodynamics
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Thermodynamics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Mechanical Engineering: Vehicle & Transportation Systems
description: Course Description: Directed group study in Vehicle & Transportation Systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Intership in Engineering
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in mechanical engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

name: — Mentoring & Tutoring Engineering in the Community
description: Course Description: Mentoring, coaching, tutoring and/or supervision of students in K-12 schools in Engineering-related topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Group Study in Medical Microbiology and Immunology; primarily for lower division students. Directed reading and discussion on selected topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Medical Mycology
description: Course Description: Various aspects of pathogenic fungi, particularly affecting humans, will be discussed including epidemiology, pathogenesis and pathology, diagnosis and therapy. Course offered in alternate years.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; a course in pathogenic microbiology.

name: — Human Virology
description: Course Description: Covers viruses that cause diseases in humans, the structure and classification of medically-important viruses, methods of transmission and replication strategies. Viruses that are important human pathogens and epidemiology, immune response, detection, diagnosis and treatment of human viral infections. Discussion of clinical cases, cellular pathology, cancer and emerging and reemerging human viral diseases including Coronaviruses, vaccines, antivirals, and use of viruses in medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102 or BIS 101 or BIS 103 or BIS 104 or BIS 105.

name: — Human Immunology
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Understand the human immune system, the nomenclature and functional significance of the tissues, cells, proteins and genes, as well as the normal regulatory mechanisms and pathologic outcomes related to the immune response.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): consent of instructor; undergraduate level introductory Biology course.

name: — Human Immunology
description: Course Description: Understand the human immune system, the nomenclature and functional significance of the tissues, cells, proteins and genes, as well as the normal regulatory mechanisms and pathologic outcomes related to the immune response.

name: — Internship in Medical Microbiology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in medical microbiology and related fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

name: — Senior Honors Project in Medical Microbiology & Immunology
description: Course Description: Project in research related to immunology of medically important viruses. Development of a hypothesis-driven project, performance of experimental protocols and preparation of graphical representation of original data. Requires oral and written presentation of research results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MMI 199; consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study in Medical Microbiology
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion and/or laboratory investigation on selected topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Research in Medical Microbiology
description: Course Description: Individual research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

name: — Mechanisms for Microbial Interactions with Hosts
description: Course Description: Study of mechanisms involved in microbial interactions within a host environment. The following principles are basic to understanding these interactions: host recognition, invasion, competition and growth, and host defense.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIB 200A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Critical Analysis of Contemporary Research on Animal Models of Human Infectious Disease
description: Course Description: Topics will include diverse vertebrate and invertebrate models of human infectious diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; students funded by the Animal Models of Infectious Diseases Training Grant.

name: — Comparative Analysis of Animal Models of Human Infectious Diseases
description: Course Description: Compares the major vertebrate and invertebrate animal models that are used most commonly to study human infectious disease, including mouse, non-human primate, Caenorhabditis elegans, and drosophila.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students funded by the Animal Models of Infectious Diseases Training Grant; others by consent of instructor.

name: — Medical Parasitology
description: Course Description: Epidemiology, pathogenesis, diagnostic methods and current literature discussion of protozoa, helminths and arthropods of medical importance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student with consent of instructor.

name: — The Endogenous Microbiota in Health & Disease
description: Course Description: Recent insights into the microbial communities inhabiting mucosal surfaces, and will discuss how the composition of these communities contributes to normal development, metabolism, education of the immune system, and disease susceptibility. Offered in spring quarter; even years.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Seminar in Microbiology & Immunology
description: Course Description: Research seminars on current topics in microbiology and immunology.

name: — Group Study in Medical Microbiology & Immunology
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion and/or laboratory investigation on selected topics. Sections 1, 2, 4, 5 are S/U grading only.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Laboratory investigation contributing to the dissertation for a graduate degree.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

name: — Physician Scientist Molecular Medicine Journal Club
description: Course Description: Weekly seminars by students on research articles in current literature. Topics/articles to be selected by instructors to include a broad range of frontiers in biomedical literature.

name: — Medical Mycology
description: Course Description: Various aspects of pathogenic fungi, particularly affecting humans, will be discussed including epidemiology, pathogenesis and pathology, diagnosis and therapy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; a course in pathogenic microbiology.

name: — Medical Immunology
description: Course Description: Helping to understand the immune system, the nomenclature and functional significance of the tissues, cells, proteins and genes of the immune system, as well as the normal regulatory mechanisms and pathologic outcomes related to the immune response.

name: — Medical Microbiology
description: Course Description: Discussion of the diseases caused by infectious agents includes their pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, diagnosis, treatment epidemiology and prevention. Covers the general properties of and diagnostic techniques for bacteria, fungi and viruses.

name: — Medical Microbiology D
description: Course Description: Continuation of longitudinal medical microbiology course series.

name: — Tutoring in Medical Microbiology
description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum of the School of Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; appropriate preparation in subject matter.

name: — Group Study in Medical Microbiology & Immunology
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion and/or laboratory investigation on selected topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in pharmacology and related fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division student with good academic standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Internship in Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in pharmacology and related fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Problem Solving in Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Introduction to a current biomedical problem that would benefit from a developing drug and will develop an experimental strategy for addressing the issue. Develop model systems for testing various classic and recent pharmacological approaches.

name: — Drug Discovery & Development
description: Course Description: Survey of the process by which a drug is discovered, developed and made available to the public. Topics include drug identification and optimization, safety testing, clinical evaluation, regulatory issues, intellectual property, formulation, and the global pharmaceutical industry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An equivalent course in general pharmacology, or knowledge of basic pharmacology.

name: — Advanced Cardiac Physiology & Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Detailed characterization of the mechanisms involved in cardiac excitation–contraction coupling, alterations that occur in heart disease and pharmacological interventions. Topics include cardiac contractile apparatus, action potential, Ca cycling, excitation–transcription coupling, cardiac inotropy, heart failure and arrhythmias.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An equivalent course in general pharmacology or physiology (example, BIM 204), or knowledge of basic pharmacology/physiology.

name: — Gene & Cellular Therapies
description: Course Description: Gene therapy from basic concepts to clinical applications. Topics include the human genome and genetic variation, genetic diseases, methods to manipulate gene expression, viral and non-viral delivery vectors, history and progress of gene therapy, case studies, and ethical issues.

name: — Advances in Computational Physiology & Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Multi-scale biomedical modeling methodologies and applications, with emphasis on ion channel structure-function, computer-aided drug design, and membrane excitability. State-of-the-art techniques used for multi-scale modeling of biomedical systems and their applications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No formal requirements; basic knowledge of mathematics, physics, chemistry, and biology helpful.

name: — Pharmacology Research Seminar Series
description: Course Description: Research seminars on current topics in Pharmacology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division or graduate standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Principles in pharmacology, including pharmacokinetics, drug metabolism and the actions, uses and toxicities of the major classes of drugs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Principles in pharmacology, including autonomic pharmacology, general anesthetics, neuropharmacology and sedative/hypnotics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Treatment of respiratory and cardiovascular disease, central nervous system drugs, GI, Toxicology and chemotherapy. Specific topics include: asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and the treatment of arrhythmias. Pain Management, depression, psychosis, acid reflux, IBS and toxicology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHA 400A; PHA 400B; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — Introduction to Integrative Medicine
description: Course Description: Basic principles of alternative medical systems (e.g., traditional Chinese, Ayurvedic, Tibetan), alternative practices (e.g., chiropractic, osteopathy, naturopathy, homeopathy, herbalism, guided imagery/meditation, massage therapy), and mind/body connection are presented as introduction to integrating alternative treatments into traditional medicinal practice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

name: — Seminar in Pharmacology for Medical Students
description: Course Description: Seminar in pharmacology for medical students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Pharmacology
description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in preparation for one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum of the School of Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Medical Students
description: Course Description: Special study in pharmacology for medical students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Research for Medical Students
description: Course Description: Directed research in pharmacology for medical students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study in Medicine for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Participate in research projects relating to medicine with faculty in the School of Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Medical Education Internship for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Participate in projects related to curriculum development in support of curriculum for M.D. degree. Gain work experience and appreciation for innovative approaches to learning in basic and clinical sciences of medical education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor;competency with computers.

name: — Summer Pre-Matriculation Program
description: Course Description: Two-week program provides students from diverse backgrounds an early introduction to learning skills that will facilitate success in medical school.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Applications of Computers to Medical Practice
description: Course Description: Proficiency in computer applications relative to practice of medicine, with emphasis on email, literature searching, file transfer, and hospital information services. Given online, at home or in lab; time and place determined by student.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in medical school.

name: — Clinical & Cultural Spanish
description: Course Description: Fluent Spanish-speakering medical students, nursing students and physician assistants students learn a comprehensive set of medical vocabulary and cultural aspects related to the treatment of Spanish speaking patients.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Science & Practice of Mindfulness & Compassion
description: Course Description: Examines current scientific evidence for the effects of different mindfulness and compassion meditation practices in both healthy and clinical samples.

name: — Endocrinology, Nutrition, Reproduction & Genetics
description: Course Description: Basic and pathophysiologic processes involved in human reproductive and endocrine control systems, nutritional regulation, and foundational genetics across the lifespan. Integrate information across these systems and use clinical reasoning process to identify and understand relevant perturbations and diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BCM 410A; HPH 400; consent of instructor.

name: — Advancing Student-Run Clinics at UC Davis
description: Course Description: Introduction to resources, applied clinical skills, and program-building for medical students who volunteer at student-run free clinics, with the goal to improve care for the patients served. Introduce and review application of basic clinical skills needed to care for common diseases. Connect students to resources from state and national organizations. Create sustainability of student-run clinics through program-building and training.

name: — Doctoring 1
description: Course Description: Small group training in patient communication, interviewing techniques, physical exam and clinical identification. Outpatient clinical experiences and didactic presentations also included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Doctoring 1
description: Course Description: Small, case-based learning groups with training in patient communication and interviewing techniques, clinical identification and problem solving, applications of social, psychological, cultural, bioethical, and basic science concepts to patient case scenarios, outpatient clinical experiences and didactic presentations.

name: — ACE-PC Program Doctoring 1
description: Course Description: Small case-based learning groups with training in patient communication and interviewing techniques clinical identification and problem solving applications of social psychological cultural bioethical and basic science concepts to patient case scenarios outpatient clinical experiences and didactic presentations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — ACE-PC Program Doctoring 1
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science to clinical cases in small groups. History, physical examination with preceptors. Didactics in epidemiology, ethics, sexuality and clinical reasoning. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — ACE-PC Clinical Skills Foundation
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science to clinical cases in small groups. History, physical examination with preceptors. Didactics in epidemiology, ethics, sexuality and clinical reasoning. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of medicine. Includes small case-based learning groups with training in patient communication and interviewing techniques.

name: — Population Health & Evidence-Based Medicine
description: Course Description: Introduces the fundamental concepts and tools of population health, evidence-based medicine, and system science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Critical Appraisal of Topics in Population Health
description: Course Description: Apply foundational skills to explore critical issues in 21st-century public health, including tobacco control, firearm violence, and obesity. In a series of small-group discussions “interpreting the medical literature,” key concepts from epidemiology and biostatistics are reinforced while students are armed with specific strategies for addressing high-risk behaviors in the context of population health.

name: — Population Health & System Science
description: Course Description: Addresses the social, economic, cultural, policy-related, and environmental factors that affect the health of populations and individuals, and the role of health care systems (locally, regionally, nationally, and globally) in moderating the effects of these factors. Content builds on MDS 415A & MDS 415B, the TeamPEACE (Teamwork for Professionalism, Ethics, and Cultural Enrichment) curriculum in Doctoring 1, and students’ lived experience in UC Davis free clinics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Clncl Skills
description: Course Description: Longitudinal clinic component of the second year of the ACE-PC Program. Start with a four-week immersion experience and then 12 additional half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.

name: — Clinical Skills
description: Course Description: First in a series of courses that span across the pre-clerkship curriculum designed to integrate the clinical teaching within the pre-clerkship curriculum at the UC Davis School of Medicine. In year 1, students acquire the foundational knowledge, skills, and attitudes to succeed in medical training, including: history taking, physical exam, and interpersonal communication skills.

name: — Clinical Skills B
description: Course Description: Second in a series of courses designed to integrate the clinical teaching within the pre-clerkship curriculum at the UC Davis School of Medicine. In year 2, students build upon the foundation in clinical skills and professional behavior set out in year 1. The year 2 clinical skills course involves applying clinical skills to the caring for patients who present with active medical issues requiring further diagnostic investigation and therapeutic management.

name: — Clinical Experiences A
description: Course Description: Clinical Experiences longitudinal thread is designed to provide continued clinical exposure throughout the pre-clerkship curriculum at the UC Davis School of Medicine. In Year 1, students apply the basic physical exam and history taking skills to real-life patients in outpatient clinical settings.

name: — Clinical Experiences B
description: Course Description: Clinical Experiences longitudinal thread is designed to provide continued clinical exposure throughout the pre-clerkship curriculum at the UC Davis School of Medicine. In year 2, students use their growing knowledge and skill set to complete supervised encounters with real patients in the inpatient setting. In addition to practicing their physical exam and history taking skills, students apply their presentation and counseling skills in real-life encounters.

name: — Health & Humanity A
description: Course Description: Health and Humanity longitudinal thread is designed to integrate wellness, professionalism, and the behavioral sciences within the pre-clerkship curriculum at the UC Davis School of Medicine. Throughout Year 1, students acquire the foundational knowledge surrounding the social determinants of health, implicit bias, and cultural humility.

name: — Multisystem Clinical Presentations
description: Course Description: Capstone course integrates coursework, knowledge, skills and experiential learning to enable the student to demonstrate a broad mastery of learning across the curriculum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of Pathophysiology Block.

name: — Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science to clinical cases in small groups. History, physical examination with preceptors. Didactics in epidemiology, ethics, sexuality and clinical reasoning. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social & clinical science concepts to cases in small groups. History, physical examination with preceptors. Didactics in epidemiology, ethics, sexuality, and clinical reasoning. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the School of Medicine on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — ACE-PC Program Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: MDS 421KA-­C are a year-­long series of courses. Objectives and assessments have been accelerated to accommodate the students enrolled in the ACE­PC Program. Participate in all aspects of Doctoring 2, other than what was done in MDS 411KA & MDS 411KB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 411KA; MDS 411KB; admission into ACE-PC.

name: — ACE-­PC Program Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: MDS 421KA-­C are a year-­long series of courses. Objectives and assessments have been accelerated to accommodate the students enrolled in the ACE­PC Program. Participate in all aspects of Doctoring 2, other than what was done in MDS 411KA & MDS 411KB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the School of Medicine on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — ACE­-PC Program Doctoring 2
description: Course Description: MDS 421KA-­C are a year-­long series of courses. Objectives and assessments have been accelerated to accommodate the students enrolled in the ACE­PC Program. Participate in all aspects of Doctoring 2, other than what was done in MDS 411KA & MDS 411KB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by the School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress; medical students only.

name: — Foundations of Bioethics
description: Course Description: Exposure to core content in bioethics and the law and introduce a framework for ethical decision-making, while emphasizing relationships between bioethics and clinical care.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Transition to Clerkships
description: Course Description: Incoming third-year medical students participate in a variety of educational experiences designed to prepare them to begin their clerkship curriculum. Content disseminated in large and small group settings.

name: — Introduction to Doctoring 3
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Doctoring 3
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social and clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Doctoring 3
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social & clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Doctoring 3
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social & clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Doctoring 3
description: Course Description: Application of multidisciplinary basic, social & clinical science concepts to clinical cases in small group discussions facilitated by medical school faculty. Evaluation of professional competencies, attitudes and skills needed in the practice of clinical medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student Progress.

name: — ACE-PC Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship A
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship will combine the Internal Medicine, OBGYN, Pediatrics, Psychiatry and Surgery Clerkships for the ACE-PC Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — ACE-PC Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship B
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship will combine the Internal Medicine, OBGYN, Pediatrics, Psychiatry and Surgery Clerkships for the ACE-PC Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — ACE-PC Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship C
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship will combine the Internal Medicine, OBGYN, Pediatrics, Psychiatry and Surgery Clerkships for the ACE-PC Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Doctoring 4 Teaching Fellowship
description: Course Description: Instruction on teaching methodology and pedagogy. Mentored teaching of junior medical students in seminar, lecture, and bedside.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 430A; MDS 430B; MDS 430C; MDS 430D; consent of instructor.

name: — Combined Ophthalmology & Otolaryngology Clerkship
description: Course Description: Fundamental knowledge of ophthalmology and otolaryngology for the treatment of eye, ear, nose and throat problems at a level of training of general physicians, including when to refer patients to a specialist.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by Committee on Student Promotion and Evaluation.

name: — Race & Health in the United States
description: Course Description: Interprofessional course facilitates the professional and personal developmental of medical students and other health professions students who think they would like to be leaders in securing equity in population health and work environments.

name: — Transition to Residency
description: Course Description: Transition to Residency program addresses the graduating medical students need to improve clinical skills necessary for the first six months of residency and unmet graduation competencies in our competency-based curriculum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to UC Davis Medical Center
description: Course Description: Designed to assist medical student in transition from classroom to hospital setting.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year medical student.

name: — Student Run Clinics
description: Course Description: Learn counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease under supervision of physician. Meet all requirements and prerequisites of the particular clinic within which they work.

name: — Entry to ARC-MD
description: Course Description: Designed to orient ARC-MD and PSTP students to research opportunities at UC Davis, provide a structure for group engagement, expose them to hearing and asking critical research questions, and provide a foundation for the five-year research experience linked to the SOM curriculum.

name: — Introduction to Clinical Research
description: Course Description: Introduction to the CRGG program and overview of major clinical research topics. Overview of basic clinical skills needed to accomplish CRGG mentored research project.

name: — Strategies for Grant Writing
description: Course Description: Practical skills and strategies to create successful grant proposals in the NIH style and format. Generating ideas, identifying and accessing research resources, grant components, specific aims, backgound and significance, preliminary studies, budgets, and bios. Matriculation through UC system, and resubmissions.

name: — Introduction to Clinical Epidemiology & Study Design
description: Course Description: Anatomy and physiology of conducting clinical epidemiologic research. Familiarity with three basic study designs (cross-sectional, case-control,and cohort). Discussion of principles of measurements in clinical epidemiological studies, basic methods for analyzing data, and ethical issues involved in conducting research.

name: — Methods in Clinical Research
description: Course Description: Overview of major approaches to clinical research, including health services research techniques, informatics, the GCRC, and preclinical methodologies to enhance clinical projects. Overview of UC Davis clinical research support infrastructure. Methodologies applicable to clinical research and its multi-disciplinary perspective.

name: — Responsible Conduct of Research
description: Course Description: The nine NIH-mandated modules:  Data Acquisition and Reporting, Mentor Training, Publication Practices and Authorship, Peer Review/Grant Process, Collaborative Science, Human Subjects, Research with Animals, Conflict of Interest, Research Misconduct, and Entrepreneurship/Industry Collaborations/Intellectual Property/Technology Transfer.

name: — Introduction to Medical Statistics
description: Course Description: Biomedical applications of statistical methods in clinical, laboratory and population medicine. Graphical/tabular data presentation, probability, binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions, elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression/correlation, life tables. Microcomputer applications of statistical procedures in population medicine.

name: — International Clinical Preceptorship
description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary preceptorship in a foreign country. Clinical credit will be awarded using this course, once approval has been received from the appropriate governing committee.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students.

name: — International Elective
description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary preceptorship in a foreign country. Used to award non-clinical credit for international experiences which have been approved by the appropriate governing committee.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students.

name: — Rx One Health SSM
description: Course Description: Field course in epidemiology and public health leadership.

name: — Introduction to Dentistry
description: Course Description: Introduction to Dentistry and basic Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. Offered by the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery department at UC San Francisco.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good standing.

name: — Human Architecture & Function
description: Course Description: First course of the pre-clerkship phase curriculum of the I-EXPLORE; runs eight weeks from August-September. Disciplines include gross anatomy, microscopic anatomy (normal histology), clinical history & physical examination skills, and health systems science.

name: — Molecular & Cellular Medicine
description: Course Description: Second course of the pre-clerkship phase curriculum of the I-EXPLORE. Run six weeks from late September to early November.

name: — Pathogens & Host Defense
description: Course Description: Third course of the pre-clerkship phase curriculum of the I-EXPLORE. Runs five weeks from November-December.

name: — Cardiovascular, Pulmonary, & Renal Systems
description: Course Description: Fourth course of the pre-clerkship phase curriculum of the I-EXPLORE. Runs 19 weeks from January-May.

name: — Endocrinology, Reproduction, & Gastrointestinal Systems
description: Course Description: Endocrinology, Gastroenterology, & Reproduction is the fifth course of the pre-clerkship phase of the I-EXPLORE curriculum and will run 16 weeks from July through November.

name: — Dermatology & Musculoskeletal Systems
description: Course Description: Sixth course of the pre-clerkship phase of the I-EXPLORE curriculum. Runs three weeks from November through December.

name: — Brain & Behavior
description: Course Description: Seventh course of the pre-clerkship phase of the I-EXPLORE curriculum. Run eight weeks from January through February.

name: — I-RESTORE (Pre-Clerkship Intersession)
description: Course Description: Presents additional integration of the biomedical, clinical and health systems sciences, support for professional identity formation and wellness. Held longitudinally throughout the pre-clerkship phase.

name: — I-RESTORE (Pre-Clerkship Intersession)
description: Course Description: Presents additional integration of the biomedical, clinical and health systems sciences, support for professional identity formation and wellness. Held longitudinally throughout the pre-clerkship phase.

name: — Clerkship Intersession Course
description: Course Description: Longitudinal experience to supplement and support the clerkships in their efforts to facilitate students’ acquisition of the graduation competencies; to ensure biomedical science and health systems science are taught and learned in the context of the clinical science-focused clerkship year; to support students’ professional identity formation and wellness, and provide time for enrichment activities and scholarly work.

name: — Insights in Clinical Research
description: Course Description: Seminars on research presented by Medical School faculty; overview of pertinent issues, including medical ethics, human subjects protocols, case control methods, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

name: — Insights into Clinical Specialties
description: Course Description: Exposure to various medical specialties, their residency programs and ways in which medical students can prepare for and improve their candidacy for such programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

name: — Lecture Series in Reproductive Health
description: Course Description: Psychosocial and public health aspects of providing quality reproductive health care and application in student-run free clinics and in 3rd year clerkships.

name: — Insights in Political, Legal & Business Aspects of Medicine
description: Course Description: Practical aspects of a medical career.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students in good standing.

name: — First Aid for Health Policy
description: Course Description: Introduces the fundamental concepts and tools of health policy which are becoming necessary for students and physicians to become invested and active participants in healthcare. Focuses on the basic principles of health policy–the structure of government, how a bill becomes a law, the role of legislative visits, the role of healthcare foundations in California, the role of non-profits in California, our current healthcare system after the Affordable Care Act.

name: — Health Policy Lecture Series
description: Course Description: Lecture series provides an overview of local, state, national and international health policy. The current challenges health care reform implementation is facing provides how medical students can successfully advocate for changes in health policy.

name: — Topics in Health Care Improvement
description: Course Description: Lecture series will cover major topics in health care improvement, presented by guest speakers who are leaders in the field.

name: — History & Ethics of Medicine
description: Course Description: Introduction to ethical problems and events in health care in both modern and historical contexts. Eight one-hour and fifteen-minute interactive sessions designed to introduce students to historical topics in medicine and medical ethics.

name: — Directed Studies
description: Course Description: Independent studies to accommodate modified curriculums, prepare for taking USMLE exams and for remediation course work directed by the Committee on Student Progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum, USMLE exams, and/or as required by Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Clinical Reintroduction Experience
description: Course Description: Learn and practice basic clinical skills in a supervised clinical setting. Skills include patient interviewing, history, physical examination, diagnostic and clinical reasoning, case presentation, and medical records documentation. Direct observation and individual feedback on clinical skills development is provided.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — USMLE Directed Remedial Studies
description: Course Description: Independent studies to accommodate remediation for taking USMLE exams directed by the Committee on Student Progress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Recommendation by Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Community Health Scholars Seminar A
description: Course Description: Longitudinal year-long course starting on July 1 and concluding at the end of Block 2. Focuses on immersing students in their respective communities to understand the strengths and challenges they face in relation to health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Community Health Scholars Seminar B
description: Course Description: Longitudinal year-long course starting on July 1 and concluding at the end of Block 2. Focuses on immersing students in their respective communities to understand the strengths and challenges they face in relation to health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Community Health Scholars Seminar C
description: Course Description: Longitudinal year-long course starting on July 1 and concluding at the end of Block 2. Focuses on immersing students in their respective communities to understand the strengths and challenges they face in relation to health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Community Health Scholars Seminar D
description: Course Description: Longitudinal year-long course starting on July 1 and concluding at the end of Block 2. Focuses on immersing students in their respective communities to understand the strengths and challenges they face in relation to health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — TEACH-MS Pediatric Advocacy & Community Health Elective
description: Course Description: Through this elective, third- or fourth- year students gain understanding in the importance of community partnerships by directly engaging with community organizations that provide health education, patient navigation services, and other resources that they may refer their patients to. Students who complete this elective will develop key skills necessary for educating the public and lobbying key decision-makers in government.

name: — Interpretive Electrophysiology & Applied Cardiology–SSM
description: Course Description: Four-week special study module teaches and provides a basis for systemic interpretation of the EKG as well as cardiology management with the underserved populations in the Central Valley. Addresses underlying normal cardiac structure/function and cardiac abnormalities as reflected in the EKG and tie in the underlying basic science principles of cardiac electrophysiology.

name: — Independent Special Study Module
description: Course Description: Student developed alternative to the SSM/SPO Requirement. Approval by FYOC is required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — International & Comparative Health Care: SSM
description: Course Description: Through a series of lectures, seminars and clinical experiences, all occurring in other nations, students will research how health care systems address critical health issues. SSM Component.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — International & Comparative Health Care: Clinical
description: Course Description: Through a series of lectures, seminars and clinical experiences, all occurring in other nations, students will research how health care systems address critical health issues. Clinical Component.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching the Basic Sciences SSM
description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a yearlong in progress court to teach lecture and discussion education technique and theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 440 required concurrently; consent of instructor.

name: — Improving Quality in Health Care
description: Course Description: Working in interdisciplinary teams, will explore the theory and practical methods being employed to make improvement in health care systems while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Improving Quality in Health Care
description: Course Description: Working in interdisciplinary teams, will explore the theory and practical methods being employed to make improvement in health care systems while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Improving Quality in Health Care
description: Course Description: Working in interdisciplinary teams, will explore the theory and practical methods being employed to make improvement in health care systems while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Enhancing Patient Safety in Health Care
description: Course Description: Inter-professional module is designed to explore the theory and practical methods being employed to improve patient safety in health care while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year Medical student.

name: — Non-Clinical Medical Student Externship
description: Course Description: Generic course for awarding externship credit for medical student rotations that are not primarily focused on patient care.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Medicine Literature Review
description: Course Description: Independent study: topics for selection include, but are not restricted to, medical ethics, economics and jurisprudence, culture and medicine, ethnicity and medicine, gender and medicine, history of medicine, health manpower, and medical education. A prepared paper on the selected topic will be required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good academic standing and permission of the Associate Dean of Curricular Affairs.

name: — California Oregon Medical Partnership to Address Disparities in Rural Education & Health (COMPADRE)
description: Course Description: Through this elective, third- or fourth-year students enrolled in COMPADRE participate in the clinical care of patients from rural, underserved, or indigenous communities. Students may rotate through outpatient clinics, inpatient wards, and consult services, and may also be introduced to local community organizations that provide health education, patient navigation services, and other resources that they may refer their patients to.

name: — Scholarly Project
description: Course Description: Develop a research project on a focused topic area, implements the research, writes a publishable paper, and presents an oral summary of the project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; project proposal must be accepted by the Scholarly Project Executive Committee (SPEC).

name: — Scholarly Project Selective
description: Course Description: Individual, scholarly project, approved by mentor. Includes scientific inquiry, development of a testable hypothesis or clinical research and concludes with written report and public, oral, presentation, taking place during Clerkship curriculum phase.

name: — Medical Student Research Fellowship
description: Course Description: Independent research project as part of the Medical Student Research Fellowship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students in good standing; competency with computers.

name: — Global Population, Health, & Environment
description: Course Description: Students critically examine multi-scale processes involving human, animal, and ecosystem health. Online team and independent work engage local and global topics around population pressures on environments and environmental pressures on populations.

name: — Knights Landing One Health Center
description: Course Description: Internship at Knights Landing One Health Center (KLOHC) for undergraduate pre-veterinary student. Application of veterinary and One Health concepts to their work at the center.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VME 125L (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

name: — Knights Landing One Health Center Lab
description: Course Description: Internship at Knights Landing One Health Center (KLOHC) for undergraduate pre-veterinary students. Interns may offer technical help, assist with patient registration and records, animal handling, and foreign language interpretation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VME 125 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

name: — Infectious Disease in Ecology & Conservation
description: Course Description: Introduction to the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife, including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Basic epidemiological models and application to field data. Scientists' role in developing disease control policies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; or equivalent. EVE 100 is recommended.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: — Special Studies for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special studies for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Evaluation & Use of Diagnostic Tests
description: Course Description: Clinical and epidemiologic properties and application of diagnostic tests for disease, with emphasis on selecting tests; validating, evaluating, and interpreting new tests individually and in aggregate; determining cutoff values; and developing testing strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 205 or EPI 205; consent of instructor.

name: — Viral Pathogenesis Seminar/Journal Club
description: Course Description: Participatory seminar addressing the mechanisms of retroviral pathogenesis in a journal club format. Focus on the review of current scientific journal papers concerning viral pathogenesis, immunology and virology with a special focus on retroviruses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student status in the Comparative Pathology, Microbiology or Immunology graduate groups.

name: — Infectious Disease in Ecology & Conservation
description: Course Description: Presentation, analysis and discussion of primary literature on the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife, including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Multidisciplinary approach combines perspectives of ecology and veterinary medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VME 158 must be taken concurrently.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study in selected areas of the clinical sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Student in School of Veterinary Medicine or consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Early Medieval Culture
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Readings (in translation) in medieval culture, such as Codes of Justinian, Confessions of Saint Augustine, Beowulf, the Nibelungenlied, The Song of Roland, the Summa Theologica of Thomas Aquinas, the Chronicles of Froissart, Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, and Dante's Divine Comedy.

name: — The Culture of the High Middle Ages
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Great transformations that created the modern world: Constitutional Government, the Hundred Years War, the Black Death, and the Peasants Revolts, the Renaissance, Reformation and Counter-Reformation, and the Baroque.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Student Facilitated Course
description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

name: — Special Themes in Medieval Cultures
description: Course Description: Each offering concentrates on an interdisciplinary aspect of medieval culture in the Middle East and Europe: the idea of the hero, mysticism, urban development. Extensive readings focused on medieval source material.

name: — Special Themes in Renaissance Culture
description: Course Description: Each theme illuminates an interdisciplinary aspect of Renaissance culture in the eastern and western hemispheres: exploration, medical pathology, daily life, baroque culture. Immersion in source material from 1500-1650.

name: — Cross-Cultural Relations in the Medieval and/or Early Modern World
description: Course Description: Medieval and/or Renaissance aspects of cross culturalism. Relations between Christians, Jews, and Muslims: Europeans, Africans, and Asians; Old World and New World.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MST 020A or MST 020B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Medieval & Early Modern Culture
description: Course Description: Focus on a particular problem or issue in the Medieval or Early Modern periods. Seminar topics might include (but not limited to) monasticism, origins of the university, chivalry, exploration, the role of women in the Medieval and Early Modern world.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MST 020A or MST 020B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Senior Thesis
description: Course Description: Preparation of a research paper dealing with a selected aspect of medieval culture, under supervision of three members of the Committee in Charge.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing and major in Medieval Studies.

name: — Tutoring in Medieval Studies
description: Course Description: Tutoring in MST 020A & MST 020B, including leadership in small discussion groups affiliated with the course.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MST 020A; MST 020B; upper division standing; consent of instructor and chairperson of curriculum committee.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Student Facilitated Course
description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for upper division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will offer under 098F/198F.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
description: Course Description: Student facilitated. Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching Assistant training practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Microbial Biology
description: Course Description: Designed to provide an overview of various aspects of microbiology and microbial processes. Topics will include microbial genetics and genomics, microbial metabolism, signaling, and adaptations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102; or equivalent; prior coursework in Microbiology.

name: — Advanced Microbiology Laboratory Rotations
description: Course Description: Two five-week assignments in microbiology research laboratories. Individual research problems with emphasis on methodological/procedural experience and experimental design.

name: — Microbial Interactions
description: Course Description: Analysis at the molecular level of the interactions of microbes with the environment, microbes with other microbes, and microbes in symbiotic and/or pathogenic associations with eukaryotic hosts. Topics discussed will vary.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIB 200A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Research Conference
description: Course Description: Presentation and critical discussion of staff research activities. Designed for advanced graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research under the guidance of dissertation committee.

name: — Natural History of Infectious Diseases
description: Course Description: Topics in the natural history of infectious diseases principally affecting humans. Introduction to infectious microbial agents, ecology, epidemiology, and induction of disease. Focus on diseases of a contemporary nature.

name: — Introduction to Research
description: Course Description: Discussion of faculty research focusing on the biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology of microorganisms, along with ways undergraduates can participate in research projects of faculty members.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; or equivalent.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introductory Microbiology
description: Course Description: Survey of microorganisms emphasizing their interactions with humans and diseases. Topics include microscopy, survey of various microbes, the immune system, food microbiology, microbial pathogens, and mechanisms of disease transmission. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional schools.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A or BIS 002A); CHE 002B (can be concurrent).

name: — Introductory Microbiology
description: Course Description: Essentials of microbial biology, emphasizing phylogeny, physiology, genetics, ecology, and pathogenesis. Interactions with other microbes, humans, and the biosphere. Uses of microbes in agriculture and biotechnology. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A or BIS 002A); CHE 002B (can be concurrent).

name: — Introductory Microbiology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Introduction to principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional school admission. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102 C- or better; CHE 002B.

name: — General Microbiology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms. Designed for students continuing in microbiology, genetics, or biochemistry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102 C or better; (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 129A); and consent of instructor.

name: — Microbial Diversity
description: Course Description: Survey of the major groups of microorganisms emphasizing diversity of energy metabolism, morphology, evolution, and natural history.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102 or MIC 104; BIS 101; BIS 103 or BIS 105 strongly recommended.

name: — Microbial Diversity Laboratory
description: Course Description: Classical enrichments for the isolation of metabolically diverse microbes; modern molecular methods for the identification of isolates; cultivation independent analysis of microbial communities from local environmental samples.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MIC 102 or MIC 104); (MIC 102L or MIC 104L); MIC 105 (can be concurrent).

name: — Human Microbiology
description: Course Description: Biology of microorganisms that form commensal, mutualistic, and pathogenic relationships with human beings, emphasizing their phylogeny, physiology, genetics, and ecology. Effects on human nutrition, development and physiology. Mechanisms of pathogenesis, immune response evasion, antibiotic action, and antibiotic resistance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102; BIS 101.

name: — Recombinant DNA Cloning & Analysis
description: Course Description: Cloning and analysis of recombinant DNA, with emphasis on Escherichia coli host-vector systems. DNA-modifying enzymes; vectors and their use; manipulation and expression of insert DNA; polymerase chain reaction; and sequence annotation. Graduate students see MIC 215.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; or the equivalent.

name: — Analysis of Molecular Genetic Circuits
description: Course Description: Project-based course focused on problem-solving strategies in biology and medicine. Testing hypotheses by translating real-world problems into an appropriate mathematical model and translating the results into real-world understanding.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; MAT 017A; MAT 017B; MAT 017C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Microbial Ecology
description: Course Description: Interactions between non-pathogenic microorganisms and their environment, emphasizing physiological and metabolic characteristics of various groups and their adaptation to and modification of specific habitats.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 105; (BIS 102 or BIS 105).

name: — Bacterial Physiology
description: Course Description: Fundamentals of bacterial growth and bacterial responses to environmental stresses. Topics will include carbon and nitrogen regulation, growth rate control, post-exponential growth, and motility and chemotaxis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 101,  BIS 102,  BIS 103 (can be concurrent)) or (BIS 101,  BIS 105); MIC 102 recommended.

name: — Genomes of Pathogenic Bacteria
description: Course Description: Molecular genetics and comparative genomics of representative pathogenic bacteria. Roles of mobile genetic elements, lateral gene transfer, and genome rearrangements in pathogen evolution. Mutation, recombination, and complementation as tools for genetic analysis. Content includes close examination of primary research articles.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102; BIS 101.

name: — Bacterial Physiology Lab
description: Course Description: Physiology and genetics of bacteria. Isolation and characterization of mutant strains. Mapping of mutations by conjugation and transduction studies of control of enzyme synthesis by induction, repression, and catabolite repression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MIC 140 or MIC 150); MIC 120L; and consent of instructor.

name: — General Virology
description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of the nature of animal, bacterial, and plant viruses, including their structure, replication and genetics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102 or BIS 105 recommended.

name: — Yeast Molecular Genetics
description: Course Description: Survey of the genetics, cell biology and technologies in yeasts and related lower eukaryotes. Topics include diversity of yeasts; cell structure; metabolism; cell cycle; genetic approaches and genomics; gene expression; yeasts as models to study higher eukaryotes; and contemporary techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; MIC 102 or MIC 105 strongly recommended.

name: — Host-Parasite Interactions
description: Course Description: Exploration of host-parasite interactions at multiple levels, with an emphasis on global health and medically important human parasites.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102 or MIC 101 or MIC 104; BIS 101; Biological Sciences 102 or 105 strongly recommended.

name: — Cancer Biology
description: Course Description: Exploration of the causes and treatments of cancer at multiple levels: molecular/cell biology, clinical manifestations, epidemiology and prevention.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (BIS 102 or BIS 105).

name: — Undergraduates Research Conference
description: Course Description: Presentation and critical discussion of staff research activities: designed for advanced undergraduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 199 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; upper division standing; MIC 199 required concurrently.

name: — Introduction to Research for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Discussion of faculty research focusing on the biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology of microorganisms, along with ways undergraduates can participate in research projects of faculty members.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; or equivalent.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Technical and/or professional experience on or off campus. Supervised by a member of the Microbiology Section faculty.

name: — Microbiology Honors Research
description: Course Description: Continuation of an individual microbiological research project culminating in writing of a senior thesis under a faculty director.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; eligibility for college honors; completion of 6 units of MIC 199; consent of section.

name: — Tutoring in Microbiology
description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor in one of the section's regular courses by tutoring individual or small groups of students in a laboratory, in voluntary discussion groups, or other voluntary course activities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Bacteriology
description: Course Description: Intended for first-year graduate students in Microbiology and closely-related fields. Advanced topics in phylogeny, physiology and diversity of bacteria.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIB 200A.

name: — Recombinant DNA
description: Course Description: Application of recombinant DNA technology to modern problems in biology, biochemistry, and genetics, emphasizing molecular cloning strategies, choice of vectors, preparation of insert DNA, and selection procedures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 103; or the equivalent.

name: — Analysis of Molecular Genetic Circuits
description: Course Description: Project-based course focused on problem-solving strategies in biology. Emphasis on testing hypotheses by translating real-world problems into an appropriate mathematical model and translating the results into real-world understanding.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced General & Molecular Virology
description: Course Description: Advanced integrated presentation of animal, bacterial, and plant viruses, including their structure, modes of regulation, expression and replication, and effects on host cells and organisms.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Principles of Protein-Nucleic Acid Interactions
description: Course Description: Physical basis of protein-nucleic acid interaction. Topics include nucleic acid recognition by proteins, thermodynamics of protein-nucleic acid stability, and kinetics of binding process for both non-specific and sequence-specific nucleic acid binding proteins. Emphasis on systems that represent paradigms in protein-nucleic acid interactions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced graduate standing and completion of one year of basic graduate course work in biochemistry, biophysics, chemistry, genetics, microbiology, or molecular biology.

name: — Seminar in Genetic Recombination
description: Course Description: Biochemical and genetic aspects of genetic recombination in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Mechanisms of recombination and biochemical and genetic characteristics of recombination proteins. Proteins include DNA strand exchange, DNA helicases, and Holliday junction resolving proteins.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Seminar in DNA Repair & Recombination
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current research and literature in DNA repair and recombination with presentations by individual students and invited speakers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing in Microbiology or closely-related field.

name: — Advanced Concepts in DNA Metabolism
description: Course Description: DNA damage checkpoints, homologous recombination, and meiotic recombination. An advanced treatment of the clinical and current literature to discuss emerging principles and current models in these research areas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 221C or GGG 201C or equivalent course recommended.

name: — Advanced Research Conference
description: Course Description: Presentation and critical discussion of staff research activities. Designed for advanced graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Selected Topics in Microbiology
description: Course Description: Current progress in microbiology and cellular and molecular biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Seminar in Bacterial Physiology & Genetics
description: Course Description: Review and discussion of current research and literature in bacterial physiology and genetics, with presentations by individual students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing in Microbiology or closely-related field.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship on and off campus in the area of Middle East & South Asia Studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Middle East & South Asia: Comparative Perspectives
description: Course Description: Ethnographic and historical points of intersection and divergence in various aspects of the Middle East and South Asia in precolonial, colonial, and postcolonial societies. Anthropological, historical, and theoretical debates surrounding the region.

name: — Great Cities of Arab Middle East & South Asia
description: Course Description: In-depth examination of the great cities of North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia as cultural and historical artifacts. Topics include: the concept of the Islamic city, processes of modernity, and representations that reinforce imagination, memory and personal identity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; some knowledge of Islamic/Middle Eastern history is very useful.

name: — History of South Asian Islam
description: Course Description: Comparative study of Muslim communities of South Asia. Commonalities in cultural identity and historical experience. Rise and spread of Islam, comparative history of Islamic Empires, colonial rule, and post-colonial nationalism.

name: — Shahnameh: The Persian Book of Kings
description: Course Description: In-depth analysis of the Persian Book of Kings (Shahnameh) by Abu al-Qasim Ferdowsi (d. 1020 CE) in its historical context with a comparative perspective on the role of this work in Persian and world literature.

name: — A Story for a Life: The Arabian Nights
description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of The Arabian Nights, the best-known work of pre-modern Arabic literature and a major work of world literature. Analysis of the work in its historical context and in comparison to other frame tales in world literature.

name: — Themes in the Arabic Novel
description: Course Description: Select modern Arabic fiction (novels and short stories) in translation. Thematically connected readings supplemented by non-fictional writings when appropriate.

name: — Modern Iranian Cinema
description: Course Description: Iranian cinema of the 20th century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Iran especially since the Iranian Revolution. Productions by representative directors such as Kiarostami, Makhmalbaf, Bahram Beizaie are included. Knowledge of Persian not required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

name: — Modern South Asia Cinema
description: Course Description: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Religion & Media in Arab World
description: Course Description: Exploration of the role and experience of media technologies in the Arab world. Study of digital and electronic media as well as alternative media practices. Investigation of new trends in political activism and identity formation.

name: — Women & Islamic Discourses
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the debates/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debates/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debates/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, feminist and religious movements.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 050; or comparable course.

name: — Iranian Society & Culture
description: Course Description: In-depth investigation of modern Iranian society and culture. Exploration of structures of Iranian society: family, gender, religion, minorities, economy, politics, and state. Iran’s role in the globalizing world, and the role of Iranian diasporas.

name: — Topics in Middle East & South Asian Studies
description: Course Description: Comparative perspective on the Middle East and South Asia. Topics may include: modernity, religious traditions, colonialism, subalternity and social movements, gender and sexuality, history and memory, science and development, ritual and performance, public culture, diasporas.

name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
description: Course Description: Iran & Persian topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
description: Course Description: Indian/South Asia topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies: Arab Studies
description: Course Description: Arab Studies topics.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia
description: Course Description: Seminar in Iran & Persian topics specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSA 100 recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia
description: Course Description: Seminar in India/South Asia topics specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSA 100 recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia: Arab Studies Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminar in Arab Studies topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSA 100 recommended.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship on and off campus in the area of Middle East & South Asia Studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Independent study of a problem in Middle East/South Asian studies involving the writing of an honors thesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to majors of senior standing who qualify for honors program.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
