description: Course Description: Social, political, cultural movements of indigenous South Americans in response to establishment, expansion of European colonialism, post-colonial nation-states. Ethnopolitical processes developed through interactions between Indians, Euroamericans. Socioethnographic analysis of main indigenous areas and the development of national societies. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 001; (NAS 010 or NAS 055).

name: — Corporate Colonialism
description: Course Description: Price of progress and modernity for native and non-native people. History of the corporation and neoliberalism, military and intelligence agencies, debt, Taylorism, education institutions, media, and law. Discussion of alternatives advocated by contemporary and indigenous social movements.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 001, NAS 010 or NAS 012 encouraged, but not required.

name: — Native American Community Development
description: Course Description: Application of community development theory and techniques to the development problems of Native American communities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 001 or NAS 010.

name: — Native Foods & Farming of the Americas
description: Course Description: Crop domestication, agrodiversity, and cuisines of the Americas. Cultural and social history of native American foods like maize, potatoes, quinoa, chocolate, peppers, beans, avocados, etc. Discussion of socio-economic, environmental, legal challenges facing indigenous and peasant farmers today.

name: — Performance & Culture Among Native Americans
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary study of public expressive forms among Native Americans. Comparison and analysis of music, dances, rituals, and dramas from throughout North, Central, and South America in their social and cultural contexts. Extensive film viewing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Native American Ethno-Historical Development
description: Course Description: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America before 1770s.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Native American Ethno-Historical Development
description: Course Description: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America, 1770-1890.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Native American Ethno-Historical Development
description: Course Description: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America after 1890.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Ethnohistory of Native People of Mexico & Central America
description: Course Description: Ethnohistorical development of pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial Mexican and Central American indigenous people; the impact of economic and political factors on the process of cultural adaptation. Attention is given to the questions of nation-building, forced assimilation, indigenous resistance, organized political responses.

name: — Ethnohistory of Native Peoples of Mexico & Central America to 1500
description: Course Description: Ethnohistorical development of the indigenous peoples of Mexico and Central America up to and including the earliest period of European contact. Focus is on indigenous written historical records of the Maya, Mixtec, and Nahuatl peoples.

name: — Ethnohistory of Native Peoples of Mexico & Central America 1500 to 2000
description: Course Description: Ethnohistory of indigenous peoples of Mexico and Central America from 1500 to contemporary times. Focus on social and cultural dynamics, particularly the role of indigenous people in the process of nation-state building in Mexico and Central America.

name: — Race, Culture, & Nation
description: Course Description: Exploration of complexities of Native American racial, cultural and national identities and alliances. Study of tribal and federal citizenship, mixed descent and diasporic people(s), claims to resources, ethnic fraud and contemporary movements of cultural resurgence and political sovereignty and self-determination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.

name: — Gender Construction in Native Societies
description: Course Description: Historical and traditional Native American constructions of feminine, masculine, and non-binary genders with attention to culture- and place-based gender roles and statuses. Analysis of problems with contemporary terminologies and impacts of colonization on contemporary constructions of gender identities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.

name: — Orientation to Research in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic research resources pertinent to Native American subjects available in the region, including libraries, archives, museums, etc. Emphasis on learning to use documentary resources or other collections of data. Students will carry out individual projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; Native American Studies major or minor, or consent of instructor; NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.

name: — Native American Religion & Philosophy
description: Course Description: Religious and philosophical traditions of Native American/indigenous peoples of the Americas.

name: — California Indian Environmental Policy I
description: Course Description: Contemporary California Indian environmental policy issues, with a focus on water, minerals, contamination, and alliance-building. Issues will be placed within historical and political context, drawing on theories of Native environmental ethics, environmental justice, and Federal Indian law.

name: — California Indian Environmental Policy II
description: Course Description: Contemporary California Indian environmental policy issues, with a focus on planning, site protection, and collaborative structures. Issues will be placed within historical and political context, drawing on theories of Native environmental ethics, environmental justice, and Federal Indian law.

name: — Keepers of the Flame: Native American Cultural Burning & Land Stewardship in California
description: Course Description: Use of fire by California Indian tribes to maintain ecosystems that sustain their economic, cultural, and spiritual well being. Guests include Native American cultural practitioners and prescribed fire professionals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): consent of instructor; course involves regular field days working with cultural burn practitioners.

name: — Native American Women
description: Course Description: Native American women's life experiences, cross-cultural comparisons of gender roles, and Native women's contemporary feminist thought. Utilizes texts from literature, social science, and autobiography/biography.

name: — Native American Literature
description: Course Description: Works of fiction (short story, novel) by contemporary Native American authors, with an emphasis on writers from the United States.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 005 or ENG 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003.

name: — Native American Literature
description: Course Description: Works by or about Native Americans including non-fiction novels, biographies and autobiographies. Explore ways Native Americans create and recreate their culture through the creative process in literature. Examine from a critical perspective autobiographies and testimonial literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 005 or ENG 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003.

name: — Contemporary Native American Poetry
description: Course Description: Works of poetry by contemporary Native American/indigenous poets, with some attention to traditional cultural poetic expressions.

name: — Contemporary Indigenous Literature of Mexico
description: Course Description: Contemporary indigenous literature of Mexico, with a focus on the genres (poetry, fiction, drama, essay); analysis of cultural, historical, and spiritual themes, imagery, styles and performances; biographies of and influences on the Native writers themselves.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 001 or NAS 010; NAS 181A or NAS 181C recommended; reading knowledge of Spanish required.

name: — Native American Literature in Performance
description: Course Description: Performance of contemporary Native American literature onstage, through adaptations of selected literature as well as the creation of  original pieces.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Native American Literary Studies
description: Course Description: Special topics drawn from Native American literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and one of the following recommended: NAS 005, NAS 010, NAS 181A, NAS 181C.

name: — Powwow Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship for the annual UC Davis Powwow.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Seminar of critical issues faced by Native American people.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior Standing.

name: — Topics in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Selected topics in Native American Studies related to indigenous knowledges and worldviews from a historical, cultural, hemispheric perspective.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised internship in the CN Gorman Museum, community, and institutional settings related to Native American concerns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern position in Native American Studies or the CN Gorman Museum, with priority to Native American Studies minors/majors.

name: — Special Studies for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or project under direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior qualifying for honors.

name: — Special Studies for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or project under direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior qualifying for honors.

name: — Field Experience in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Field work with governmental and community groups, under supervision of faculty advisor and sponsor. Knowledge acquired in other courses to be applied in field work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 161; senior standing and major in Native American Studies, completion of lower division major requirements.

name: — Senior Project in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Guided research project that enables student to apply the theory and research principles from major course work. Final product is to be a major senior project or thesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 195 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; senior standing and major in Native American Studies.

name: — Community Tutoring in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Supervise tutoring in community.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of major committee; upper division standing with major in Native American Studies.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Basic Concepts in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Analysis of characteristics of the discipline of Native American Studies. Concentration of traditional and contemporary native scholarship and thought as well as theoretical and methodological consequences derived from application of these ideas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Advanced Topics in Native American Studies
description: Course Description: Advanced study of selected topics or themes relevant to the field of Native American studies. Topics will be announced at the time of offering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Leadership Skills & Strategies in California Language Documentation & Revitalization
description: Course Description: Introduction to the indigenous languages of the Americas, with a focus on California; an examination of how contemporary Native communities document and revitalize their heritage languages. Learn to assist and administer language programs.

name: — Advanced Study of Native American Languages
description: Course Description: Advanced study of Native American languages. Development of proficiency in a particular language in order to incorporate language into Native American Studies research and argumentation. Engagement with theoretical perspectives on social, cultural, and structural dimensions of language to guide language study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NAS 107 or equivalent background with a Native American language.

name: — Community Development for Sovereignty & Autonomy
description: Course Description: Examines a sample of contemporary indigenous communities from south, central and north America with the goal of understanding and evaluating the strategies adopted by Native American communities to develop and implement forms of sovereignty or autonomous self-management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Native Criminality & Deviance
description: Course Description: Examination of "deviance" in Native communities with focus on Native criminality in North America. Analysis of the concept of deviance from several different world views. Readings from a range of theories to incorporate varying theoretical perspective on criminality and deviance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Public Law 83-280: Colonial Termination
description: Course Description: Examination of the signature law of the Termination Era, Public Law 83-280. Discussions to include termination, societal conformity, political consent, jurisdiction, self-determination & decolonization, and colonial relationship between Native Peoples and the United States.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing, including school of law students.

name: — Colonialism, Neoliberalism, & Indigenous Self-Determination
description: Course Description: History, political economy and legacies of imperial/colonial systems. Continuities and discontinuities with corporate globalization and neoliberalism. Focus on resistance and self-determination of indigenous peoples, but with comparison to other groups.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Performance in the Americas
description: Course Description: Ethnomusicological and anthropological approaches to study of public performance in the Americas. New ways of looking at music, dance, rituals and other forms of public expressive forms normally called "folklore" or "popular culture."
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Visual Sovereignty
description: Course Description: Extensively examine the field of contemporary Native American and Indigenous photography, film and performance through research of artworks, writings by artists, theorists, and material in museum collections.

name: — Native American Art Collections & Museums
description: Course Description: Research and examination of regional Native American art held in museums and other public institutions, as well as privately-held collections. Includes onsite viewing and research of museum collections and archives.

name: — Native American Public Health: Topics & Issues
description: Course Description: Introduction to Native American public health issues and contributing causal factors (including environmental justice and historical trauma); the dimensions of cultural competency in diagnosis and service provision; the structure of Native health care institutions; and debates in Native treatment modalities.

name: — Native American/Indigenous Research Methodologies
description: Course Description: Introduction to advanced methodologies currently influencing research in Native American Studies and among Indigenous communities. Develop an original project and course assignments will guide them through the process of research design and implementation.

name: — Indigenous Critique of Classic Maya Ethnographies
description: Course Description: Construction of the Maya world through ethnographic writing during the present century. Deconstruction of ethnographies about the Mayans considering the modern theories and social/anthropological critiques of modern ethnographies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Native American Literature
description: Course Description: Introduction to the field of Native American Literature, creative works (fiction, poetry, memoir, personal essay), literary studies.

name: — Indigenous Religious Traditions in the Americas
description: Course Description: Religious/spiritual traditions, belief-systems, and world-views of Native American/indigenous peoples in the Americas. Land, ecological knowledge, sacred sites, the role of tricksters, language (revitalization), gender, ethics of representation, cultural revitalization, renewed ancient knowledge and practices, ceremonial (and daily) performance of the sacred, music, the arts, the worlds of the sacred, the rules of the sacred, freedom of religion.

name: — Ethnohistorical Theory & Method
description: Course Description: Discussion of the ethnohistorical method; the utilization of diverse types of data, especially documentary sources, to reconstruct socio-cultural history. Particular attention to the applied area of ethnohistory in the solution of contemporary social problems.

name: — Group Study for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Group study for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Special Study for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — General Biology
description: Course Description: Concepts and issues in biology. Emphasis on composition and structure of organisms; regulation and signaling; heredity, evolution and the interaction and interdependence among life forms and their environments. Designed for students not specializing in biology.

name: — Plant Nematology
description: Course Description: Plant-parasitic nematodes. Cellular, biochemical, and molecular aspects of plant-nematode interaction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101.

name: — Introduction to Nematology
description: Course Description: Relationship of nematodes to the human environment. Classification, morphology, ecology, distribution, and importance of nematodes occurring in water and soil as parasites of plants and animals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular & Physiological Plant Nematology
description: Course Description: Molecular biology and physiology of nematodes using Caenorhabditis elegans as a model, but with emphasis on plant-parasitic species. Plant responses to nematodes. Discussion of current literature emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; PLP 120; (NEM 100 or NEM 110).

name: — Ecology of Parasitic Nematodes
description: Course Description: Major concepts in population and community ecology of animal- and plant-parasitic nematodes. Current advances in techniques, theory, and basic information about nematode-host dynamics, and application to management of nematode diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NEM 100 or NEM 110 or ENT 156); (EVE 101 or PLB 117).

name: — Management of Plant-Parasitic Nematodes
description: Course Description: Theory, foundation, principles and practices of nematode management. Techniques and equipment used to manage nematodes and methods used to analyze their effectiveness.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NEM 100 or NEM 110.

name: — Insect Nematology & Biological Control
description: Course Description: Biology of insect-parasitic nematodes, their effect on the host, and their potential as biological control agents of insect and other invertebrate pests. Application of ecological theory in classical and augmentative biological control.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NEM 100; NEM 110; (ENT 100 or ENT 110).

name: — Nematode Systematics & Evolution
description: Course Description: Nematode diversity as revealed by morphological and molecular evidence. Laboratory experience focuses on structural features used in taxonomy. Phylogenetic relationships based on morphological and molecular data used to consider patterns of character change among taxa.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NEM 100 or NEM 110 or ENT 156; EVE 100 recommended.

name: — Molecular Phylogenetic Analysis
description: Course Description: Theory and practice of inferring phylogenetic trees using molecular sequence data. Practical techniques for obtaining sequence data, advantages and disadvantages of common approaches for inferring trees, statistical methods for comparing alternative hypotheses.

name: — Field Nematology
description: Course Description: Six-day demonstration and field study in applied nematology including diagnosis and prediction of nematode field problem strategies for control field plot design, and establishment in association with diverse California crops.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NEM 100.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminar.

name: — Advanced Research Conference
description: Course Description: Planning and results of research programs, proposals, and experiments. Discussion and critical evaluation of original research being conducted by the group. Discussion led by individual research instructors for research group.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Nephrology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in nephrology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

name: — Nephrology Research
description: Course Description: Research topics in Nephrology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Curriculum Design for Doctoring
description: Course Description: Design of Doctoring curriculum for medical students in focused topic areas to be announced annually. Students design sessions, consider resource needs, and work with IORs to initiate the curriculum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; second-year standing in School of Medicine.

name: — Nephrology & Fluid Balance
description: Course Description: Active participation in all inpatient/outpatient clinical activities, attendance at specific lectures and conferences at UC Davis Medical Center covering the field of nephrology and fluid-electrolyte disorders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of third-year medical school; completion of Medicine Core Clerkship.

name: — Research in Nephrology
description: Course Description: Independent laboratory research on a specific problem related to biochemical or immunologic causes of renal disease and/or uremic disorders in humans or animals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; individual arrangement.

name: — Elementary Human Physiology
description: Course Description: Introduction to physiology for non-science majors. Includes basic cell physiology and survey of major organ systems and how they function in homeostasis and human health.

name: — Exercise & Fitness: Principles & Practice
description: Course Description: Human movement from physiological, psychological, sociological, and historical perspectives. Biology and psychology of exercise across the human lifespan.

name: — The Human Brain & Disease
description: Course Description: Normal function and diseases of the human brain and nervous system. Diseases discussed include Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, leprosy, amnesia and schizophrenia. Intended for non-science majors.

name: — Extreme Animal Athletes
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Overview of biomechanics, focusing on animal locomotion. Physical principles underlying traits such as speed, maneuverability, endurance, and precision. Comparisons of animals and human athletes performing similar feats, with animals often outperforming humans by a wide margin. Biomechanical concepts through hands-on exercises, problem sets, and readings from the scientific literature.

name: — Illusions: Fooling the Brain
description: Course Description: Introduction to perceptual processing in the human nervous system; illusions.

name: — The Biology & Physiology of Aging
description: Course Description: Broad examination of age-associated changes in body functions. Includes basic cell physiology, a survey of major organ systems and the age-induced alterations in system function. Some age-associated diseases will also be examined. Intended for non-science majors.

name: — The Biology & Physiology of Aging
description: Course Description: Broad examination of the biological and physiological basis of aging in animals and plants. Concepts in demographic, evolutionary, genetic, and cell aging. Major human organ systems, age-related alterations in system function, and age-related diseases. Intended for non-science majors.

name: — The Path to Cyborgs: Introduction to Prostheses & Human Machine Interfaces
description: Course Description: Interface of biology and technology. Mind-controlled prosthetic limbs, artificial organs, and implantable devices. Emphasis on basic physiological functions and how they can be replaced by devices. Suitable for majors and non-majors.

name: — Biological Science for Social Justice
description: Course Description: Broad survey of the many ways one can use the biological sciences to better the lives of others and break down barriers that have restricted social mobility.

name: — Biology of Drug Addiction & Abuse
description: Course Description: Broad examination of addictive substances and their use/abuse. Topics include historical perspective, physiological effects, etiology, neurobiology of addiction and the impact of drugs on contemporary society. Intended for non-science majors.

name: — Lower Division Seminar: Issues in Body Weight Regulation
description: Course Description: Critical examination of issues in body weight regulation through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, debates and oral presentations. Limited enrollment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Human Color Perception
description: Course Description: Neural determinants of color appearance, and why we see the world in the way we do. Discussions center around demonstrations of color phenomena and what they tell us about the human brain.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

name: — Current Issues in Animal Behavior
description: Course Description: The mechanisms and outcomes of sexual selection (mate choice and mate competition). Theory, current models and evidence that supports or refutes the models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

name: — Lower Division Seminar: Current Issues in Reproductive Endocrinology
description: Course Description: The integrative roles of reproductive hormones in mammalian reproduction and health. Current theory and models regarding hormone function and use in reproductive health and contraception, and evidence that supports or refutes the models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

name: — Biology of Aging
description: Course Description: Current theories on the biology of aging covering genetic, biochemical, and physiological aspects. Emphasis on critical evaluation of controversial and contemporary issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Freshman standing.

name: — Visual Impairment & Blindness: A World Wide Problem
description: Course Description: Examination of various abnormalities of the eye and the important geographic and cultural factors that influence the epidemiology of those abnormalities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

name: — Research Conference
description: Course Description: Research findings and methods in neurobiology, physiology, and/or behavior. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 099 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; lower division standing in Neurobiology, Physiology and Behavior or related biological science; NPB 099 required concurrently.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Lower division standing.

name: — Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Brains and nervous systems, neurons and neural circuits. Coordination of movement. Development of nervous systems. Vision, hearing, and feature extraction by the central nervous system. The cell biology of learning and memory. Perception, cognition, and disorders of the brain.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; PHY 009A, PHY 009B or PHY 007A, PHY 007B recommended.

name: — Neurobiology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Experimental basis of neurobiology principles discussed in NPB 100. Topics include neurophysiology, sensory systems, motor systems, cellular neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, and quantitative data analysis and modeling techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 (can be concurrent) or NPB 110B (can be concurrent).

name: — Quantitative Foundations of Neurobiology
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Computational methods and mathematical models used to study phenomena in neurobiology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 (can be concurrent).

name: — Systemic Physiology
description: Course Description: Systemic physiology with emphasis on aspects of human physiology. Functions of major organ systems, with the structure of those systems described as a basis for understanding the functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; (CHE 002B or CHE 002BH); PHY 001B or PHY 007C strongly recommended.

name: — Systemic Physiology Discussion
description: Course Description: Discussion and problem solving related to fundamental principles of systemic physiology as presented in NPB 101.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

name: — Systemic Physiology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Selected experiments to illustrate functional characteristics of organ systems discussed in NPB 101.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110C.

name: — Animal Behavior
description: Course Description: Basic principles of behavioral organization in vertebrate and invertebrate animals. Underlying physiological and ethological mechanisms. The evolution of behavior, with special emphasis on behavior under natural conditions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

name: — Quantitative Topics in Animal Behavior
description: Course Description: Study of the quantitative concepts and exemplar models used in animal behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B; NPB 102 (can be concurrent).

name: — Cellular Physiology/Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Cellular physiology with emphasis on membrane transport processes and neuronal physiology. Fundamental physical-chemical and biological mechanisms of membrane transport will be considered in relation to cytoplasmic homeostasis, communication between cells,and the cellular mechanisms of sensory and motor transduction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 103 or BIS 105); BIS 104; PHY 007C recommended.

name: — Cellular Physiology/Neurobiology  Laboratory
description: Course Description: Experiments in the physical and chemical processes of cells and tissues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101L; (BIS 103 or BIS 105).

name: — Experiments in Neurobiology, Physiology, & Behavior: Design & Execution
description: Course Description: Design and execution of experiments in neurobiology, physiology, and/or behavior. Choose and design a project in consultation with the sponsoring faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 110A or NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 102); NPB 199; and consent of instructor.

name: — Cell Signaling in Health & Disease
description: Course Description: Basics of cell signaling pathways, their disruption in disease, and their current utility and future potential as therapeutic targets. Focus is on signaling pathways specific to nervous, endocrine and immune systems, and those fundamental to all cells.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102 or BIS 105.

name: — Animal Behavior Laboratory
description: Course Description: Hybrid course, consisting of limited in-person lectures and the rest laboratory exercises. Laboratory exercises are online, and require students to view and score videos of animal behavior in order to test behavioral hypotheses.

name: — Kinesiology: Analysis & Control of Human Movement
description: Course Description: Functional anatomy, motor control, and biomechanics of human movement understood in the context of body structures, basic principles of physics, and functional characteristics of muscle.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007A; PHY 007B; NPB 101 or NPB 110C recommended; CHA 101 CHA 101L (same as EXB 106 EXB 106L) or equivalent recommended.

name: — Foundations 1: From Molecules to Individuals
description: Course Description: Major concepts in cell biology with special emphasis on connections between cell biology and behavior. Includes: cellular metabolism, cellular sensing and signaling, membrane structure-function, molecular switches, electrical and chemical signaling, endocrine signaling, cell cycle and differentiation, cytoskeleton, and integrative examples. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B); (CHE 002B or CHE 003A); PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended; BIS 002C recommended.

name: — Foundations 2: Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Core concepts of neurobiology including single-neuron biophysics, synapses and transmitters, neuronal development, motor systems, central pattern generation, neuronal circuits, intracellular signal transduction, sensory processing, multisensory integration, autonomic nervous system, neuromodulation, learning and memory, and higher cognition and disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110A C- or better; PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended.

name: — Foundations 3: Physiology
description: Course Description: Focuses on the structure, function, and interactions of human and other animal organ systems in homeostasis and reproduction, and the response to perturbations of homeostasis; neural and endocrine signaling; skeletal muscle and movement; cardiovascular and respiratory systems; renal, digestive, immune, and reproductive physiology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110A C- or better; PHY 007A; PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.

name: — Advanced Systemic Physiology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Selected comprehensive experiments in the autonomic nervous system and the cardiovascular, respiratory, and neuromuscular systems. Emphasis on conceptual and methodological approaches in demonstrating the physiology of organ systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101L.

name: — Cardiovascular, Respiratory, & Renal Physiology
description: Course Description: Intense and advanced presentation of concepts in cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal physiology including discussion of acid-base balance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 110C or NPB 101); CHE 008B, PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.

name: — Gastrointestinal Physiology
description: Course Description: Gastrointestinal anatomy and physiology. Digestion, secretion, absorption, motility, comparative physiology and pathology. Strong emphasis on neural and hormonal regulation and on cellular mechanisms of secretion and absorption.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 110C or NPB 101); BIS 105 or BIS 103 recommended, BIS 105 preferred.

name: — Stress Physiology in Health & Disease
description: Course Description: Adaptive and maladaptive physiological responses to acute and chronic stress in mammals, with emphasis on humans. Role of endocrine and autonomic nervous system in stress response. Prenatal and postnatal effects of stress on cognitive and affective development. Wellness interventions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Avian Physiology
description: Course Description: Physiology of the various systems of birds with emphasis on digestion, respiration, excretion, and endocrine systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B); CHE 002B; NPB 101 or NPB 110C  strongly recommended.

name: — Comparative Biomechanics
description: Course Description: Comparative biomechanics, exploring how animals and other organisms interact with their physical environment. Animal locomotion, form and function of morphological traits, mechanical properties of biological materials, and rules for fluid flow and structural design. Biomechanical concepts through hands-on exercises, quantitative problem sets, and readings from the scientific literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 012 or MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A or MAT 021AH or MAT 021M); (PHY 001A or PHY 007A or PHY 009A); (BIS 002A or BIS 002B or BIS 002C or BIS 010); or consent of instructor.

name: — Physiology of Reproduction
description: Course Description: Physiological mechanisms related to reproduction, breeding efficiency and fertility, with special reference to domestic animals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 110C or ANS 100.

name: — Physiology of Reproduction Laboratory
description: Course Description: Experiments on the reproductive systems of domestic animals including male and female gametes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 121 (can be concurrent).

name: — Developmental Endocrinology
description: Course Description: Hormonal control of development, maturation and senescence from the cellular to organismal level, with emphasis on the human. Prenatal and neonatal life, childhood and adolescence, adulthood and pregnancy, as well as the endocrinology of aging.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101.

name: — Comparative Vertebrate Organology
description: Course Description: Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates. Each system examined from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform diverse physiological functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B).

name: — Comparative Neuroanatomy
description: Course Description: Overview of the neuroanatomy in mammalian vertebrates, focusing on the cerebral cortex and experimental techniques. Examine changes or modifications to neural structures as a result of morphological or behavioral specializations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 100 or NPB 110B or PSC 121.

name: — Comparative Neuroanatomy Laboratory
description: Course Description: Comparative neuroanatomy laboratory illustrating modern neuroanatomical techniques in determining neural connections within the mammalian brain. Includes experimentation and presentation of results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 124 (can be concurrent).

name: — Comparative Physiology: Sensory Systems
description: Course Description: Basic physiological mechanisms involved in sensory systems. Comparative approach to considerations of mechanosensitive systems (audition, lateral lines, touch, echolocation, equilibrium), chemosensitive systems (olfaction, taste, pheromones), photosensitive systems (vision, infrared detection, UV detection), electroreception, and pain. Emphasis on receptors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 101.

name: — Comparative Physiology: Endrocrinology
description: Course Description: Comparison of physiological functions in the animal kingdom: animal hormones and their functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101.

name: — Physiology of the Endocrine Glands
description: Course Description: Advanced presentation of concepts in endocrinology with emphasis on the role of hormones in reproduction, metabolism, and disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ANS 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110C).

name: — Nature vs. Nurture: Physiological Interactions Among Genes, Nutrients & Health
description: Course Description: Biochemical, physiological, genetic, and nutritional causes of important medical problems such as obesity, anorexia, heart disease and diabetes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001A or BIS 002A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Genes & the Brain
description: Course Description: Genetic contributions to brain evolution, development and disorders. Topics include evolution of genomic programs of neurodevelopment and the role of genetics in autism, intellectual disability, and schizophrenia.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110B or NPB 100; or consent of instructor. BIS 101 recommended.

name: — General Immunology for Physiologists
description: Course Description: Immunology for undergrads interested in physiology aimed at understanding the physiological role of immune responses. Illustrated with examples of human diseases including diabetes, allergies and asthma, and emerging diseases such as Ebola and Zika.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 C- or better or NPB 110C C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Neural Networks & Machine Learning in Biology
description: Course Description: Neural networks as models of brain function and as powerful tools in machine learning. How neuroscience and machine learning have shaped each other. Applications of machine learning tools to biological research and health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 017C C or better or MAT 021B C or better; or consent of Instructor; some background in neuroscience, cognitive science or programming (any one of the three) is recommended.

name: — Frontiers in Physiology
description: Course Description: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in physiology. Offered every fourth year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100; NPB 101; NPB 102 (can be concurrent).

name: — Principles of Environmental Physiology
description: Course Description: Physiological aspects of interactions of organisms and environmental, cellular, system, and organismal levels. Emphasis on regulatory responses/mechanisms to thermal, pressure, gravity and light environmental variables.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 110C; BIS 102 recommended.

name: — Physiological Adaptation of Marine Organisms
description: Course Description: Physiological adaptation to the environment among organisms in marine and estuarine habitats.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing; residence at Bodega Marine Laboratory required.

name: — Physiological Adaptation of Marine Organisms/Advanced Laboratory Topics
description: Course Description: Training in scientific research from hypothesis to publication, including methods of library research. Research related to a topic covered in NPB 141.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 141 (can be concurrent); residence at Bodega Marine Laboratory required; NPB 141 required concurrently.

name: — Environmental Endocrinology: Mechanisms for Life Cycles
description: Course Description: Effects of environmental factors on endocrine responses that affect vertebrate life history and fitness. Introduction to finite state machine theory and allostasis in life histories and coping strategies. Focus on life history stages including non-breeding, hibernation, reproduction, migration and moult.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

name: — Neurobiology & Pathophysiology of Mental Illness
description: Course Description: Comparison of the neurobiology and physiology of mental health to the pathophysiology of mental illness. Causative factors of mental illness (e.g., genetic, social, environmental) through a neurobiology and pathophysiology lens (e.g., neurotransmission, neuroimmunology, nervous system malfunction).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 C- or better; or NPB 110B C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Animal Behavior
description: Course Description: Advanced integrative survey of biological principles of behavioral organization, emphasizing historical roots, current research directions, conceptual issues and controversies. Laboratory exercises on the description and analysis of the behavior of captive and free-living animals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 102 or PSC 101; or consent of instructor.

name: — Hormones & Behavior
description: Course Description: Endocrine physiology with an emphasis on the principles of behavior. Fundamental relationships between hormones and various behaviors engaged in by the organism during its lifetime. Role of hormones in behavioral homeostasis, social behavior, reproductive behavior, parental behavior, adaptation to stress.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 101 or NPB 110C); (NPB 102 or PSC 101).

name: — Diabetes: Physiology & Management
description: Course Description: Normal regulation of blood glucose contrasted with dysfunction in diabetes. Types of diabetes, physiological consequences of diabetes, as well as current and future medications and treatments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110C or NPB 101.

name: — Advanced Physiology of Animal/Human Disease
description: Course Description: Centers on fundamental mechanisms and pathophysiological basis for animal and human diseases. Case-based and uses animal and human diseases to help exemplify the physiological consequences of organ dysfunction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 B+ or better or NPB 110C B+ or better; consent of instructor.

name: — Frontiers in Behavior
description: Course Description: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in behavioral biology. Offered every fourth year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 100,  NPB 101,  NPB 102) or (NPB 110A,  NPB 110B,  NPB 110C).

name: — Developmental Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Issues, theoretical concepts, and methodologies in developmental neurobiology. Topics include prenatal and postnatal differentiation of neurons, and plasticity in the mature and aging brain. Integration of neurochemical, structural, physiological and behavioral perspectives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B.

name: — Neural Mechanisms of Behavior
description: Course Description: Relationship between brain and behavior. Identification and analysis of the relevant neural circuits involved. Examples of systems to be considered are birdsong, locomotion, echolocation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B.

name: — Systems Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Concepts and techniques in systems neuroscience: e.g., measuring and manipulating neural activity, structure of neocortex, sensory processing, motor control, storage of information, neural codes, neural mechanisms underlying cognitive functions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 110B; or equivalent basic neuroscience training with consent of instructor.

name: — Mammalian Vision
description: Course Description: Structure and function of the mammalian visual system, from the formation of images on the retina through visually guided behavior and perception. Emphasis on biological mechanisms underlying vision.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 110B or PSC 101.

name: — Neurobiology of Speech Perception
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approach to speech perception with emphasis on functional neuroanatomy and behavior. Topics include auditory processing in time and space, intelligibility in noisy environments, visual speech, evolution of vocal communication, models of speech perception, development, and hearing impairment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110B or NPB 100 or NPB 101; or consent of instructor.

name: — Math Tools for Neuroscience
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to mathematics techniques used in neuroscience. Applications to neuroscience of differential equations, linear algebra, Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, and probability theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 100 or NPB 110B); (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B,  MAT 016C) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B,  MAT 017C) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C); or consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Neuroscience
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Mathematical models and data analysis techniques used to describe computations performed by nervous systems. Lecture topics include single neuron biophysics, neural coding, network dynamics, memory, plasticity, and learning. Lab topics include programming mathematical models and data analysis techniques in MATLAB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 100 or NPB 110B); (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B,  MAT 016C) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B,  MAT 017C) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C); or consent of instructor; PHY 007A, PHY 007B or equivalent recommended.

name: — Neurobiology of Addictive Drugs
description: Course Description: Neurobiological basis for the effects and mechanisms of action of drugs with addictive potential, including opiates (morphine, heroin, methadone), amphetamines, cocaine, nicotine, marijuana (cannabinoids), alcohol, caffeine, and mind-altering drugs such as LSD and antidepressants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 110B or NPB 110C or NPB 101; or equivalents.

name: — Frontiers in Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in neurobiology. Offered every fourth year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 110A.

name: — Physiology of Neuroimmune Interactions
description: Course Description: Explores the complex interactions of the nervous and immune systems, and examine how the systems function together to serve homeostasis, behavior, and disease (such as Alzheimer's, autism, and multiple sclerosis).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; (NPB 012 (can be concurrent) or NPB 100 (can be concurrent) or NPB 110B (can be concurrent)); or consent of instructor; completion of PMI 126 or MMI 188 recommended prior to this course.

name: — Map Formation in the Brain
description: Course Description: Topographic map connection is a fundamental principle for establishing neural network in the brain. Provides comprehensive understanding of the current concepts of map formation in various sensory and motor nervous systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 C- or better or NPB 110B C- or better; or equivalent basic neuroscience training with consent of instructor.

name: — Neurobiology of Brain Disorders
description: Course Description: Examination of brain disorders from a basic science perspective to gain insights into the mechanisms of their action. Genetic, molecular, cellular, circuit, and environmental basis of a variety of brain disorders. How insights about underlying mechanisms may lead to the development of improved therapies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110B or NPB 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference
description: Course Description: Research findings and methods in neurobiology, physiology, and/or behavior. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 199 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; upper division standing in Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior or related biological science; NPB 199 required concurrently.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in neurobiology, physiology, & behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

name: — Neurobiology, Physiology, & Behavior: Honors
description: Course Description: Honors project in Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior. Laboratory research on a specific question. Project is developed with the sponsoring faculty member and approved by the student’s Honors Thesis Committee. Honors thesis to be submitted upon completion of the project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; minimum 3.500 GPA in courses counted toward major; approval by the master advisor.

name: — Neurobiology, Physiology & Behavior: Honors
description: Course Description: Honors project in Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior. Laboratory research on a specific question. Project is developed with the sponsoring faculty member and approved by the student’s Honors Thesis Committee. Honors thesis to be submitted upon completion of the project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; minimum 3.500 GPA in courses counted toward major; approval by the master advisor.

name: — Neurobiology, Physiology, & Behavior: Honors
description: Course Description: Honors project in Neurobiology, Physiology, and Behavior. Laboratory research on a specific question. Project is developed with the sponsoring faculty member and approved by the student’s Honors Thesis Committee. Honors thesis to be submitted upon completion of the project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; minimum 3.500 GPA in courses counted toward major; approval by the master advisor.

name: — Tutoring in Neurobiology, Physiology, & Behavior
description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor by tutoring students in one of the Department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Topics in Neuroimaging
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of the most influential advanced issues in neuroimaging, emphasizing fMRI design/analysis and the integration of fMRI with EEG/MEG.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 210; or consent of instructor.

name: — Light & Fluorescence Microscopy
description: Course Description: Theory and practical application of light and fluorescence microscopy in the biological sciences. Laboratory component focuses on an optics bench, where we build simple compound and confocal microscopes on an optical rail.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Avian Physiology
description: Course Description: Study in depth of a topic in avian physiology through development of a lecture with associated instructional materials such as lesson plan, readings, presentation, and evaluation aids.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 117 required concurrently; and consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Cellular Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Advanced course on cellular and subcellular organization of the nervous system. Membrane channels, sensory transduction, synaptic transmission and cellular aspects of development and learning.

name: — Systems Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Integrative and information-processing aspects of nervous system organization. Topics include sensory systems, motor function, sensorimotor integration, the limbic system, and the neurobiology of learning and memory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Models of Cellular Signaling
description: Course Description: Computational and mathematical techniques in modeling of regulatory and signaling phenomena in neurobiology and cell physiology, focusing on linear and nonlinear ordinary differential equation models. Applications include ion channel kinetics, electrical activity, signal transduction, calcium oscillations, and simple neural circuits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Functional Neurogenomics
description: Course Description: The theory, methods and principles of functional neurogenomics with emphasis on the relationship to molecular mechanisms involved in development and disease of the nervous system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Vision: Eyes & Retinal Mechanisms
description: Course Description: Structure and function of the visual system, with emphasis on the eye and retina, including optics, anatomy, transduction, retinal synapses, adaptation, and parallel processing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or the equivalent; graduate standing.

name: — Topics in Vision: Systems, Psychophysics, Computational Models
description: Course Description: Functions of the central visual pathways and their underlying mechanisms. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NPB 261A recommended.

name: — Topics in Vision: Clinical Vision Science
description: Course Description: Causes and mechanistic bases of major blinding diseases. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system related to disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 261A; NPB 261B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Modeling in Systems Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Modeling as a tool in systems neuroscience. Mathematical techniques will be introduced and used to explore advanced topics in echolocation, sound localization, electroreception, communications, and motor systems. Other topics include transforms, modeling assumptions, scales and linearity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Mathematical models and data analysis techniques used to describe computations performed by nervous systems. Lecture topics include single-neuron biophysics, neural coding, network dynamics, memory, plasticity, and learning. Lab topics include programming mathematical models and data analysis techniques in MATLAB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in general Neuroscience at the level of NPB 100 or NPB 110B; one year college-level Calculus at the level of MAT 016A, MAT 016B, MAT 016C or higher; one year Physics at the level of PHY 007A, PHY 007B, PHY 007C recommended; or consent of instructor.

name: — How to Write a Fundable Grant Proposal in the Biomedical Sciences
description: Course Description: Teaches the do’s and don’ts of writing grants in the biomedical sciences and the mechanisms of the review process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
description: Course Description: Core concepts and methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity. Behavioral paradigms and measurement approaches in human and animal studies of learning and plasticity, as well as a consideration of the functional, anatomical and neuronal mechanisms underlying brain plasticity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
description: Course Description: Core concepts and detailed survey methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity, from the cellular and molecular level to the level of neural circuits. Areas of learning, memory, and plasticity research where recent progress has been made in linking across these levels of analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 271A or NSC 271A or PSC 271A.

name: — Translational Approaches to Learning, Memory, & Plasticity Disorders
description: Course Description: Neurological disorders, the effect of these disorders on learning, memory and plasticity, approved therapeutic options and current research designed to improve understanding and treatment of these diseases: (i) the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and existing therapies, (ii) mechanistic studies in humans and animal models, and (iii) molecular pathways involved in the disease and approaches for drug discovery.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 271B or NSC 271B or PSC 271B.

name: — Literature in Visual Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Literature in visual Neuroscience.

name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Auditory Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Exploration of various important aspects of auditory physiology, behavior and psychophysics through review of original literature. New topic each quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112 or NSC 222; or the equivalent.

name: — Human Clinical Neuroanatomy
description: Course Description: Clinically relevant anatomy of the normal human nervous system, including external and internal anatomy of the brain, spinal cord, and cranial nerves. Blood supply to the brain and spinal cord. Functional neuroanatomy of motor, sensory, and cognitive systems. Application of neuroanatomical principles relevant to clinical problem solving for students entering health care professions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHA 101; or consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Special Study & Research
description: Course Description: Individual special study in neurophysiology and biomedical engineering is offered to qualified students. Studies on psychophysics, single-unit electrophysiology and instrumentation are offered in Davis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: For graduate students desiring to explore particular topics in depth. Lectures and conferences may be involved.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Special Study & Research
description: Course Description: Individual special study and research in Neurophysiology and Biomedical engineering is offered at both Davis and Sacramento Medical Center.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Clinical Neurosciences
description: Course Description: Pathophysiology underlying neurological disorders, including disorders of development, muscle, nerve, cerebral circulation, metabolism, myelin, cortical function, movement, cerebrospinal fluid, autonomic function and special senses. Anatomical basis of clinical testing, nervous system infection, neoplasia and trauma.

name: — Where Drugs Come From: How They are Discovered, Developed, Regulated, & Marketed
description: Course Description: Includes the following topics: Overview of the Drug Discovery Process; Drug Regulation in the United States; Patents and Other Forms of Exclusivity; Drug Targets and Pharmacology; Identification of Lead Candidates; Preclinical Assessment; ADME Including Basic Pharmacokinetic Principles; Principles of Drug Toxicity; Principles of Drug Safety; Clinical Trials; Generic Drugs; Pharmaceutical Industry; Drug Distribution and Marketing; Dietary Supplements; Controlled Substances.

name: — Clinical Neurology Clerkship
description: Course Description: Critical elements of neurological clinical skills (history & exam) and basic and clinical neurological concepts expected for general residency preparation. Active, didactic, experiential and independent learning to encourage maturation of general professional competencies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to all fourth-year medical students; third-year medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Clinical Neurology
description: Course Description: Course teaches the principles and skills necessary to recognize and manage the neurologic diseases a general medical practitioner is most likely to encounter in practice. Students will gain clinical experience in both inpatient and outpatient settings, and learn how to interview patients and their caregivers to obtain a complete and reliable neurologic history and perform a reliable neurologic examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of four-week Neurology selective.

name: — Child Neurology
description: Course Description: Exposure to children with disorders of the nervous system, both in outpatient and inpatient services. Cases presented to a member of full-time faculty who will discuss clinical findings,differential diagnosis, management and therapy. Satisfies fourth-year neuroscience requirement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; OBG 430; PED 430; consent of instructor.

name: — Externship in Neurology
description: Course Description: Externship course for Neurology rotations not meeting the qualifications to be an Acting Internship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Externship in Advanced Neurology
description: Course Description: Away rotation in Neurology where coursework meets the standards to be counted as an Acting Internship.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Issues in Geriatric Care
description: Course Description: Four-week module teaches an approach to common problems in the elderly through history and exam, with an emphasis on integration of underlying anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology in common geriatric presentations.

name: — Group Study in Neurology
description: Course Description: Directed readings and discussions with a comprehensive written examination at the end of course.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Laboratory investigation on selected topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Laboratory Methods in Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Individual research in the laboratory of a faculty member. Research problems emphasize the use of contemporary methods and good experimental design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in the Neuroscience Graduate Group.

name: — Laboratory Methods in Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Individual research in the laboratory of a faculty member. Research problems emphasize the use of contemporary methods and good experimental design.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in the Neuroscience Graduate Group.

name: — Neuroanatomy
description: Course Description: Mix of lectures, demonstrations, and dissections, emphasizing functional significance of neuroanatomy from a biological perspective, with comparisons between human and non-human brains. Emphasis placed on functional anatomy of the nervous system, integrated with cellular, molecular, cognitive, and developmental concepts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advaced Topics in Neuroimaging
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of the most influential advanced issues in neuroimaging, emphasizing fMRI design/analysis and the integration of fMRI with EEG/MEG.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 210; or consent of instructor.

name: — Design to Data: Statistics for Modern Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Statistical methods and applications for neuroscience. Quantitative foundations covering key concepts, methods, and applications, from descriptive analysis through data science. Statistical considerations in experimental design, analysis and statistical testing in hypothesis and data-driven contexts, and responsible conduct of research in the acquisition, storage, analysis, and presentation of scientific data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in neuroscience or related discipline or consent of instructor.

name: — How to Give a Scientific Seminar
description: Course Description: Presentation of effective seminars. Student presentations of selected neuroscience topics in seminar format. Must be taken in two consecutive quarters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Cellular Neurophysiology
description: Course Description: Physiological aspects of cellular and subcellular organization of the nervous system. Neuronal cell biology, the structure and function of ion channels, electrical excitability, signaling cascades, sensory transduction and, mechanisms of synaptic transmission, and the cellular basis of learning and memory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Systems Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Integrative and information-processing aspects of nervous system organization. Topics include sensory systems, motor function, sensorimotor integration, the limbic system, and the neurobiology of learning and memory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Graduate core course for neuroscience. Neurobiological bases of higher mental function including attention, memory, language. One of three in three-quarter sequence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in Psychology or Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of the experiments and methods described in research papers. Readings of seminal, primary research papers, reviews, and book chapters. Reading materials will be distributed one week in advance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Continuation of NSC 224A. Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology, focusing on developmental topics. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of experiments and methods described in associated literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 224A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Translational Research in the Neurobiology of Disease
description: Course Description: Provides an overview of major neuropsychiatric and neurological disorders from both the clinical and fundamental science perspectives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 221 (can be concurrent); NSC 222 (can be concurrent); NSC 223 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; past or concurrent enrollment in NSC 221 NSC 222 NSC 223.

name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology. Topics include neural induction and patterning, neurogenesis, axon guidance, synapse development and remodeling. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of the experiments and methods described in primary seminal research papers and current literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Cellular & Behavioral Neurobiology
description: Course Description: An advanced examination of several currrent problems in neurobiology. Topics vary in different years.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Functional Neurogenomics
description: Course Description: The theory, methods and principles of functional neurogenomics with emphasis on the relationship to molecular mechanisms involved in development and disease of the nervous system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Biology of Neuroglia
description: Course Description: The properties and functions of non-neuronal or neuroglial cells in the mammalian central nervous system with relevance to neuronal development, physiology and injury response.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Vision: Eyes & Retinal Mechanisms
description: Course Description: Structure and function of the visual system, with emphasis on the eye and retina, including optics, anatomy, transduction, retinal synapses, adaptation, and parallel processing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or the equivalent; graduate standing.

name: — Topics in Vision: Systems, Psychophysics, Computational Models
description: Course Description: Functions of the central visual pathways and their underlying mechanisms. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NSC 261A recommended.

name: — Topics in Vision: Clinical Vision Science
description: Course Description: Causes and mechanistic bases of major blinding diseases. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system related to disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 261A; NSC 261B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Mathematical models and data analysis techniques used to describe computations performed by nervous systems. Lecture topics include single neuron biophysics, neural coding, network dynamics, memory, plasticity, and learning. Lab topics include programming mathematical models and data analysis techniques in MATLAB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one course in general Neuroscience at the level of NSC 100; or NPB 110B; one year college-level Calculus at level of MAT 016A, MAT 016B, MAT 016C or higher; one year Physics at the level of PHY 007A, PHY 007B, PHY 007C, recommended; or consent of instructor.

name: — How to Write a Fundable Grant Proposal in the Biomedical Sciences
description: Course Description: Teaches the do's and don'ts of writing grants in the biomedical sciences and the mechanisms of the review process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
description: Course Description: Core concepts and methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity. Behavioral paradigms and measurement approaches in human and animal studies of learning and plasticity, as well as a consideration of the functional, anatomical and neuronal mechanisms underlying brain plasticity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
description: Course Description: Core concepts and detailed survey methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity, from the cellular and molecular level to the level of neural circuits. Areas of learning, memory, and plasticity research where recent progress has been made in linking across these levels of analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 271A or NPB 271A or PSC 271A.

name: — Translational Approaches to Learning, Memory, & Plasticity Disorders
description: Course Description: Neurological disorders, the effect of these disorders on learning, memory and plasticity, approved therapeutic options and current research designed to improve understanding and treatment of these diseases: (i) the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and existing therapies, (ii) mechanistic studies in humans and animal models, and (iii) molecular pathways involved in the disease and approaches for drug discovery.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 271B or NPB 271B or PSC 271B.

name: — Neurobiological Literature
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and analysis of recent journal articles in neurobiology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Development of Sensory Systems
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of recent literature on the development of sensory systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Literature in Visual Neuroscience
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of current literature in visual neuroscience.

name: — Frontiers in Biology of Glia
description: Course Description: Frontiers of glial biology. Research articles in current literature on experimental approaches, technical aspects of experimental techniques, data interpretation, and other topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor

name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
