prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Analysis and discussion of seminal and current research papers in molecular and developmental neurobiology. Different topics will be covered each quarter. In the past topics have included, "Synaptic vesicle dynamics," "Neuronal polarity," and "Glutamate receptors."

name: — Research Conference in Neurobiology
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in neurobiology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 299 required concurrently; graduate standing in Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

name: — Cortical Plasticity & Perception
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of research articles on cortical plasticity and changes in perception. Examples drawn from studies of the somatosensory, visual, auditory, and motor cortex.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or equivalent or consent of instructor.

name: — Literature in Neuroengineering
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of current literature in neuroengineering.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study in Neurosurgery for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Students may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate standing with consent of instructor.

name: — Neurosurgery Research
description: Course Description: Student may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student with consent of instructor.

name: — Neurosurgical Critical Care Clerkship
description: Course Description: Students participate in the care of neurosurgical patients in the NSICU and in the admission and surgical management of patients admitted through the Emergency Room.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year medical student having completed a neurosurgical clerkship or consent of instructor.

name: — Clinical Pediatric Neurosurgery
description: Course Description: Admission and follow-up of pediatric patients. Neurological history, examination, and diagnostic procedures are emphasized. Students will participate in surgical procedures and are required to attend all pediatric neurosurgery conferences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSU 460; consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical students.

name: — Clinical Neurosurgery
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Admission and follow-up of patients. Neurological history, examination, and further diagnostic procedures emphasized. Participate in meaningful aspects of surgical procedures and attend listed conferences, rounds, and seminars.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- and fourth-year medical students.

name: — Externship
description: Course Description: Clerkship in neurosurgery to be arranged at another institution with accredited residency program in neurosurgery under proper supervision.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student having completed a neurosurgical clerkship or consent of instructor.

name: — Neurocritical Care
description: Course Description: In this Acting Internship, learn and practice how to safely assess and manage acutely ill patients with life-threatening neurologic and neurosurgical disease or life-threatening neurologic manifestations of systemic disease as part of our multidisciplinary neurocritical care team.

name: — Neurocritical Care (NSICU)
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Participate in the care of neurosurgical patients in the NSICU and in the admission and surgical management of patients admitted through the Emergency Room.

name: — Advanced Clinical Neurosurgery
description: Course Description: Student will function as acting intern on neurosurgery service. Admission and management of patients. Neurological history, examination, diagnostic procedures, and surgical management are emphasized. Students participate in meaningful aspects of surgical procedures and attend required conferences and rounds.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Away Acting Internship in Neurosurgery
description: Course Description: Away acting internship in Neurosurgery.

name: — Insights in Neurosurgery
description: Course Description: Observation of neurosurgical care in emergency room, operating room and hospital floors, including manner of treatment of a variety of chronic and acute neurological diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.

name: — Neurosurgery Research
description: Course Description: Student may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

name: — Quantitative Design & Data Collection in Nursing & Healthcare
description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative study designs, common methods for sampling, data collection, and instrument selection. Implications of various design and methods choices on causal inference, internal and external validity, and ethical considerations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Quantitative Research Methods in Nursing & Healthcare
description: Course Description: Foundational approaches to describing and analyzing quantitative data. Assumptions and appropriate selection of basic descriptive and inferential statistics, and interpreting and communicating the results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 200AY B- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Quantitative Analysis in Nursing & Healthcare
description: Course Description: Practice of quantitative data analysis. Develop research questions using quantitative methods, identify appropriate datasets, prepare data, conduct secondary analysis, and report results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 200BY B- or better; or consent of Instructor.

name: — Health Status & Care Systems
description: Course Description: Comparative health status data, major current health issues globally, nationally, regionally. Theoretical perspectives on social, political, economic determinants of health. Health-care systems examined, linked to data, and evaluated in regards to outcomes. Aging, rural, ethnic minority populations highlighted.

name: — Implementation Science
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Change processes in health care from political, historic, economic and sociologic frameworks. Historic and current examples of transformative change in the health-care system. Skills for system transformation through health policy, practice, research and education are emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current enrollment in the Nursing Science and Health-Care Leadership graduate program or consent of instructor.

name: — Leadership in Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Critical examination of leadership from a variety of theoretical and philosophical perspectives and focuses on specific challenges in health care and leadership at various levels, e.g., patient, organizational, and policy levels.

name: — Research Skills for Nursing Science & Health-Care Leadership
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Foundation for analyzing research, health, and systems data to answer clinical, systems, or policy questions. name: — Research Design in Nursing & Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Major types of quantitative and qualitative research design and their application to nursing and health-care research. Implications of choosing alternative research designs and critical analysis of philosophical underpinnings. Evaluation of control and validity, sampling, instruments to measure health concepts.

name: — Overview of Research in Nursing Science & Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Provides an overview of quantitative and qualitative paradigms in scientific inquiry and the major designs related to each paradigm. name: — Quantitative Research in Nursing Science & Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduces principles of quantitative data collection and analysis as applied to major study designs in nursing and health-care research. name: — Qualitative Research in Nursing Science & Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduces principles of qualitative data collection and analysis as applied to major study designs in nursing and health-care research. name: — Community Connections
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Community-based learning and experiences including community participation, assessment, data collection and analysis using multiple approaches, community health improvement projects, collaborative leadership practice, all with the guidance of community members and nursing faculty.

description: Course Description: Introduction to thinking like a scientist, history of nursing research and philosophy of science. Debates about scientific research that coincided with the founding of Nursing Science in the middle of the 20th century.

description: Course Description: Concepts used in scientific research, critical thinking skills to examine the association between concepts and empirical evidence. Identifying new concepts that can be the analytic foundations of new research questions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Theoretical & Conceptual Frameworks in Nursing & Healthcare
description: Course Description: Applied approach to introduce common theoretical and conceptual frameworks used in nursing and health sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Methods in Health Informatics

name: — Applied Health Informatics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Within the conceptual framework of the Foundation of Knowledge model, integrates nursing science, information science, computer science and cognitive science to acquire, process, generate and disseminate knowledge.

description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Interprofessional graduate course provides an introduction to rural health theory, research, policy, and practice, with an emphasis on rural health assets and disparities.

System-based approach to human anatomy and investigated based on underlying biochemical, cellular and molecular genetic perturbations in homeostasis that result in human disease.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — DNP Immersion A
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Three-course immersion series designed to augment the DNP student’s online education in face to face sessions conducted at the Betty Irene Moore School of Nursing in Sacramento. Constructed to provide insight into the health system and the challenges faced by underserved populations thereby contributing to the student’s ability to become a leader in clinical practice.

name: — DNP Immersion B
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Three-course immersion series designed to augment the DNP student’s online education in face to face sessions conducted at the Betty Irene Moore School of Nursing in Sacramento. name: — Nature of Caregiving
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Explores theoretical and conceptual frameworks to enable clinicians to understand the nature of family caregiving. Students examine and apply frameworks in order to conduct comprehensive person and family based assessments and interventions incorporating various dimensions of family caregiving.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Family Centered Communication & Shared Decision Making
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Incorporates shared decision-making principles and group communication to address family centered care planning and challenging clinical discussions. Targets competencies needed by health professionals to partner effectively to enhance the caregiving experience and reduce negative sequelae over the caregiving trajectory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Patient & Family Centered Care Plan Development
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Synthesizes assessment data and analyzes impact of technology, individual, family, sociocultural, health care system, and illness-related variables in specific family care-giving situations. Co-create comprehensive evidence based plan to facilitate the health and well-being of the family unit through shared decision-making.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Health Policy for Health-Care Professionals
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Addresses current major health policy issues and the institutions, processes and forces that shape them. Discusses health care policy in terms of legislative and executive processes at the state and federal levels; key forces involved in policy-making, including economic, social, ethical and political factors; and the central players involved in policy-making, including elected officials, interest groups, the press and legislative staff.

name: — Organizational & System Change Through Leadership, Research, & Practice
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Deepens the critical understanding and analysis of leadership theory as related to healthcare systems. Apply leadership principles and theory within the context of building successful organizations and engaging in health policy, practice, research and education arenas. Address change processes in healthcare from political, historic, economic and sociological frameworks, learning from both historic and current examples of transformative change.

name: — Improving Patient & Population Health
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Highlights the health outcomes of groups with a focus on reducing health inequities among populations by exploring factors such as the environment, social structures, and resource distribution. Introduces the principles of public health as well as epidemiology and evidence-based public health.

name: — Ensuring Quality and Safety in Healthcare
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Provides the knowledge and skills necessary for students to understand the fundamentals of conducting research and quality improvement. Explore the relationship and be able to differentiate between quality improvement and research and the appropriate application of both processes. Specific attention paid to different types of data, research levels of evidence, quality improvement techniques, and basics of measurement.

name: — Health Promotion & Disease Prevention Across the Lifespan
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Health promotion and disease prevention examined using population-based and multidisciplinary approaches. Focuses on developing increased knowledge, skills and appreciation for the promotion of health and prevention of disease among culturally diverse communities. Epidemiological, psychosocial and environmental principles discussed as a basis for focusing upon factors related to the reduction of health disparities among vulnerable populations.

name: — Clinical Ethics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Emphasis on exploration of ethical knowledge development with a focus on clarification, analysis and justification relevant to advanced nursing practice; examination and development of learners' moral understanding; and distinguishing between moral and other professional responsibilities. Includes pertinent topics on how ethical and legal standards intersect and how this impacts health professionals and health care systems.

name: — Business Essentials for Health Care
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Interprofessional online course on business essentials in healthcare establishes a foundational understanding of healthcare business basics including finance, human resources, management and physical resources. Develop leadership-level thinking to provide quality cost-effective care and to participate in the implementation of care.

name: — Basic Clinical Skills

name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

name: — Current Topics & Controversies in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Exploration of current applications and controversies in nutrition. Rread scientific journal articles and write summaries, as well as give brief oral presentations. Topics change to reflect current interests and issues.

name: — Individual Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Individual study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Environmental & Nutritional Factors in Cellular Regulation & Nutritional Toxicants
description: Course Description: Cellular regulation from nutritional/toxicological perspective. Emphasis: role of biofactors on modulation of signal transduction pathways, role of specific organelles in organization/regulation of metabolic transformations, major cofactor functions, principles of pharmacology/toxicology important to understanding nutrient/toxicant metabolism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (BIS 103 or ABI 103).

name: — Nutrition through the Life Cycle
description: Course Description: Unique nutrient needs of people in different stages of the life cycle, including pregnant and lactating women, infants, children, adolescents, adults and the elderly. Physiological changes and conditions that influence nutrient needs, factors that influence food choices and appropriate dietary recommendations, and recent research are discussed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 103 or ABI 103); NUT 111AY; or consent of instructor.

name: — Food Chemistry for Clinical Nutrition
description: Course Description: Chemical and physical principles that influence functional properties, nutrient content, safety, and sensory aspects of food. Emphasis on the application of these concepts in clinical nutrition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B C- or better or CHE 118B C- or better or CHE 128B C- or better; concurrent with FST 100A recommended.

name: — Introduction to Nutrition & Metabolism
description: Course Description: Introduction to metabolism of protein, fat and carbohydrate: the biological role of vitamins and minerals; nutrient requirements during the life cycle; assessment of dietary intake and nutritional status.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; NPB 101; or the equivalent of NPB 101.

name: — Recommendations & Standards for Human Nutrition
description: Course Description: Critical analysis of the development of nutritional recommendations for humans. Topics include: history of modern recommendations, development of the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) and other food guides; the Dietary Reference Intakes (DRI); administrative structure of regulatory agencies pertinent to nutrition recommendations; introduction to scientific methods used to determine the recommendations; food labeling laws; nutrition recommendations in other countries and cultures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B); NUT 111AY; NPB 101 recommended.

name: — Nutritional Assessment
description: Course Description: Methods of human nutritional assessment, including dietary, anthropometric, biochemical methods. Principles of precision, accuracy, and interpretation of results for individuals and populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((ABI 102,  ABI 103) or (BIS 102,  BIS 103)); NUT 111AY; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or PLS 120).

name: — Principles of Epidemiology in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Introduction to epidemiology as it relates to the field of nutrition, including study design, principles of epidemiologic inference, criteria for causality, and interpreting measures of disease risk.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y or PLS 120 or STA 100.

name: — Developmental Nutrition
description: Course Description: Role of nutritional factors in embryonic and postnatal development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ABI 102 or BIS 102); (ABI 103 or BIS 103); NUT 111AY; NUT 111B.

name: — Animal Nutrition
description: Course Description: Comparative differences among animals in digestion and metabolism of nutrients. Nutrient composition of feeds, digestive systems, digestion, absorption, feeding strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B or CHE 118B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Clinical Nutrition
description: Course Description: Biochemical and physiological bases for therapeutic diets. Problems in planning diets for normal and pathological conditions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; NPB 101; or the equivalent to NPB 101.

name: — Clinical Nutrition Practicum
description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of planning and evaluating therapeutic diets and patient education for pathological conditions covered in 116A.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116A (can be concurrent).

name: — Clinical Nutrition
description: Course Description: Biochemical and physiological bases for therapeutic diets. Problems in planning diets for normal and pathological conditions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; NPB 101; or the equivalent to NPB 101.

name: — Clinical Nutrition Practicum
description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of planning and evaluating therapeutic diets and patient education for pathological conditions covered in NUT 116B. Continuation of NUT 116AL.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116AL; NUT 116B (can be concurrent).

name: — Experimental Nutrition
description: Course Description: Methods of assessing nutritional status. Application of chemical, microbiological, chromatographic and enzymatic techniques to current problems in nutrition.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; BIS 102; BIS 103; MCB 120L or other laboratory course in biochemistry is recommended.

name: — Community Nutrition
description: Course Description: Nutrition problems in contemporary communities and of selected target groups in the United States and in developing countries. Nutrition programs and policy, principles of nutrition education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116A; (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B.

name: — Global Nutrition
description: Course Description: Global prevalence, etiology, and consequences of nutrition problems, ranging from under nutrition and food insecurity to overweight and associated chronic diseases; underlying social, environmental, and behavioral factors that contribute to malnutrition; strategies to improve nutritional status, with emphasis on low- and middle-income countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 111AY; NUT 111B; or consent of instructor.

name: — International, Community-Based Nutritional Assessment
description: Course Description: A six-week summer course in Peru. Implementation of a community-based nutritional assessment survey, including development of the survey instrument, selection. Taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 119A; and consent of instructor.

name: — Nutritional Anthropology
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Nutritional anthropology from historical and contemporary perspectives; the anthropological approach to food and diet; field work methods; case histories that explore food patterns and their nutritional implications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 010 or NUT 010V); (ANT 002 or SOC 001 or SOC 003); upper-division standing.

name: — Nutritional Geography
description: Course Description: Nutritional geography from historical and contemporary perspectives; the geographical approach to food and diet; cultural and environmental factors that influence dietary practices; food-related landscapes and patterns.

name: — Ruminant Nutrition & Digestive Physiology
description: Course Description: Study of nutrient utilization as influenced by the unique aspects of digestion and fermentation in ruminants, both domestic and wild. Laboratories include comparative anatomy, feed evaluation, digestion kinetics using fistulated cows, computer modeling, and microbial exercises.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ABI 103 or BIS 103); BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; (ANS 100 or NPB 101); or consent of instructor. MAT 016B recommended.

name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition
description: Course Description: Comparative nutrition of animals; including laboratory, companion, zoo, and wild, animals. Digestion and metabolic adaptations required for animal species to consume diverse diets. Relation of nutrition to metabolic adaptations and physiological states, including growth, reproduction, and diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 or BIS 103.

name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition Laboratory
description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises leading to written reports on establishment of nutritional requirements and formulation of complete diets for laboratory, companion, zoo and wild animals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 or BIS 103.

name: — Nutrition & Feeding of Finfishes
description: Course Description: Principles of nutrition and feeding of fishes under commercial situations; implication of fish nutrition to the environment and conservation of endangered species.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103 or ABI 103.

name: — Environmental Stress & Development in Marine Organisms
description: Course Description: Taught at Bodega Marine Laboratory. Effects of environmental and nutritional stress, including pollutants, on development and function in embryos and larvae of marine organisms. Emphasis on advanced experimental methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101 or BIS 102 or BIS 104; or equivalent course; ETX 114A or NUT 114 recommended.

name: — Journalistic Practicum in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Critical analysis and discussion of current, controversial issues in nutrition; use of journalistic techniques to interpret scientific findings for the lay public. Students required to write several articles for campus media.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; or consent of instructor; a course in written or oral expression.

name: — Experiments in Nutrition: Design & Execution
description: Course Description: Experiments in current nutritional problems. Experimental design:students choose project and, independently or in groups of two-three, design a protocol, complete the project, and report findings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NUT 111AV, NUT 111AY, NUT 111B or NUT 114 recommended.

name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition & Metabolism
description: Course Description: Foundational principles of nutrition, nutrient composition of feed ingredients, digestive systems of domestic and exotic animals, nutrient digestibility and absorption, nutrient metabolism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103; (NUT 115 or NUT 116A or NUT 116B); or consent of instructor.

name: — Companion Animal Nutrition
description: Course Description: Applied companion animal nutrition, focused primarily on dogs and cats. Nutritional considerations specifically related to health and longevity of companion animals. Evaluation of commercial and prescription-type diets with an emphasis on functional ingredients. Impact of physiological status and disease on nutrient requirements of the animal and nutrient utilization in the body.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 102; NUT 115; recommend ANS 042.

name: — Proseminar in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Discussion of human nutrition problems. Each term will involve a different emphasis among experimental, clinical, and dietetic problems of community, national and international scope.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B.

name: — Nutrition Research Conference
description: Course Description: Introduction to research findings and methods in nutrition. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Nutrition or related biological science.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in practical application of nutrition, supervised by a faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one upper division course in nutrition.

name: — Tutoring in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in nutrition courses, assistance with discussion groups or laboratory sections, weekly conference with instructor in charge of course: written evaluations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; Nutrition Science, Clinical Nutrition or related major.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — International Nutrition
description: Course Description: Epidemiology, etiology, and consequences of undernutrition, with particular focus on the nutritional problems of children and women in low income populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 111AV; NUT 111AY; graduate standing; undergraduates only admitted with consent of instructor.

name: — International Nutrition
description: Course Description: Intervention programs to prevent or ameliorate nutritional problems in low-income populations. Planning, implementing, and evaluating nutrition intervention programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 219A.

name: — Experiments in Nutrition: Design & Execution
description: Course Description: Student-selected projects to enhance laboratory skills. Independently, or in groups of two-three students, design a protocol, carry out the project, analyze the results and report the findings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NUT 201, NUT 202, NUT 203, NUT 204, or the equivalent recommended.

name: — Metabolic Homeostasis
description: Course Description: Regulatory mechanisms of carbohydrate, lipid, and protein homeostasis; mechanisms of metabolic enzyme regulation and of the metabolic hormones; homeostatic mechanisms and interactions; fuel-fuel interactions; nutrition-energy balance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Passing the Nutrition Graduate Group Preliminary Examination or consent of instructor.

name: — Nutrition & Immunity
description: Course Description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying interactions of nutrition and immune function, including modulation of immunocompetence by diet and effects of immune responses on nutritional needs. Lectures and discussion explore implications for resistance to infection, autoimmunity and cancer.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126; ABI 102; MMI 107; or the equivalent to MMI 107.

name: — Nutrition & Development
description: Course Description: Relationship of nutrition to prenatal and early postnatal development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUB 210A, NUB 210B, and NUB 210C recommended.

name: — Control of Energy Balance & Body Weight
description: Course Description: Comprehensive study of the biochemical, nutritional and physiological mechanisms controlling food intake, body composition and energy expenditure. Subject matter will be approached through lectures and discussions where students and staff will critically evaluate the literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Applications of Systems Analysis in Nutrition
description: Course Description: Quantitative aspects of digestion and metabolism; principles of systems analysis. Evolution of models of energy metabolism as applied in current feeding systems. Critical evaluations of mechanistic models used analytically in support of nutritional research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 202; or the equivalent.

name: — Field Research Methods in International Nutrition
description: Course Description: Issues and problems related to implementation of nutrition field research in less-developed countries, including ethics; relationships with local governments, communities, and scientists; data collection techniques and quality assurance; field logistics; research budgets; and other administrative and personal issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Nutrition & Aging
description: Course Description: Interaction between nutrition and aging. Topics include physiological/biochemical basis of aging, age-related changes affecting nutritional requirements, nutrition and mortality rate, assessment of nutritional status in the elderly, and relationship between developmental nutrition and the rate of aging.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 201; NUT 202; NUT 203; NUT 204; three of the four courses.

name: — Scientific Ethics in Biomedical Studies:   Emphasis on Nutrition
description: Course Description: Scientific ethics in biomedical studies, especially nutrition. Discussion and case study presentations on scientific integrity, fraud, misconduct, conflict of interest, human and animal research protections.

name: — Beginning Nutrition Seminar
description: Course Description: Discussion and critical evaluation of topics in nutrition with emphasis on literature review and evaluation in this field. Students give oral presentations on relevant topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year graduate standing.

name: — Research Conference
description: Course Description: Major professors lead research discussions with their graduate students. Research papers are reviewed and project proposals presented and evaluated. Format will combine seminar and discussion style.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Advanced Nutrition Seminar
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in nutrition research. Multiple sections may be taken concurrently for credit.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year graduate standing.

name: — Current Topics in Obesity, Food Intake & Energy Balance
description: Course Description: Current research and its evaluation. Principles of experimental design and scientific background for given article. Articles summarized for posting on Internet for use by healthcare professionals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 129; or graduate standing; undergraduates with upper division standing with at least one writing course may enroll with consent of instructor.

name: — Current Topics in Obesity, Food Intake, & Energy Balance with Special Topics
description: Course Description: Undergraduates with upper division standing with at least one writing course may enroll with consent of instructor. A continuation of NUT 293A, with additional special topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 129; Graduate standing.

name: — Current Topics in Developmental Nutrition
description: Course Description: Effects of nutrition on embryology, morphogenesis, and developmental mechanisms.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 114 or NUT 252; or consent of instructor.

name: — Supervised Teaching in Nutrition
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practical experience in teaching nutrition at the university level; curriculum design and evaluation; preparation and presentation of material. Assistance in laboratories, discussion sections, and evaluation of student work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in nutrition or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Professionalism: An Academic Perspective
description: Course Description: For graduate students in their initial quarter of residence. Professionalism topics are presented and examples drawn from both the biological and social sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Grant Writing
description: Course Description: Preparation of grants for governmental agencies (particularly NIH and USDA) and private foundations. Students will write a research grant or fellowship application.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Nutrition or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Nutrition I: Nutrition & Metabolism, Macronutrients
description: Course Description: Advanced general nutritional concepts. Integrating nutrition with biological systems, population nutrition issues, and research approaches. Advanced concepts on lipid and protein metabolism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Nutrition II: Nutrition & Cell Biology, Micronutrients
description: Course Description: Effects of nutrients at the cellular level. Principles of cell signaling and signaling modulation by nutrients. Advanced concepts of mineral and vitamin metabolism. Mineral and vitamin deviencies and associated pathologies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Nutrition III: Nutrition in Health & Disease
description: Course Description: Integration of biochemical, physiological, and genetic aspects of nutrition in the context of clinical and epidemiological observations related to health and disease, including obesity and diabetes, cancer, vascular and neurodegenerative diseases, osteoporosis, and birth defects. Review and consideration of governmental.

name: — Research Group Conference
description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in animal sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Shifa Clinic Student Volunteer
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in Obstetrics & Gynecology.

name: — Shifa Clinic Student Volunteer
description: Course Description: Attend clinic every third Sunday performing duties of receptionist, intake, translation, monitor. Students attend a meeting immediately after end of clinic. There is a mandatory Monday meeting with Clinic co-directors. Students are expected to participate on various committees.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; applications will be available for students; selection of students will be made by selection committee of medical students coordinators and the instructor of record.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Genetics of Reproduction
description: Course Description: Introduction to genetics of mammalian reproduction for domestic species, species used in research, and the human. Mendelian and non-Mendelian modes of inheritance. Research paper.

name: — Current Topics in Research
description: Course Description: Selected topics in reproductive biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Research

prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Obstetrics & Gynecology Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics, gynecologic and gynecological oncology experience in the delivery room, operating room, clinics and wards at UCDMC and affiliated sites. Rounds, conferences, interactive student presentations and seminars ongoing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

name: — SJVP OBGYN Clerkship at UCSF
description: Course Description: Obstetrics, gynecologic and gynecological oncology experience in the delivery room, operating room, clinics and wards at UCSF Fresno. Rounds, conferences, interactive student presentations and seminars ongoing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Clinical Studies in OBGYN
description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Studies in OBGYN
description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Away Clinical Elective in OBGYN
description: Course Description: Active participation in inpatient and outpatient care. Attendance at specified conferences; student-faculty member informal conferences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; or the equivalent, and consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student.

name: — Away Acting Internship in OBGYN
description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Students are expected to provide direct patient management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; and consent of instructor; other third-year core clerkships.

name: — Gynecologic Oncology Acting Internship
description: Course Description: Four week elective primarily involves direct inpatient management of women on the UCDMC Gyn/Onc service. Students will be acting at the level of a sub-intern and will work under the supervision of house staff, fellows, and attendings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor; the third-year core clerkships.

name: — Ambulatory Gynecology & Obstetrics Elective
description: Course Description: Conduct examinations, present patients and discuss treatment regimens at the following ambulatory clinics: General Obstetrics & Gynecology, New and Return Obstetrics (including Post-Partum), High-Risk Obstetrics, Pre-Operative Clinic, and other sub-specialty clinics as assigned.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; and consent of instructor. Third- or fourth-year Medical Student.

name: — Family Planning & Reproductive Health
description: Course Description: Elective focuses on the Gynecologic Subspecialty of Family Planning. Counseling and provision of contraceptive methods, experience with pelvic ultrasounds, management of spontaneous, inevitable and induced abortion and post-abortion care by both surgical and medical techniques are included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor.

name: — Labor & Delivery Acting Internship
description: Course Description: Four week elective primarily involves direct inpatient management of women on the UCDMC L&D unit. Students will be acting at the level of a sub-intern and will work under the supervision of house staff, fellows, and attendings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor; the third-year core clerkships.

name: — The Birthing Process
description: Course Description: Open only to UC Davis medical students. Training to assist in the birthing process as a Doula. Topics not covered in the summer course.

name: — Gender Specific Medicine SSM
description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course on the topic: Basic Science Principles Relating to Gender Specific Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Shifa Clinic
description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

name: — Shifa Clinic
description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

name: — Shifa Clinic
description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

name: — Shifa Clinic
description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Explore particular topics in-depth in Obstetrics and Gynecology. Extensive contact with and oversight by instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Obstetrics & Gynecology
description: Course Description: Research in Obstetrics and Gynecology arranged with instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student.

name: — Research Internship
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in ophthalmology research. Research staff in Ophthalmology have programs in cell biology, electron microscopy, biochemistry, immunology and visual psychophysics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Basic Research in Visual Science
description: Course Description: Basic research in visual science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Ophthalmology
description: Course Description: Ocular disease diagnosis and management relevant to the clinical practice of future primary care physicians and others.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year Medical Student with consent of instructor; consent of advisor; completion of third-year clerkships in Medicine and Surgery; consult Course Coordinator.

name: — Advanced Subspecialty Ophthalmology
description: Course Description: Participation in disciplines of neuro-ophthalmology/pediatric ophthalmology, diseases of the cornea and external eye, glaucoma and retina.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; consent of instructor; medical students in third or fourth year.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Ophthalmology
description: Course Description: Individual research on selected topics in optics and visual physiology, cornea and external disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

name: — Special Studies for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special studies for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — The Musculoskeletal System
description: Course Description: Basic and clinical science of orthopaedic surgery and rheumatology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of committee on student progress.

name: — Ambulatory & Emergency Room Orthopaedics
description: Course Description: Introduction to general orthopaedic problems and trauma and their management in an outpatient environment, including the emergency room. Conduct orthopaedic examinations, present patients to staff rotating through trauma, hand, pediatrics, adult and foot clinics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Community Preceptorship
description: Course Description: Acquaints student with private practice of orthopaedics in the community setting. Opportunity to observe and assist private practitioners in office, emergency room, operating room and inpatient environment. Student must provide own transportation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing; consent of instructor.

name: — Acting Internship
description: Course Description: Rotation designed to increase basic knowledge of musculoskeletal abnormalities at clinical level. Attention focused on selective case material. For those students who demonstrate proficiency, responsibility will be similar to that of intern.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Externship in Advanced Orthopaedics
description: Course Description: Advanced Orthopaedic rotation done at an approved institution. Topics may include Trauma, Sports, Spine, Pediatrics, Joint and/or Foot/Ankle. Students are expected to perform at the level of an Intern.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Away Clerkship in Orthopaedics
description: Course Description: Orthopaedic advanced clerkship at an approved institution.

name: — Insights in Orthopardic Surgery
description: Course Description: Exposure to aims, methods and procedures in orthopaedic surgery via attendance at grand rounds, patient care conferences, and group discussions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.

name: — History of Medicine for Medical Students
description: Course Description: Overview of the history of medicine throughout the world to introduce medical students to landmark accomplishments and key figures in the development of health care and to provide an expanded philosophical perspective on the everchanging field of modern medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year students in the School of Medicine or second-year students with consent of instructor.

name: — Orthopardics Research
description: Course Description: Laboratory or clinical investigation on selected topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

name: — Internship in Otolaryngology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in otolaryngology and related fields. Final project report.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

name: — Special Study in Otolaryngology for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study in Otolaryngology for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate with consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Otolaryngology
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and student research in otolaryngology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate students; medical students; advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Speech, Hearing & Equilibrium
description: Course Description: Presentations by faculty and guest lecturers on anatomy, physiology, and behaviors involved in speech production, hearing, and equilibrium. Each student expected to make one class presentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate students; medical students; advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Study in Otolaryngology for Advanced Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Individual study in Otolaryngology for advanced graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced graduate student with consent of instructor.

name: — Basic Principles of Reconstructive Surgery
description: Course Description: Formal presentations covering basic principles of reconstructive surgery, including wound healing, treatment of lacerations, skin and bone grafts, flaps, Z-plasties and revision of scars. Laboratory session utilizing animal tissues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year medical student with consent of instructor.

name: — Otolaryngology Required Clerkship
description: Course Description: Provide fundamental knowledge of otorhinolaryngologic diagnosis and principles, develop facility with basic ENT instruments, provide an understanding of treatment for ear, nose and throat problems and provide knowledge of what patients should be referred for otorhinolaryngologic care.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent by Committee on Student Evaluation and Promotion.

name: — Fourth Year Otolaryngology Elective
description: Course Description: Participation in Otolaryngology Clinic and operating room. Evaluation and management of common Otolaryngologic diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year Medical Students.

name: — Clinical Otolaryngology Elective
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Total involvement in clinical activities of the department.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- and fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

name: — Away Acting Internship in Otolaryngology
description: Course Description: Externship rotation for Acting Internships in Otolaryngology.

name: — Journal Seminar
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Monthly review of current otolaryngologic and related literature and recent advances.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

name: — Individual or Group Study
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic research in Otolaryngology. Lectures, discussion and laboratory study of sensory and motor systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Participation in ongoing projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

name: — Internship in Human Pathology
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in pathology and related fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

name: — Special Study in Pathology for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study in Pathology for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced undergraduates.

name: — Research Group Conferences
description: Course Description: Focused around the mechanisms of function of the central nervous system under normal and pathogenic conditions. Seminars lead by various speakers from UC Davis and other Institutions, both domestic and international.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate level standing.

name: — Neurodevelopment Group Study
description: Course Description: Explore mechanisms that impact perinatal development of the cerebral cortex, and other cortical structures, under normal and pathological conditions.

name: — Advanced Group Study
description: Course Description: Group Study provides the opportunity for a faculty member to work with students in a focused manner.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Brain Cutting Conference
description: Course Description: Current specimens are sectioned, discussed, and clinical correlations proposed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- and fourth-year medical students or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Neuropathology
description: Course Description: Presents an integrated introduction to mechanisms of the central and peripheral nervous system injury. Gain an understanding of pathological mechanisms underlying disease, the anatomic and molecular manifestations of pathologic processes of the CNS and PNS.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student.

name: — General & Endocrine Pathology
description: Course Description: Pathologic mechanisms of human disease. Concepts of general pathologic processes, i.e., cell death, inflammation and neoplasia. Endocrine pathology in the context of clinical human disease. Emphasis on integration of clinical practice with gross and histologic images emphasizing team-based learning.

name: — Systemic Pathology
description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include hematopathology and neuropathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

name: — Systemic Pathology
description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include pulmonary pathology, cardiovascular pathology, hematopatology, oncologic pathology, and nephropathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

name: — Systemic Pathology
description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Content parallels concurrent clinical courses with integration of lectures and discussions. Topics include gastrointestinal and gynecologic pathology, hepatopathology, oncologic pathology and musculoskeletal pathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

name: — Clinical Patient Care in Pathology
description: Course Description: Four-week course is designed to give the third-year medical student an exposure to the diverse roles that pathologists have in clinical patient care.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completed one of the following 3rd year clerkships: Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, OBGYN or Pediatrics.

name: — Surgery-Pathology-Radiology (SPR) Research Laboratory
description: Course Description: Provide future clinicians and scientists with basic clinical and bioengineering laboratory skills to prepare for careers in translational research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Diagnostic Medicine: Pathology in Practice
description: Course Description: Asynchronous learning course bridges the gap between foundational pathophysiology learned in pre-clerkship curriculum and the utilization of pathology and laboratory medicine studies in clinical practice.

name: — Anatomic Pathology
description: Course Description: Anatomic pathology with an emphasis on autopsy and surgical pathology with application to clinical practice. Specimen grossing, frozen sections, microscopic sign-out and conferences. Exposure to cytopathology, hematopathology, and clinical pathology is available.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical students.

name: — Applied Clinical Laboratory Medicine
description: Course Description: Emphasis upon laboratory techniques, procedures, and interpretation of laboratory results. Students will be expected to participate fully and in all laboratory operations including bench techniques, laboratory management, and quality control.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Sub-Specialty in Didactic Pathology
description: Course Description: Externship provides in-depth exposure to one of a variety of sub-specialties in Pathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Anatomic Pathology Acting Internship
description: Course Description: Anatomic Pathology AI will permit students to gain skills needed for first year Pathology Residency. Students will perform autopsies and take full responsibility for a variety of surgical pathology cases. A mix of outpatient and inpatient cases is expected.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student or consent of instructor.

name: — Anatomic Pathology Acting Internship
description: Course Description: Year four level course designed to provide a concentrated experience in Surgical Pathology and Cytolopathology. Rotate on the surgical and cytopathology sub-specialty teams and assume responsibility for patient cases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMD 410A; PMD 410B; PMD 410C; PMD 410D; or equivalent, and consent of instructor. Successful completion of third-year clinical rotations.

name: — Interdisciplinary Study of Gastrointestinal Cancer
description: Course Description: In-depth study of gastrointestinal, hepatic and pancreatic cancer. Emphasis on an integration of basic science and clinical medicine. Participating departments include pathology, surgical oncology, medical oncology, gastroenterology, radiology and radiotherapy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Pathology
description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in preparation for one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum of the School of Medicine.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study in variety of advanced topics in general, special, experimental, or comparative pathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research in experimental, molecular, comparative, and applied pathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Fundamentals of Immunology
description: Course Description: Overview of immunology including components of the immune system, initiation and regulation of the immune response, infection and immunity, hypersensitivity and immune dysfunction. Clinical immunologic techniques, immunodeficiency, and vaccinology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; or equivalent, or consent of instructor.

name: — Immunology Laboratory
description: Course Description: Laboratory procedures in clinical immunology. Cells of the innate and adaptive systems. Quantitative and qualitative characterization of the immune response.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126 (can be concurrent); or equivalent.

name: — Medical Bacteria & Fungi
description: Course Description: Introduction to the bacterial and mycotic pathogens of man and animals, with emphasis on pathogenic mechanisms and ecologic aspects of infectious disease.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Any Microbiology course with lab; Immunology strongly recommended.

name: — Biology of Animal Viruses
description: Course Description: Fundamental physical and chemical properties of animal viruses; methods of propagation, purification and assay. Mechanisms of viral replication and pathogenesis of viral infections in man and animals. Immunity to virus diseases and oncogenic properties of animal viruses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102.

name: — One Health: Human, Animal & Environment Interfaces
description: Course Description: Introduction to fundamentals, challenges, and opportunities in One Health  using local and global health case studies. Animal, human, and environmental health problems, along with tools and transdisciplinary approaches, will be introduced to foster innovative thinking that addresses complex issues.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Research Foundations
description: Course Description: Introduction to key components of graduate school success including mentor/mentee relationship issues, avoiding plagiarism, hypothesis development and experimental design, demystifying the grant writing process, understanding the NIH administrative structure, preparing for a non-academic career, and strategies to maintain a work-life balance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Integrative Pathobiology Core I
description: Course Description: Overview of molecular biology techniques, tissue structure and function, cell membrane pathology and cellular mechanisms of disease including cellular responses and adaptations to stress, cell cycle, cell death, cell biomechanics, vascular disturbances, and mechanisms of neoplasia and tumorigenesis.

name: — Integrative Pathobiology Core II
description: Course Description: The second required core course in the graduate group with topics in inflammation, host-pathogen interaction, regenerative medicine, integrative pathology and population and ecosystem health.

name: — Experimental Design & Data Analysis in Pathobiology
description: Course Description: Follows two required core courses, PMI 201 & PMI 202, for Ph.D. and M.S. students. Goal is to bridge gap between statistics and real-world pathobiology to increase students' skills and independence in experiment design and data analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Mentored Scientific Writing
description: Course Description: Drafting a scientific manuscript for publication based on research results. Students engage in collaborative peer review and learn effective writing, including how to convey a persuasive message and write clearly and succinctly.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Vector-borne Infectious Diseases: Changing Patterns
description: Course Description: Vector-borne infectious diseases especially as they relate to changing patterns associated with climatic changes, trade and population movement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to graduate students, MPVM and MPH students, DVM and medical students with second- or third-year standing; open to upper division undergraduate students with consent of instructor(s).

name: — Topics in Virus  Research
description: Course Description: Discussion-based seminar covering graduate student virology research. Informal presentations and discussion of technical problems in research design and experimentation are encouraged. Current stage of the research project is not important.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing (Ph.D. or M.S.).

name: — Advanced Immunology
description: Course Description: Current concepts of immunology with an emphasis on interactions between the host, the environment and the pathogen. These interactions will include those that are protective and successful for the host as well as those that are deleterious.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory course in Immunology.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Topics in pathology, microbiology or immunology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate level standing.

name: — Seminar in Infectious Diseases
description: Course Description: Discussion of current topics and cases of infectious diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current enrollment in health science professional school or graduate standing in biological sciences.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Special Study in Pediatric Research
description: Course Description: Special study for Pediatric research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate student with consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation as determined by instructor.

name: — Pediatric Research
description: Course Description: Pediatric research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate students who are candidates for a degree in some area of biology or behavioral sciences.

name: — Preceptorship in Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Opportunity to observe and participate in primary medical care in a practicing pediatricians office. Participation in history-taking and physical examination will be at discretion of preceptor and dependent on students experience. Evaluation by student.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year medical student or first-year medical student with consent of instructor.

name: — Clinical Experience in Private Practice
description: Course Description: Opportunity to participate in practice of preceptor, performing such tasks as history taking, physical examination, and patient management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; third-or fourth-year medical student; consent of preceptor and Chairperson.

name: — Pediatrics Lecture Series
description: Course Description: Lecture series covers major topics in pediatrics with case presentations and panels from pediatric subspecialists. Topics include, but are not limited to: cardiology, pulmonology, nephrology, gastroenterology, critical care, and primary care pediatrics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology
description: Course Description: Elective is designed to combine for study a variety of aspects of the physiology, anatomy and biochemistry of the fetus and newborn with relevant clinical examples of disorders in each of the 10 topics that will be discussed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Pediatric Clerkship
description: Course Description: Eight week clinical clerkship providing students with the opportunity to learn fundamentals of caring for the pediatric patient by participating in nursery, ambulatory and inpatient services at UCDMC and affiliated clinical sites. Rounds, conferences, student presentations ongoing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

name: — SJVP Pediatric Clerkship at UCSF
description: Course Description: Eight-week clinical clerkship providing students with the opportunity to learn fundamentals of caring for the pediatric patient by participating in nursery, ambulatory and inpatient services at UCSF Fresno. Rounds, conferences, student presentations ongoing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (A)
description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (B)
description: Course Description: Longitudinal clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (C)
description: Course Description: Longitudinal clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Studies in Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Pediatrics for the Differentiated Student
description: Course Description: One goal is to facilitate the development and reinforcement of the knowledge, skills and attitudes needed as an intern caring for children. Provides a bridge between student experiences in the pre-clerkship phase, the Pediatric clerkship, their Pediatric acting internships and varied Pediatric electives and the Transition to Residency course.

name: — General Inpatient Pediatric Acting Internship
