description: Course Description: The Ward Acting Intern functions in a manner similar to that of a pediatric intern. The Acting Intern takes admissions in the regular sequence and is expected to take night call.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; and consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

name: — Acting Internship: Outpatient Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Supervised experience in pediatric care on outpatient service at UCDMC. Student functions as Acting Intern with appropriate supervision by residents and attending faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; and consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

name: — Pediatric Inpatient AI in Hematology/Oncology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of oncologic and hematologic disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

name: — Elective in Pediatric Endocrinology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of endocrine endocrine disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of second-year study or the equivalent.

name: — Medical & Mental Health Evaluation of Children at Risk for Maltreatment
description: Course Description: Elective for fourth-year medical students covers basic areas of knowledge needed for child abuse prevention and consultation. Rotation includes legals cases, abuse exams, child and parent interactive therapy and visits to community organizations.

name: — Acting Internship in Neonatology
description: Course Description: Diagnostic and therapeutic aspect of the medical and surgical high-risk neonate. Student expected to take night call.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

name: — Pediatrics Specialty Elective
description: Course Description: Supervised experience in a variety of pediatric subspecialties at a local or away site.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor.

name: — Elective in Pediatric Cardiology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of cardiologic disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; satisfactory completed.

name: — Elective in Pulmonary Medicine
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient management of pediatric patients with pulmonary diseases. These will include but will not be limited to cystic fibrosis, asthma, and other forms of chronic pulmonary diseases as well as congenital abnormalities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Pediatric clerkship.

name: — Elective in Pediatrics Nephrology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of renal disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

name: — Elective in Pediatric Infectious Disease
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and treatment of infectious disease of infants and children. Laboratory and clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

name: — Elective in Pediatric Neurology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of neurological disorders in children. Students will also participate in other pediatric subspecialty clinics which serve children with neurological disorders. Does not satisfy the fourth-year neurology requirement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; IMD 430; OBG 430; consent of instructor; all courses satisfactory completed.

name: — Elective in Pediatric Gastroenterology
description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of gastroenterology disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

name: — Clinical Rotation in Adolescent Medicine
description: Course Description: Under supervision, students will see patients in the UC Davis clinic and at a number of community-based sites. Emphasis on the socially-mediated problems that face adolescents, including substance abuse, STD's, pregnancy, depression and suicide. One hour of lecture each week.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year Medical Student.

name: — Away Acting Internship in Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Expectation is to provide direct patient management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; satisfactory completion of Pediatrics Clerkship.

name: — Neonatal (ICU)
description: Course Description: The Pediatric ICU at UC Davis Children's Hospital is a 24 bed ICU on Davis 10 that provides care for critically ill pediatric patients. These patients are usually younger than 18 years of age and can have either primary medical or surgical issues.

name: — Acting Internship in Pediatric Intensive Care
description: Course Description: Evaluation and support of critically ill infants and children. In general, student expected to take night call every third night during rotation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 A is required; or consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

name: — Pediatric Intensive Care Unit
description: Course Description: Evaluation and support of critically ill infants and children. In general, student expected to take night call every third night during rotation.

name: — Ethical, Legal & Social Issues in Clinical Genetics
description: Course Description: Develop advanced knowledge, communication skills and attitudes necessary to provide compassionate, knowledgeable, and expert care to patients who may be at increased genetic risk for disease. Seminars cover ethical and legal principles, epidemiology, and genetics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Living with Intellectual & Developmental Disability in the Community
description: Course Description: In-depth experience with Intellectual & Developmental Disability across the lifespan.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology SSM
description: Course Description: Elective is available for students interested in exploring the fascinating world of the fetus and neonate. Designed to combine the basic sciences with relevant clinical examples of disorders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Intellectual & Developmental Disability in the Community
description: Course Description: In-depth experience with Intellectual & Developmental Disability across the lifespan.

name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology
description: Course Description: Didactic is available for students interested in exploring the fascinating world of the fetus and neonate. Designed to combine the basic sciences with relevant clinical examples of disorders.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Explore in-depth various topics in Pediatrics. Extensive contact with and oversight by instructor.

name: — Research Topics in Pediatrics
description: Course Description: Individual research project in pediatric subspecialty areas (cardiology, endocrinology, hematology, metabolism, newborn physiology and others) may be arranged with faculty member. Independent research by student will be emphasized and long-term projects are possible.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Student in Medical School with consent of instructor.

name: — Methods & Materials in Theatre Research
description: Course Description: Essential research tools in theatre and related fields; bibliographies, primary sources; methods of evaluating and presenting evidence; delineating research areas in the field.

name: — Topics in Contemporary Theatre & Performance
description: Course Description: Special topics designed to study in depth aspects of contemporary performance including performance analysis, cultural and historical context, modes of production, theoretical and political entailments, and issues of spectatorship; e.g., "Brecht and After," "British Theater," "Race and Gender in Performance."

name: — Performance Studies: Modes of Production
description: Course Description: Introduction to the literature of performance production in a variety of media: theatre, dance, film, video, computer-based, looking at cultural, aesthetic, rhetorical and political theory.

name: — Performance Studies: Signification & the Body
description: Course Description: Introduction to analysis of the body in performance, drawing on theoretical models from several fields.

name: — Performance Studies: Performance & Society
description: Course Description: Introduction to the role of performance (broadly defined), in everyday life, sociopolitical negotiation, identity, social movements, the media, and the state.

name: —  Performance Studies: Theory, History, Criticism
description: Course Description: Introduction to the theory, history and criticism, informing performance studies.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project, to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

name: — Colloquia in Performance Studies
description: Course Description: Designed to provide cohort identity and faculty exchange. Opportunity to present papers, hear guest   lecturers, and see faculty presentations, gather for organizational and administrative new, exchange of information and make announcements. Must be taken every year that a Performance Studies graduate is registered, prior to taking the Qualifying Examination.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Registration in Performance Studies Graduate Group and prior to Qualifying Examination.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Individual Study
description: Course Description: Individual study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Dissertation Research
description: Course Description: Dissertation research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advancement to Candidacy.

name: — Approaches to Theatre & Dance
description: Course Description: Work on approaches to theatre, dance, film/video, design and performance, with a focus on methodology and professional development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced graduate students.

name: — Elementary Persian
description: Course Description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.

name: — Elementary Persian
description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 001. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 001; or consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Persian
description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 002. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 002; or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Persian
description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills as well as cultural topics in intermediate Persian.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 003; or the equivalent.

name: — Intermediate Persian
description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing as well as cultural topics in Intermediate Persian.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 021; or the equivalent.

name: — Intermediate Persian
description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills as well as cultural topics in Intermediate Persian.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 022; or equivalent knowledge of Persian.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Persian: Topics in Modern Persian Culture 1900-Present
description: Course Description: Integrated work on reading, listening, discussion and writing about modern Persian cultural production using fiction and poetry as well as cinema and theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Persian: Topics in Medieval Persian Culture 900-1500
description: Course Description: Integrated work on reading, listening, discussion, writing about medieval Persian culture with a focus on lyric and narrative poetry and representative selections of literary prose, rhetoric, biography, history, religious and philosophical discourse.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Persian
description: Course Description: Review, refinement, and development of skills learned in intermediate Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues. Integrated approach to reading, writing, listening, speaking Persian.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Persian
description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 121. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking modern Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 121; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Persian
description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 122. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking modern Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 122; or consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching practicum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology I
description: Course Description: First of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Introductory overview of basic concepts in pharmacology/toxicology, followed by in-depth blocks on fate processes of chemicals in the body, fate processes in tissue selective responses, selective toxicity employed therapeutically.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; NPB 101.

name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology II
description: Course Description: Second of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Principles of pharmacodynamics and mechanisms of drug/toxicant actions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201.

name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology III
description: Course Description: Integrated physiological systems, cardiovascular and nervous systems and how drugs and toxicants act to perturb function.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201; PTX 202.

name: — Electrophysiology Techniques & Applications
description: Course Description: Broad scope of topics in electrophysiology techniques and applications.

name: — Advanced Topics in Pharmacology & Toxicology
description: Course Description: In-depth coverage of selected topics for graduate students in Pharmacology-Toxicology and related disciplines. Topics determined by instructor in charge for each quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201; and consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular Mechanisms in Cancer & other Diseases
description: Course Description: Exploration of cutting edge investigations on the underlying mechanisms of cancer biology, cancer therapy and other diseases. Current medical research in cancer and other diseases, as it spans the bench to bedside.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 121 or MCB 122; undergraduate or graduate introductory course in cell biology (such as BIS 104), and general biochemistry (MCB 121 or MCB 122) required; PTX 202 recommended.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Current topics in pharmacology and toxicology.

name: — Advanced Research Conference
description: Course Description: Provide credit for participation in and attendance at research conferences.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research with a faculty member in the Pharmacology & Toxicology Graduate Group.

name: — Introduction to Philosophy
description: Course Description: Problems of philosophy through major writings from various periods. Problems are drawn from political, aesthetic, religious, metaphysical, and epistemological concerns of philosophy.

name: — Critical Reasoning
description: Course Description: Criteria of good reasoning in everyday life and in science. Topics to be covered may include basic principles of deduction and induction; fallacies in reasoning; techniques and aids to reasoning; principles of scientific investigation; aids to clarity.

name: — Philosophical Perspectives on Sexuality
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues related to sexuality, including, but not limited to, ethical and social issues regarding sexual practice, orientation, classification and identity.

name: — Philosophical Perspectives on Sexuality
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues related to sexuality, including, but not limited to, ethical and social issues regarding sexual practice, orientation, classification and identity.

name: — Introduction to Cognitive Science
description: Course Description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary cognitive scientific approach to the study of mind, drawing concepts and methods from psychology, philosophy, linguistics, artificial intelligence, and other disciplines.

name: — Asian Philosophy
description: Course Description: Survey of the main philosophical systems of south and east Asia: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, and Taoism. Topics include the nature of reality, including God, the universe and the human self, human knowledge, and the proper conduct of human life.

name: — Introduction to Symbolic Logic
description: Course Description: Syntax and semantics of the symbolic language sentence logic. Symbols of sentence logic. Translation between sentence logic and English. Truth table interpretation of sentence logic. Proof techniques. Application of truth tables and proof techniques to arguments in English.

name: — Minds, Brains, & Computers
description: Course Description: Computational theories of the nature of the mind. Mind as a computer process. Possibility of machine intelligence, consciousness, and mentality.

name: — Minds, Brains, & Computers with Discussion
description: Course Description: Computational theories of the nature of the mind. Mind as a computer process. Possibility of machine intelligence, consciousness, and mentality.

name: — Ethical & Social Problems in Contemporary Society
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues and positions involved in contemporary moral and social problems. Possible topics include civil disobedience and revolution, racial and sex discrimination, environment, population control, technology and human values, sexual morality, freedom in society.

name: — Introduction to Bioethics
description: Course Description: Critical analysis of normative issues raised by contemporary medicine and biology. Possible topics include euthanasia, reproductive technologies, genetic engineering, informed consent and patient autonomy, experimentation on human subjects and non-human animals.

name: — Philosophical Foundations of American Democracy
description: Course Description: The philosophical underpinnings of democratic government and the tension between the goals of providing security and of preserving democracy and civil liberties. Illustration of the tension through focus on issues related to war and terrorism.

name: — Language, Thought, & World
description: Course Description: Puzzles in the philosophy of language, such as what language is, how language conveys thoughts, whether we each speak our own private language, and what we can learn about the world by studying language.

name: — Philosophical Classics of the Ancient Era
description: Course Description: Survey of ancient Western philosophy with special attention to the Pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, and the Sceptics.

name: — Philosophical Classics of the Modern Era
description: Course Description: Survey of modern Western philosophy, including Descartes, Locke, Hume, and Kant.

name: — Introduction to Ethics
description: Course Description: Reading of historical and contemporary philosophical works in ethics. Topics include the nature of morality, the justification of moral claims, and major ethical theories, such as consequentialist, deontological, and virtue theories.

name: — Introduction to Philosophy of Science
description: Course Description: Basic problems in the philosophy of science, common to the physical, biological, and social sciences. Analysis of explanation, confirmation theory, observational and theoretical terms, the nature of theories, operationalism and behaviorism, realism, reduction.

name: — Appraising Scientific Reasoning
description: Course Description: Introduction to scientific hypotheses and the kinds of reasoning used to justify such hypotheses. Emphasis on adequate justification, criteria, and strategies for distinguishing scientific from pseudoscientific theories. Concrete historical and contemporary cases.

name: — Understanding Scientific Change
description: Course Description: Concepts of scientific change in historical and philosophical perspective. Survey of models of growth of knowledge, 17th century to present. Relationship between logic of theories and theory choice. Kuhns revolution model. Examples from various sciences.

name: — Introduction to Philosophy of Biology
description: Course Description: Non-technical introduction to philosophical, social, and scientific ideas, methods and technologies in contemporary biological fields such as evolution, genetics, molecular biology, ecology, behavior. Philosophical consideration of determinism, reductionism, explanation, theory, modeling, observation, experimentation. Evaluation of scientific explanations of human nature.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Metaphysics
description: Course Description: Theories of being. Such topics as reality, substance, universals, space, time, causality, becoming, body, experience, persons, freedom, and determinism. Views of the nature and method of metaphysics. Anti-metaphysical arguments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Theory of Knowledge
description: Course Description: Analysis of the concept of knowledge. The relation between knowledge, belief and truth. Development of foundationalist, coherentist and externalist theories of justified belief. Examination of skepticism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy on Mind
description: Course Description: The relation between mind and body, our knowledge of other minds, and the explanation of mental acts. Discussion of such concepts as action, intention, and causation.

name: — The Evolution of Mind
description: Course Description: Interpretation of human thought and behavior through the lens of evolutionary theory. Topics include the nature/nurture debate concerning cognitive and other mental capacities and traits, and the interaction between evolution, learning and development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Religion
description: Course Description: Logical, metaphysical, epistemological, and existential aspects of selected religious concepts and problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy of the Physical Sciences
description: Course Description: Nature of testability and confirmation of scientific hypotheses; nature of scientific laws, theories, explanations, and models. Problems of causality, determininism, induction, and probability; the structure of scientific revolutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One Philosophy course or a science background recommended.

name: — Philosophy of the Biological Sciences
description: Course Description: Scientific method in biology. Nature of biological theories, explanations, and models. Problems of evolutionary theory, ecology, genetics, and sociobiology. Science and human values.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Biology or one course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy of the Social Sciences
description: Course Description: The nature of the social sciences, their subject matter and methods. Similarities to and differences from natural and life sciences. Predicting and explaining human behavior. Behaviorism. Reduction, holism, and individualism. Related moral issues. The social sciences and philosophy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or a social science recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Space & Time
description: Course Description: Philosophical problems of space and time. Philosophical implications of space-time theories, such as those of Newton and Einstein. Topics may include the nature of geometry, conventionalism, absolutist versus relationist views of space and time, philosophical impact of relativity theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One upper division Philosophy course recommended.

name: — Intermediate Symbolic Logic
description: Course Description: Predicate logic syntax and semantics. Transcription between predicate logic and English. Models, truth-trees, and derivations. Identity, functions, and definite descriptions. Introduction to concepts of metatheory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Metalogic
description: Course Description: The metalogic of classical propositional and first-order predicate logic. Consistency, soundness and completeness of both propositional and predicate logic. The Löwenheim-Skolem theorem for predicate logic. Undecidablity of predicate logic.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112; MAT 108; or the equivalent.

name: — History of Ethics
description: Course Description: Study of some classic texts from the history of philosophical writing on central problems of ethics, taking the form either of a survey or concentrated examination of selected historical figures. Readings from such philosophers as Aristotle, Butler, Hume, Kant, Mill.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous Philosophy course recommended.

name: — Problems in Normative Ethics
description: Course Description: Moral philosophy studied through examination of moral problems and the moral principles and common sense intuitions that bear on them. Problems discussed may include: animal rights, fetal rights, euthanasia, justice and health care, war, nuclear deterrence, world hunger, environmental protection.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Ethical Theories
description: Course Description: Study of fundamental concepts and problems in ethical theory through an examination of classical and contemporary philosophical theories of ethics. Among the theories that may be discussed are utilitarianism, virtue theory, theories of natural rights, Kantian ethical theory, and contractarianism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in ethics recommended.

name: — Foundations of Ethics
description: Course Description: Advanced investigation of questions about the nature and foundations of morality. Among the topics that may be discussed are moral realism and anti-realism, cognitivism and non-cognitivism, types of relativism, moral skepticism, normative language and normative belief.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 114, 115, 116, 101, or 137 recommended.

name: — Political Philosophy
description: Course Description: Intensive examination of some central concepts of political thought such as the state, sovereignty, rights, obligation, freedom, law, authority, and responsibility.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Law
description: Course Description: Philosophical theories of the nature of law, legal obligation, the relation of law and morals. Problems for law involving liberty and justice: freedom of expression, privacy, rights, discrimination and fairness, responsibility, and punishment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Environmental Ethics
description: Course Description: Conceptual and ethical issues concerning the environment. Extension of ethical theory to animals, all life, and ecosystem wholes. Topics may include contemporary environmental issues such as global warming, sustainability and biodiversity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Bioethics
description: Course Description: In-depth coverage of topics in bioethics including resource allocation, measures of health and disease/disability, public health, and ethical issues related to research on human subjects and emerging technologies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 015 recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Race
description: Course Description: Core issues in the philosophy of race, including investigation of the nature and reality of race, use of race in science and medicine, nature of racial identity, and ethical responses to racial injustice.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Aesthetics
description: Course Description: Nature of art, of artistic creation, of the work of art, and of aesthetic experience; nature and validity of criticism; relations of art to its environment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Theory of Action
description: Course Description: Survey of prominent contemporary approaches to leading problems in action theory. Problems include issues about the nature of intentional action and the conceptual character of explanations of actions in terms of the agent's reasons.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Rationality
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues concerning rationality in its various forms. Focus is on theoretical and practical reasoning and conditions for rational belief, choice, and action. Possible additional topics include rationality and human limitations; paradoxes of rationality; varieties of irrationality; rationality and objectivity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Knowledge & the A Priori
description: Course Description: Self-evidence, intuition, the (in)fallibility and (in)defeasibility of a priori methods. Analytic, formalist and Kantian accounts of how knowledge can be acquired through reasoning and intuition alone, without recourse to empirical methods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Logic & Mathematics
description: Course Description: Nature of formal systems and mathematical theories. Selected topics include logical and semantical paradoxes; foundations of mathematics; set theory, type theory, and intuitionistic theory; philosophy of geometry; philosophical implications of Gödels incompleteness results.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 or one course for credit in mathematics.

name: — Logic, Probability, & Artificial Intelligence
description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical artificial intelligence with a focus on nonmonotonic logic, Bayesian networks, and learning theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012; (PHI 112 or STA 013).

name: — Modal Logic
description: Course Description: Survey of the main systems of modal logic, including Lewis systems S4 and S5. Possible worlds semantics and formal proofs. Applications to epistemology, ethics, or temporality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112 or MAT 108; or the equivalent.

name: — Alternative Logics
description: Course Description: Alternatives to standard truth-functional logic, including many-valued logics, intuitionist logics, relevance logics, and non-monotonic logics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 or MAT 108; or the equivalent.

name: — Formal Epistemology
description: Course Description: Formal (mathematical) approaches to belief revision, knowledge and deduction, meta-knowledge, (multi-agent) epistemic logic, Bayesian confirmation, Bayes nets, epistemic and probabilistic paradoxes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012.

name: — Philosophy of Language: Theory of Reference
description: Course Description: Survey of issues and views concerning reference, or how words refer to things. Topics include names and descriptions, the distinction between sense and reference, the puzzle of non-referring terms, causal theories of reference, and possibility and necessity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Language: Truth & Meaning
description: Course Description: Comparative treatment of theories about the relationship between truth and meaning. Topics include: the identification of meaning with truth conditions, the nature of propositions, theories of linguistic understanding, the roles of mind and world in determining meaning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

name: — Philosophy of Language: Semantics & Pragmatics
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues and positions concerning the meaning and use of language. Topics include the distinction between meaning and implication, the roles of context and convention in language use, speaker meaning versus linguistic meaning and speech act theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

name: — Socrates & the Socratic Dialogue
description: Course Description: Philosophy of Socrates as found in the Socratic dialogues of Plato. Topics include the Socratic practice of refutation, its method, epistemological foundation, and moral purpose; Socratic eudaimonism and Socratic virtue theory; the paradoxes of Socratic intellectualism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — Hellenistic Philosophy
description: Course Description: Positions and arguments of the major philosophical schools of the Hellenistic period: Stoicism, Epicureanism, and Scepticism. Focus is on ethical, epistemological and metaphysical questions and their interconnectedness.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — Christian, Islamic, & Jewish Philosophers of the Middle Ages
description: Course Description: Major Christian, Islamic, and Jewish philosophers of the Middle Ages.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — 19th-Century European Philosophy
description: Course Description: Survey of the main movements in 19th-century philosophy on the European continent. Idealism in Schopenhauer and Hegel, dialectical materialism in Marx, irrationalism in Kierkegaard, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Contemporary Analytic Philosophy
description: Course Description: Consideration of central issues such as meaning/reference, analytic/synthetic, reductionism, formal and ordinary language, essential properties, ontological commitment, possible world semantics; influential works by philosophers such as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Austin, Carnap, Quine, Putnam, Kripke, van Fraassen.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — 20th-Century European Philosophy
description: Course Description: Survey of the main movements in 20th-century philosophy on the European continent, including phenomenology, existentialism, post-structuralism and post-modernism. Philosophers covered are Husserl, Heidegger, Sartre, Foucault, Derrida.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Pre-Socratics
description: Course Description: Study of the metaphysical views of such pre-Socratic figures as the Milesians, the Pythagoreans, Heracleitus, Parmenides, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, and the atomists.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — Plato
description: Course Description: Examines Platos most important contributions in metaphysics, epistemology, psychology, cosmology, ethics and political philosophy. Dialogues will be selected from Platos middle and later writings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — Aristotle
description: Course Description: Overview of Aristotles most central and influential writings. Topics selected from fields such as metaphysics, physics, ethics, logic, and psychology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

name: — Descartes
description: Course Description: Philosophical writings of René Descartes. Topics include the refutation of skepticism, the nature and existence of mind and body, the existence of God, and the foundations of science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Spinoza & Leibniz
description: Course Description: Philosophical writings of Spinoza and Leibniz in the 17th century. Topics drawn from both philosophers include: the nature and existence of God, the nature of mind, the relation between mind and body, human freedom, metaphysical monism vs. pluralism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Locke & Berkeley
description: Course Description: Principal metaphysical works of John Locke and George Berkeley. Topics include abstract ideas, existence of matter, primary and secondary qualities, essence, substance, the existence of God, and the nature of scientific knowledge.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Hume
description: Course Description: David Hume's Treatise of Human Nature and related writings. Topics include empiricism, space, causality, belief, skepticism, the passions, and morality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Kant
description: Course Description: Immanuel Kant's Critique of Pure Reason and related writings. Topics include the nature of human cognition, space and time, a priori concepts, substance, causality, human freedom, and the existence of God.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

name: — Frege
description: Course Description: Development of Gottlob Frege's views about language and logic. Formulation of his grand mathematical idea known as logicism and how it led to the philosophy of language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one upper division course in Philosophy recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: History of Philosophy
description: Course Description: Special topics in History of Philosophy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Metaphysics
description: Course Description: Special topics in Metaphysics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Theory of Knowledge
description: Course Description: Special topics in Theory of Knowledge.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Ethics
description: Course Description: Special topics in Ethics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Political Philosophy
description: Course Description: Special topics in Political Philosophy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Philosophy of Law
description: Course Description: Special topics in Philosophy of Law.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Aesthetics
description: Course Description: Special topics in Aesthetics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Philosophy of Mind
description: Course Description: Special topics in Philosophy of Mind.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Philosophy of Science
description: Course Description: Special Topics in Philosophy of Science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Philosophy of Language
description: Course Description: Special topics in Philosophy of Language.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Special Topics in Philosophy: Logic
description: Course Description: Special topics in Logic.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

name: — Honors Research Project
description: Course Description: Completion of honors research project under direction of an instructor. Consult departmental major advisor for list of instructors available in a given quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students who are members of the honors program in Philosophy.

name: — Research Project
description: Course Description: Completion of honors research project under direction of an instructor. Consult departmental major advisor for list of instructors available in a given quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students who are members of the honors program in Philosophy.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Proseminar I
description: Course Description: Intensive study of core works in a selected area of philosophy. Intensive experience in philosophical writing, discussion, and presentation of written work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Proseminar II
description: Course Description: Intensive study of core works in a selected area of philosophy. Intensive experience in philosophical writing, discussion, and presentation of written work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Metaphysics
description: Course Description: Topics vary from quarter to quarter and may include the following: What are things? Do names refer to things? If so, how? Do things have essential properties? What is the nature of necessity?
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Theory of Knowledge
description: Course Description: Topics vary from quarter to quarter. Sample topics include belief, skepticism, justification, externalism, naturalized epistemology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Mind
description: Course Description: Topics in the philosophy of mind, such as the mind-body problem, mental representation, consciousness, intentionality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Mind Practicum
description: Course Description: Specific research conducted and prepared for publication by advanced students in a team setting. Topics include knowledge representation and learning in neural networks, the nature and formal properties of mental representation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Physics
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one (or more) topic(s) in the philosophy of physics, such as foundations of spacetime theories, the interpretation of quantum mechanics, or foundations of statistical mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Biology
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one (or more) topic(s) in the philosophy of biology, such as foundations of evolutionary theories, reductionism in biology, sociobiology and cultural evolution.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Science
description: Course Description: Treatment of one or more general topics of current interest in philosophy of science. Topics may include scientific explanation, theories of confirmation, scientific realism, reduction in physics and biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Logic & Mathematics
description: Course Description: Philosophical issues in logic and math. Topics may include nature of logical and mathematical truth or knowledge, correctness of logical systems, foundations of mathematics, metaphysical and epistemological presuppositions, applications to philosophical problems and formalization of philosophical theories.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112 or PHI 113 or MAT 108; or MAT 125 or the equivalent.

name: — Advanced Logic for Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Intensive study of advanced logic, including set theory, metatheory of predicate logic, and modal logic.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy.

name: — Ethics
description: Course Description: Topics may include morality and motivation, objectivity in ethics, the relationship between the factual and the moral. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

name: — Political Philosophy
description: Course Description: Advanced studies in political philosophy. Topics vary but may include distributive justice, enforcement of morality by the state, equality, obligation to obey the law, social contract theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Environmental Ethics
description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one or more topic(s) in environmental ethics, such as biodiversity, sustainability, composition of the moral community, invasive species, endangered species, applications of ethical theories to contemporary environmental issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Language
description: Course Description: Study of philosophical issues raised by language, such as the nature of semantic content, proper semantics for verbs of propositional attitude, feasibility and limitations of formal semantics and pragmatics for natural languages.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Philosophy of Language Workshop
description: Course Description: Discussion of recently published, unpublished and in-progress research in philosophy of language, including work on the relation of language and mind, of language and logic, and linguistic theory.

name: — Plato
description: Course Description: Advanced seminar designed for analysis of arguments, doctrines, and texts from Plato's works. Methods of argumentation and interpretation are especially stressed. Topics vary according to instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Aristotle
description: Course Description: Advanced seminar designed for analysis of arguments, doctrines, and texts from Aristotle's works. Methods of argumentation and interpretation are especially stressed. Topics vary according to instructor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Kant
description: Course Description: Intensive study of a topic in the philosophy of Kant, in such areas as metaphyics, theory of knowledge, ethics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

name: — History of Philosophy
description: Course Description: Topics in the history of philosophy. Topics vary according to instructor from quarter to quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Research Approaches to Disability & Rehabilitation
description: Course Description: Discussion and evaluation of research approaches to medical rehabilitation, community integration, and quality of life of disabled persons, with a focus on the progressive disabilities associated with neuromuscular diseases. Intent is to encourage interest in professions that serve the disabled community and increase awareness of rehabilitation goals.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Sports Medicine
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic concepts of Sports Medicine in Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation. Students attend afternoon clinic with Sports Medicine attending; attend lectures focusing on Sports Medicine topics. Students also eligible to cover sporting events with attending physicians where available.

name: — Introduction to Rehabilitation Medicine
description: Course Description: Rehabilitation and comprehensive care of physically disabled and physical medicine management of neurologic, neuromuscular and musculoskeletal disorders. Emphasis on evaluation and conservative treatment of spinal disorders, sports injuries and neuromuscular disease. Additional emphasis on inpatient rehabilitation, pediatrics, spine or sports possible.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; consent of instructor.

name: — Comprehensive Rehabilitation Medicine
description: Course Description: Four-week rotation designed as broad overview of Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation practice for students interested in residency training in the specialty. Emphasis on evaluation and conservative treatment of spinal disorders, sports injuries, neuromuscular disease, neurological and non-operative orthopedic problems requiring rehabilitative management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; consent of instructor.

name: — Rehabilitation Medicine Clinical Elective
description: Course Description: Emphasis on evaluation of patients with neurological or orthopaedic problems requiring rehabilitative techniques for their management. Introduction to management of such patients. Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation at off-campus facility must be approved by Chairperson.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; and consent of instructor; completion of third-year in Medical School.

name: — Pediatric Rehabilitation Medicine: Caring for Developmental Disabilities
description: Course Description: Clerkship. Participate in the outpatient clinical care of children with a wide variety of medical conditions at Shriner's Hospitals for Children. Rotate through a variety of different outpatient clinics including cerebral palsy, neuromuscular disease, limb difference, spinal cord injury, spina bifida, brachial plexus, and sports medicine.

name: — Away Acting Internship in Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation
description: Course Description: AI Externship option for PM&R rotations at other institutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Musculoskeletal Anatomy: Sports & Spine SSM
description: Course Description: This four-week module will review the anatomy and biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system as well as its associated pathology. The students will be instructed on appropriate musculoskeletal exam techniques and logical approach to the patient in the clinical setting.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Musculoskeletal Anatomy: Sports & Spine
description: Course Description: Review of the anatomy and biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system as well as its associated pathology. Instruction on appropriate musculoskeletal exam techniques and logical approach to the patient in the clinical setting.

name: — Advanced Group Study
description: Course Description: Study and experience for medical students in any of a number of areas in physical medicine and rehabilitation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research for Medical Students
description: Course Description: Research on any of a variety of topics in physical medicine and rehabilitation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Professional Practice in Healthcare 1
description: Course Description: Role of the Physician Assistant in the context of healthcare system. Physician Assistant topics in practice of healthcare delivery within interprofessional team.

name: — Principles of Physics
description: Course Description: Mechanics. Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics with emphasis on applications in applied agricultural and biological sciences and in physical education.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Trigonometry or consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Physics
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 001A. Heat, optics, electricity, modern physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 001A or PHY 009A.

name: — General Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for students majoring in a biological science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B (can be concurrent) or MAT 017B (can be concurrent) or MAT 021B (can be concurrent); completion or concurrent enrollment in MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B.

name: — General Physics
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 007A.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007A.

name: — General Physics
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 007B.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007B.

name: — Classical Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for physical science and engineering majors. Classical mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021B or MAT 021M; or consent of instructor.

name: — Classical Physics
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena, optics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D (can be concurrent).

name: — Classical Physics
description: Course Description: Electricity and magnetism including circuits and Maxwell's equations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B; MAT 021D; (MAT 022A or MAT 027A (can be concurrent)).

name: — Modern Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to physics concepts developed since 1900. Special relativity, quantum mechanics, atoms, molecules, condensed matter, nuclear and particle physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009C; (MAT 022A or MAT 027A); MAT 022B or MAT 27B recommended (may be taken concurrently).

name: — Honors Physics
description: Course Description: Classical mechanics. Same material as PHY 009A in greater depth. For students in physical sciences, mathematics, and engineering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Honors Physics
description: Course Description: Special relativity, thermal physics. Continuation of PHY 009HA.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009HA or PHY 009A); MAT 021C (can be concurrent).

name: — Honors Physics
description: Course Description: Waves, sound, optics, quantum physics. Continuation of Physics 9HB.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HB; MAT 021D (can be concurrent).

name: — Honors Physics
description: Course Description: Electricity and magnetism. Continuation of Physics 9HC.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HC; MAT 021D.

name: — Honors Physics
description: Course Description: Application of quantum mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HD; (MAT 022B or MAT 027B (can be concurrent)).

name: — Topics in Physics for Nonscientists
description: Course Description: Emphasis varies: survey of basic principles or a deeper exploration of some particular branch. Past topics included black holes, space time, and relativity; physics of music; history and philosophy; energy and the environment; and natural phenomena.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

name: — Physics of California
description: Course Description: Atmospheric phenomena common in CA, local weather patterns and microclimes. Applications to CA energy, water, and resource management policies. Physics underlying regional sports in CA.

name: — Physics of California
description: Course Description: Conceptual understanding of the physics underlying regional sports in CA. Focus on skiing, surfing, and scuba diving. Atmospheric phenomena common in CA, local weather patterns and microclimes, applications to CA energy, and water are also discussed.

name: — Visualization in Science
description: Course Description: Production, interpretation, and use of images in physics, astronomy, biology, and chemistry as scientific evidence and for communication of research results.

name: — Fractals, Chaos & Complexity
description: Course Description: Modern ideas about the unifying ideas of fractal geometry, chaos and complexity. Basic theory and applications with examples from physics, earth sciences, mathematics, population dynamics, ecology, history, economics, biology, computer science, art and architecture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A.

name: — Introduction to Physics Computation
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to programming using C++ with examples from computational physics. Introduction to modern tools used for scientific analysis, including Scientific computing with Python.

name: — Computational Physics
description: Course Description: Algorithms and programming techniques of computational physics with applications from introductory physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 040; PHY 009C or PHY 009HD.

name: — Supplementary Work in Lower Division Physics
description: Course Description: With consent of instructor, students with partial credit in lower division physics courses may complete the credit under this heading.

name: — Experimental Techniques
description: Course Description: Experimental techniques. Design of circuits. Data analysis, sources of noise,  statistical and systematic uncertainties. Light sources, detection, and measurement in basic optical systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009D or PHY 009HD.

name: — Lower Division Seminar
description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Physics through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, or special activities such as laboratory work.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Primary for lower division students.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Laboratory in Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to computational physics and to the computational resources in the physics department. Preparation for brief programming assignments required in other upper division physics classes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 021D,  (MAT 022A or MAT 027A),  (MAT 022B or MAT 027B)),  (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD),  PHY 040,  PHY 104A (can be concurrent).

name: —  Introductory Methods of Mathematical Physics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the mathematics used in upper division physics courses, including applications of vector spaces, Fourier analysis, partial differential equations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better,  PHY 009D C- or better) or (PHY 009HB C- or better,  PHY 009HC C- or better,  PHY 009HD C- or better,  PHY 009HE C- or better)); (MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better),  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)); or consent of instructor.

name: — Computational Methods of Mathematical Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the use of computational techniques to solve the mathematical problems that arise in advanced physics courses, complementing the analytical approaches emphasized in PHY 104A.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105AL; or consent of instructor.

name: — Intermediate Methods of Mathematical Physics
description: Course Description: Applications of complex analysis, conditional probability, integral transformations and other advanced topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Analytical Mechanics
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009B C or better,  PHY 009C C or better,  PHY 009D C or better) or (PHY 009HB C or better,  PHY 009HC C or better,  PHY 009HD C or better,  PHY 009HE C or better); (MAT 021D C or better,  (MAT 022A C or better or MAT 027A C or better),  (MAT 022B C or better or MAT 027B C or better)); or consent of instructor.

name: — Analytical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C or better; PHY 105A C or better; or consent of department for any of the courses.

name: — Continuum Mechanics
description: Course Description: The continuum hypothesis and limitations, tensors, isotropic constitutive equations, and wave propagation. Applications such as elastic solids,heat flow, aerodynamics, and ocean waves.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Optics
description: Course Description: The phenomena of diffraction, interference, and polarization of light, with applications to current problems in astrophysics, material science, and atmospheric science. Study of modern optical instrumentation. Open to non-majors.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 007A,  PHY 007B,  PHY 007C) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE)); (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C,  MAT 021D); or consent of instructor.

name: — Optics Laboratory
description: Course Description: The laboratory will consist of one major project pursued throughout the quarter, based on modern applications of optical techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 108 (can be concurrent); PHY 108 required concurrently.

name: — Electricity & Magnetism
description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better,  PHY 009D C- or better) or (PHY 009HB C- or better,  PHY 009HC C- or better,  PHY 009HD C- or better,  PHY 009HE C- or better); MAT 021D C- or better; (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better); (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better); PHY 104A; PHY 105A; or consent of department.

name: — Electricity & Magnetism
description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 110A C- or better; PHY 104A C- or better; or consent of department.

name: — Electricity & Magnetism
description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 110B C- or better; or consent of department.

name: — Computational Physics Lab for Electricity & Magnetism
description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from electricity and magnetism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 110B (can be concurrent).

name: — Thermodynamics & Statistical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Introduction to classical and quantum statistical mechanics and their connections with thermodynamics. Theory is developed for the ideal gas model and simple magnetic models and then extended to studies of solids, quantum fluids, and chemical equilibria.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A; or the equivalent.

name: — Computational Physics Lab for Statistical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from statistical mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 112 (can be concurrent).

name: — Foundation of Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the methods of quantum mechanics with applications to atomic, molecular, solid state, nuclear and elementary particle physics. Extensive problem solving.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105A C- or better; or consent of department.

name: — Applications of Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Angular momentum and spin; hydrogen atom and atomic spectra; perturbation theory; scattering theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or consent of department.

name: — Computational Physics Lab for Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from Classical and Quantum Mechanics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 115A.

name: — Electronic Instrumentation
description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical study of important analog electronic circuits. Linear circuits, transmission lines, input impedance, feedback, amplifiers, oscillators, noise.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009C or PHY 009HD); (MAT 022B or MAT 027B); or consent of instructor.

name: — Electronic Instrumentation
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 116A. Introduction to the use of digital electronics and microcomputers in experimental physics. Nonlinear electronics, integrated circuits, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters, transducers, actuators.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009C or PHY 009HD; or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Computer-Based Experiments in Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques for making physical measurements using computer-based instrumentation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD); PHY 116B; MAT 022B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Physics Instrumentation with Analog & Digital Electronics
description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical study of important electronic circuits involving analog and digital components. Feedback, amplifiers, oscillators, noise, integrated circuits, digital logic, timers, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 080.

name: — Physics Instrumentation for Data Acquisition
description: Course Description: Experimental application of modern high-density integrated circuits. Automated data acquisition, microprocessors, field programmable gate arrays.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 080; PHY 045 or ECS 036B.

name: — Advanced Laboratory in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Course Description: Experimental techniques and measurements in solid-state physics. Three-six experiments performed depending on difficulty. Individual work is stressed. Thorough write-ups of the experiments are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 110B; PHY 115A; PHY 112 (can be concurrent); PHY 080; or consent of the department.

name: — Advanced Laboratory in Particle Physics
description: Course Description: Experimental techniques and measurements in nuclear and particle physics. Students perform three to six experiments depending on difficulty. Individual work is stressed. Thorough write-ups of the experiments are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 110B; PHY 115A; PHY 112 (can be concurrent); PHY 080; or consent of the department.

name: — Signals & Noise in Physics
description: Course Description: Techniques of measurement and analysis designed to avoid systematic error and maximize signal/noise ratio. Illustrative examples of optimal filters ranging from condensed matter to cosmology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE); PHY 104A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Nuclear Physics
description: Course Description: Survey of basic nuclear properties and concepts requiring introductory knowledge of quantum mechanics: nuclear models and forces, radioactive decay and detecting nuclear radiation and nuclear reaction products, alpha, beta and gamma decay.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Nuclear Physics, Extensions & Applications
description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 129A. Nuclear reactions, neutrons, fission, fusion accelerators, introduction to meson and particle physics, nuclear astrophysics, and applications of nuclear physics and techniques to mass spectrometry, nuclear medicine, trace element analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 129A.

name: — Elementary Particle Physics
description: Course Description: Properties and classification of elementary particles and their interactions. Experimental techniques. Conservation laws and symmetries. Strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions. Introduction to Feynman calculus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Particle Physics
description: Course Description: Properties and classification of elementary particles and their interactions. Experimental techniques. Conservation laws and symmetries. Strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions. Introduction to Feynman calculus.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Solid State Physics
description: Course Description: Survey of fundamental ideas in the physics of solids, with selected device applications. Crystal structure, x-ray and neutron diffraction, phonons, simple metals, energy bands and Fermi surfaces, semiconductors, optical properties, magnetism, superconductivity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or equivalent course passed with C- or better, or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Solid State Physics
description: Course Description: Survey of fundamental ideas in the physics of solids, with selected device applications. Crystal structure, x-ray and neutron diffraction, phonons, simple metals, energy bands and Fermi surfaces, semiconductors, optical properties, magnetism, superconductivity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or equivalent course passed with C- or better, or consent of instructor.

name: — Special Topics in Physics
description: Course Description: Topics vary, covering areas of contemporary research in physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE); or consent of instructor.

name: — Stellar Structure & Evolution
description: Course Description: Chemical composition, structure, energy sources and evolutionary history of stars, with equal emphasis on both the observational data and theoretical models, including black holes, neutron stars and white dwarfs and the formation of substellar masses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE); or consent of instructor.

name: — Galactic Structure & the Interstellar Medium
description: Course Description: Structure, contents, and formation of our Milky Way galaxy, viz. its shape and size, the nature of the interstellar medium, stellar populations, rotation curves, mass determination and evidence of dark matter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE)); PHY 105A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Extragalactic Astrophysics
description: Course Description: Structure and evolution of galaxies and clusters of galaxies, including distance and mass determination, galaxy types and environments, active galactic nuclei and quasars, gravitational lensing and dark matter, global cosmological properties.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE)); PHY 104A; PHY 105A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Astrophysical Applications of Physics
description: Course Description: Applications of classical and quantum mechanics, thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and electricity and magnetism to astrophysical settings such as the Big Bang, degenerate white dwarf and neutron stars, and solar neutrinos.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 105A; PHY 105B; PHY 110B (can be concurrent); PHY 115A (can be concurrent); PHY 112; PHY 112 or consent of instructor; PHY 110B and PHY 115A required concurrently.

name: — General Relativity
description: Course Description: Definition of the mathematical frame work for the description of the gravitational field, introduction of the dynamical equations of Einstein governing its evolution and review of the key solutions, including black holes and expanding universes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 105B; PHY 110A; PHY 105B and PHY 110A or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Cosmology
description: Course Description: Contemporary knowledge regarding the origin of the universe, including the Big Bang and nucleosynthesis, microwave background radiation, formation of cosmic structure, cosmic inflation, cosmic acceleration and dark energy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE)); PHY 105A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Astronomy Instrumentation & Data Analysis Laboratory
description: Course Description: Experimental techniques, data acquisition and analysis involving laboratory astrophysics plus stellar, nebular and galaxy digital imaging, photometry and/or spectroscopy. Students perform three experiments. Individual work stressed. Minimum 10-15 page journal style articles of two experiments are required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 080; PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 110A; PHY 110B (can be concurrent); PHY 115A (can be concurrent); and consent of department.

name: — Formation of Galaxies & Cosmic Structures
description: Course Description: Formation of the cosmic web, including dark-matter halos and galaxies within them. Components of the Universe (dark matter, gas, stars) and their dynamical evolution. Gravitational collapse and virialization. Gas dynamics, heating, and cooling. Galactic star formation and stellar dynamics. Emphasis on theoretical concepts, computational methods, and simulations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A or PHY 009HA C- or better); (PHY 009B or PHY 009HB C- or better); (PHY 009C or PHY 009HC C- or better); (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD C- or better); PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

name: — Environmental Physics & Society
