description: Course Description: Impact of humankind on the environment are discussed from the point of view of the physical sciences. Calculations based on physical principles will be made, and the resulting policy implications are considered.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009D or PHY 007C); (PHY 010 or PHY 001B); MAT 016B; or the equivalent.

name: — Alumni Seminar Series
description: Course Description: Weekly guest speakers (usually a physics alumnus or alumna) tell students about their careers. Speakers use their experience to give students valuable perspectives on life after a degree in physics.

name: — Careers in Physics
description: Course Description: Overview of important research areas in physics, discussions of research opportunities and internships, strategies for graduate school and industrial careers, the fellowship and assistantship selection process, preparation of resumes, personal statements, and letters of recommendation.

name: — Internship in Physics
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience requiring the application of physics principles and techniques in a professional setting, including but not limited to industry and national laboratories.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor/Physics Internship Director.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Open only to Physics and Applied Physics majors who satisfy the College of Letters and Science requirements for entrance into the Honors Program. Independent research project at a level significantly beyond that defined by the normal physics curriculum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Open only to Physics and Applied Physics majors who satisfy the College of Letters and Science requirements for entrance into the Honors Program. Independent research project at a level significantly beyond that defined by the normal physics curriculum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Senior Thesis
description: Course Description: Open only to Physics and Applied Physics majors with senior standing. Preparation of a senior thesis on a topic selected by the student with approval of the department.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Physics & Astronomy
description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in lower division courses. Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the department's regular courses. Weekly meeting with instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Theory of Mechanics & Electromagnetics
description: Course Description: Theoretical approaches in classical mechanics including the use of generalized coordinates and virtual work; variational calculus; Lagrange equations; symmetries, conservation laws, and Noether theorem; Lagrangian density; Hamilton formalism; canonical transformations; Poisson brackets; and Hamilton-Jacobi equations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 204A (can be concurrent); PHY 104B; PHY 105B; PHY 110C; or equivalent to PHY 110C; PHY 204A required concurrently.

name: — Theory of Mechnics & Electromagnetics
description: Course Description: Theoretical approaches in electromagnetics including static electromagnetic fields; Maxwell's equations; plane waves in various media; magnetohydrodynamics; diffraction theory; radiating systems; and special relativity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 200A; PHY 204B (can be concurrent); PHY 204B concurrently.

name: — Theory of Mechanics & Electromagnetics
description: Course Description: Theoretical approaches in electromagnetics including static electromagnetic fields; Maxwell's equations; plane waves in various media; magnetohydrodynamics; diffraction theory; radiating systems; and special relativity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 200A; PHY 204B (can be concurrent); PHY 204B concurrently.

name: — Methods of Mathematical Physics
description: Course Description: Linear vector spaces, operators and their spectral analysis, complete sets of functions, complex variables, functional analysis, Greens functions, calculus of variations, introduction to numerical analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; or the equivalent.

name: — Methods of Mathematical Physics
description: Course Description: Linear vector spaces, operators and their spectral analysis, complete sets of functions, complex variables, functional analysis, Green's functions, calculus of variations, introduction to numerical analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 104B; or the equivalent.

name: — Computational Physics
description: Course Description: Analytic techniques to solve differential equations and eignevalue problems. Physics content of course will be self-contained, and adjusted according to background of students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Knowledge of Fortran or C.

name: — Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Formal development and interpretation of non-relativistic quantum mechanics; its application to atomic, nuclear, molecular, and solid-state problems; brief introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics and the Dirac equation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115B; or the equivalent.

name: — Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Formal development and interpretation of non-relativistic quantum mechanics; its application to atomic, nuclear, molecular, and solid-state problems; brief introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics and the Dirac equation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115B; or the equivalent.

name: — Quantum Mechanics
description: Course Description: Formal development and interpretation of non-relativistic quantum mechanics; its application to atomic, nuclear, molecular, and solid-state problems; brief introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics and the Dirac equation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115B; or the equivalent.

name: — Statistical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Foundations of thermodynamics and classical and quantum statistical mechanics with simple applications to properties of solids, real gases, nuclear matter, etc. and a brief introduction to phase transitions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215B; or equivalent.

name: — Statistical Mechanics
description: Course Description: Further applications of thermodynamics and classical and quantum statistical mechanics. The modern theory of fluctuations about the equilibrium state, phase transitions and critical phenomena.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 219A.

name: — Group Theoretical Methods of Physics-Condensed Matter
description: Course Description: Theory of groups and their representations with applications in condensed matter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215A; PHY 215B; PHY 215C (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor. PHY 215C required concurrently.

name: — Group Theoretical Methods of Physics-Elementary Particles
description: Course Description: Theory of groups and their representations with applications in elementary particle physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215A; PHY 215B; PHY 215C (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor. PHY 215C required concurrently.

name: — Nuclear Physics
description: Course Description: Comprehensive study of the nucleon-nucleon interaction including the deuteron, nucleon-nucleon scattering, polarization, determination of real parameters of Smatrix, and related topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215B.

name: — Nuclear Physics
description: Course Description: Study of nuclear models, including shell model, collective model, unified model. Energy level spectra, static momenta, and electromagnetic transition rates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 224A.

name: — Nuclear Physics
description: Course Description: Study of nuclear scattering and reactions including the optical model and direct interactions. Beta decay and an introduction to weak interactions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 224B.

name: — Advanced Nuclear Theory
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in nuclear theory; theory of quantum-mechanical scattering processes. Exact formal theory and models for two-body scattering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 224C.

name: — Advanced Nuclear Theory
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in nuclear theory; theory of quantum-mechanical scattering processes. Exact formal theory and models for three-body scattering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 229A.

name: — Quantum Theory of Fields
description: Course Description: Relativistic quantum mechanics of particles; techniques and applications of second quantization; Feynman diagrams; renormalization.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215C.

name: — Quantum Theory of Fields
description: Course Description: Continuation of 230A, with selected advanced topics, such as S-matrix theory, dispersion relations, axiomatic formulations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A.

name: — Quantum Theory of Fields
description: Course Description: Renormalization theory and applications, including dimensional regularization, Ward identities, renormalization group equations, coupling constant unification, and precision electroweak calculations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A; PHY 230B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Topics in String Theory
description: Course Description: Current research trends in string theory, with topics ranging from perturbative worldsheet methods, nonperturbative aspects and dualities, AdS/CFT correspondence, string field theory, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor; PHY 230A, PHY 230B, PHY 230C PHY 260 or equivalent are strongly recommended.

name: — Advanced Topics in Geometry & Physics
description: Course Description: Modern geometric methods in theoretical physics, with topics ranging from from pseudo-Riemannian differential geometry and topology with application to general relativity, black holes, and string theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A, PHY 230B, PHY 230C,  PHY 260 or equivalent strongly recommended.

name: —  Condensed Matter Physics A
description: Course Description: Topics in condensed matter physics: Crystal structure; one-electron theory; transport and optical properties of semiconductors; phonons, electron-phonon scattering.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 215C; PHY 219A; PHY 140A PHY 140B or equivalent recommended.

name: — Condensed Matter Physics B
description: Course Description: Topics in condensed matter physics: transport and optical properties of metals and quantum structures; experimental measurement the Fermi surface and of phonon spectra.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 240A.

name: — Condensed Matter Physics
description: Course Description: Review of second quantization. Interacting electron gas, electron-phonon interaction and effects, including instabilities of electronic systems. Topics in the theory of superconductivity and magnetism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 240A; PHY 240B.

name: — Advanced Topics in Magnetism
description: Course Description: Topics chosen from areas of current research interest.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 240A; PHY 240B; PHY 240C; PHY 240D; or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Topics in Superconductivity
description: Course Description: Topics chosen from areas of current research interest.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 240A; PHY 240B; PHY 240C; PHY 240D; or consent of instructor.

name: — Surface Physics of Materials
description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical fundamentals of surface and interface physics and chemistry, including electronic and magnetic structure, thermodynamics, adsorption kinetics, epitaxial growth, and a discussion of various spectroscopic and structural probes based on photons, electrons, ions, and scanning probes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 140A; PHY 140B; PHY 115A; PHY 115B; or the equivalent to any; PHY 215A, PHY 240A, or the equivalents recommended.

name: — Surface Physics of Materials
description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical fundamentals of surface and interface physics and chemistry, including electronic and magnetic structure, thermodynamics, adsorption kinetics, epitaxial growth, and a discussion of various spectroscopic and structural probes based on photons, electrons, ions, and scanning probes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 140A; PHY 140B; PHY 115A; PHY 115B; or the equivalent to any; PHY 215A, PHY 240A, or the equivalents recommended.

name: — Surface Physics of Materials
description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical fundamentals of surface and interface physics and chemistry, including electronic and magnetic structure, thermodynamics, adsorption kinetics, epitaxial growth, and a discussion of various spectroscopic and structural probes based on photons, electrons, ions, and scanning probes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 140A; PHY 140B; PHY 115A; PHY 115B; or the equivalent to any; PHY 215A, PHY 240A, or equivalents recommended.

name: — High-Energy Physics
description: Course Description: Phenomenology and systematics of strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions of hadrons and leptons; determination of quantum numbers; quarks and quarkonia; deep inelastic scattering; the quark parton model; experiments at hadron colliders and electron-positron colliders.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A.

name: — High-Energy Physics
description: Course Description: Electroweak interactions; phenomenology of the Standard Model of SU(2)LxU(1); weak interaction experiments; properties of and experiments with W and Z vector bosons; Glashow-Weinberg-Salam model and the Higgs boson; introduction to supersymmetry and other speculations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 245A.

name: — Collider Physics
description: Course Description: Collider physics. Topics include quark and gluon distribution functions and the computation of cross sections; Large Hadron Collider and International Linear Collider phenomenology; collider and detector characteristics; extracting models from data; software tools for analyzing experimental data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 245A; PHY 252B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; PHY 252B taken previously or concurrently.

name: — Supersymmetry: Theory & Phenomenology
description: Course Description: Construction of supersymmetric models of particle physics; superfields; supersymmetry breaking the minimal supersymmetric standard model; supergravity. Collider phenomenology of supersymmetry. Dark matter phenomenology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A, PHY 230B, PHY 245A, PHY 245B recommended, or consent of instructor.

name: — Supersymmetry: Theory & Phenomenology
description: Course Description: Construction of supersymmetric models of particle physics; superfields; supersymmetry breaking the minimal supersymmetric standard model; supergravity. Collider phenomenology of supersymmetry. Dark matter phenomenology. Not offered every year.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 230A; PHY 230B; PHY 245A, PHY 245B recommended or consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Supersymmetry
description: Course Description: Advanced topics in supersymmetry. Topics include holomorphy, the Affleck-Dine-Seiberg superpotential, Seiberg duality for SUSY QCD, dynamical SUSY breaking, Seiberg-Witten theory, superconformal field theories, supergravity, anomaly and gaugino mediation, and the AdS/CFT correspondence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 246A.

name: — Special Topics in Physics
description: Course Description: Topic varies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Techniques of Experimental Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques and methods of designing and executing experiments. Problems and examples from condensed matter research will be utilized.

name: — Techniques of Experimental Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques and methods of designing and executing experiments. Problems and examples from nuclear and particle research will be utilized.

name: — Statistics & Data Analysis for Particle Physics
description: Course Description: Introduction to statistical data analysis methods in particle physics. Theoretical lectures combined with practical computer laboratory work.

name: — Signals & Noise in Physics
description: Course Description: Techniques for extracting signals from noise, systematic error.

name: — Econophysics
description: Course Description: Application of ideas from statistical mechanics to the financial markets. Market dynamics from a physics and systems perspective, including the statistical distributions of returns, the dynamics of prices, and models for the markets.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Knowledge of Python, R, Excel, Matlab, or consent of instructor.

name: — Physics of Information
description: Course Description: Nonlinear dynamics, deterministic chaos, bifurcations, pattern formation, symbolic dynamics, measurement theory, stochastic processes, elementary information theory, information in complex systems, computational laboratory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced undergraduate or introductory graduate differential equations, applied linear algebra, and probability theory; e.g., MAT 119A/MAT 119B or MAT 207A, MAT 167 or MAT 226A, and MAT 135A/MAT 135B or MAT 235A, respectively; or in PHY 104A/PHY 104B/PHY 104C or PHY 204A/PHY 204B.

name: — Physics of Computation
description: Course Description: Structural complexity, computational mechanics, information measures, causal inference, applications to complex materials, quantum dynamics, and nonequilibrium thermodynamics, computational laboratory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 256A; consent of instructor; advanced undergraduate or introductory graduate differential equations, applied linear algebra, and probability theory; e.g., MAT 119A/MAT 119B or MAT 207A, MAT 167 or MAT 226A, and MAT 135A/MAT 135B or MAT 235A, respectively; or in PHY 104A/PHY 104B/PHY 104C or PHY 204A/PHY 204B.

name: — Introduction to General Relativity
description: Course Description: An introduction to general relativity. Differential geometry and curved spacetime; the Einstein field equations; gravitational fields of stars and black holes; weak fields and gravitational radiation; experimental tests; Big Bang cosmology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 200A; PHY 200B.

name: — Early Universe Cosmology
description: Course Description: Introduction to early universe cosmology: the Big Bang, inflation, primordial nucleosynthesis, dark matter, dark energy, and other topics of current interest.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing in Physics Graduate Program or consent of instructor.

name: — Cosmic Structure Formation
description: Course Description: Growth of structure from small density inhomogeneities in the early universe to the diverse structures observable today. Use of observable properties (cosmic microwave background, gravitational lensing, peculiar velocities, number density, etc.) to constrain models of structure formation and fundamental physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 260.

name: — High Energy Astrophysics & Radiative Processes
description: Course Description: Survey covering galactic and extragalactic X-ray and gamma-ray astronomy, radiative processes, and techniques of high-energy astrophysics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Data Analysis for Astrophysics
description: Course Description: Survey covering measurement and signal analysis techniques for astrophysics and cosmology throughout the electromagnetic spectrum.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Observational Extragalactic Astronomy & Cosmology
description: Course Description: Survey covering current areas of research on extragalactic objects, their physical properties, origin, evolution, and distribution in space.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Research Methods in Astrophysics
description: Course Description: Introduction to research methods in astrophysics and cosmology. Problems and examples from observational and theoretical work will be included.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 204A, PHY 204B and PHY 215A recommended.

name: — Stellar Structure & Evolution
description: Course Description: Underlying physics of stars as the building blocks of the Universe. Reasons for their existence, mechanisms behind their function, their evolution and ultimate fate. Structure of self-gravitating objects, energy transport in stars, nuclear fusion in stars, stellar evolution, and the birth of compact objects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 200A, PHY 200B, and PHY 215A recommended; graduate standing in Physics; or consent of instructor.

name: — Current Topics in Physics Research
description: Course Description: Reading and discussion to help physics graduate students develop and maintain familiarity with the current and past literature in their immediate field of research and related areas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Careers in Physics
description: Course Description: Designed to give Physics graduate students an in-depth appreciation of career opportunities with a graduate degree in physics. Professional physicists, mainly from outside academia, will give seminars describing  both research and career insights.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics.

name: — Seminar in Physics
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in physics. Topics will vary weekly and will cover a broad spectrum of the active fields of physics research at a level accessible to all physics graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Nuclear Physics
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in nuclear physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Elementary Particle Physics
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in elementary particle physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — High Energy Frontier Initiative & Cosmology Theory Seminar
description: Course Description: Weekly seminar on current issues in Particle physics and Cosmology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Physics graduate students.

name: — Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in condensed matter physics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Cosmology
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in Cosmology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction to Departmental Research
description: Course Description: Seminar to introduce first- and second-year physics graduate students to the fields of specialty and research of the Physics staff.

name: — Field, Strings, & Gravity Seminar
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of topics of current research interest in the areas of quantum field theory, string theory and gravity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research on the Teaching & Learning of Physics
description: Course Description: Discussion and analysis of recent research in how students construct understanding of physics and other science concepts and the implications of this research for instruction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Teaching in an Active-Engagement Physics Discussion/Lab Setting
description: Course Description: Analysis of recent research on science/physics teaching and learning and its implications for teaching labs, discussions, and discussion/labs with an emphasis on differences between conventional and active-engagement instructional settings. The appropriate role of the instructor in specific instructional settings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009D; or equivalent.

name: — Methods of Teaching Physics
description: Course Description: Practical experience in methods and problems related to teaching physics laboratories at the university level, including discussion of teaching techniques, analysis of quizzes and laboratory reports and related topics. Required of all Physics Teaching Assistants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing in Physics.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — PBGG Core Course Series–Fall quarter
description: Course Description: The first of three PBGG graduate core courses. Coverage includes (1) plant genes, (2) biotechnology, (3) genomes and gene flow, (4) principles of plant systematics, and (5) the evolution of flowering plants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; a broad background of undergraduate level coursework in Plant Biology is recommended.

name: — PBGG Core Course Series–Winter quarter
description: Course Description: The second of three PBGG graduate core courses. Coverage includes (1) embryo development, (2) cytoskeleton and vesicle trafficking, (3) cell walls, (4) cell growth, (5) secondary metabolism, (6) plastids and (7) senescence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBI 200A.

name: — PBGG Core Course Series–Spring quarter
description: Course Description: The third of three PBGG graduate core courses. Coverage includes (1) plant water relations, (2) cellular & long distance transport processes, (3) mineral nutrition, (4) environmental impacts on growth & development, (5) stress perception & responses, (6) canopy processes, and (7) plant interactions with other organisms.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBI 200A; PBI 200B.

name: — Biology of the Plant Cell
description: Course Description: Recent progresses in plant cell biology. Intracellular motility in plant cells. Common techniques associated with the progress of plant cell biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 111 or BIS 104; or the equivalent.

name: — Plant Ecophysiology
description: Course Description: Study of the mechanisms of physiological adaptation of plants to their environment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 111; PLB 112; PLB 117.

name: — Physiology of Herbicidal Action
description: Course Description: Study of the fundamental processes involved in the physiological action of herbicides. Detailed consideration of the fate of herbicides in plants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 112.

name: — Higher Plant Cell Walls
description: Course Description: Lectures focus on the structure, analysis, synthesis, and development-related metabolism of cell walls. Discussions center on analysis of scientific papers related to lecture topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 112; A course in Biochemistry.

name: — Plant Developmental Biology
description: Course Description: A survey of the concepts of plant development and organization. Examines plant cells, tissues, and organs with special emphasis on experimental evidence for mechanisms regulating developmental processes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Plant Anatomy, Physiology, and Biochemistry.

name: — Special Topics in Scientific Method
description: Course Description: Examine the historical and philosophical background of the scientific method. Analyze the rational, perceptual, causal, creative and social aspects of scientific knowledge. Clarify the roles of reason, experimentation and creativity in scientific research.

name: — Plant Molecular Biology
description: Course Description: Molecular aspects of higher plant biology with emphasis on gene expression. Plant nuclear and organelle genome organization, gene structure, mechanisms of gene regulation, gene transfer, and special topics related to development and response to biological and environmental stimuli.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 121 or MCB 161.

name: — Molecular Biology of Plant Reproduction
description: Course Description: Molecular genetic basis of plant reproduction. Emphasis on understanding developmentally regulated gene expression as it relates to the major changes that occur during plant reproduction and on the genetic control of flowering.

name: — Faculty Seminar
description: Course Description: Discussion of research area of seminar speakers in Plant Biology Graduate Group Seminar Series.

name: — Seminar
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Seminars presented by visiting scientists on research topics of current interest.

name: — Research Conference in Botany
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion by faculty and graduate students of research projects in botany.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and/or consent of instructor.

name: — Graduate Student Seminar in Plant Biology
description: Course Description: Student-given seminars on topics in plant biology, with critiques by instructor and peers. How to give a seminar, including preparation of visual and other teaching aids. Topic determined by instructor in charge.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing.

name: — Seminars in Plants Biology
description: Course Description: Review of current literature in botanical disciplines. Disciplines and special subjects to be announced quarterly. Present and analyze assigned topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Postharvest Biology
description: Course Description: Intensive study of selected topics in the postharvest biology of fruits, vegetables, and ornamentals.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Open to advanced undergraduates.

name: — Tutoring in Plant Biology
description: Course Description: Offers graduate students, particularly those not serving as teaching assistants, the opportunity to gain teaching experience.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

name: — The Teaching of Plant Biology
description: Course Description: Consideration of the problems of teaching botany, especially of preparing for and conducting discussions, guiding student laboratory work, and the formulation of questions and topics for examinations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; concurrent appointment as a teaching assistant in Plant Biology.

name: — Plant Biology
description: Course Description: The social and natural science of plants. Cultural history and socioeconomic importance of plants. Biology of plants reproduction, including flowers, seeds and fruits. Historical, cultural, religious and medicinal uses of plants. Plants in the visual arts, music and literature.

name: — Plant Science Seminar
description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in a small group setting.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Technical and/or professional experience on or off campus. Supervised by a member of the Plant Biology faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — California Floristics
description: Course Description: Survey of the California flora, emphasizing recognition of important plant families and genera and use of taxonomic keys to identify species. Phylogenetic relationships among families. Principles of systematics and taxonomy. Two Saturday field trips.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or equivalent course in Plant Science.

name: — Developmental Plant Anatomy
description: Course Description: Structural anatomy of vascular plants. Training in basic tissue sectioning, staining, and use of the compound microscope.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C; or other similar preparation in plant biology.

name: — Systematics & Evolution of Angiosperms
description: Course Description: Diversity and classification of angiosperms (flowering plants) on a world scale, and current understanding of the origin of angiosperms and evolutionary relationships and trends within them based on morphological and molecular evidence.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

name: — Plant Physiology
description: Course Description: Plant cell as a functional unit. The processes of absorption, movement, and utilization of water and minerals. Water loss, translocation, photosynthesis, respiration.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (CHE 008B (can be concurrent) or CHE 118B (can be concurrent)); PHY 007C (can be concurrent); PLB 105 recommended.

name: — Problems in Plant Physiology
description: Course Description: Discussion of problems and applications relating to principles presented in PHY 111. Problems assigned weekly showing novel applications of principles described in PHY 111; repare answers to be delivered orally during the class period.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 111 required concurrently.

name: — Plant Growth & Development
description: Course Description: Introduction to the mechanisms and control systems that govern plant growth and development and the responses of plants to the environment. Strong emphasis on vegetative development of flowering plants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (CHE 008B or CHE 118B); BIS 101.

name: — Problems in Plant Growth & Development
description: Course Description: Discussion of problems and applications relating to principles presented in PLB 112. Students will be assigned problems each week showing novel applications of the principles described in PLB 112 and will prepare answers to be delivered orally during class period.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 112 required concurrently.

name: — Molecular & Cellular Biology of Plants
description: Course Description: Molecular and cellular aspects of the growth and development of plants and their response to biological and environmental stresses. Primary focus on processes unique to plants. Experimental approaches will be emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); BIS 101.

name: — Problems in Molecular & Cellular Biology of Plants
description: Course Description: Discussion of topics and applications related to principles presented in PLB 113. Assigned topics each week show novel applications of the principles described in PLB 113; discussion of topics during class period.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 113 required concurrently.

name: — Plant Morphology & Evolution
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the form, development and evolution of vascular plants. Emphasis given to the form and development of reproductive structures in ferns and seed-producing plants as a basis for determining evolutionary relationships.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory Plant Biology (e.g., BIS 002C, PLS 002).

name: — Plant Ecology
description: Course Description: The study of the interactions between plants, plant populations or vegetation types and their physical and biological environment. Special emphasis on California. Four full-day field trips and brief write-up of class project required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); PLB 111 recommended.

name: — Population Biology of Invasive Plants & Weeds
description: Course Description: Origin and evolution of invasive plant species and weeds, reproduction and dispersal, seed ecology, modeling of population dynamics, interactions between invasive species, native species, and crops, biological control. Laboratories emphasize design of competition experiments and identification of weedy species.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); introductory statistics recommended.

name: — Plant-Virus-Vector Interaction
description: Course Description: Analysis of interactions necessary for viruses to infect plants.Interactions among insect vectors and host plants involved in the plant-virus life cycle. Evolutionary aspects of the molecular components in viral infection and modern approaches to the interdiction of viral movement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 101; PLB 105, PLP 120, and ENT 100 recommended.

name: — Plant Biochemistry
description: Course Description: The biochemistry of important plant processes and metabolic pathways. Discussion of methods used to understand plant processes, including use of transgenic plants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103 or BIS 105.

name: — Evolution of Crop Plants
description: Course Description: Origins of crops and agriculture, including main methodological approaches, centers of crop biodiversity, dispersal of crops, genetic and physiological differences between crops and their wild progenitors, agriculture practiced by other organisms, and role and ownership of crop biodiversity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — Introductory Mycology
description: Course Description: Systematics, ecology, evolution, and morphology of fungi. Importance of fungi to humans.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

name: — Experiments in Plant Biology: Design & Execution
description: Course Description: Provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to formulate experimental approaches to current questions in plant biology and to carry out their proposed experiments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); or the equivalent courses in Plant Sciences, and consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Plant Biology
description: Course Description: Introduction to research methods in plant biology. Design of field or laboratory research projects, survey of appropriate literature, and discussion of research by faculty and students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Plant Biology or related discipline.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Technical and/or professional experience on or off campus. Supervised by a member of the Plant Biology Department faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Independent study of selected topics under the direction of a member or members of the staff. Completion will involve the writing of a senior thesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to majors of senior standing on honors list.

name: — Tutoring in Plant Biology
description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor by tutoring students in one of the Department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Practical experience in acting as teaching assistant in Plant Biology courses. Learning activity: hands on experience in preparing for and conducting discussions, guiding student laboratory work, and the formulation of questions and topics for examinations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Edible Mushroom Cultivation
description: Course Description: Principles and practices of growing edible mushrooms, including culture maintenance, basic mushroom substrate preparation, composting, spawn generation techniques, inoculation methods, harvesting, and pests and pest management.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 010 or MIC 020 recommended.

name: — Plant Pathogen Biology
description: Course Description: Behavior, pathology, ecology, and evolution of plant pathogens with global impact on food security and environmental health. Bacteria, fungi, viruses, and other pathogens that infect plants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

name: — Introduction to Plant Pathology
description: Course Description: The nature, cause, and control of plant diseases.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C; or consent of instructor; MIC 102 recommended.

name: — Plant-Virus-Vector Interaction
description: Course Description: Analysis of interactions necessary for viruses to infect plants.Interactions among insect vectors and host plants involved in the plant-virus life cycle. Evolutionary aspects of the molecular components in viral infection and modern approaches to the interdiction of viral movement.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 101; PLB 105, PLP 120, and ENT 100 recommended.

name: — Fungal Biology & Disease
description: Course Description: Physiology, cell biology and biochemistry of fungi. Pathobiology of the diseases that fungi or their metabolites cause on plants, animals and humans. Control of fungal pathogens using fungicides.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A  (can be concurrent); BIS 002B (can be concurrent); BIS 002C (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Field Identification of Mushrooms
description: Course Description: Collection and identification of mushrooms and other fleshy fungi based on macro and microscopic features.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory course in Biological Sciences; course in mycology recommended.

name: — Introductory Mycology
description: Course Description: Systematics, ecology, evolution, and morphology of fungi. Importance of fungi to humans.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

name: — Fungal Ecology
description: Course Description: Ecological roles of fungi as saprobes, mutualists and parasites in native and managed ecosystems. Physiological and reproductive strategies associated with adaptations to diverse habitats.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C; or equivalent.

name: — Advanced Mushroom Taxonomy
description: Course Description: Microscopic and molecular methods used in the identification of mushroom species; molecular characterization including PCR-amplification of ribosomal nuclear DNA, digestion of the product with restriction enzymes, and DNA sequencing; a one-day field trip is required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PLP 135 or PLP 148); BIS 101; or the equivalent to BIS 101.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus, supervised by a member of the faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; and consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Impacts, Mechanisms & Control of Plant Disease
description: Course Description: Case-studies approach to analysis of plant diseases caused by bacteria, fungi, oomycetes, and viruses, including impacts, etiology, pathogen taxonomy and epidemiology, biochemical and genetic aspects of pathogen-host interactions, virulence and resistance, and approaches to disease control.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; graduate student status in the Plant Pathology Graduate Program or consent of instructor.

name: — Impacts, Mechanisms & Control of Plant Disease
description: Course Description: Case-studies approach to analysis of plant diseases, including emerging diseases, caused by bacteria, fungi, nematodes, and oomycetes: impacts, etiology, pathogen taxonomy, epidemiology, biochemical and genetic aspects of pathogen-host interactions, virulence, resistance, disease control and statistical analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; PLP 201A; graduate student status in the Plant Pathology Graduate Program or consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Plant Pathology - Field Biology, Diagnosis, Management, & Outreach
description: Course Description: Field biology, economic impacts, diagnosis, epidemiology, and management of disease in agricultural crops. Plant disease in agricultural settings at different production stages (nursery, field, processing, post-harvest).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 201A or PLP 201B; or consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Plant Pathology - Field Trip
description: Course Description: Continuation of PLP 202A. Four-day field trip investigating diseases of agricultural crops and forest trees.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 202A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Diseases of Vegetable & Field Crops
description: Course Description: Clinical study of diseases of vegetable and field crops with emphasis on etiology, epidemiology, diagnosis, and control. Field trips required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120.

name: — Diseases of Vegetable & Field Crops; Summer Field Trip
description: Course Description: Continuation of PLP 205A. Four-day field trip investigating diseases of vegetable and field crops.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; PLP 205A.

name: — Diseases of Fruit, Nut, & Vine Crop
description: Course Description: Clinical study of fruit, nut, and vine crops diseases with emphasis on etiology, epidemiology, diagnosis, and control. PLP 205 may be taken concurrently.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; PLB 119; and consent of instructor.

name: — Diseases of Fruit, Nut, & Vine Crop
description: Course Description: Clinical study of fruit, nut, and vine crops diseases with emphasis on etiology, epidemiology, diagnosis, and control. PLP 205 may be taken concurrently.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; PLB 119; and consent of instructor.

name: — Biochemistry & Molecular Biology of Plant-Microbe Interaction
description: Course Description: Discussion of plantmicrobe interactions, focused on the underlying cellular, biochemical, and molecular events that determine the diseased state.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 103; BIS 104; or the equivalent.

name: — Molecular Genetics of Fungi
description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of molecular biology and genetics of filamentous fungi and yeasts, including gene structure, organization and regulation; plant pathogenesis; secretion; control of reproduction; reproduction; molecular evolution; transformation; and gene manipulation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 103; MCB 161; PLB 119; PLP 130; PLP 215X; graduate standing in a Biological Science; MIC 215 recommended.

name: — Advanced Mycology
description: Course Description: Physiology, cell biology and biochemistry of fungi. Topics include mycotoxins, epidemiology and nature of emerging and re-emerging fungal diseases, fungicides, and fungicide resistance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PLP 148 or PLB 148); PLP 120; or consent of instructor.

name: — Plant Bacteriology
description: Course Description: Study of plant pathogenic microorganisms including taxonomy, biology, molecular mechanisms of disease, and plant disease management. Topics include quorum sensing, rhizosphere biology, genomics, virulence factors, and host plant resistance genes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; or equivalent or consent of instructor.

name: — Plant Virology
description: Course Description: Viruses as causal agents of plant disease and as tools for manipulating plants; structures of virus particles; mechanisms of transmission, replication, and spread in the plant; cytology and molecular biology in susceptible and resistant reactions to virus infection; virus disease control.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate course in Molecular Biology or graduate student in Plant Pathology.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Review and evaluation of current research in plant pathology.

name: — Advanced Research Conference
description: Course Description: Presentation, evaluation, and critical discussions of research activities in the area of advanced plant pathology; primarily designed for graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Molecular Plant Pathology
description: Course Description: Review and evaluation of current literature and research in biochemistry and molecular biology of plant microbe interactions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLP 120; or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Mycology
description: Course Description: Review and evaluation of current literature and research in mycology.

name: — Special Group Study
description: Course Description: Special group study.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Agriculture, Nature & Society
description: Course Description: Multiple perspectives and connections between natural sciences, social sciences, and agriculture. Emphasizes agriculture's central position between nature and society and its key role in our search for a productive, lasting and hospitable environment. Several full-period field trips provide hands-on learning.

name: — Botany & Physiology of Cultivated Plants
description: Course Description: Holistic introduction to the underlying botanical and physiological principles of cultivated plants and their response to the environment. Includes concepts behind plant selection, cultivation, and utilization. Laboratories include discussion and interactive demonstrations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school course in biology and chemistry recommended.

name: — Seminar: Overview of the Plant Sciences Major
description: Course Description: Introduction to topics covered in the core courses and areas of specialization within the Plant Sciences major. Research and internship opportunities and potential career paths in plant breeding, crop management and ecology, horticulture, precision agriculture, crop quality and safety, ecosystem management and restoration, and related fields.

name: — Flower Power; Art & Science of Flowers & Their Uses
description: Course Description: Introduction to the art and science of using and growing flowers to harness the power that is represented by their aesthetic beauty. Handling, production, arranging, breeding and marketing of flowers. Emphasis on potted plants and cut-flowers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school biology.

name: — Flower Power; Art & Science of Flowers & Their Uses
description: Course Description: Introduction to the art and science of using and growing flowers to harness the power that is represented by their aesthetic beauty. Handling, production, arranging, breeding and marketing of flowers. Emphasis on potted plants and cut-flowers.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school biology.

name: — Just Coffee: The Biology, Ecology & Socioeconomic Impacts of the World’s Favorite Drink
description: Course Description: Coffee used as a case study to examine biological, ecological and social factors influencing sustainability of farming systems and how food production systems impact human well-being.

name: — Just Coffee: The Biology, Ecology & Socioeconomic Impacts of the World's Favorite Drink
description: Course Description: Coffee used as a case study to examine biological, ecological and social factors influencing sustainability of farming systems and how food production systems impact human well-being.

name: — Plants & Society
description: Course Description: Dependence of human societies on plant and plant products. Plants as resources for food, fiber, health, enjoyment and environmental services. Sustainable uses of plants for food production, raw materials, bioenergy, and environmental conservation. Global population growth and future food supplies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school biology.

name: — Chocolate, Covered: The Past, Present, & Future of Cacao
description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on the crop that gives us chocolate. History, genetics, agronomy, sensory science, and economics of cacao production.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school biology.

name: — Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture
description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary introduction to agricultural sustainability with a natural sciences emphasis. Sustainability concepts and perspectives. Agricultural evolution, history, resources and functions. Diverse agricultural systems and practices and their relative sustainability. Laboratories provide direct experience with selected agricultural practices and systems.

name: — Application of Computers in Technology
description: Course Description: Concepts of computing and applications using personal computers, spreadsheets, database management, word processing and communications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

name: — Application of Computers in Technology
description: Course Description: Concepts of computing and applications using personal computers, spreadsheets, database management, word processing and communications.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

name: — Organic Crop Production Practices
description: Course Description: Principles and practices of organic production of annual crops. Including organic crops, soil, and pest management, cover cropping, composting, seeding, transplanting, irrigation, harvesting and marketing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in subject areas pertaining to plant and environmental sciences. Internship supervised by a faculty member.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; primarily for lower division students.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; primarily for lower division students.

name: — Metabolic Processes of Cultivated Plants
description: Course Description: Principles of energy capture and photosynthesis, water use, and nutrient cycling. Conversion of these resources into products (carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and other chemicals) by plants. Emphasis on the relationships between environmental resources, plant metabolism and plant growth.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Metabolic Processes of Cultivated Plants Laboratory
description: Course Description: Techniques and instruments used to study plant metabolic processes, including water relations, respiration, photosynthesis, enzyme kinetics, microscopy, immunochemistry, and nitrogen fixation. Quantitative methods, problem solving, and practical applications are emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100A (can be concurrent); or the equivalent.

name: — Growth & Yield of Cultivated Plants
description: Course Description: Principles of the cellular mechanisms and hormonal regulation underlying plant growth, development, and reproduction. Emphasis on how these processes contribute to the harvestable yield of cultivated plants and can be managed to increase crop productivity and quality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100A; or the equivalent of PLS 100A.

name: — Growth & Yield of Cultivated Plants Laboratory
description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises in plant growth and development and their regulation, including photomorphogenesis, plant growth regulators, plant anatomy, seed germination, fruit ripening and senescence. Includes field trips to illustrate relationships to cropping and marketing systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100B (can be concurrent); or equivalent.

name: — Environmental Interactions of Cultivated Plants
description: Course Description: Principles of plant interactions with their physical and biological environments and their acquisition of the resources needed for growth and reproduction. Emphasis on how management practices and environmental conditions affect crop productivity.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100A; or the equivalent of PLS 100A.

name: — Environmental Interactions of Cultivated Plants Laboratory
description: Course Description: Techniques and instruments used to study plant interactions with their physical and biological environments, including light responses, transpiration, microclimatology, nutrient availability and utilization, biomass accumulation. Quantitative methods and modeling are emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100C (can be concurrent).

name: — Agriculture & the Environment
description: Course Description: Focus on the interaction between agriculture and the environment to address the principles required to analyze conflict and develop solutions to complex problems facing society.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002; or consent of instructor.

name: — California Floristics
description: Course Description: Survey of the California flora, emphasizing recognition of important plant families and genera and use of taxonomic keys to identify species. Phylogenetic relationships among families. Principles of systematics and taxonomy. Two Saturday field trips.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or equivalent course in Plant Science.

name: — Concepts in Pest Management
description: Course Description: Introduction to the ecological principles of integrated pest management, biology of different classes of pests and the types of losses they cause, population assessment, evaluation of advantages and disadvantages of different techniques used for pest management, IPM programs.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; (PLS 002 or BIS 002B or BIS 002C).

name: — Crop Management Systems for Vegetable Production
description: Course Description: Horticultural principles applied to production and management systems for vegetable crops. Laboratory and discussion illustrate efficient field management and resource use practices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

name: — Principles of Agronomic Crop Production Systems
description: Course Description: Principles, practices and technologies of agronomic cropping systems, including crop systematics, physiology, agroecology, equipment, and management. Cropping systems analysis and integration of economic and ecological decision-making considerations involved in crop production. One weekend field trip required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

name: — Forage Crop Production
description: Course Description: Forages as a world resource in food production. Ecological principles governing the adaptation, establishment, growth and management of perennial and annual forages, including pastures, rangelands and hay; aspects of forage quality which affect feeding value to livestock.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Biological Applications in Fruit Tree Management
description: Course Description: Physiology, growth, development and environmental requirements of fruit trees and the cultural practices used to maintain them. Emphasis on the application of biological principles in the culture of commercially important temperate zone fruit tree species.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; or equivalent.

name: — Biological Applications in Fruit Production
description: Course Description: Reproductive biology of tree crop species. Biological principles of fruit production, tree nutrition and orchard management for optimizing cropping. Laboratories emphasize hands-on work with orchard tree systems that are done specifically to produce the crop.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; PLS 113 recommended.

name: — Plant Morphology & Evolution
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the form, development, and evolution of vascular plants. Emphasis given to the form and development of reproductive structures in ferns and seed-producing plants as a basis for determining evolutionary relationships.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory Plant Biology (e.g., BIS 002C, PLS 002).

name: — Applied Statistics in Agricultural Sciences
description: Course Description: Application of statistical methods to design and analysis of research trials for plant, animal, behavioral, nutritional, and consumer sciences. Basic concepts and statistical methods are presented in lectures, laboratories emphasize data processing techniques, problem solving, and interpretation in specialized fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Introduction to Plant & Crop Systems Modeling
description: Course Description: Modeling approaches commonly used in plant and crop applications. Fundamentals of how plant/crop models are developed and considerations regarding their limitations. Example model applications include degree-day and radiation-use-efficiency models of growth and yield, phenological models, and crop coefficients.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): college algebra/precalculus  college physics recommended.

name: — Introduction to Digital Agriculture
description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative approaches for collecting, analyzing, and interpreting environmental data used in plant sciences research. Remote sensing data for estimating plant structure, function and water status, spatial and temporal aspects of data, data science and machine learning, synthesizing complex, high-dimensional data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 021 C or better (can be concurrent) or PLS 021 C or better (can be concurrent); PLS 120 C or better; PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Rangelands: Ecology, Conservation & Restoration
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the ecological principles and processes important for an understanding of the dynamics of range ecosystems. Emphasis on ecological and evolutionary concepts underlying management strategies for conserving biological diversity and environmental quality in rangelands.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002B or BIS 002C; or consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

name: — Identification & Ecology of Grasses
description: Course Description: Taxonomy and identification of western grasses. Development of skills in using plant identification keys. Ecology and evolution of grasses in grazing ecosystems. Given the week following spring quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 130 or PLS 102 or PLS 147 recommended.

name: — Ecology & Community Structure of Grassland & Savannah Herbivores
description: Course Description: Feeding ecology of grassland herbivores and its importance in evolution of herbivore communities and social systems. Optimal foraging, interspecific interactions, and primary productivity are considered as factors structuring natural and managed grassland and savannah systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A or BIS 001B); (PLS 002 or BIS 001C); General ecology course (ESP 100) recommended.

name: — Ethnobotany
description: Course Description: Relationships and interactions between plants and people, including human perceptions, management, and uses of plants, influences of plants on human cultures, and effects of human activity on plant ecology and evolution. Concepts, questions, methods, and ethical considerations in ethnobotanical research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — Trees & Forests
description: Course Description: Biological structure and function of trees as organisms; understanding of forests as communities and as ecosystems; use of forests by humans; tree phenology, photosynthesis, respiration, soil processes, life histories, dormancy, forest biodiversity, and agroforestry.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — California Plant Communities
description: Course Description: Ecology, distribution, and species of California's plant communities. Environmental forces that determine these communities, the threats they face, and their conservation and restoration opportunities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C.

name: — California Plant Communities Field Study
description: Course Description: Visits to many of northern California's plant communities, from the north coast to the Central Valley to the Sierras. Discussion of community ecology and hands-on identification of species. Two Saturday and two three-day field trips required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PLS 002 or BIS 002C); concurrent or previous enrollment in PLS 147.

name: — Field Course: Flora of Northern California's Mountains
description: Course Description: Diversity, taxonomy, ecology, evolution, and traditional cultural importance of the flora of the Cascade and Klamath mountain ranges. Conservation and management issues. Legal and ethical responsibilities of field botanists. Hands-on botanical field methods including plant identification, characterization of vegetation types, and rare plant surveys. Field course offered the last two weeks of July, based at Lassen Volcanic National Park.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Sustainability & Agroecosystem Management
description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary analysis of agricultural production and food systems with primary emphasis on biophysical processes. General concepts governing the functioning of temperate and tropical agroecosystems in relation to resource availability, ecological sustainability, and socio-economic viability. Comparative ecological analyses of agroecosystems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 010; CHE 002A; (PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C).

name: — Plant Genetics
description: Course Description: Basic principles of transmission genetics, cytogenetics, population and quantitative genetics, and molecular genetics. Practical aspects of genetic crosses and analysis of segregating populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001A or BIS 002A; or consent of instructor.

name: — Plant, Cell, Tissue & Organ Culture
description: Course Description: Basic and applied aspects of plant tissue culture including media preparation, micropropagation, organogenesis, embryogenesis, anther culture, protoplast culture and transformation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — Introduction to Plant Breeding
description: Course Description: Principles, methods and applications of plant breeding and genetics to the improvement of crop plants. Illustration of how plant breeding is a dynamic, multidisciplinary, constantly-evolving science. Laboratory emphasizes hands-on experience in the basics of breeding through experiments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 152 or BIS 101; or consent of instructor.

name: — Physiology of Environmental Stresses in Plants
description: Course Description: Stress concepts and principles; molecular, physiological, developmental and morphological characteristics enabling plants to avoid or tolerate environmental stresses; stress acclimation and adaptation processes; responses of wild and cultivated species to drought, flooding, nutrient deficiencies, salinity, toxic ions, extreme temperatures, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100C or PLB 111 or PLB 112 or ENH 102 or VEN 110.

name: — Mineral Nutrition of Plants
description: Course Description: Evolution and scope of plant nutrition; essential elements; mechanisms of absorption and membrane transporters; translocation and allocation processes; mineral metabolism; deficiencies and toxicities; genetic variation in plant nutrition; applications to management and understanding ecological effects of nutrient availability or deficiency.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 100A or PLB 111 or ENH 102 or VEN 110.

name: — Agroforestry: Global & Local Perspectives
description: Course Description: Traditional and evolving use of trees in agricultural ecosystems; their multiple roles in environmental stabilization and production of food, fuel, and fiber; and socioeconomic barriers to the adoption and implementation of agroforestry practices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C); (PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B); or general ecology course in lieu of PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B.

name: — Urban Ecology
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Application of fundamental concepts and approaches in landscape and ecosystem ecology to urban ecosystems. Ecological and social drivers and responses. Landscape heterogeneity, nutrient dynamics, invasive species, altered hydrology and climate, and pollution. Discussion of primary literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Course in general or plant ecology such as PLB 117, ESP 100, EVE 101, EVE 120 or PLS 163.

name: — Ecosystem & Landscape Ecology
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Integration of concepts to understand and manage ecosystems in a complex and changing world. Emphasis on interactions among biotic, abiotic & human factors and changes over space/time. Local to global controls over water, carbon and nutrients across ecosystems/landscapes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ESP 100 C- or better) or (SSC 112 C- or better) or (EVE 117 C- or better) or (PLB 117 C- or better) or (PLS 144 C- or better) or (ESM 144 C- or better) or (PLS 162 C- or better) or (ENH 160 C- or better) or (EVE 101 C- or better); or similar class with consent of instructor.

name: — Practicum in Ecological Restoration
description: Course Description: Hands-on field exposure to various aspects of ecological restoration throughout the seasonal restoration cycle with real-world practitioners. Emphasis on grassland/rangeland, riparian, and oak woodland communities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENH 160 recommended.

name: — Fruit & Nut Cropping Systems
description: Course Description: Overview of production and handling systems of major pomological crops, analysis of current cultural and harvesting problems and concerns associated with commercial fruit growing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Fruit & Nut Cropping Systems
description: Course Description: Overview of production and handling systems of major pomological crops, including analysis of current cultural and harvesting problems and concerns associated with commercial fruit growing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 002C; or consent of instructor.

name: — Principles & Practices of Plant Propagation
description: Course Description: Principles and practices of propagating plants covering anatomical, physiological, and practical aspects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — Biology and Quality of Harvested Crops
description: Course Description: Overview of physiological and molecular processes related to the quality and safety of harvested crop products. Targeted approaches and technologies to improve/maintain crop quality and limit crop losses after harvest. Socioeconomic aspects of crop losses and food waste.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; PLS 002; or consent of instructor.

name: — Molecular & Cellular Aspects of Postharvest Biology
description: Course Description: Basic concepts and current knowledge of issues relevant to postharvest biology. Mechanisms of fruit ripening, senescence, programmed cell death. Metabolism and functions of phytohormones, carbohydrates, lipids, pigments, flavor compounds, and phytonutrients at molecular and cellular levels.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; or equivalent.

name: — Microbiology & Safety of Fresh Fruits & Vegetables
description: Course Description: Overview of microorganisms on fresh produce, pre- and postharvest factors influencing  risk of microbial contamination, attachment of microorganisms to produce, multiplication during postharvest handling and storage, and methods of detection. Mock outbreak trial and presentation of science-based forensic discovery.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; or equivalent.

name: — Introduction to Weed Science
description: Course Description: Weed biology and ecology, methods of weed management, biological control, herbicides and herbicide resistance. Weed control in managed and natural ecosystems; invasive species. Laws and regulations. Application of herbicides. Sight and software-assisted identification of common weeds.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

name: — Biology & Management of Aquatic Plants
description: Course Description: Brief survey of common and invasive fresh water plants and macroalgae, their reproductive modes, physiology, growth (photosynthesis, nutrient utilization), development (hormonal interactions), ecology, modes and impacts of invasion, and management. Two Saturday field trips required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C); (CHE 008B or CHE 118B); PLS 100C, PLB 111, ENH 102, or HYD 122 recommended.

name: — Undergraduate Research Proposal
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Preparation and review of a scientific proposal. Problem definition, identification of objectives, literature survey, hypothesis generation, design of experiments, data analysis planning, proposal outline and preparation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: — Laboratory Research in Plant Sciences
description: Course Description: Formulating experimental approaches to current questions in plant science; performance of proposed experiments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 188; and consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar on Alternatives in Agriculture
description: Course Description: Seminar on topics related to alternative theories, practices and systems of agriculture and the relationship of agriculture to the environment and society. Scientific, technological, social, political and economic perspectives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Research Group Conference
description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in the plant sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

name: — Internship
description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in subject areas pertaining to plant and environmental sciences. Internship supervised by a faculty member.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

name: — Garden & Farm-Based Experiential Education Methods
description: Course Description: Methods of teaching children and youth about fruit and vegetable production and consumption. Lesson and activity planning for garden and farm field trips. Basic biology, ecology, plant science, and crop management practices. Mentorship in experiential learning. Preparation of garden site.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Senior Honors Thesis
description: Course Description: Independent study of selected topics under the direction of a member or members of the staff. Completion will involve the writing of a senior thesis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; overall GPA of 3.250 or higher and consent of master advisor.

name: — Postharvest Technology of Horticultural Crops
description: Course Description: Intensive study of postharvest considerations and current procedures and challenges in postharvest handling for fruits, nuts, vegetables, and ornamentals in California. Scheduled first two weeks immediately following last day of spring quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate student standing.

name: — Tutoring in Plant Sciences
description: Course Description: Leading small voluntary discussion or lab groups affiliated with one of the department's regular courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing, completion of course being tutored or the equivalent.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Experimental Design & Analysis
description: Course Description: Introduction to the research process and statistical methods to plan, conduct and interpret experiments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 120; or equivalent.

name: — Applied Multivariate Modeling in Agricultural & Environmental Sciences
description: Course Description: Multivariate linear and nonlinear models. Model selection and parameter estimation. Analysis of manipulative and observational agroecological experiments. Discriminant, principal component, and path analyses. Logistic and biased regression. Bootstrapping. Exercises based on actual research by UC Davis students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 120; (STA 106 or STA 108 or PLS 205).

name: — Applied Statistical Modeling for the Environmental Sciences
description: Course Description: Introduction to building statistical models in classical and Bayesian frameworks, model fitting methods, introduction to hierarchical Bayes, regularization and priors, applications of hierarchical Bayesian models to important kinds of problems of environmental data analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 205 (can be concurrent); PLS 206 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

name: — Postharvest Biology & Biotechnology of Fruits & Nuts
description: Course Description: Review of postharvest biology of fruits and nuts and biotechnological approaches to address postharvest challenges.
