Morphology, biology and postharvest handling of fruits and nuts are presented along with current research, including biotechnology, and discussion of future research needs and approaches.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 172.

name: — Postharvest Physiology of Vegetables
description: Course Description: Comparative physiology of harvest vegetables; emphasis on maturation, senescence, compositional changes, physiological disorders and effects of environmental factors. Concepts and research procedures.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 172 or PLS 100B or PLB 112.

name: — Field Techniques in Plant Physiology
description: Course Description: Hands-on practice applying a wide range of field-oriented plant physiology equipment and techniques. Use of water relations techniques, gas exchange devices, and image analysis, with extensive focus on dataloggers and sensing. Training in field-based plant physiology techniques intended to help students design research projects and appreciate the value and limitations of new equipment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Prior coursework in plant physiology such as PLS 100A, PLS 100CL, PLS 157, PLS 210, PLB 111 or similar.

name: — Genomics & Biotechnology of Plant Improvement
description: Course Description: Integration of modern biotechnology and classical plant breeding including the impact of structural, comparative and functional genomics on gene discovery, characterization and exploitation. Covers molecular markers, plant transformation, hybrid production, disease resistance, and novel output traits.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; or the equivalent.

name: — Genomics & Breeding of Vegetable Crops
description: Course Description: Preview of genome structure, mapping, gene tagging and development of other genetic resources applied to improvement of major vegetables. For graduate students contemplating a career in modern vegetable breeding and biotechnology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; or equivalent.

name: — Advanced Plant Breeding
description: Course Description: Philosophy, methods, and problems in developing improved plant species. Topics include: inbreeding, heterosis, progeny testing, breeding methodology, index selection, germplasm conservation, and breeding for stress resistance. Laboratories include tours of breeding facilities and calculation and interpretation of quantitative data.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 154; PLS 205; GGG 201D or ANG 107 recommended.

name: — Quantitative Genetics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the principles of quantitative genetics including the study and analysis of quantitative variation, concepts of heritability and genetic gain from artificial selection, and application of classic and genome-informed approaches in breeding.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 205; GGG 201D; or consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Extension Education, Outreach & Science Communication
description: Course Description: History, theory, and current practice of extension education. Role and skills needed of the extension educator. Pluralistic nature of extension education. Development of skills to create lasting change through outreach and communication in an extension education program.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Topics of current interest related to Plant Sciences.

name: — Research Conference
description: Course Description: Research conference.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Plant Sciences
description: Course Description: Designed for graduate students who desire teaching experience but are not teaching assistants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing; completion of course to be tutored or the equivalent.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Clinical Plastic Surgery Elective
description: Course Description: Total involvement in patient care involving surgical preparation, treatment, operative care, and follow-up. Developing and understanding reconstruction and aesthetic plastic surgery. Microvascular surgery included. Student rotation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical students.

name: — American National Government
description: Course Description: Survey of American national government, including the constitutional system, political culture, parties, elections, the presidency, Congress, and the courts.

name: — Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: Course Description: Introduction to basic concepts in political analysis and application of them in comparative studies of selected countries. Coverage is given to cultural and other informal dimensions of politics as well as to more formal political and governmental structures.

name: — International Relations
description: Course Description: International conflict and cooperation, including the Cold War, nuclear weapons, and new techniques for understanding international politics.

name: — Basic Concepts in Political Theory
description: Course Description: Analysis of such concepts as the individual, community, liberty, equality, justice, and natural law as developed in the works of the major political philosophers.

name: — Contemporary Problems of the American Political System
description: Course Description: In-depth treatment of selected problems and issues of American politics, governmental institutions, and policies.

name: — Contemporary Issues in Law & Politics
description: Course Description: Seminar focusing on the political dimensions of American law and institutions. Examines the role of courts in resolving contemporary issues of law and politics including abortion, capital punishment, and civil rights.

name: — America Decides: Who Will Win This Year's Election?
description: Course Description: Survey of factors influencing presidential and congressional elections. Analysis of candidate nominations, campaign strategy, campaign finance, media coverage, and voter decision-making.

name: — Citizen Lawmaking: Direct Democracy, Public Policy & Political Representation in America
description: Course Description: Analysis of direct participation by citizens in the lawmaking process.

name: — Politics & Film
description: Course Description: Survey of portrayals of politics and policy issues in moving pictures. Analysis of political processes, policy development, social mores, and historical periods as highlighted in Hollywood movies, television, and/or documentary films.

name: — Political Persuasion
description: Course Description: Examination of political influence and persuasion.

name: — Politics & Sports
description: Course Description: Core issues in American and world politics through the lens of sports and the athletes who play them. Introduction of American civil rights movement, the Cold War, Middle East Tensions, and democratization.

name: — Climate Change & Politics
description: Course Description: Analysis of political institutions' response and adaptation to climate change.

name: — Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

name: — Scientific Study of Politics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the basic principles of the scientific study of politics. Research design and empirical analysis of data with applications to different methodological approaches and different substantive areas in political science.

name: — Lower Division Seminar
description: Course Description: Examines fundamental issues and concepts that shape the study and practice of politics. Students will read, discuss and write about some of the most significant texts in political science in order to develop a foundation for the study of politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Local Government & Politics
description: Course Description: Politics and government of local communities in the United States, including cities, counties and special districts. Emphasizes sources and varieties of community conflict, legislative and executive patterns, expertise, decision making and the politics of structure. Observation of local governing boards.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Urban Public Policy
description: Course Description: Political and economic relationships among central cities, suburbs, and regional, state, and federal governments. Focuses upon policy areas such as poverty, transportation, welfare, and housing, and upon who governs and who benefits from the policies in these areas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 recommended.

name: — California State Government & Politics
description: Course Description: California political system. Political culture, constitution, elections and parties, direct democracy, legislature, governor, executive branch, courts, finances, state-local relations and policy issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Legislative Process
description: Course Description: Legislative process with emphasis on the United States Congress; legislative organization and procedures, legislative leadership and policy making, legislators and constituents, relations between Congress and other agencies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Presidency
description: Course Description: American presidencies origins and development; presidential power and influence as manifest in relationships with Congress, courts, parties, and the public in the formulation and administration of foreign and domestic policy; nominations, campaigns, and elections.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Environmental Politics & Administration
description: Course Description: Environment as a political issue in the United States. Development of administrative mechanisms for handling environmental problems. Changing role of Congress, the presidency, the bureaucracy and the courts in environmental policy formulation and implementation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Policy Making in the Public Sector
description: Course Description: Theoretical rationale for governmental activity, program evaluation, PPBS, positive theories of policy making, the quantitative study of policy determinants, implementation, and proposals for improved decision making.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 recommended.

name: — Public Policy & the Governmental Process
description: Course Description: Processes of formulating public policy, including individual and collective decision making, political exchange, competition, bargaining, coalition formation and the allocation of public goods, resources and opportunities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Strategy of Politics
description: Course Description: Introduction to game theory. Explanation of the behavior of individuals in strategic interaction. Rational and behavioral approaches. Applications to political science and other fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Contemporary Democratic Theory
description: Course Description: Major contemporary attempts to reformulate traditional democratic theory, attempts to replace traditional theory by conceptual models derived from modern social science findings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — American Political Thought
description: Course Description: Origins and nature of American political thought. Principles of American thought as they emerge from the founding period to the present.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — Quantitative Analysis of Political Data
description: Course Description: Logic and methods of analyzing quantitative political data. Topics covered include central tendency, probability, correlation, and non-parametric statistics. Particular emphasis will be placed on understanding the use of statistics in political science research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 051 recommended.

name: — Medieval Political Thought
description: Course Description: Examination of the ideas central to medieval political thinking. Emphasis will be upon the thoughts of the major political thinkers of the period, rather than upon political history.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — Foundations of Political Thought
description: Course Description: Analysis and evaluation of the seminal works of a major political philosopher or of a major problem in political philosophy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — Topics in the History of Political Thought
description: Course Description: Political thought of a specific historical period. Topics may include: Ancient Athens, the Italian Renaissance, the Enlightenment, or 19th-century Germany.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — History of Political Theory:  Ancient
description: Course Description: Critical analyses of classical and medieval political philosophers such as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero and St. Thomas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — History of Political Theory: Early Modern
description: Course Description: Critical analysis of the works of early modern political philosophers such as Machiavelli, Montaigne, Hobbes, Locke and Hume.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — History of Political Theory:  Late Modern
description: Course Description: Critical analyses of the works of late modern political philosophers such as Rousseau, Kant, Hegel, Tocqueville, Mill, Marx and Nietzsche.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — Contemporary Political Thought
description: Course Description: Contemporary political thought from the end of the 19th century to the present. Emphasis upon an individual philosopher, concept, or philosophical movement; e.g., Nietzsche, Continental political thought, Rawls and critics, theories of distributive justice, feminist theory.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — Theories of International Politics
description: Course Description: Major contemporary approaches to the study of international politics, including balance of power, game theory, Marxist-Leninist theory, systems theory, and decision-making analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — Scientific Study of War
description: Course Description: Analysis of political processes involved in the initiation, conduct and termination of modern interstate warfare.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — International Law
description: Course Description: Selected topics in international law; territory, sovereign immunity, responsibility, the peaceful settlement or nonsettlement of international disputes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — The Politics of Interdependence
description: Course Description: In the past several decades, growing economic interdependence has generated new problems in international relations. Deals with difficulties in managing complex interdependence and its implication on national policies and politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — The Politics of Global Inequality
description: Course Description: Analysis of current economic and political international relations resulting from a long standing division of the global system into rich and poor regions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — Ethnic Self-Determination & International Conflict
description: Course Description: Compares the claims of the state and ethnic peoples in countries undergoing internal conflicts; e.g., South Africa, Northern Ireland. Analyzes the role of the international community in facilitating the peaceful resolution of conflicts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — Special Studies in International Politics
description: Course Description: Intensive examination of one or more special problems in international politics. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — Recent U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Course Description: Broad survey of the development of U.S. foreign policy in 20th century with emphasis on transformation of policy during and after World War II, and the introduction to analytic tools and concepts useful for understanding of current foreign policy issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — Analysis of U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Course Description: Detailed presentation and examination of the formulation of execution of U.S. foreign policy. Survey of numerous factors influencing policy outcomes and how such determinants vary according to policy issue areas.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — National Security Policy
description: Course Description: Development of national security policies since 1945. Analysis of deterrence and assumptions upon which it is based. Effects of nuclear weapons upon conduct of war, alliance systems, and the international system. Prospects of security and stability through arms control.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — Africa & U.S. Foreign Policy
description: Course Description: Overview of American foreign policy toward Africa. Relationship to global adversaries. Legacies of colonialism. Challenge of national self-determination and white racism. Policies on non-alignment, producer cartels, multinational corporations, continental integration and trade and aid relations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — International Politics of the Middle East
description: Course Description: International politics of the Middle East as a microcosm of world politics. The Middle East as a regional system. Domestic and International Politics in the Middle East. Changing Political Structures in the Middle East. Superpower involvement in the Middle East.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — The Arab-Israeli Conflict
description: Course Description: Causes, course, and implications of Arab-Israeli conflict. Competing Israeli and Arab narratives, politics of force, diplomacy. Domestic politics and A-I conflict, the superpowers and the A-I conflict, A-I conflict and world politics, potential solutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — International Relations in Western Europe
description: Course Description: Analysis of European unity, problems of the Atlantic alliance, Atlantic political economy, East-West relations, communism in Western Europe and the relationship between domestic politics and foreign policy. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 003 recommended.

name: — Special Studies in Foreign Policy
description: Course Description: Extensive examination of one or more special problems in foreign policy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — Comparative Political Institutions:  Electoral Systems
description: Course Description: Workings of electoral institutions, focusing on systems used to elect presidents and assemblies, pass laws, and generally make decisions. Examples from systems throughout the world, including cases from both the advanced industrial and developing worlds.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Comparative Political Institutions:  Parties
description: Course Description: Factors shaping political parties and their role in democratic representation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — Comparative Political Institutions:  Legislatures
description: Course Description: Examination of legislatures from a comparative perspective.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — When Institutions Fail
description: Course Description: Examination of factors contributing to the success and failure of political institutions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Policy-Making Processes
description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of policy-making in the U.S. and other countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Experiments in Social Change
description: Course Description: Concept and practice of randomized policy experiments. Applications in comparative politics. Practical exercises in cleaning, analyzing, visualizing, and interpreting data from experiments.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002; POL 051 recommended.

name: — Comparative Development:  Political Development in Modernizing Societies
description: Course Description: Nature and sequence of political development; its economic and social concomitants; role of elites, military, bureaucracy, and party systems; social stratification and group politics; social mobilization and political participation; instability, violence, and the politics of integration.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — Comparative Development: Politics & Inequality
description: Course Description: Linkages between politics and the distribution of social and economic goods. Impact of civil rights legislation, the politics of welfare states, and the effects of political participation on the distribution of goods.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — Comparative Political Development: Democracy & Democratization
description: Course Description: Examination of conditions promoting democratization and democratic stability.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Latin American Politics
description: Course Description: Issues related to democratic consolidation in Latin America, with a regional focus on South America. Topics include transitions to democracy, the role of the military, political economy, and political behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Mexican Politics
description: Course Description: Introduction to the politics of contemporary Mexico. Focus on rise, fall, and aftermath of Mexico's one-party dominant system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Politics of Post-Communist Countries:  East European Politics
description: Course Description: Post-war democratization, state-building and economic reform in East European states.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Politics of Post-Communist Countries:  Russia
description: Course Description: Democratization, state-building and economic reform; creation of new institutions; impacts of Soviet rule.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Politics in Israel
description: Course Description: Introduction to the domestic politics of Israel in comparative perspective, including issues of internal cultural diversity, religion and politics, fragmentation of the political party system, and coalition governance.

name: — Politics of Africa: Issues in Contemporary African Politics
description: Course Description: African politics since the end of the Cold War. Topics include: Strategic Security Approach, Democratization, Human Rights, HIV/AIDS, African Peacekeeping, Terrorism, Religious and Ethnic Conflict, Debt and Stalled Development.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Politics of Africa:  Development in Africa
description: Course Description: Political and economic development within Sub-Saharan Africa. States and institutions, democracy, party systems, military coups/rule, bureaucracy/corruption, race/ethnicity, national/regional integrations, trade unions, economic development strategies, class formation, and women's roles and ideology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — West European Politics
description: Course Description: Evolution, politics, and contemporary problems of selected political systems of Western Europe. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — West European Politics:  British Politics
description: Course Description: Evolution, politics, and contemporary problems of Britain's political system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — West European Politics:  French Politics
description: Course Description: Evolution, politics and contemporary problems of France's political system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — West European Politics: German Politics
description: Course Description: Evolution, politics and contemporary problems of Germany's political system.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Government & Politics of East Asia: China
description: Course Description: Evolution of political institutions and political culture in China with emphasis on the post-1949 period. Primary attention to nationalism, modernization and political efficacy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Government & Politics in East Asia: Japan
description: Course Description: Japanese politics, with an emphasis on the postwar period. Particular emphasis on political parties, elections, political economy, and social problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Government & Politics in East Asia: Southeast Asia
description: Course Description: Evolution of political institutions and economy of selected nations in Southeast Asia. Emphasis on imperialist legacy, nation building in multi-ethnic communities, and contrasts in economic performance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 002 recommended.

name: — Judicial Politics & Constitutional Interpretation
description: Course Description: Politics of judicial policy making, issues surrounding constitutional interpretation and decision making, prerequisite for courses on the politics of constitutional law.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Constitutional Politics of the First Amendment & the Right to Privacy.
description: Course Description: Constitutional politics surrounding such issues as the right to free expression, associational rights, the right to free exercise of religious beliefs and the right to privacy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Constitutional Politics of the Equality
description: Course Description: Constitutional politics of equality in the American political system; issues surrounding constitutional doctrine and judicial policymaking; special attention on racial and sexual equality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Constitutional Politics of the Justice System
description: Course Description: Constitutional politics of the American criminal justice system. Issues surrounding constitutional doctrine and judicial policymaking on issues such as search and seizure. Arrest, trial, incarceration and other issues of due process.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Legal Philosophy
description: Course Description: Analysis of the nature and functions of law; law as an instrument of social control and the relationship between law and morality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Judicial Process & Behavior
description: Course Description: Analysis of the behavior of judges and courts in the political process. Techniques of judicial decision making. Relationships among courts and other decision-making bodies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — American Political Parties
description: Course Description: Analysis of the structured operations of the party system in the United States; party functions and organizations, nomination processes, campaigns and elections, party trends and reforms.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Ballots, Bucks, & Maps: The Rules of the Electoral Game in American Politics
description: Course Description: Analysis of laws and court cases on the organization and administration of elections in the United States. Topics include campaign finance, redistricting, voting rights, race & representation, and comparisons with other democracies.

name: — Elections & Voting Behavior
description: Course Description: Analysis of American elections and partisan behavior; political socialization, political participation, partisanship and individual and group determinants of voting.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Group Politics
description: Course Description: Groups, institutions and individuals, especially in American politics. Historical and analytical treatment of group theories as applied to interest groups (especially labor, business, agriculture, science, military); to racial, ethnic and sectional groups; to parties, public and legislative groups, bureaucracies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Public Opinion
description: Course Description: Nature of public opinion in America as it is supposed to be and as it is. Distribution of opinions among different publics and the significance of that distribution for system stability and institutions. Opinion polling and its problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 recommended.

name: — Mass Media & Politics
description: Course Description: Organization of and decision making within the media; media audiences and the effect of the media on attitudes and behavior; the relationship of the government to the media (censorship, secrecy, freedom of the press, government regulation);the media in election campaigns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Mass Media & Politics
description: Course Description: Organization of and decision making within the media; media audiences and the effect of the media on attitudes and behavior; the relationship of the government to the media (censorship, secrecy, freedom of the press, government regulation);the media in election campaigns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Women in Politics
description: Course Description: Role of women in American politics. Historical experiences; contemporary organizations and strategies; areas of legislative concern; the impact of differences in social class, race, and ethnicity upon the involvement of women in politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Chicano Politics
description: Course Description: Political aspects of Chicano life in America; examines the Chicano's political role as it has been historically defined by different groups in society and the Chicano's responses to his/her political environment.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Political Psychology
description: Course Description: Overview to the growing literature on political psychology. Introduction to how psychological concepts (personality, attitudes, stereotypes, heuristics, affect, identity, group dynamics) help us understand how citizens think about politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — The Politics of Energy
description: Course Description: Nature and performance of political processes for making energy choices at the international, national and state levels. Interaction of energy policy with other political goals and the ability of governmental institutions to overcome constraints on policy innovation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — American Political Development
description: Course Description: Systematic analysis of contemporary issues in American political development: historical determinants of political change; the timing and character of institutional development; conditions for successful political action. Democratization, cultural change, party formation, state-building, constitutionalism, race relations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Government & the Economy
description: Course Description: Political basis of economic policy (taxation, spending and regulation); impact of prices, employment and growth on political demands; elite responses to economic conditions; policy alternatives and the public interest.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Science, Technology, & Policy
description: Course Description: Analysis of policymaking for science and the use of scientific expertise for making decisions about technology. Topics include funding of basic research, relationship of science to technological development, science and military policy, technological risks, technology assessment and scientists and politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 recommended.

name: — Racial Politics
description: Course Description: Race, racial attitudes and racial policies in the United States with a specific emphasis on African Americans.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Special Studies in Comparative Politics
description: Course Description: Intensive examination of one or more special problems appropriate to comparative politics. Coverage is given to formal and informal political institutions, economically developing and developed countries, and non-democratic, democratic, and democratizing countries.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 002 recommended.

name: — Bureaucracy in Modern Society
description: Course Description: Role of bureaucracy in a complex society, with emphasis upon changing relationships between government and the economy; consequences of rapid technological and social change for bureaucratic structures and processes; the problems of reconciling expertise and democracy and increasing the responsiveness of public bureaucracy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 001 or POL 002 recommended.

name: — Administrative Behavior
description: Course Description: Implications for American public administration of evolving concepts about behavior in organizations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 recommended.

name: — Administrative Theory
description: Course Description: Historical and critical analysis of the principal theories of organization and management of public agencies in light of such concepts as decision making, bureaucracy, authority and power, communication and control; examination of role of government bureaucracies in the total society.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 004 recommended.

name: — International Relations
description: Course Description: Analysis and evaluation of substantive issues in contemporary international relations. Readings drawn from current academic and non-academic periodicals. May be taught abroad.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; POL 003 recommended.

name: — Internship in Public Affairs
description: Course Description: Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related organizations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Instructor; highest priority assigned to students with Political Science Public Service major; upper division standing required.

name: — Internship in Public Affairs
description: Course Description: Supervised internship and study in political, governmental, or related organizations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 192A; consent of instructor; highest priority assigned to students with Political Science-Public Service major; upper division standing.

name: — Research in Practical Politics
description: Course Description: Supervised preparation of an extensive paper relating internship experience to concepts, literature, and theory of political science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 192A; POL 192B; open only to Political Science-Public Service majors, for whom it is required.

name: — Washington Center Research Seminar
description: Course Description: Core academic component of Washington Program offered every quarter. Topics coordinated with internships. Research draws on resources uniquely available in Washington, DC. Supervised preparation of extensive paper.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WAS 192W (can be concurrent).

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in preparation of a senior honors thesis under the direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in Politcal Science with upper division standing and a GPA of 3.500 in the major.

name: — Special Study for Honors Students
description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in preparation of a senior honors thesis under the direction of faculty advisor.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in Political Science with upper division standing and a GPA of 3.500 in the major.

name: — Special Studies in American Politics
description: Course Description: Intensive examination of one or more special problems appropriate to American politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Seminar in American Politics
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing in American politics. Topics may include Congress, the Presidency, the Supreme Court, federalism, voting behavior, interest groups, ethnic groups or other topics with a more specialized content than normal course offerings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Comparative Politics
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing in comparative politics. Topics may include one country or geographical area, political institutions or behavior across countries, political development, or other topics that are more specialized than normal course offerings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in International Relations
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing in international relations including study of international political institutions (UN, EU, or NATO) or interstate relations (war, trade, immigration) and other topics with more specialized content than normal course offerings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Political Theory
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, writing in political theory. Topics may include study of a single political thinker, a group of related thinkers, development of political concepts, or other topics with more specialized content than normal course offerings.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Research Methods
description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing in selected topics in Research Methods such as research design, statistics, game theory, etc.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Political Science majors or consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Political Science
description: Course Description: Tutor responsibilities such as attending class, offering a guest lecture on a select topic, assisting in group discussions, hosting consultation or review sessions, or assisting instructor with assignments (though not grading).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Urban Government & Politics
description: Course Description: Survey and analysis of the literature in the field of local government and politics in the United States. Approaches to the study of political reform, local autonomy, community power, representation, expertise, service delivery, policy making and political change.

name: — American State Government & Politics
description: Course Description: Survey and analysis of the literature in the field of state government, politics, and policy. Approaches to the study of the American states as political systems, including their governing institutions and processes and their role in the Federal system.

name: — American Government: The Presidency
description: Course Description: Thorough overview of the current research on political executives, with particular emphasis on the American presidency. Two principal goals: the development of important and innovative student research programs; and adequate preparation for qualifying examinations.

name: — American Government: Congress
description: Course Description: Thorough overview of the current research on Congress, with particular emphasis on political representation. Two principal goals: the development of important and innovative student research programs; and adequate preparation for qualifying examinations.

name: — American Government: Courts
description: Course Description: Survey and analysis of the literature in the field of American government with a focus on courts. Emphasis on the development and testing of theories of behavior and processes.

name: — Environmental Public Policy
description: Course Description: Analysis of the interface between the world of academic reflection about ecological and environmental problems and the world of political action. Evaluation of alternative approaches to policy analysis and recommendation. Individual research, including field research, will parallel discussion of the literature.

name: — Policy Analysis
description: Course Description: Social science techniques applied to public policy formation and evaluation.

name: — The American Political System
description: Course Description: Analysis of selected theoretical and empirical issues posed by contemporary research in American government and politics.

name: — Research Design in Political Science
description: Course Description: Introduction to philosophy of science and research design for political science. Topics include: logic of empirical research, overview of research design approaches for political science research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Research Methods in Political Science
description: Course Description: Introductory seminar on the foundations of probability theory and mathematical statistics that are critical to empirical investigations in political science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Quantitative Analysis in Political Science I
description: Course Description: Seminar provides an introduction to the linear regression model. Will obtain a working knowledge of basic regression techniques and problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 211.

name: — Quantitative Analysis in Political Science II
description: Course Description: More advanced topics in the use of statistical methods, with emphasis on political applications. Topics include: properties of least squares estimates, problems in multiple regression, and advanced topics (probit analysis, simultaneous models, time-series analysis, etc.).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 211; POL 212.

name: — Research in Political Science
description: Course Description: Research seminar sequence required of all PhD students. Design, execution, and defense of an original piece of research in political science, culminating in a paper of publishable quality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 213.

name: — Research in Political Science
description: Course Description: Research seminar sequence required of all PhD students. Design, execution, and defense of an original piece of research in political science, culminating in a paper of publishable quality.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 212; POL 214A.

name: — Introduction to Modeling Political Behavior
description: Course Description: Introduction to formal and game theoretic analyses of politics. Students will learn basic game theory and modeling skills. We examine the benefits of modeling, and look at examples of formal analysis in a variety of political science sub-fields.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 211; POL 212.

name: — Qualitative Research Methods
description: Course Description: Methodology for utilizing theoretically-oriented case studies and controlled comparison of a small number of cases to develop and test theories. Examination of how the case study method compliments experimental, statistical and deductive modes of research.

name: — Social Choice Theory & Spatial Modeling
description: Course Description: Introduction to social choice theory and formal spatial modeling including Arrows Theorem, the paradox of voting, cycling and agenda control. Focus on mastering modeling techniques as well as interpretation of classic works.

name: — Topics in Political Theory
description: Course Description: Topics vary and may be the work of a single theorist, time period, or political concept, such as justice.

name: — Political Theory Sequence
description: Course Description: Survey of the great works in ancient and medieval political theory including such writers as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, St. Augustine, Aquinas, Alfarabi and Marsilius. Discussions of various interpretations of these authors.

name: — Political Theory Sequence
description: Course Description: Survey of the great works in early modern to contemporary political theory including such writers as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill, Nietzsche, and Rawls. Discussion of various interpretations of these authors.

name: — Contemporary Political Theory
description: Course Description: Survey of important works in contemporary political theory including such writers as Nietzsche, Heidegger, Arendt, Rawls, Nozick, Sandel.

name: — Seminar in Political Theory
description: Course Description: Introduction to political theory and current debates over its study. Readings from and textual interpretations of political theory including the Federalist Papers and major works by thinkers such as Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, and Rawls. Other readings addressing issues of textual interpretation.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — International Relations
description: Course Description: International relations.

name: — International Security
description: Course Description: Contemporary scholarship on issues related to international conﬂict and political violence, with particular emphasis on how current trends in globalization and governance aﬀect global security.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 223; consent of instructor.

name: — The International System
description: Course Description: Analysis of the international system by means of theory formulation and integration; critique of research designs; use of various techniques of data generation and analysis.

name: — Seminar in International Political Economy
description: Course Description: Research in international political economy. Structure of the global economy, as well as specific dimensions of international economic relations, including trade, capital flows, global production structures, and migration.

name: — American Foreign Policy
description: Course Description: American foreign policy.

name: — U.S. Political Culture & Foreign Relations
description: Course Description: Relates U.S. political culture to formulation of foreign policy. Analyzes American ideological preferences in historical perspective, contemporary public opinion, decision making and implementation. Concludes by examining linkages between foreign policy behavior and democratic process.

name: — Communist Political Systems
description: Course Description: Systematic analysis of selected topics dealing with the political process of communist political systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar in Comparative Politics
description: Course Description: Systematic survey of theories and methods used in the study of comparative politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Comparative Institutional Change
description: Course Description: Comparison of institutional changes in countries of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe during the period of transition to democracy. Special attention to institutions of mass representation; electoral and party systems and national legislatures.

name: — Policymaking in Third-World Societies
description: Course Description: Included in an analysis of policymaking process in Third-World countries are such topics as political resources, institutional resources, decision making, resource allocations, planning, and budgeting, implementation, and distribution of world resources.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Policy Development & Impact in U.S. Courts
description: Course Description: Thorough overview of the literature regarding courts as policymaking institutions of government, with emphasis on the formation and implementation of judicial policy. Differences and similarities across the judicial, congressional, and executive branch policy processes.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Political Parties
description: Course Description: Survey of selected topics in American and comparative parties.

name: — Political Behavior
description: Course Description: Survey of selected topics in political behavior and public opinion.

name: — Political Economy
description: Course Description: Politics of economic policy as reflected in taxation, spending and regulation; impact of prices, employment, and growth on political demands; government responses to economic conditions; electoral politics and the political business cycle.

name: — Political Networks: Methods & Applications
description: Course Description: Structure of political networks, socio-matrices and affiliation networks; general networks characteristics: density, centralization, polarization, interdependence, dyadic and triadic characteristics: structural and role equivalence; subsets of networks: cliques, blocks and bloc modeling; characteristics of individuals in networks: centrality and prestige.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Bayesian Methods: for Social & Behavioral Sciences
description: Course Description: Methodology seminar introducing Bayesian quantitative methods to issues and problems in political science and other social and behavioral sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 212; or equivalent to course.

name: — Statistical Computing Issues in Political Science
description: Course Description: Methodology seminar introducing computing issues in empirical models for political science and other social and behavioral sciences.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 213; or equivalent to course.

name: — Advanced Modeling of Political Behavior
description: Course Description: Applications of formal theory to political science. Review of relevant contributions in other social sciences. Consideration of advanced techniques in game theory. Rational and behavioral approaches.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 215; or equivalent to course.

name: — Organizational Behavior
description: Course Description: Organizational behavior as it relates to public sector decision making.

name: — Advanced Network Analysis
description: Course Description: Exponential Random Graph Models (ERGMS) of networks, game theoretic models of network formation and network dynamics, diffusion processes, shocks and network collapse, percolation, cross-network spillover processes, social and political applications of advanced network models.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 211; POL 212; POL 279.

name: — Statistics of Causal Inference in Political Science
description: Course Description: Approaches to causal inference using the potential outcomes framework, with political science applications using observational and experimental data. Covers several prominent causal research designs used for studying politics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 211; POL 212; POL 213.

name: — Research in American Government & Public Policy
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on problems and issues in the study of American government and public policy.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Political Theory
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on problems and issues in the study of political theory.

name: — Research in International Relations
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on select problems and issues in the study of international relations.

name: — Research in Judicial Politics
description: Course Description: Contemporary research on judicial politics, judicial institutions, jurisprudence, and judicial behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Political Science or consent of instructor.

name: — Research in Political Parties, Politics, & Political Behavior
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on selected problems and issues in the study of political parties, politics, and political behavior.

name: — Research in Comparative Government & Policy
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on select problems and issues in the study of comparative government and policy.

name: — Research in Methodology
description: Course Description: Special research seminar on selected problems and issues in methods in political science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 212.

name: — Internships in Political Science
description: Course Description: Application and evaluation of theoretical concepts through work experience or systematic observation in public and political agencies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to persons who have internships or other positions in governmental agencies, political parties, etc.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.

name: — The Teaching of Political Science
description: Course Description: Methods and problems of teaching political science at the undergraduate level.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in Political Science.

name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Principles of Population Biology
description: Course Description: Principles of single-species ecology and evolution. Topics include ecology of individuals, population growth models, structured populations, life history strategies, stochastic populations, basic population genetics theory, deleterious alleles in natural populations, and molecular population genetics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBG 231 required concurrently; and consent of instructor.

name: — Principles of Population Biology
description: Course Description: Principles of multi-species communities. Topics include competition, mutualism, metapopulations, food webs and trophic cascades, interactions between simple ecological communities, island biogeography, succession, and large-scale patterns.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBG 200A; PBG 231.

name: — Principles of Population Biology
description: Course Description: Principles of microevolution and macroevolution. Topics include evolutionary quantitative genetics, analysis of hybrid zones, speciation, the fossil record, biogeography, and phylogeny reconstruction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBG 200B.

name: — Advanced Evolution
description: Course Description: Adaptation and speciation, and biochemical and morphological evolution in plants and animals with emphasis on the appropriateness of different methods of analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Ecology of Insect Parasitoids
description: Course Description: Insect parasitoids will be investigated as model systems to address current topics in behavioral, population, and evolutionary ecology. Theory will be synthesized and critical empirical tests of ecological hypotheses emphasized.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory animal ecology or behavior.

name: — Plant Population Biology
description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical and empirical research in plant population biology. Emphasis placed on linking ecological and genetic approaches to plant population biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate ecology course (e.g., ESP 100, EVE 101, ENT 104, PLB 117), and advanced undergraduate course in genetics and/or evolution (e.g., BIS 101 or EVE 100).

name: — Topics in Invertebrate Evolution
description: Course Description: Advanced seminar that critically examines problems relevant to evolutionary patterns among the invertebrates.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor; courses in evolutionary biology, systematics, and ecology highly recommended.

name: — Animal Behavior, Ecology & Evolution
description: Course Description: Interface between animal behavior, ecology and evolution. New developments in behavioral ecology development and testing of hypotheses in this discipline.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 102; EVE 100; EVE 101; or the equivalent, and consent of instructor, graduate standing.

name: — Field Reconnaissance for Population Biologists
description: Course Description: Biweekly field trips to acquaint students with plant and animal communities, biodiversity, and ecological and evolutionary research opportunities in northern and central California.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student in Population Biology, or consent of instructor.

name: — Terrestrial Field Ecology
description: Course Description: Field course conducted over spring break and four weekends at Bodega Bay, emphasizing student projects. Ecological hypothesis testing, data gathering, analysis, and written and oral presentation of results are stressed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory ecology and introductory statistics, or consent of instructor.

name: — Mathematical Methods in Population Biology
description: Course Description: Mathematical methods used in population biology. Linear and nonlinear difference equation and differential equation models are studied, using stability analysis and qualitative methods. Partial differential equation models are introduced. Applications to population biology models are stressed.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016C or MAT 021C; or the equivalent.

name: — Computational Methods in Population Biology
description: Course Description: Numerical methods for simulating population dynamics using the computational software package R. Emphasis  placed on model formulation and development, theoretical concepts and philosophical principles to guide simulation efforts, model parameterization, and implementing simulations with R.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in theoretical ecology (e.g., ECL 231 or an equivalent to ESP 121 from your undergraduate institution) or consent of instructor; no programming experience required.

name: — Interdisciplinary  Approaches to Biological Invasions
description: Course Description: An integrative consideration of biological invasions, including an overview of concepts from ecology, ecological theory, evolution, genetics, philosophy, and other areas. Emphasis on potential contributions of each area for interdisciplinary problem-solving.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Interdisciplinary Approaches to Biological Invasions
description: Course Description: An integrative consideration of biological invasions, including an overview of concepts from history, sociology, communications, law, policy, management, and other areas. Emphasis on potential contributions of each area for interdisciplinary problem-solving.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Collaborative Project in Biological Invasions
description: Course Description: A year-long interdisciplinary collaborative project focusing on biological invasions, resulting in a paper or other suitable product presented at a symposium at the conclusion of the project.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBG 250A; PBG 250B; or equivalent courses, and consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Evolutionary Biology
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and evaluation of current literature and ongoing research in evolutionary biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Research Conference in Ecology
description: Course Description: Critical presentation and evaluation of current literature and ongoing research in ecology. Requirements include active participation in weekly discussions and the presentation of a paper or chapter once per quarter.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Advanced Animal Behavior
description: Course Description: Reading, reports and discussion on current topics in animal behavior, with a focus on topics that lie at the interface between animal behavior, ecology and evolution.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 102; EVE 100; or the equivalents; graduate standing; consent of instructor.

name: — Seminar
description: Course Description: Seminars presented by visiting lecturers, UC Davis graduate students and faculty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Research Conference in Population Biology
description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in population biology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PBG 299 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor. Graduate standing; PBG 299 required concurrently.

name: — Topics in Ecology & Evolution
description: Course Description: Seminar presented by visiting lecturers, UC Davis faculty and graduate students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: — Seminar in Geographical Ecology
description: Course Description: Recent developments in theoretical and experimental biogeography, historical biogeography and related themes in systematics, the biology of colonizing species, and related topics.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100 or EVE 101; or consent of instructor.

name: — Group Study
description: Course Description: Group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Research
description: Course Description: Research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

name: — Internship in Veterinary Science
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in reproduction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of project prior to period of internship by faculty sponsor.

name: — Human-Animal Interactions: Benefits & Issues
description: Course Description: Contributions of animals to human society, including historic, anthropologic, developmental, human health and therapeutic perspectives, as well as effects of humans on animals. One field trip required.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Internship in Veterinary Science
description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in Reproduction.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: — Introduction to Information Management for Epidemiologists
description: Course Description: Introduction to practical application of epidemiological methods to solve problems involving population health data. Emphasis on using worksheet/database software tools for organizing, analyzing, reporting, and interpreting data. Ten, three-hour sessions.

name: — Emerging Issues at the Interface of Animal, Human, & Ecosystem Health
description: Course Description: Introduce one health topics emphasizing relationships between environmental, animal and human health. Topics include ecosystem change and impacts on animals and humans, cross-species disease transmission and approaches for addressing critical data gaps to inform ecosystem health and disease prevention.

name: — Medical Statistics I
description: Course Description: Basic statistics in clinical, laboratory and population medicine: descriptive statistics; probability; binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions; sampling distributions; parameter estimation; hypothesis testing; elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation; life table construction and analysis.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPVM or MPH standing or consent of instructor.

name: — Medical Statistics II
description: Course Description: Continuation of MPM 202. Analysis of variance in biomedical sciences; nonparametric methods; multiple regression; unconditional logistic regression; biomedical applications of statistical methods. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture. Required for students in the Preventive Veterinary Program Graduate Group (PVM) and the Masters of Public Health Program (MPH).
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 202; or consent of instructor, or equivalent.

name: — Medical Statistics III
description: Course Description: Continuation of MPM 203. Selecting the best regression equation, conditional logistic regression, Poisson regression, survival analysis, analysis of time dependent variation and trends. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture.

name: — Principles of Epidemiology
description: Course Description: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from veterinary and human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests, and an introduction to epidemiologic study design and surveillance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 202; or consent of instructor; an introductory statistics course.

name: — Epidemiologic Study Design
description: Course Description: Builds on concepts presented in MPM 205. Concepts of epidemiologic study design (clinical trials, observational cohort studies, case control studies) introduced in MPM 205A are covered in more depth, using a problem-based format. Discussion of published epidemiologic studies.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 205; or consent of instructor.

name: — Applied Epidemiologic Problem Solving
description: Course Description: Integration of epidemiologic and statistical methodology in a problem-solving approach to contemporary animal population health issues. Data validation and manipulation.

name: — Research Planning & Reporting I
description: Course Description: Identify and implement research questions through hypothesis construction, articulation of aims, acquiring permits, working as a team, and all other techniques needed to develop a successful research program.

name: — Research Planning & Reporting II
description: Course Description: Concepts and skills in effective scientific writing for publication in a peer-reviewed journal in animal health or biomedicine. Includes developing an argument, organizing and writing a manuscript, improving readability, and responding to peer review.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 208.

name: — Advanced Health Leadership
description: Course Description: Develop skills for effective scientific leadership, including: project management and collaboration, conflict resolution, communication with the public, dynamic distribution of health information, and evidence-based policy influence.

name: — Concepts & Methods in Infectious Disease Surveillance & Control
description: Course Description: Basic and advanced level of conceptual and methodological foundations in infectious disease epidemiology necessary for veterinarians to develop and evaluate programs for detection, prevention, and control of infectious diseases in animal populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Elementary Portuguese
description: Course Description: Introduction to Portuguese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Portuguese
description: Course Description: Intended for students who wish to complete three quarters of Portuguese 1, 2, and 3.

name: — Elementary Portuguese
description: Course Description: Continuation of POR 001 in the areas of grammar and development of all basic language skills in cultural context with special emphasis on communication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 001.

name: — Elementary Portuguese
description: Course Description: Continuation of POR 002 in the areas of grammar and development of all basic language skills in cultural context with special emphasis on communication.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 002.

name: — Elementary Portuguese Conversation
description: Course Description: Designed to develop oral communication skills. Emphasis on increasing vocabulary, improving listening comprehension, pronunciation, accuracy and grammar control. Practice of everyday situations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 003.

name: — Intermediate Portuguese
description: Course Description: Review and develop the grammar, vocabulary, and composition acquired in first year Portuguese through exercises and reading of modern texts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 003.

name: — Intermediate Portuguese
description: Course Description: Continuation of POR 021. Focus on more difficult grammar concepts and further composition practice. Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 021.

name: — Portuguese Composition I
description: Course Description: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Class activities include composition, journals, letters, individual and group projects.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 022.

name: — Intermediate Portuguese Conversation
description: Course Description: Continuation of POR 008. Designed to develop oral communication skills at a more advanced level. Practice in more complex situations.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 008.

name: — Intermediate Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
description: Course Description: Development of linguistic and learning skills required for Spanish-speaking students in upper division courses in Portuguese.

name: — Portuguese for Spanish-Speaking Graduate Students
description: Course Description: Intensive review of grammar and composition. Development of all language skills, but with emphasis on reading of modern texts, presentation/discussion, and writing on academic topics. Development on the following writing skills: analytical, argumentative, and creative.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study primarily for lower division students.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

name: — Principles of Luso-Brazilian Literature & Criticism
description: Course Description: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, poetry, and essays of major literary writers of the Luso-Brazilian world.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 022 or POR 023; or consent of instructor.

name: — Structure of Portuguese: Sounds & Words
description: Course Description: Linguistic description of sound patterns of Portuguese and how those sounds can be used to form larger units, such as morphemes and words. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Survey of Luso-Brazilian Literature: 1500-1800
description: Course Description: Overview of Luso-Brazilian literature, covering three major literary periods: Renaissance, Baroque, and Enlightenment. Attention to the concept of imitation and nativism.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; (POR 022 or POR 023).

name: — Portuguese Literature: Medieval & Renaissance
description: Course Description: Overview of the origins of the Portuguese literature, spanning from the 13th century to the 16th century. Studies of lyrical and epic poetry, drama, and travel narratives.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Luis de Camões
description: Course Description: Overview of the greatest Renaissance Portuguese poet, Luis de Camões. Study his famous epic poem, Os Lusiadas, and a series of sonnets written by him.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; (POR 022 or POR 031).

name: — Introduction to Luso-Brazilian Culture
description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography, and culture of Portugal and Brazil. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. Taught in Portuguese.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 023 or POR 022.

name: — Special Topics in Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Luso-Brazilian literature and culture.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
description: Course Description: Colonial Brazilian literature survey. Readings include 16th-18th centuries manuscripts and books of cultural importance in a society dominated by censorship and with no printing presses. Study of the role literary Academies played in the so called "culture of manuscripts."
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Introduction  to Brazilian Literature
description: Course Description: Narrative and poetic texts of the 19th and 20th centuries in Brazil. In-depth and comparative study of Romantic and (Neo)Naturalist movements as a forum for discussion about literary tradition and modernity in Latin America.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 003; (POR 031 or POR 031G).

name: — 20th C Masters in Brazilian Literature
description: Course Description: Overview of modern Brazilian literature from early 20th C to the poetry by João Cabral de Melo Neto and the Concretists (1960s), including European avant-garde movements and literary and cultural manifestos leading to a revolutionary body of literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

name: — Tutoring in Portuguese
description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses, including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

name: — Directed Group Study
description: Course Description: Directed group study.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and Department Chairperson.

name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
description: Course Description: Independent study with professor for advanced undergraduate students, or honor thesis students.

name: — Financial Reporting
description: Course Description: Coverage includes the fundamentals of accounting and reporting economic events and transactions. Emphasizes the preparation of balance sheets, income statements, statements of cash flow, and statements of stockholders’ equity.

name: — Intermediate Financial Reporting
description: Course Description: Focuses on the preparation of complex financial statements. Topics include accounting recognition, measurement, and disclosure, as well as the theoretical foundations of and motivations for financial reporting choices.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201 or (MGB 200A or MGP 200A or MGT 200A).

name: — Advanced Financial Reporting
description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of recognition, measurement, and disclosure including pensions, accounting for income taxes, mergers and acquisitions, consolidations, special-purpose entities, and foreign subsidiaries. Includes accounting for governmental and nonprofit entities, as well as advanced treatment of international accounting standards.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 203.

name: — Tax Reporting & Analysis
description: Course Description: Introduction to the taxation of business entities and their related transactions, with an emphasis on the details of tax law and tax reporting requirements. Topics include individual, partnership, and corporate taxation, as well as tax theory.

name: — Intermediate Tax Reporting & Analysis
description: Course Description: Detailed analysis of federal taxation of individuals. Topics include the timing of income recognition, deductions and credits for tax purposes, as well as the basics of property transactions.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 211; (MGB 264 or MGP 264 or MGT 264).

name: — Advanced Tax Reporting & Analysis
description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of complex tax transactions and entities. Topics include aspects of federal taxation of entities and the applicable impact upon individual taxpayers. Coverage includes basis analysis as applicable to pass through entities and an introduction to professional responsibilities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 213.

name: — Taxation of Individuals, Property, & Estates
description: Course Description: In-depth analysis of individual income tax issues and property transactions including non-taxable exchanges, compensation, gifts, and transfer taxes. Expanded analysis of multistate tax issues. Emphasis is on the interrelationships of complex individual transactions as well as planning techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 213.

name: — Taxation of Business Entities
description: Course Description: Analysis of detailed business entity tax issues including basis calculations, alternative minimum taxation, multistate and multinational taxation, stock transactions, and mergers and acquisitions. Tax planning for entities and relationships between business entities and their owners.
